HEADLINE: Video Dial Offers Opportunities for All

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Video Dial Tone, Strangled," your Aug. 31 editorial about the transmission of television and other video services over telephone lines, is nothing more than one more attempt by the publishing industry to scare consumers and conjure up fears that telephone companies -- if they are given the freedom to participate fully in the video programming market -- would somehow restrict access to future services. 
 This position is based on the myopic credo that new information choices and increased competition are not good for the newspaper industry and, therefore, not good for the American consumer.
The argument simply does not stand up to a clear examination of the facts. Moreover, it flies in the face of an important economic principle: Let the customer decide.
Here's the reality. The Federal Communications Commission's decision to allow telephone companies to develop and offer a video dial tone service is encouraging. It's a small first step toward developing a nationwide fiber-optic network capable of carrying entertainment and other services, such as interactive educational programs, videophone and medical imaging.
Congress must take the next step by lifting the restrictions of the 1984 Cable Act, which prohibit telephone companies from owning programming. Allowing telephone companies to compete freely in this market would accelerate the development of a ubiquitous fiber network to which all information providers, and that includes newspapers, would have equal access.
Newspapers -- instead of taking self-serving editorial positions that are aimed merely at protecting advertising revenues and stifling competition -- should focus their energies on exploring ways to participate in this exciting medium, which will have the capacity to deliver interesting, useful and innovative multimedia services for customers across the country.
 
KATHLEEN AHERN
Director, Federal Regulatory Policy
Nynex Corporation
New York, Sept. 1, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
As the Saying May Go, Too Many Suits Spoil the Sports

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
ONCE upon a time, sports in September meant athletes in action. Whether in newspaper photos or videotape, quarterbacks were throwing passes or sluggers were hitting home runs. But none of those athletes was wearing a business suit.
If somebody was wearing a business suit in a newspaper photo, you knew to keep searching for the sports section. 
 If somebody was wearing a business suit on television, you knew it had to be a politician or a mob boss on trial.
But as leaves began turning this September, sports turned into ads for men's clothiers. While quarterbacks and sluggers were all but ignored, pro football attorneys in a Minneapolis courtroom and baseball club owners in a St. Louis hotel were wearing their most sincere suits in trying to cope with free agency.
Pro football was trying to come to grips with it. Baseball was trying to come to its senses over it.
Even though a Federal Court jury of eight women decided that the National Football League's system of Plan B free agency violated the antitrust laws, the N.F.L. chirped that it had "won" its basic argument. The jury agreed that Plan B (whereby each of the 28 teams cavalierly exposes all but its best 37 players to other teams in the off season) had "significantly contributed to competitive balance."
But how can anything contribute to something that doesn't really exist?
If there were "competitive balance," every team would finish at .500.
In any team sport, winning depends on a club's judgment in selecting players, the hunger of those players for success, its coaching or managing, and its luck in averting injuries. Not on how much money it pays its players.
According to the usual storm warnings, the N.F.L. franchises that could afford the best free agents would produce the best teams.
Maybe so, but it's not working that way in baseball this season. According to the contracts of players on opening-day rosters, the Mets had the highest average salary: more than $1.7 million. The Los Angeles Dodgers had the second highest: more than $1.6 million.
As every Shea Stadium student knows, the Mets are far under .500, far out of the National League East race. The Dodgers are trying not to finish under .400, deep in last place in the National League West. So much for big payrolls.
Of baseball's four first-place teams, the Toronto Blue Jays ranked fourth in average salary (before they obtained David Cone), the Oakland Athletics eighth (before the Jose Canseco trade), the Pittsburgh Pirates 10th, and the Atlanta Braves llth.
The two surprise contenders, the Baltimore Orioles and the Montreal Expos, ranked 23d and 24th, respectively.
Of baseball's 25 top salaried players this season, only 6 are on the four divisional leaders. Ruben Sierra (acquired by the Athletics from the Texas Rangers in the Canseco deal) ranks third, Barry Bonds of the Pirates sixth, Doug Drabek of the Pirates eighth, Jack Morris of the Blue Jays 10th, Andy Van Slyke of the Pirates 14th and David Cone of the Blue Jays 16th.
When a more liberated form of free agency is ordered or negotiated in the N.F.L., the same situation will apply.
Pro football teams that load up on established free agents with Super Bowl rings will discover that those players will often be past their peak, both physically and emotionally. The more money and more glory an athlete has, the less the urgency to win. Especially in football where the collisions sound like automobile accidents. And the older the player, the more susceptible he is to injury.
The pro football draft of college talent supposedly contributes to competitive balance. If so, how come the Cleveland Browns, the Detroit Lions, the Phoenix Cardinals, the San Diego Chargers, the Houston Oilers, the Atlanta Falcons, the New Orleans Saints, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Seattle Seahawks have never been to the Super Bowl? Because too many other clubs were better judges of talent and better judges of coaches.
With that in mind, consider that having forced Fay Vincent's resignation as commissioner, the baseball club owners anointed Allan (Bud) Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers chairman of the major league executive council.
To some baseball people, Selig is known as Bud Lite, hardly a compliment in Milwaukee, a city that another beer professes to have made famous. And for all of Selig's protests of how difficult it is for smaller-market clubs to prosper in the national economy, it's even more difficult when talent is misjudged.
Selig's front office decided that Gary Sheffield would never fulfill his potential. Selig concurred. Traded to the San Diego Padres, Sheffield is threatening to lead the National League in batting, homers and runs batted in.
It's enough to make you wonder if maybe Bud Selig misjudged Fay Vincent, too. Just as all the baseball club owners have misjudged the multimillion-dollar salaries that have created an erosion of baseball's finances, an erosion dressed in all those business suits worn by the club owners in photos and videotape.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
N.F.L. to Look at New Labor Game Plans

BYLINE: By THOMAS GEORGE

 BODY:
On the heels of having their Plan B system of free agency struck down by the jury decision in Minneapolis last week, the National Football League club owners will meet in Dallas on Thursday and plan a course of action: either continued fighting in the courts or a new proposal on a collective-bargaining agreement.
A seven-member committee of owners plus Commissioner Paul Tagliabue and the league's lead lawyer, Frank Rothman, held a telephone conference call on Friday morning, one day after the verdict in the McNeil vs. the N.F.L. trial: that Plan B is too restrictive and illegal under antitrust law. This group will be very likely to arrive in Dallas with specific recommendations in mind. 
 The verdict said that the Plan B system, in which each N.F.L. team was allowed to protect 37 players, had a substantially harmful effect on competition for player services, that the rules were more restrictive than necessary, and that players suffered economic injury as a direct result of those rules. Four of the eight players who brought the suit received damages, totaling $1.6 million. But the ruling also said that Plan B significantly contributed to competitive balance in the N.F.L.
Because of that latter finding, the league believes that the jury was saying that some rules are necessary to maintain competitive balance, and that complete free agency for players is not desirable.
"The jury did not find any problem with these rules applied to the higher-paid players," Tagliabue said. "The guys that got damages were good players, ascending players, who were hurt by the system. The four who were perfectly well paid were shut out.
 
Bargaining Away From Table
 "When everyone settles down a little bit, because everyone gets emotional during the course of litigation, people will hopefully realize where they are. It's like a football game where people knock the hell out of each other in the first quarter and it's 14-14. Nothing happens. There are still three quarters to go. Everyone loses except the lawyers, and that's what I've been saying all along."
Everyone talks about the league and its players getting back to the bargaining table -- there has been no collective bargaining agreement since 1987 -- but the fact is that the two sides negotiated frequently throughout the Minneapolis trial, and as recently as two weeks ago held substantial talks.
Many of the issues clouding peace, other than free agency, were resolved, but a potential bargaining agreement dissolved primarily on two aspects of the free-agency issues: the league wants a hard salary cap and an exemptions whereby each team will be able to protect three players from free agency. The players will accept one or the other, but not both.
After the verdict Thursday, Gene Upshaw, director of the N.F.L. Players Association, the former union that had itself decertified to pursue legal action, said that the salary-cap issue was "out the window." He added that even the N.F.L. draft, now, could become the subject of litigation.
"That's ridiculous," Tagliabue said. "I believe a draft through eight rounds would be held perfectly viable in any court."
Any appeal in the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit of last week's decision would hinge partly on the league's view that the players association, despite its official decertification, continues to operate as a union.
"If it walks like a duck and talks like a duck, well. . . . " said Art Modell, the Cleveland Browns' owner. "Hopefully, this verdict will produce new dialogue. If 37 is too many players to protect, that is subject to bargaining. Unfettered free agency just won't work. I hope we can build a bigger and better game and not wait for the courts and let juries decide our fate."
 
More Lawsuits Pending
 There are several more lawsuits pending between the two sides, including similar suits to McNeil's filed in Los Angeles and in Philadelphia and a Sept. 21 court date in Washington over developmental-squad players.
Thus far, the posturing continues and the politics rage.
"What are we spending our time in court, for example, over the developmental players, the number 48 through 53 players who a lot of times never even make it in the N.F.L.?" Tagliabue said. "We need to get out of the courts."
Modell added: "There was a time when the players were our friends and we could sit around and chew the fat. Now everyone has drawn lines. Let's seek harmony in new ways. That's my goal."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gene Upshaw, executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association, after a jury ruled that the Plan B system of free agency is too restrictive. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: YACHT RACING>;
After a Liberty Cup Is Canceled, the Pondering Begins

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD

 BODY:
The recent cancellation of New York's 1992 Liberty Cup Match Racing Regatta came as a surprise to a yacht-racing circuit that has been riding a wave of increasing popularity and prize money the last few years.
In a sport known for the cold shoulder it generally gives to professionalism, competitive sailors find it hard to make a living. But match racing has represented a source of hope for career yachtsmen. 
 Although the eight-year-old Liberty Cup race series had never offered prize money, the event had become an important part of the international circuit. As one of 10 events on the Omega Grand Prix of Match Race Sailing, the Liberty Cup, which was scheduled to begin Wednesday, offered sailors a chance to enhance their world-class standing.
 
Crucial Points
 By performing well in Liberty Cup, sailors were awarded points that added to their world match-race rankings. With a high ranking, a Liberty Cup sailor was more likely to receive invitations to sail in the other circuit events, some of which offer purses close to $100,000. While the money amounts to a pittance compared with that awarded to top tennis players and other professional athletes, the purses often are considered the best in sailing.
Bill Darnell, executive director of the Harbor Festival Foundation, a nonprofit organization supported by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that attempted to organize the 1992 Liberty Cup series, said his group was unable to find corporate sponsorship.
Darnell said that it costs about $300,000 to $400,000 to stage a Liberty Cup regatta. "I was concerned about having a poor quality event," Darnell said recently, adding that he plans the renewal of the regatta next year. It is a costly event because it is in New York, he said.
In approaching companies that have contributed to sailing in the past, Darnell found that most were overburdened by commitments they had made to the America's Cup last spring, and to the Olympics this summer.
Darnell and his staff decided to manage the event themselves this year rather than bring in professional fund-raisers. But now his foundation is being criticized by both competitors and former organizers for failing to produce.
Peter Isler, a professional sailor whose team won the 1991 Liberty Cup, had lined up Mount Gay Rum as his personal sponsor for this month's event.
"With two weeks to go, it's really a shocker," Isler said while on vacation in Telluride, Colo. "Being the defending champion, I'd been planning on Liberty Cup for more than a year. It's hard. Mount Gay had already planned for events around town."
 
Money Available or Not?
 Sail Sports International of Westport, Conn., the marketing firm in charge of fund-raising for Liberty Cup last year, was not asked by the festival organizers to be involved again. "I think it's unfortunate that the Liberty Cup was cancelled," Scott MacLeod, president of Sail Sports, said. "I think New York was a great venue, and I think it's unfortunate for sailing and for New York."
The regatta involved four days of match-race sailing in the harbor off Battery Park City.
MacLeod insists that corporate sponsorship is available, despite Darnell's contention that companies are also holding back because of the recession. Sail Sports has secured full sponsorship for the Omega Gold Cup match-racing series next month in Bermuda, MacLeod said, adding that there is a purse of $80,000.
Not all of the sailing's match-racing events involve money. The Knickerbocker Cup, a series sailed out of Port Washington, L.I., last weekend, relied on volunteer support rather than corporate funding. While the Knickerbocker Cup is a lesser event on the match-racing circuit, it is considered a training ground for aspiring match-race sailors.
There has been a surge in match-race events around the world during the last five years. That very fact may spell its downfall, said Gary Jobson of Annapolis, Md., a yachtsman who has competed in the Liberty Cup five times. "More doesn't make it better," Jobson said, noting that it will be hard to put the Liberty Cup back together next year. "It may be that we are seeing the beginning of a saturation in that kind of racing."
 
MAKING WAVES
 The Manhattan Yacht Club is staging the International Yacht Club Challenge in New York Harbor this weekend. Amateur teams from 15 countries are competing on J-24 sailboats in a six-race series that is scheduled to end today off Battery Park City. A team from Belgium, led by the helmsman, TONI VAN DER WALLE, won the event in 1989.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two J-35 sloops rounding the mark in the 1991 Knickerbocker Cup.

LENGTH: 1802 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/September 6 - 11

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Two Nations, Flight Patterns Indivisible 

A week after a new aviation pact was negotiated between the United States and the Netherlands, an unprecedented global business combination has begun to take shape. KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and Northwest, in which KLM has a 49 percent stake, asked the Department of Transportation for permission to operate as a single carrier. The department said it favored the idea. The pact, which gives Dutch and American carriers the right to fly anywhere in each other's country, also gives them antitrust immunity. This enables the airlines to set fares jointly, schedule flights, coordinate routes and merge reservation systems. "We are likely to witness the creation of a number of such alliances," said John Dasburg, Northwest's president. Watching is British Airways, which owns a stake in USAir. But Britain has so far refused to negotiate a similar aviation accord.
 
Merck Under Another Name
 
Merck & Company -- one of the world's most powerful drug companies -- also has one of corporate America's most admired names. But recently it said it would create a new division to produce generic drugs under a different name altogether. Merck's new company, to be called West Point Pharma, based in West Point, Pa., will manufacture, at prices rivaling the lowest-cost producers', exact copies of Merck drugs after they have lost their patent protection. Generics now account for 40 percent of all prescriptions. West Point Pharma will begin by marketing diflunisal, a low-priced version of Merck's $100 million seller Dolobid, an analgesic. Next: probably, a version of Merck's $565 million veterinarian drug Ivermectin, which comes off patent in 1997, to be followed by Mevacor, a hugely successful cholesterol-lowering drug with sales of $1.4 billion. Mevacor loses its patent protection in 1999. "It's possible that we would market a generic formulation of all of our products," said John Doorley, a Merck spokesman.

$100 Million for Hats
 
Aside from skullcaps, Easter bonnets and motorcycle helmets, Hat Brands Inc. pretty much makes whatever it takes to cover a person's pate. Not only did the company's founder, Irving Joel, buy bankrupt John B. Stetson for $11 million in cash and the assumption of $3.1 million in debt last year (Stetsons are what the country singer Garth Brooks is partial to), but he also scooped up Resistol from Levi Strauss, giving his company 60 percent of the Western hat market. Hat Brands owns companies that make baseball caps, as well as the very proper Dobbs and Churchill hats. Last week, Hicks, Muse & Company, a leveraged buyout firm, agreed to buy Hat Brands from Mr. Joel for about $100 million. "We have looked at the business going back 10 years, and it seems to be relatively immune to business cycles," said Thomas O. Hicks, chairman.

Boeing's Overseas Order
 
The Boeing Commercial Airplane Company may be laying off workers and slowing down its assembly lines, but it still has a knack for selling those planes. Last week Tarom, the Romanian airline, ordered seven Boeing 737-300's with options on another six of the twin-jet passenger planes. The new planes will replace the carrier's aging fleet of Tupolev TU-154's. Boeing said the order was worth about $470 million.

Before the ink could dry on the Tarom deal, Boeing's marketing mavens sold four 757-200 jetliners to Shorouk Airlines of Egypt with options on four more for about $240 million.

The Shape of a Leaner T.W.A.
 
The Trans World Airlines that will emerge from Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code after it is reorganized and sold to its employees will be smaller, leaner and cheaper to run, the company said last week. T.W.A. said it would trim 12 cities from its routes -- among them Moscow, Istanbul and Palm Springs, Calif. -- and retire 20 antique wide-body Boeing 747's and Lockheed L-1011's. That would shrink its fleet to 167 planes from the current 187. T.W.A. also proposes to cut labor costs by 15 percent through wage, benefit and work-rule concessions previously negotiated with the unions. It expects to trim its daily flights by 10 percent. That leaves a last piece of business to be negotiated: a settlement with the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation over the company's underfunded pension funds.

Olympia's Bondholders Up Front
 
While Olympia & York, the world's largest property developer, is operating under bankruptcy protection in Canada and Britain, it has avoided that status in the United States. To bolster its American operations, Olympia reached an agreement with bondholders of its huge 55 Water Street complex in Manhattan (right) to take over the building. Olympia -- which owes the bondholders $548 million -- was eager to part with the property because it has a problem with asbestos. The Retirement System of Alabama, the largest investor, will provide up to $21 million to pay for a cleanup and up to $119 million more to buy outstanding bonds. Why? "We think we're somewhere near the bottom of the real estate cycle," said David G. Bronner, chief executive of the system.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Now, the 'Entry Level' Bentley
 
The recession has taken its toll on pricey Rolls-Royce. Not only has its parent company, Vickers P.L.C., put Rolls-Royce on the block -- to no avail -- but sales of its aluminum, lacquer, hand-stitched-leather and walnut land yachts are in a slump. So last week, Rolls introduced a new low-priced Bentley -- the Brooklands. The new "entry level" Bentley is priced to sell at $183,000 -- half the price of the racy Bentley Continental "R," which is turbocharged. "We see it as a 'conquest model,' " said Ian McKay, Bentley's marketing director. "People who perhaps haven't had a Bentley before may feel one is now in reach."
 
Trade Deal Runs Into Trouble
 
President Bush may point to the recently concluded North American Free Trade Agreement as evidence of his Administration's foresight and deal-making prowess, but if the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, has his way, it will go back to the negotiating table. Mr. Gephardt said that the agreement fails to protect workers' rights and that its provisions to protect the Mexican environment are far too lax. Speaking at a gathering sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. -- which opposes the agreement -- Mr. Gephardt advised the Bush Administration "to cease further efforts to win Congressional approval" of the current agreement. The White House sharply rejected Mr. Gephardt's call for withdrawal.
 
Russia, Japan and the Kuriles
 
When President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia canceled his trip to Japan last week, he cited "obtaining circumstances." But the real reason for the postponement was conflict between the two countries over Japan's insistence that Russia return the Kurile Islands, which it seized after World War II. Unless the islands are returned, Japan is unlikely to increase its direct economic assistance to Russia. "Popular sentiment in Russia is against giving the islands back," said Vladimir Kvint, a professor of international business at Fordham University. "And since Russia is now a democracy, it's that sentiment Yeltsin must listen to."
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Clinton's Answer on Welfare
 
With the nation's welfare rolls at all-time highs -- 4.8 million families now receive Federal assistance, up from just 3.7 million as recently as 1989 -- Gov. Bill Clinton called for "an end to welfare as we know it." In a speech in Atlanta, the Democratic Presidential candidate outlined a sweeping $6 billion-a-year program emphasizing education and job training that would require welfare recipients to go to work in private businesses or in government programs after two years. The program calls for $4 billion to be spent on education and training, and adds $2 billion in tax credits for the working poor. Mr. Clinton's program would increase the amount welfare recipients could save without losing their benefits to $10,000 from $1,000. And how would the program be paid for? Without increasing taxes, Mr. Clinton maintains. Cuts in the military and other spending would get it off the ground, and once welfare recipients start working, their taxes would make the program self-sustaining.
 
Partisan Number Games
 
The two political parties agree that this election is about the economy. But they do not agree on how to read the numbers. When the Congressional Joint Economic Committee said a 30-year-old man with a high-school education earned $3,500 less than a 30-year-old in 1979, the Democratic poll taker Geoffrey Garin said, "Stagnation in wages is at the heart of this election." The Republicans countered that wages for 35-year-olds had risen.
 
Renewal, as Bush Sees It
 
Last week, in an address to the Economic Club of Detroit and in a 29-page report, President Bush outlined what he called an "agenda for American renewal." Its centerpiece is a renewed call for Congress to follow through on about $130 billion in spending cuts he has proposed. "These savings alone could finance an across-the-board rate cut" of one percentage point in income tax rates, a reduction of the small-business tax rate from 15 percent to 10 percent and a reduction of the capital gains tax, Mr. Bush said. Another proposal, sure to be controversial inside the Beltway, calls for trimming 5 percent from the salaries of all Federal employees making $75,000 a year or more. And in a direct challenge to Congress, Mr. Bush said that if the House and Senate cut their operating budgets by one-third, the White House would do the same. His plan, Mr. Bush said, would nearly double the nation's gross domestic product by the end of the decade.
 
Last week, Mr. Bush said: "I went along with one Democratic tax increase and I'm not going to do it again. Ever. Ever." Was that a pledge? Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater backed off: "It wasn't a pledge, no. He was saying, as he's said before, that he wouldn't make that mistake again."

Tug-of-War Over Cable
 
One of the cornerstones of the Reagan Revolution was the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984. It took away the right of local governments to regulate prices. Trouble was, cable charges soared. Last week, negotiators in the House and Senate agreed on a measure that would substantially overturn the 1984 act -- requiring the Federal Communications Commission to set rates for basic cable service and regulate the price of cable equipment like remote control devices and transmission boxes. The measure also would require local cable operators to negotiate license fees from local broadcasters to retransmit their signals. The Reagan revolutionaries still in the White House threaten to veto the bill.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Behind the Scenes;
Though Advisers Differ, Clinton's in Tune With All

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If a man is known by the company he keeps, Bill Clinton is clearly a left-leaning liberal. Also, a right-leaning moderate. In foreign policy he is a United Nations multinationalist and an America-first interventionist. In a city where every Democrat suddenly wants to be a "friend of Bill," Mr. Clinton is a man for all advisers.
The Democratic Presidential nominee's economic advisers include a former planning commissioner for Santa Monica, Calif., a city so determinedly of the left that some conservatives call it "the People's Republic of Santa Monica." They also include policy analysts for a group so determinedly of the center that some liberals accuse it of trying to turn Democrats into Republicans. 
 Mr. Clinton's foreign policy advisers range from dovey former Carter Administration figures to adherents of the philosophy of former Senator Henry M. Jackson, the hawkish Democrat from Washington State whose supporters regarded President Carter's approach as softheaded to the point of mush.
In the Democrats' first real season of hope since 1976, all of these people apparently find in the policies and oratory of Mr. Clinton evidence that in his secret heart their party's Presidential nominee is one of them.
It is an entirely understandable impulse, stemming from the endlessly mixed signals that emit from a candidate with something for everyone.
Mr. Clinton is, as he likes to say, "pro-business and pro-labor," "for economic growth and for protecting the environment," "for affirmative action but against quotas," for keeping abortion legal and also for "making it as rare as possible."
He is for a free-trade agreement with Mexico but not necessarily for the one now awaiting Congressional ratification. After Congress voted in January 1991 to authorize President Bush to use force against Iraq, Mr. Clinton said he would have voted with the majority but sympathized with the minority.
The candidate, his advisers and his supporters all argue that this sort of amorphous talk is a result of an intellectually honest search for answers that avoid the polarization that has come to characterize the national debate. They say Mr. Clinton should be regarded as the first Presidential candidate of the post-ideological age.
But others -- most important among them Mr. Clinton's Republican opponents, who have attacked the Democrat as more liberal than he lets on -- see in his blurred outline a familiar creature of American politics: the ideological shape-changer who becomes what each beholder wishes to see.
Whatever the truth, it is undeniable that sharply diverse groups of ideologues claim Mr. Clinton as one of theirs.
"Progressives are getting behind Clinton in a big way because we recognize that he is at least open to being pushed," said Jamin Raskin, who teaches law at the American University in Washington and is a former counsel to the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Rainbow Coalition. "There is a sense among progressives that Clinton's election would create a real swing in the political spectrum that would create all sorts of openings for creative policy-making."
Mr. Raskin, and other intellectuals of the Democrats' left, or progressive, wing, generally regard with satisfaction most of the policy choices made by Mr. Clinton and the Democratic Party of 1992. "The cultural issues -- abortion, civil rights, gay rights -- have all been decided on the left," Mr. Raskin said. "The prominence of gay and lesbian rights in the Democratic platform is just extraordinary."
Centrist Democrats beg to differ; Mr. Clinton, they say, belongs to them.
Elaine Kamarck, a leading Democratic policy expert of the Progressive Policy Institute, the Washington-based policy arm of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, of which Mr. Clinton was a founder, gave this reasoning:
"Basically, Democrats all agree that government should be activist. But we who are involved in the new thinking of the party believe in an activist approach that is non-bureaucratic, as distinct from the Great Society liberalism. "We believe in an approach that avoids false choices. I think that from the way Bill Clinton governs, his instincts are very much those of a new Democrat. You can see that in the way he will not cede the family-values debate to the opposition and in the way he stresses personal responsibility and belief in a strong interventionist foreign policy."
 
Economic Plan an Example
 A good example of how these variously striped ideologues find in Mr. Clinton a reasonably comfortable intellectual home can be seen in the formulation of the campaign's central policy document, the economic plan known as "Putting People First." The candidate introduced the plan in a June speech before the United States Conference of Mayors.
Mr. Clinton's more liberal economic advisers maintain that the plan represents a clear triumph of their point of view, with its emphasis on large new programs of Government spending as an "investment" in the future economy over the need for drastically cutting the Federal debt. The more conservative advisers affiliated with the Progressive Policy Institute say the document bears their mark, with its call for large-scale changes in the Federal welfare program stressing the obligations that recipients of tax-dollar largess owe to society.
The plan was largely conceived by Robert Reich and Ira Magaziner, two liberal senior advisers who are both long-time friends of the candidate. An additional but lesser contribution came from Derek Shearer, a former Santa Monica planning commissioner who is also a long-time Clinton friend. The result, says one left-leaning Democratic policy analyst, is "a very impressive document from a progressive point of view."
The analyst, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, called the plan a "clear victory for the progressive side."
"The big choice was whether to stress an investment economy, with increased government spending, which would entail some new taxes, or to focus on reducing the deficit and middle-class tax cuts," the analyst said. "Clinton went with the latter; he made all the big decisions the right way."
 
Rejecting Liberal Thoughts
 But the plan also reflects the thinking of people like Roger Altman, a New York investment banker, and Robert J. Shapiro, a vice president of the Progressive Policy Institute.
Mr. Shapiro rejects the assertions of liberals in slightly annoyed tones. "There has been a lot of this of late, people who fought Bill Clinton all the way and supported an entirely different approach to government now declaring victory," Mr. Shapiro said. "This is simply not true. These people were against our national service plan, against welfare reform, against almost everything we have been proposing for years, all of which is in 'Putting People First.'
"Certainly, there is language in 'Putting People First' that traditionalists can cite as theirs, but structurally the plan is not a traditional Democratic document. It is a program committed to fiscal restraint and based on the view that business, not government, is the source of prosperity."
The development of the plan, according to an account that emerges from interviews with various participants, shows the policy-making process of the campaign to be fairly informal, highly political and directly steered by a candidate whose impulse is for the compromise, not the absolute. It was Mr. Clinton who pushed the plan's development, largely because he felt the political imperative to put forward a comprehensive economic package that would highlight the lack of such a plan on the Republican side.
The initial outline of the plan was drawn by Mr. Reich, Mr. Magaziner, Mr. Shapiro, Mr. Altman and several others and debated and developed in informal working meetings. In these meetings, two of the candidate's chief political strategists, James Carville and George Stephanopoulos, reportedly pushed for more spending, on the ground that it was politically necessary to please major Democratic constituencies, like organized labor, big city mayors and black political groups.
 
Candidate Settled Issue
 Mr. Shapiro was among those who fought to keep spending down. Ultimately the debate was settled by Mr. Clinton, who took part in four or five meetings in which the various options were presented. He ruled on a position that favored spending over deficit-reduction.
Gene Sperling, a 33-year-old former adviser to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, was hired to coordinate the contributions of the senior economic advisers and develop the program's mathematical base. Robert Boorstin, a former New York Times reporter who left to work in Michael Dukakis's campaign and is now Mr. Clinton's deputy director of communications, helped write the final draft in prose accessible to the general public. Mr. Sperling works under Bruce Reed, the campaign's issues director, while Mr. Boorstin works under Mr. Stephanopoulos.
 
Differences on Foreign Policy
 In foreign policy, Mr. Clinton's advisers are as varied as in economics. By all accounts the lead adviser is Anthony Lake, a professor at Mount Holyoke College who was director of the State Department's policy planning staff under President Jimmy Carter. He is joined by Samuel Berger, a Washington lawyer who served directly under Mr. Lake in the Carter Administration.
Mr. Lake and Mr. Berger, both of whom have known Mr. Clinton since they all worked in George McGovern's 1972 Presidential campaign, are regarded unfavorably by interventionist-minded Democrats as proponents of a multilateralist, United Nations-dominated approach.
Warren Christopher, Deputy Secretary of State under President Carter, has also advised Mr. Clinton; Mr. Christopher headed the Vice-Presidential search that resulted in Mr. Clinton's choosing Senator Al Gore of Tennessee as his running mate. Mr. Christopher is likewise seen by some interventionist-minded Democrats as too unwilling to put American interests first and to use force to back up those interests.
But Mr. Clinton's main adviser on Russian affairs, Michael Mandelbaum, a professor at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, is regarded as more of an interventionist. And Mr. Clinton has also consulted Congressional Democrats like Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn and Representative Dave McCurdy of Oklahoma, both of whom are seen as strong interventionists.
Nancy Soderberg, a former aide to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, serves as Mr. Sperling's counterpart on the foreign policy side, coordinating the flow of ideas and arguments from the foreign policy advisers to Mr. Clinton.
Eyeing the diversity of advisers around Mr. Clinton, those who support his candidacy wonder a bit, and some worry.
"We have some very active elements in the party who have a lot to do with the electoral process and who are ground deeply into the philosophy of the party," said John White, a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee in the Carter Administration. "These people are all around Clinton, and they are serious liberals.
"And the Democratic Leadership Council people are all around him, too, and they are serious about ultimately moving the party back towards the right. So there is bound to be some conflict at some point. I don't think Clinton will let either side dominate. He'll try to compromise and paper things over. I think he can do it. I hope he can do it. If he can't, we'll get our tails beat, if not now, then in 1996."

HEADLINE: Kansas City, a Midwestern Beauty

BYLINE: By SUZANNE WINCKLER; SUZANNE WINCKLER, based in Omaha, frequently writes about history and natural history in the Midwest.

 BODY:
WILLIAM ROCKHILL Nelson, founder of The Kansas City Star, is credited with saying this about his adopted hometown: "I decided that if I were to live here, the town must be made over." However imperious that might have sounded back then -- and sounds even now -- anyone who has lived or visited Kansas City is a beneficiary of his surety and determination. In the early years of this century, Nelson -- and a number of other equally tenacious and benignly tyrannical entrepreneurs -- went about imposing their own ideal of beauty on Kansas City. Fortunately, their ideal is a hard one to dispute. It is centered on the notion of giving people lots of parks, boulevards, outdoor art and grand public buildings.
What makes their achievement even more noteworthy is that the exigencies of urban life in America in the last few decades, to which Kansas City has not been immune, have failed to mask or tarnish their handiwork. Kansas City is still a beautiful city. To visit is to get a welcome respite from the world of shrinking expectations. 
 The Kansas City I'm talking about is the bigger, more bustling one in Missouri, which converges inconspicuously with its smaller, quieter sister -- Kansas City, Kan. -- along a straight and narrow seam called State Line Road. A taxi driver, when questioned about the boundary situation between the two cities, demonstrated their proximity by straddling his vehicle over the yellow line on State Line Road. "You're on both sides now," he said.
Kansas City, Mo., grew up along the banks of the Missouri River where the river takes a big easterly swing toward its confluence with the Mississippi. Like many cities that developed on the interior watercourses of this continent -- Louisville, Cincinnati, Minneapolis, St. Paul and Jefferson City, to name a few -- Kansas City benefits as much, and maybe more, from its terrain than from its river.
The city sits astride bluffs, huge oceanic swells of earth stacked along the Missouri River that provide outstanding vantages for obtaining the long view. While Kansas City is rightfully known for its barbecue and music, its vistas are equally impressive, and you don't have to clog your arteries or stay up past your bedtime to appreciate them.
An excellent place to get the lay of the land is Liberty Memorial. This elegant 217-foot Art Deco tower, at Main Street and Pershing Road in Penn Valley Park, was built to commemorate casualties of World War I. It stands on the prow of a bluff overlooking downtown Kansas City to the north and is situated at roughly the midway point of a five-mile stretch of the city that will keep a weekend visitor busily entertained with urban pleasures. These include such enduring institutions as Arthur Bryant's Barbecue, the Grand Emporium (noted for the blues), Thomas Hart Benton's home, the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, and two shopping areas, City Market and Country Club Plaza.
In Kansas City, Main Street lives up to its name. It is a major north-south thoroughfare that stretches from City Market to and beyond Country Club Plaza, and most of the recommended stops are either on Main Street or just off it.
At Liberty Memorial you can take an elevator to its pinnacle, or simply stand on its grand plaza with the breeze in your face. You will note a number of prominent structures on the downtown horizon to the north. The one with the glittering gold-leaf cupola is the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception. The slim, soaring spire is the Kansas City Light and Power Building, another of the city's masterworks from the Art Deco era. But the most conspicuous object in this urbanscape is Union Station. You can't miss it, because it is so big and so lonesome.
If you start to feel too optimistic up here on the bluff, Union Station will bring you back to earth. It is one of the few legacies from Nelson that haven't segued into these times of tight money. Union Station, which has been empty for nearly 10 years, is the subject of litigation between the city and several companies that reneged on redeveloping it. The station is also a topic of heated debate beween preservationists and pragmatists who disagree on whether the building is worth restoring. It is hard to gaze down on Union Station -- the inside is inaccessible -- and imagine what could become of the gorgeous but obsolescent terminal short of the reincarnation of passenger trains.
What has made it to the end of the century -- has even survived the whims of fickle economies -- are Kansas City's parks and public spaces, its broad and winding boulevards, its copious outdoor sculptures and fountains. Whether you go on foot (the recommended way) or by car (that is, one with the windows rolled down), it is virtually impossible to be far from the sound of trickling, spraying, gushing or pulsing water.
The fountains cover the artistic spectrum: from the grandiose classical-style horses and riders splashing amid the geysers of the Plaza Fountain on the esplanade at 47th and Main Streets; to the serenely stylized Art Deco stone statues of a man and woman each perpetually pouring water from vessels in their hands, which stand in the fragrance and texture garden at Loose Memorial Park; to the abstract and ultramodern stainless-steel pipe-and-waterworks sculpture in a downtown pocket park at Walnut and 12th Streets.
Kansas Citians latched on to the concept of public sculpture long before it was fashionable in this country. Consequently, an endeavor that often seems like an afterthought or affectation in many other cities is an intrinsic part of living and doing business in Kansas City. The maintenance and acquisition of public sculpture is a given, like snow removal. Having been at it for so long, Kansas City has all styles of sculpture rather than what is so often the urban norm: a few monstrosities of abstraction purchased when the fancy for public art coincided briefly in the 1970's and early 1980's with procurable money and taxpayer support.
Everyone has his or her favorites. Mine are:
The Indian scout on horseback, a circa 1915 sculpture by Cyrus E. Dallin, standing on the crest of a bluff in Penn Valley Park.
The numerous voluptuous bronzes by the English sculptor Henry Moore, all lounging about on the sweeping lawn of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art.
The bronze wild boar on Nichols Road in the Plaza Shopping Center, whose nose you are invited to rub for good luck while also being invited to drop a few coins in the pond at his cloven feet for the Children of Mercy Hospital.
A 1977 sculpture by J. Seward Johnson of a young man eating a hamburger while reading a book at the entrance to the McDonald's at Nichols Road and Jefferson Street. If you get down on your knees and look up at the bronze book cover (an assignment only for the limber), you will discover that it is Milton Friedman's "There's No Such Thing as a Free Lunch." The book is opened to the chapter entitled "Is Money Too Tight?"
What is even more impressive than this concerted effort to put art in public places is the public's concerted effort to get out into these open spaces and enjoy their art. At least on the weekends, people are out in force in Kansas City, pursuing all the ordinary activities -- walking, jogging, biking, shopping, pushing a baby carriage, sitting on a park bench -- that can make life wonderful in a city. Their presence provides an added attraction for those bystanders who watch people as avidly as they watch art.
While surely there are shopping malls somewhere in the metropolitan area, we did not see one. If you hew to the Main Street course, you will be just as fortunate. The city's best shopping areas are at City Market on the north end of Main Street, where shopping is a latter-day take on the age-old bazaar, and further south on Main Street at Country Club Plaza, where art meets commerce.
Country Club Plaza, which Kansas Citians simply call the Plaza, is one of the oldest and most indomitable shopping complexes in America. Begun in 1922, when this area of the city verged on farmland, the Plaza is now the heart of a thriving district of businesses, condominiums, apartments, and hotels. The Plaza makes no bones about being what it has been for seventy years -- an unrepentant orgy of retail opportunities -- but it is also simply an exhilarating place to mill about. Its beguiling Spanish-style buildings, several of which are crowned with exotic domed towers, make the Plaza look more like a rambling palace than a shopping center, and you cannot turn a corner without bumping into a sculpture.
City Market, at Fifth between Main Street and Grand Avenue down by the riverfront, can claim a greater longevity than the Plaza. People have been selling their wares here since the 1850's, and even as Kansas City grew south, the market never missed a beat. City Market offers shopping of an altogether different sort from the Plaza. Here the socioeconomic spectrum of the merchants, their merchandise and the clientele is much broader, and the mercantile emphasis shifts from refined elegance toward willful chaos. For example, at Hung Yuong Market, an Asian grocery and seafood purveyor, you will find underwear in the same aisle as the canned mangoes. On Saturday and Sunday during harvest time, when vendors and shoppers are out in greatest number, and their stalls are stacked with mounds of fresh produce, City Market comes close to resembling an experience in Latin America or Asia, where open-air markets still have primacy and shopping is an art form in itself.
For people who don't shop, or need an occasional break from it, Kansas City has three premier public parks. Penn Valley Park, which encompasses the previously mentioned Liberty Memorial, is a 200-acre expanse of undulating bluffs and ravines that was being talked up as early as 1892 by George E. Kessler, Kansas City's visionary park planner and landscape architect. His Penn Valley Park lies just south of downtown and across from Crown Center, the multipurpose complex of shops, offices, hotels and dwelling places that is also the headquarters of Hallmark Cards.
Considerably south but still an easy drive by most urban standards, is Swope Park. It begins at 63d Street Trafficway and Swope Parkway and rolls south for a thousand-plus acres. Although the huge park was far removed from the city limits when it was dedicated in 1986, Kansas City has grown around it. Swope Park has a zoo, a nature center and Starlight Theater, an open-air amphitheater for summertime music and theater.
Between these two huge parks is a smaller one that is, in part because of its more intimate size, more inviting to foot traffic. Jacob L. Loose Memorial Park is just south of the Country Club Plaza on Wornall Road between 51st and 55th Streets. Loose Park is a pleasant compromise between formal gardens and less tamed expanses of meadows and trees. It is highly recommended for full-bore walking (and running), especially for out-of-town visitors, because its paths, which loop around the perimeter, have that certain symmetry conducive to getting exercise and because the park is near numerous hotels in Country Club Plaza. Loose Park has the distinction of having once been wrapped in saffron nylon by Christo.
A weekend of walking and shopping can leave even the fit a little weary and footsore, which brings us to the subject of footwear. In the courtyard of the Raphael Hotel, one of the popular Country Club Plaza hostelries, there is a reproduction of a Florentine statue. It depicts a young boy sitting with his left leg propped on his right knee and he is bent over examining the bottom of his foot, as if lost in the contemplation of a blister. There is a message in that sculpture. Kansas City is made for walking, and you had better pack a pair of comfortable shoes.
 
 
 
SIGHTS AND SOUNDS NEAR MAIN STREET
Art
 The Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, just east of Country Club Plaza at 4525 Oak Street, (816) 561-4000, is one of the jewels of the William Rockhill Nelson legacy. The museum was also endowed substantially by Mary Atkins, a reclusive former schoolteacher.
The Nelson-Atkins's Oriental collection is renowned. It includes ancient ritual and funerary art, Buddhist painting and sculpture, Ming dynasty furniture and Chinese scroll paintings. Also outstanding are the museum's collection of sculpture by Henry Moore, and works by the Missouri artist Thomas Hart Benton (though many of his pieces will be on tour until December). Open Tuesday to Thursday 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Friday to 9 P.M. and Saturday to 5 P.M.; Sunday 1 to 5 P.M. Admission is  $1 for students and those 6 to 18.
Benton left the hotbed of New York City and the growing Abstract Expressionist movement to return to his home state where until his death at 85 he produced allegorical works in representational style, which are now acclaimed but in their time were out of fashion.
The Thomas Hart Benton Home and Studio, 3616 Belleview Street, (816) 931-5722, where the painter lived from age 50, is a quiet, cloistered compound tucked into a woody, vine-covered lot. The rambling stone house, with its garage-cum-studio, is a charming landmark in the annals of American art history. Open Monday to Saturday 10 A.m. to 4 P.M. and Sunday noon to 5 P.M. Admission is $2; $1.25 for those aged 6 to 12.
 
Eating
 Lamar's Donuts, just east of Main Street at 240 East Linwood Boulevard, (816) 931-5166, is an old filling station retrofitted to produce doughnuts to write home about.
Arthur Bryant's, 1727 Brooklyn Street, (816) 231-1123, has been famous for its barbecue for so long that a reasonable person might assume the reputation is likely to have outstripped reality. It hasn't. For abut $8 a person can visit a shrine -- and feast on a sliced pork sandwich and mountain of fries.
Whistler's Mother, 427 Westport Road, (816) 531-7971, is a coffee shop that serves sweets, coffee and tea upstairs at Whistler's Books.
Cafe Allegro, 1815 West 39th Street, (816) 561-3663, is expensive by Midwestern standards but the intimate, sophisticated setting, well-crafted dishes like yellowfin tuna tartare and French-cut lamb chops with Middle Eastern rice, and the extensive wine list justify the tariff. Dinner for two with wine $125.
 
Late-Nighting
 Once a great jazz city, Kansas City is still a good one. The Grand Emporium, 3832 Main Street, (816) 531-1504, is the place to stay out late. This club is a nationally known venue for musicians, famous and obscure, primarily of the blues persuasion. And the audience is invited to dance to the music.
In operation since 1917, the Mutual Musicians Foundation, 1823 Highland Street, (816) 471-5212, carries on the historic Kansas City jazz tradition with jam sessions after midnight on weekends and sometimes on Saturday afternoons; call first.
Other city spots that feature music and stay open late:
The Phoenix, 302 West 8th Street, (816) 472-0001, a piano bar with an emphasis on jazz.

The Tuba, 333 Southwest Boulevard, (816) 471-6510, which books local rhythm and blues and jazz bands and occasionally nationally known performers.

HEADLINE: Fugitive Leader of Maoist Rebels Is Captured by the Police in Peru

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Sept. 13

 BODY:
In a stunning blow to the guerrilla insurrection that has paralyzed much of Peru and shaken its Government, the police here have captured the movement's leader, Abimael Guzman Reynoso, after a 12-year manhunt.
The capture of Mr. Guzman on Saturday night is seen as Peru's greatest victory in a war that has cost 25,000 lives and an estimated $22 billion in damage. 
 "My turn to lose," Mr. Guzman, the head of the Maoist Shining Path group, reportedly said when the police arrested him at a house in the middle-class Surco neighborhood here.
 
A Dozen Others Captured
 The police said that in that raid and in another nearby they had captured about a dozen high-ranking members of a group formally called the Communist Party of Peru but more widely known as Sendero Luminoso, or Shining Path.
The group's 12-year insurrection is by far the largest and most violent in Latin America. Its challenge to the Peruvian Government has provoked widespread concern in the region, and its control of coca-growing regions in Peru has complicated antidrug efforts by the United States and other countries.
The movement, which has an estimated 5,000 fighters and thousands of other supporters, was born in 1970 in the Andean city of Ayacucho, where Mr. Guzman was a philosophy professor in the 1960's and 70's. In 1980 it began its armed insurgency. [Page A8.]
It has spread to all of Peru's provinces in 12 years of almost uninterrupted growth, fed in part by the wide gulf between rich and poor and in part by Shining Path's emphasis on giving power to indigenous people, the great majority of the population, at the expense of the elite of Spanish heritage.
"We are in front of a monster," President Alberto K. Fujimori told Peruvians tonight as state television showed a videotape of the imprisoned guerrilla leader standing shirtless.
In other prison footage, Mr. Guzman stood impassively behind bars, his right fist raised. In another scene, the bearded and bespectaled leader appeared with seven other Shining Path prisoners, several of them striking the air with their fists.
"I don't have the slightest doubt that we will apply the maximun punishment," Peru's President said, referring to a man he called "a war criminal" and "a malevolent genius."
Since seizing authoritatian powers last April, Mr. Fujimori has decreed that jailed terrorist leaders will be tried by military judges on treason charges. In Peru, a treason conviction can bring a life sentence or the death penalty.
"I have promised to end terrorism by 1995," said the President. "But let's not crow victory. Nothing would be more ominous for Peruvians than to lower their guard now."
Several analysts predicted today that while the arrests would increase Mr. Fujimori's short-term popularity, they would not spell the end of the insurgency.
Within Shining Path, the 57-year-old Mr. Guzman enjoys virtually godlike stature. His followers acclaim him as "the fourth sword of Marxism" and his writings are held to be on a par with those of Marx, Lenin and Mao.
"They have captured the godhead -- it is like capturing an Inca," said Paul L. Doughty, a University of Florida anthropology professor and expert on Shining Path.
In Lima, which bears the scars of repeated Shining Path attacks, including a car-bombing campaign in July, there was jubilation today.
"Public Enemy No. 1 Arrested" read a headline in a special edition of the newspaper Expreso. "Abimael Guzman is captured; the most wanted murderer of the century arrested."
 
Rebel Attacks on the Rise
 Expreso said that Mr. Guzman was captured as he met with other members of Shining Path's central committee to plan an October bombing campaign named "Operation Conquer Lima."
Guerrilla attacks in the capital and elsewhere in the nation of 23 million people have intensified this year. Mr. Fujimori cited the conflict when he suspended constitutional rule on April 5. He made the capture of Mr. Guzman a top priority.
"The arrest is going to greatly strengthen Fujimori politically," said Nelson Manrique, a Lima historian who has studied Shining Path. "If the Government capitalizes on this success, it could win a majority in the Assembly."
Mr. Fujimori hopes that two slates he is backing will win the Nov. 22 election for a new Congress, a body that is also to function as a constitutional convention.
In April, Mr. Fujimori closed Peru's courts and Congress, charging that they were obstacles to his war on terrorism. In public opinion polls, his popularity surged to 85 percent, and then fell back to about 60 percent last week.
"His popularity is fragile," said Mr. Doughty, the University of Florida professor. "If Fujimori makes too much of this, it could be disastrous. Where is he going to come up with one million jobs? He is not out of the woods by any means."
Peru is in deep recession and its economic problems have been compounded by the cost of the war against Shining Path and the damage the group has inflicted. Bombing targets often include bridges, rail lines and power installations.
Mr. Guzman's capture was the second major anti-insurgency victory for the Government this year. Three months ago the police arrested Victor Polay, the leader of Peru's other guerrilla group, the Cuban-inspired Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement.
The elusiveness of Mr. Guzman, whom officials said was being held at the headquarters of the anti-terrorist agency here, had become legendary in Peru over the last decade.
In June 1990, he was nearly captured at a Lima safe house, but slipped away. When the police broke in, they found only his reading glasses and medication.
 
A History of Violence
 In another raid in Lima, in January 1991, the police found a videotape showing the Shining Path leader mourning at the funeral of his wife, Augusta La Torre. He and 14 other Shining Path leaders were dressed in collarless jackets of the type popular in China under Mao Zedong.
The movement has been marked by a high degree of violence, which in turn has provoked harsh measures by the security forces.
In a recent example, seven people were killed at a gasoline station near here on Sept. 5. Eight guerrillas robbed the station, apparently to draw the police. When they fled, they left behind a van. When the police arrived and opened the door of the van, a bomb exploded, killing the 7 and seriously injuring 13.
Car bombings in Lima this summer, in response to Mr. Fujimori's crackdown, caused scores of casualties and widespread damage.
Although Shining Path followers revere Mr. Guzman, they have said that the struggle will survive him.
"This will demonstrate to the world that what we have in Peru is a peoples' war, not a central committee's war," said Adolfo Olaechea, a director of the Sol Peru Committee, a London-based group that supports the rebels. "The war has more to do with a class struggle than with personalities."
Several analysts said the Government had strengthened its hand by capturing the Shining Path leader alive, rather than dead.
"Peru is a country with martyrs, not with heroes," Mr. Doughty said. "All the national icons are martyrs. The Government has to take care of his capture, in order not to martyr him."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Anxious in His Lead, Clinton Fights to Run Race His Way

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 13

 BODY:
Part of the ritual of Presidential campaigns is the ceremonial boarding and unboarding of the plane, with the candidate walking past a gantlet of reporters shouting questions on the issues of the day. A relaxed candidate will stop and take a few. Gov. Bill Clinton strides right on by these days.
One week after Labor Day, with only seven weeks to go until the election, this is a tense and careful campaign. Mr. Clinton has retained his lead in the polls, even enlarged it in the Newsweek survey released Saturday. But every day is a struggle to keep the election focused where he wants it focused: on the ailing economy and on President Bush's shortcomings, rather than on the character issues that the Bush campaign wants front and center, notably Mr. Clinton's shifting accounts of his draft record.
 
Formidable Hurdles Remain
 
 His aides call it staying "on message": a manufacturing-jobs program last Tuesday, welfare reform on Wednesday, values on Friday, more jobs proposals this week. "What people want is fairly basic," said Stan Greenberg, the polltaker for the Clinton campaign. "They know they don't want Bush, and they want to know where Bill Clinton wants to take the country, and that's what we're laying out. It's a meat-and-potatoes election."
The economy played a big role in the results of the Newsweek poll, which showed Mr. Clinton running 15 points ahead of the President, 53 percent to 38 percent. Seventy percent of those surveyed disapproved of the way Mr. Bush was handling the economy; 47 percent thought Mr. Clinton would handle it better. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
But while the race may seem stable in the polls now, Clinton aides say that much of the campaign's future is outside their control. The real television advertising has yet to begin. The draft issue continues to percolate, despite Mr. Clinton's attempts to cast it as settled. And the debates, assuming the Bush campaign ultimately agrees to a schedule, are almost certain to have an enormous impact. Mr. Clinton spent much of the past week preparing for them, and aides say he will be in East Lansing, Mich., on Sept. 22, the date set for the first debate by the Commission on Presidential Debates, regardless of where Mr. Bush is.
It is a stage of the election where the risks and the rewards are great for a challenger like Mr. Clinton. He told a crowd on Saturday night that he sometimes felt bewildered by how far his campaign has come, a standard political gesture of humility but one with some credibility, given Mr. Clinton's experience with near political death in the primaries. The atmospherics on the trail these days underscore the stakes: the heckling is tougher, the cheers more impassioned.
A group of Bush-Quayle supporters, fresh-faced young people who said they were from local colleges, greeted Mr. Clinton at an event in a leafy suburb in Virginia on Saturday night. "Hey, hey, ho, ho, draft dodgers got to go!" they chanted as his car rolled past the placards asserting, "Clinton You're No Patriot." They also chanted the distillation of another line of Republican attack: "Failed Governor, Small State!"
At his speech on values at Notre Dame on Friday, Mr. Clinton was interrupted by the shouts of a handful of anti-abortion demonstrators almost every time he talked about the needs of children: "What about the babies, Bill?" they yelled. "What about the babies?"
But Mr. Clinton's supporters seem equally intense, energized, it seems, by the Republican convention and its numerous attacks on the nominee and his wife, Hillary. At the University of Notre Dame on Friday, the hall erupted in sustained cheers when Mrs. Clinton was introduced, a kind of determined assault on the scattered boos in the room; afterwards, many young women pushed to the front of the crowd, trying to get a close-up look at her, shouting, "Hillary! Over here, Hillary!"
His aides say he is trying to step up to the moment, to articulate a vision, to be big enough, in other words, for the voters to see him as something more than not Bush. Clinton aides bristle at the rumble of criticism in recent days from pundits and politicians that Mr. Clinton is sitting on his lead, being too cautious, not risking or reaching or working enough. "The object is to win, not to kill him," snapped Paul Begala, a Clinton aide, on the campaign plane the other day.
 
Detente on Issues Criticized
 But Mr. Clinton, in the way he handles many issues, often feeds the criticism that he is excessively cautious and too political, or, in the words of Mr. Bush, "waffling" in a way that is unacceptable in a President. This is sometimes applied to his position on the North American Free Trade Agreement, which Mr. Clinton says he supports in principle but is withholding final judgment on until he reads the fine print.
It is sometimes applied to his solicitous courtship of a wide range of constituents. On Saturday, for example, he attended a rally on the Washington Mall with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, which was intended to honor black families and kick off a voter registration drive; a crab feast in the Virginia suburbs, and, finally, a fund raiser at the Middleburg, Va., estate of Pamela Harriman, deep in horse country.
But the campaign seems more sensitive to the charge of excessive politics when it is applied to Mr. Clinton's account of how he managed to avoid the draft in the Vietnam War, which his Republican critics assert has changed several times depending on the audience and the time frame.
The Governor blew up at reporters who asked about it last Monday; since then, his aides have calmly stated that he has talked about it quite enough. Publicly, they dismiss the notion that the Republican emphasis on this issue in recent days has them worried
"I think whatever people think about Bill Clinton and the draft, they've already made up their mind," said Mickey Kantor, the chairman of the Clinton campaign. "There doesn't appear to be any movement one way or the other, based on the recent Bush-Quayle discussion of it."
 
Focus on the Economy
 Still, a campaign that watched its lead disappear in New Hampshire, when charges that he had manipulated his draft status first broke, can hardly stay sanguine about it today.
Mr. Clinton, campaigning this weekend, kept his focus on the economy, on a mocking assault on President Bush's economic proposals and on what he asserted was a dark Republican plot to win the election by dividing the nation. Saturday night, in the backyard of a home in Falls Church, Va., he cut loose, ridiculing Mr. Bush as a man who promises to "never, ever" raise taxes again, then sends his press secretary out to declare "that was not a pledge."
He compared Mr. Bush to the sinner who contends, "the devil made me do it," when he blames Congress for forcing him into the 1990 budget agreement that included tax increases. "They made me do it," he said, his voice edging into a whine. "What do you expect? I'm just the President."
Then he segued, reaching for a larger appeal: "It's our responsibility to bring the reality back into this campaign, and to bring the hope back into this campaign, and to keep people's visions on the future. We are better than this. We are better than this. And we can do better than this. The only way we will not prevail is if one more time we become divided or distracted, if one more time we allow fear to dominate hope."
In Falls Church, and at every event n recent days, he talked of the number of days remaining, just over 50 now. But he did so almost grimly, warily, like a man who sees a finish line, but one so distant it gives little solace.

HEADLINE: MILITARY FLIES AID TO RAVAGED ISLAND

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Skimming low over the calm blue Pacific and over acres of roofless houses and broken palm trees, military C-130 relief flights landed in a daylong stream today on the lush tropical island of Kauai, forming the only link to the outside world for residents devastated by Hurricane Iniki on Friday.
Loaded with generators and communications equipment as well as military rations and bottled water, the relief flights brought the essentials of daily life to 55,000 residents and thousands of stranded tourists. And today commercial airlines began ferrying tourists off the island. 
 A spokeswoman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency said 10,000 homes on the island had sustained major damage and up to 8,000 people were staying in shelters set up by the Red Cross. Two deaths and 98 injuries were reported on Kauai, and one death on the main island of Oahu.
 
Sounds of Hammering
 The spokeswoman, Linda Sacia, said the storm had destroyed the island's macadamia nut crop and other crops that form a mainstay of the island's economy. She said it also knocked out Kauai's water and power systems, and local officials said it would take weeks to restore them.
Across the island, fields of sugar cane were flattened and an estimated 90 percent of utility poles were toppled by the 160-mile-an-hour winds. The sounds of hammering and sweeping could be heard from village to village today.
Broken palm fronds and thousands of roof tiles carpeted the ground along with scattered white and yellow plumeria flowers, oranges and jackfruit.
A towering brick smokestack at the Lihue Plantation, the island's largest sugar refinery, was snapped in half.
"There's pain, a lot of pain," said Ken Cagulada, who lost his home in the storm. Mr. Cagulada, a foreman with a roofing company, said: "We're roof folks. We've got a lot of work now, but it's more sorrow than work."
Gov. John Waihee 3d called Hurricane Iniki "probably the worst disaster we've ever had in the state of Hawaii."
Kauai's Mayor, JoAnn Yukimura, estimated the damage to the island at $1 billion.
On an island where it is common to say that "everybody knows everybody," many residents affected by the storm were expected to find help and shelter with friends and relatives.
Mike Allen, a spokesman for the emergency management agency, which was criticized for responding slowly to Hurricane Andrew in Florida last month, had begun "a full-court press" here.
He said he was not aware that the agency had modified its operations following the criticism about its Florida response.
Some officials from the agency were on the ground even before the hurricane struck on Friday afternoon, and the agency director, Wallace Stickney, arrived Saturday.
State officials voiced concern that the storm could hurt the state's tourism industry, which has already been in a slump and which suffered a severe setback after Hurricane Iwa 10 years ago.
"The sun is shining and visitors are enjoying what they came to Hawaii to do," said Stanley Hong, the president of the Hawaii Visitors Bureau. He said his office was hurrying to produce what he called a "video news release" to assure potential visitors that they could still enjoy themselves here.
But on Kauai, where rations were short at the luxury hotels, tempers were becoming short among stranded tourists.
"Why are we angry?" asked Helen Figura, a guest at a luxury hotel who is visiting from Anaheim, Calif. "Because we don't have nothing to eat. There's no electricity, no power, no phone, no nothing." Rather than lying on the beach, she had spent Saturday afternoon standing in a line with her husband at one of the few operating grocery stores on the island to buy extra food and water.
Maj. Wayne Yoshioka, a spokesman for the Hawaii National Guard, said that 10 C-130 aircraft and a fleet of military helicopters were flying around-the-clock relief missions and that Guardsmen were providing security around the island. There were some isolated reports of looting.
He said stranded tourists could join homeless residents at shelters if they needed extra rations.
He said Hawaiian Airlines would soon begin ferrying tourists on special flights from the island, where the airport has been closed because of damage to the control tower.
 
Extensive Erosion
 Despite the difficulties, the storm caused remarkably little injury or loss of life. Hospital officials on Kauai said that of the 98 people hurt on the island only seven were hospitalized, none with major injuries.
But devastation was widespread. "The destruction was island-wide," said Mayor Yukimura after flying over Kauai in a helicopter on Saturday. "Huge chunks of shoreline along the Na Pali coast were washed away and there is a lot of erosion. It's like the coast aged a century in one day."
One resident, 68-year-old Cecilio Dacay, described the destruction in words echoed by many of his neighbors. "This," he said, "used to be a beautiful place. Now it seems like a war zone."
Surveying the remains of his garden, he pointed to an acre of barren soil and said: "Ginger, eggplant, cabbage, lettuce, carrots, papaya, bananas, tangerines, onions, corn, orchids, you name it, I had it.
"Its all gone," he said. "But the people are still here. That's wonderful. We've just got to start all over again."
After surveying the island from a helicopter on Saturday, Governor Waihee also spoke of the power of nature and the resilience of the human spirit.
"There is not a single spot on the island that has escaped damage," he said. "I was struck by the way nature had altered herself," leveling vegetation and reshaping the coastline.
In the Poipu area along the southern coast, for example, where the storm swept ashore, officials reported that the "debris line" on trees and buildings from the waves was 30 to 40 feet above the ground.
But the Governor also noted that once the winds had died, residents had emerged from their homes and were joining together to rebuild.
"It's heartening to see people pulling back together," he said.
Gas, electric and telephone workers were busy today across the island but officials said full services would not be restored for weeks.
Norman Ahu, a telephone company technician visiting the island on Saturday, said it would take at least two weeks to restore full service. Claire Morris, a power company spokeswoman, said full power would not be restored for at least a month.
Relief flights were arriving almost hourly. Two of the flights ferried 51 dialysis patients from the island so that they could continue their treatments where electric power is available.
Major Yoshioka of the National Guard said that about 300 troops were assisting in the relief operations on the island and that generators had been distributed to hospitals and police stations.
Batteries and household supplies were being shipped in along with 1.2 million military food rations, he said.
For the longer run, said Mr. Allen, the emergency agency spokesman, procedures were being put in place for residents to apply for grants of up to $1,500 and for rental or home repair assistance for up to 18 months.
The storm's fatalities included a 91-year-old woman, who was killed when her house collapsed in the winds, and a 76-year-old man who was killed by flying debris.
A boy was killed in a fire on the main island, Oahu, in a fire that officials said was caused by a candle that was used when the storm caused a power outage.
Oahu, 80 miles to the southeast and home to 800,000 people, mostly in Honolulu, was spared the brunt of the storm and suffered relatively light damage estimated by officials at $2.5 million.
"It was very scary, very, very scary," said George Kawakami, who is the field representative for Senator Daniel K. Inouye.
"When the wind picked up some roofing and slammed a tree into the side of my home, I wondered why I didn't go to a shelter," he said. "I guess it's the same reason I live here in Kauai. It's my home."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Bush Voices Sympathy
 By Reuters -- As residents of Kauai began digging out from a hurricane that devastated their island, President Bush pledged yesterday to "stand by" the people of Hawaii after its worst storm this century.
Mr. Bush, speaking before leaving Washington for a three-day West Coast campaign trip, said, "Our hearts go out to people of Hawaii and we pledge to stand by them, of course, in their hour of need."
He said he had no plans to visit Hawaii.
Mr. Bush, who was criticized by some officials for what they called a slow response to Hurricane Andrew in South Florida, declared most of Hawaii a disaster area on Saturday as the National Guard rushed aid to Kauai.
