SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1258 words

HEADLINE: GERMANY PROMISES INTEREST-RATE CUT TO REVIVE GROWTH

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, Sept. 13

 BODY:
After days of turmoil on European money markets, Germany promised tonight to lower its high interest rates, a move that is expected to strengthen the slipping dollar and take pressure off the troubled economies of Britain, France and other European countries.
Word of Bonn's decision, announced by Prime Minister Giuliano Amato of Italy in Rome and the European Community in Brussels, immediately drew sighs of relief from Paris and London. France and the Netherlands are expected to respond by lowering their interest rates, making it easier for businesses to borrow money and thus inject some sense of movement into the European economy. 
 Significantly, Germany's decision, made in tandem with an Italian agreement to devalue its currency, was announced just a week before the French vote on a referendum on European political and economic unity. For months, Germany has resisted pressure from its allies and trading partners to cut its interest rates, and only last week, the president of the Bundesbank said the bank saw "no room for maneuver to lower rates." [News analysis, page D2.]
 
Persuasion for the French
 Polls have indicated that the vote in France will be close. Some people interpreted the German decision -- which comes after months of criticism by its allies -- as an attempt to persuade French voters to support the treaty on European union. After voters in Denmark voted against the treaty in a referendum in June, many European political leaders and economists said a rejection by the French would end the push for European unity and disrupt the region's economy.
"The opportunities created by the will of the Bundesbank to lower its lending rates are of considerable significance," Finance Minister Michel Sapin of France said after the German announcement. The German promise, he said, "demonstrated the true solidarity of Germany towards its European partners and opened the way to an easing of interest rates in Europe, which is necessary to support growth and employment."
 
White House Reaction
 In Washington, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said in a statement: "We welcome the action taken this weekend to realign the European Monetary System, and we are especially pleased that the Bundesbank intends to reduce interest rates Monday morning. This is a positive development for world markets."
The German decision is expected to buoy the dollar because the chief reason for the dollar's weakness has been the huge spread between the Federal Reserve's low interest rates and the Bundesbank's high ones. The high rates attract many investors. With lower German interest rates, fewer investors will be buying marks, and that currency is likely to drop in value against the dollar, and other currencies as well.
[In Monday trading in Asia and Australia, the dollar was up sharply against the mark.]
Tonight's move represented a reversal of European monetary policy, just a week after European finance ministers said at a meeting in Bath, England, that they would not realign the currencies. The looming vote in France, as well as the continuing slide of the lira, apparently produced the turnabout.
The Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, said in a statement tonight that it would announce cuts in its official interest rates on Monday. It provided no details of the extent to which interest rates would be reduced. The announcement of the pending cut was itself extraordinary; the Bundesbank hardly ever discloses a rate change in advance.
But even nations outside the European Monetary System, like Finland and Sweden, have been feeling the strain of high German interest rates. Sweden, for instance, was forced last week to raise its inter-bank interest rate to 75 percent to protect its krona against the mark.
Finance Minister Theo Waigel of Germany said the decision to devalue the lira had been reached unanimously by the European Community's finance ministers and central bank governors.
"This decision will contribute to overcoming the tensions which have arisen on European foreign exchange markets, especially in the last few days," Mr. Waigel told reporters on the North Sea island of Sylt.
Before agreeing to lower interest rates, Germany insisted that Italy devalue the lira by 7 percent against other European currencies, a step that is expected to calm the markets. But the lira's devaluation is expected to reinforce the perception of Italy as the economic sick man of Europe.
"The results should have positive effects for Europe and the world and could also turn out positively for Italy." Mr. Amato said.
In Britain, Norman Lamont, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, said the value of the pound against the mark would not be affected. "We particularly welcome the intention of the Bundesbank council to cut its official interest rates in order to reduce strains" within the European monetary system, he said.
European Community exchange rates are governed by a system that sets upper and lower limits for currency fluctuations and obliges central banks to intervene to support weak currencies.
Technically, the devaluation of the lira was the result of a 3.5 percent upward revaluation of other European currencies against the theoretical accounting unit, the European Currency Unit, and a 3.5 percent devaluation of the lira against it.
Before the currency markets closed on Friday, the lira had slipped below its designated floor against the mark. An increase in Italian interest rates, the purchase of $1.5 billion of lira by the Bank of Italy and costly intervention by other European central banks failed to halt the collapse.
 
Fundamental Weakness
 The devaluation of the lira is also likely to be interpreted here as a long-overdue recognition of Italy's fundamental economic weakness stemming from the nation's huge budget deficit -- Europe's largest in absolute terms. The deficit could reach $150 billion by the end of the year. That represents about 11 percent of Italy's gross domestic product, the second highest percentage in Western Europe, after Greece.
While it is unclear how large the German interest rate reductions will be, if they are more than of token size, they could counter the mark's recent strength against European currencies and the dollar.
 
A Few Complaints
 Not everyone was delighted. Peter Pietsch, an economist at Commerzbank, said: "The Bundesbank has let itself be blackmailed. This is sensational that for the first time, they have let their independence be compromised. This clearly has come from political pressure."
Prime Minister Amato said Germany had been pressing for several weeks to revalue the mark, while Italy had been campaigning for lower interest rates.
"We have acted in a strong European spirit and our Government has succeeded in finally allowing German interest rates to fall," he told a news conference at which, for domestic political reasons, he sought to salvage some honor from a move many Italians are certain to see as humiliating.
Despite the expectation among many Europeans of more stable money markets, some people remain skeptical of the impact of a German rate cut, particularly if the Bundesbank makes only marginal cuts in interest rates or if French voters reject the Maastricht Treaty on European political and economic union.
"I hope we can now go back to the long period of monetary stability we have known," Finance Minister Phillipe Maystadt of Belgium said. "Of course, all this depends on the hypothesis that the French do not vote against Maastricht."

HEADLINE: To Fill a Shortage of Doctors, Town Nurtures 2 of Its Own

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Colo.

 BODY:
When the Pilmentel and Perez families moved here from Mexico in the 1970's, there was a shortage of manual laborers for the kind of dirty, back-breaking, low-paying field work that seemed reserved for those who spoke Spanish.
Like many rural towns, Burlington today faces a worker shortage at the opposite end of the economic and social spectrum: physicians. In the past four years, Burlington has spent $50,000 on a campaign to recruit a doctor or two, but none would settle in this 3,000-person town, which is a flat spot near the Kansas border and not much else. 
 The town ultimately found a solution in its own backyard: It persuaded a wealthy resident to finance the medical school costs of two Burlington High School graduates in exchange for their promise to return home.
Burlington now looks forward to the day when "Dr. Sacramento Pilmentel" and "Dr. James Perez," the sons of field workers and dishwashers, come home to hang out their shingles. The two young men have just begun their first year at the University of Colorado Medical School.
"My son will help the town," a beaming Israel Pilmentel, a 46-year-old farm hand, said through an interpreter. His 14-year-old son Jerardo added his own comment: "Man, I am so proud."
The town's newspaper will run a regular feature that keeps up with the progress of the medical students. "This town is real proud of these kids," said John Hudler, the news editor at The Burlington Record.
 
From Field to Field
 "We want people to know how things are going for them and their families," he said. "That way, when they come home for Christmas, people can ask them about classes and life at school. And by the time they've finished up, people here will still have a connection to them. They won't be strangers."
Born in Mexico to migrant workers, the young men spent their early years traveling to fruit and vegetable fields in California, Florida and Colorado with their families. They usually stayed in beaten-up trailers, although Sacramento Pilmentel recalls a stint of staying in an old Buick.
Their fathers worked in the sugar beet fields here and eventually found permanent jobs as farm hands. Their mothers work as dishwashers in local restaurants. Neither of the young men spoke English when they came to Burlington. As a child, Mr. Perez said he knew, "My father -- the Mexicans -- did work no one else was willing to do."
A Spanish teacher at the high school would come to the elementary school to help sometimes, but mostly they learned the language on their own.
"We watched a lot of 'Sesame Street,' " said Mr. Perez.
For a time, the two young men doubted they would even go to college, much less medical school. In the summer after graduation from Burlington High School in 1988, Mr. Perez was working on a farm, and Mr. Pilmentel had gone to the oil fields of Wyoming in search of work. They told their parents they would probably not be going to college. They could not afford it.
 
2-Person Support Group
 But Colorado State awarded them scholarships, and the young men nervously went off to campus. "Most kids had parents who had gone to college, or older siblings, and they knew what to expect," said Mr. Perez. "If we hadn't had each other, we probably would have put our backpacks in the car and gone home."
The year the boys went to college the town began searching for a doctor because two of the town's physicians retired. Burlington could have applied for a Federal program that assigns doctors to rural regions, in exchange for forgiveness of loans. But the town was skeptical. Those doctors often leave as soon as their obligations are fulfilled.
The town was unaware that James Perez, who is married and the father of a three-month-old boy, had been accepted to medical school. But news spread quickly when he came to the Bank of Burlington last winter in search of a hefty loan.
Despite the common view that scholarship money is always available for bright minority students, officials at the Colorado Medical School said the pool of financial aid had been inadequate for several years.
 
Not a Marcus Welby
 The Burlington loan officer, Charles Baker, called Mr. Hudler at the newspaper and asked, "Do you suppose there is anything we can do for him?"
Mr. Hudler met with Mr. Perez. "If we paid for your schooling," he asked, "would you come back here?"
At first, Mr. Perez was skeptical that an offer would be made. Hispanic people account for less than 10 percent of the town's population. He wondered whether they might have been looking for a doctor that looked more like Marcus Welby. "I didn't think Burlington would want me, you know, being a minority," he said.
One local resident assured Mr. Perez: "Look, if you have a good bedside manner, it won't matter if you're 10 different colors and striped to boot."
Vayo Rodriguez, a 31-year-old who works for the city's electric department and is a friend of the Pilmentel family, said the majority of the townspeople were fair-minded. And the others? "Well, they're learning something, aren't they," he said, and smiled broadly. "They're about to turn around and see that one of those people -- the ones who are below them -- has gotten as high in this town as you can get."
 
'Mr. Potter' Steps In
 As products of the working class, the young men said, they will be able to relate to patients in a way that other doctors might not. "Most doctors are from pretty educated, well-to-do backgrounds, and the patients know it," Mr. Pilmentel said. "But if a concrete worker or a welder or a farm worker comes into the office, I'll be able to say, 'Hey, I can relate to what you're doing.' And it will give the patients some connection."
As a gruff old man with plenty of power and money in a small town, Harold McArthur is a kind of warm-hearted version of Mr. Potter in "It's a Wonderful Life."
"I've been lucky," said Mr. McArthur, 82, as he sat near a sign on the wall about shooting salesmen and spat tobacco juice. "I've made potfuls of money, and I'm going to spend it."
He has a long list of beneficence and is also executor of a charitable trust. He was approached about the idea of using trust money for the young men.
"I like this idea so much I'll pay for it myself," he said.
He has earmarked about $30,000 a year for the two students. But if that isn't enough, townspeople say they will get the money somehow.
"It's going to be like some corny Norman Rockwell painting," said Mr. Hudler, the newspaper editor. "This whole town is going to pull together."
Before the agreement was made, Mr. McArthur wanted to meet the boys at his farm implements dealership. A sometimes cantankerous man, Mr. McArthur has been known to have physically removed a salesman or two in his time. As he sat in work trousers behind a cluttered desk, he asked the young men some hard questions.
 
Sealed by a Handshake
 "What really turned me on about these boys," said Mr. McArthur, who came from an impoverished family of 12 children, "was the way they want to learn, really learn."
Mr. Hudler had gone along to the meeting with a contract that would legally bind the young men to return to Burlington.
"Nope, I don't do business that way," said Mr. McArthur, who simply wanted to shake hands on the deal.
"Pretty cool," said Mr. Pilmentel. And they shook.
To hear the townspeople, the arrangement is the most creative idea in Burlington since the 1950's, when a local farmer decided to arrange and attend his own funeral. He thought it was a shame for eulogies to be wasted on the dead. So the farmer, who was in his 70's, sat in his casket and listened to people mourn and talk about what a splendid fellow he was. Life magazine even sent a photographer.
"This whole darned thing is just wonderful," said Barry Hinkhouse, a farmer who employs James Perez's father. "They'll be such great role models -- for everyone."
Two years ago, Mr. Pilmentel and his brother David spent the summer at a meat packing plant in Dodge City, Kan., to raising money to send David to mechanic's school in Denver.
"He's about to get a job," said Mr. Pilmentel, "and then he's going to help me out."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Burlington, Colo., is solving its doctor shortage by financing the medical school costs of two local high school graduates in exchange for a promise to return home. James Perez, left, and Sacramento Pilmentel have just begun at the University of Colorado Medical School. (Ellen Jaskol Kelsey for The New York Times) (pg. B7)

HEADLINE: U.S., Mindful of Setbacks in Past, Offers Guarded Praise of Capture

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD R. KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Long frustrated in its efforts to develop an effective policy toward Peru, the Bush Administration responded today to the capture of the rebel leader Abimael Guzman Reynoso with a mixture of satisfaction and caution.
Some officials compared the arrest of the Shining Path leader with the capture of Che Guevara, the Marxist revolutionary who was tracked down and executed in Bolivia in 1967. They expressed hope that Mr. Guzman's capture would turn the tide in the losing war against the Peruvian rebels and the drug traffickers who finance them. 
 But Administration officials also noted that Shining Path has shown enormous resiliency in recent years and has repeatedly spirited its members out of prisons. Also tempering the urge to celebrate was the mixed outcome of the Administration's fitful efforts to help fight Shining Path while pressing President Alberto K. Fujimori to reverse his seizure of near-dictatorial powers and improve his human rights record.
 
Rebels' Link to Drug Traffic
 In suspending the Constitution on April 5, Mr. Fujimori said he needed untrammeled authority to fight the rebels and drug traffickers. Shining Path's base of operations in the Upper Huallaga Valley is the richest area of coca cultivation in the world, and the group taxes and protects growers and cooperates with traffickers to finance its operations.
Peru supplies the raw material for more than half the cocaine consumed in the United States. In recent months, the Administration's concern about Shining Path has deepened with reports that its operations are spreading into neighboring Bolivia.
"These people direct the most violent and vicious terrorist group that has ever existed in Latin America," the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Bernard W. Aronson, said today.
He predicted that the arrests would "provide the Peruvian Government and people with what they need most in this battle: some sense of hope and confidence."
Mr. Aronson said it was too early to tell whether the capture would help restore a sense of legitimacy to the Peruvian Government or help mend relations between Lima and Washington, which have been strained since Mr. Fujimori dissolved the legislature, the courts and the Constitution.
But the Assistant Secretary of State hinted that a better relationship had been in the making since Mr. Fujimori pledged to hold new legislative elections in November and to allow observers of the Organization of American States to monitor the polling.
United States officials refused to say whether American intelligence or military personnel were in any way involved in the events that led to Mr. Guzman's arrest.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs, said it was "certainly possible" that the United States had provided some intelligence assistance in the operation, although military aid to Peru was suspended last spring.
Mr. Torricelli predicted that the capture of Mr. Guzman would help ease tensions between Lima and Washington. "I say this with great reservation, but this represents somewhat of a vindication for Fujimori's actions," the New Jersey Democrat said.
Even before Mr. Fujimori seized emergency powers in April, Congress had held up Administration efforts to train Peruvian military units in anti-drug operations and had delayed economic aid aimed at weaning local economies from dependence on coca growing. Many Democrats warned of an American military entanglement similar to the one in Vietnam.
Mr. Fujimori's suspension of the Constitution led to the cancellation of $167 million in economic aid and the withdrawal of 20 advisers training Peruvian police in operations against drug traffickers. Relations deteriorated further when a Peruvian Air Force jet opened fire on an American transport plane involved in anti-drug reconnaissance on April 24, causing the death of one crewman.
The Bush Administration contends that the Peruvian people will only follow a democratic government in the long run. Today United States officials agreed that Mr. Fujimori's standing would be bolstered by the capture of the terrorist leader but said it was unclear what policies he would pursue from a position of greater strength.
Among the human rights abuses attributed to the Peruvian authorities in recent years are sporadic mass killings in Indian communities and torture in prisons.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

International
In a move that should bolster the beleaguered dollar and ease worldwide market tensions, Germany agreed to reduce its high interest rates after Italy decided to devalue the ailing lira by 7 percent against other European currencies. [Page A1.] The fiercely independent German central bank gave in to pressure to lower rates because of the serious chaos in world currency markets and the threat that its hard-line position posed to European unity. [D2.]
The U.S. and China are scheduled to begin trade talks this week in Beijing amid an escalating war of words that has been aggravated by Washington's decision to sell jet fighters to Taiwan. [D1.] 
 Investors in Mexican equities hoped to see quick benefits from the North American Free Trade Agreement; last month's accord is having the opposite effect because of doubts about whether the U.S. and Canada will ratify the pact. [D1.]
Russia will need about $18 billion in foreign aid next year to continue its traumatic transition to a market economy -- the same amount it is getting this year -- with about $3 billion more from the International Monetary Fund, a top I.M.F. official says. [D2.]
In a sign that Japanese companies are having a hard time avoiding layoffs, the nation's steel industry is asking Tokyo to subsidize the costs of job cuts. Other business sectors are likely to follow. [D6.]
 
The Economy
Manufacturers of mobile homes are experiencing a boom as residents of southern Florida try quickly and inexpensively to replace housing destroyed by Hurricane Andrew. [D1.]
 
Companies
The number of mergers and acquisitions has jumped recently after sputtering for nearly two years, with heavy activity among well-known brands like Gillette and Stella D'Oro. [D1.]
The merger of Air Canada and Canadian Airlines, Canada's two biggest airlines, creates the 12th-largest international carrier as the industry continues a shift to big global combinations. [D6.]

CBS is having trouble maintaining the loyalty of its affiliates. A Detroit station is dropping the network's morning news program, and there are worries about late-night shows as well. Not even the prime-time offerings are immune. [D1.]
Time Warner and the musician Quincy Jones have teamed up to put out Vibe, a funky new magazine about hip-hop, a culture rooted in black music, like rap and soul, which has been embraced by whites. The test issue goes on sale today. [D8.]

Looking to bring professional baseball to Maine, Daniel B. Burke, the president and chief executive of Capital Cities/ABC is in the market for a minor league team. [D8.]
 
Today's Column
Despite falling mortgage rates, Wall Street is turning a cold shoulder to the home-building industry, fearing that consumers' lack of confidence will stem the tide of buying. An index of home-builder stocks has fallen 15 percent since its recent high in early August. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D4.]

HEADLINE: German Concession;
The Bundesbank Bows to Pressure In Lowering Its High Interest Rates

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Germany's fiercely independent central bank is famous for staring down outsiders when they urge it to reduce its painfully high interest rates. But with today's announcement that it would cut rates, the Bundesbank blinked.
The pressures were too great. World currency markets were in chaos as the dollar slid to record lows against the German mark, and several European currencies withered in the face of the mark's strength. At the same time, economic growth was evaporating in Germany and Europe in general because of the Bundesbank's stratospheric rates -- which were intended to help reduce Germany's inflation but at the same time undermined growth by discouraging companies from borrowing and investing. 
 What is more, the French -- and some German officials -- complained that the Bundesbank's bullheadedness was sabotaging the road to European unity, and would push the French to reject a treaty calling for a single European currency when they vote on the matter next Sunday.
 
'It Was Right to Act'
 "The Bundesbank acted under enormous pressure, and it was right to act," said Stanley Fischer, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who used to be the World Bank's chief economist. "They were anxious not to be seen as bowing to pressure, but they did."
Finance Minister Michel Sapin of France said the Bundesbank decision showed the willingness of German authorities to take into account the economic situation beyond their borders.
 "Eight days before a vote which will be decisive for the building of Europe," Mr. Sapin said, "I am convinced that a 'yes' to the referendum will allow France to take advantage of the positive opportunities offered for its economy to take full advantage of the lowering of interest rates in Europe."
 
Higher Dollar Is Seen
 Although the German central bank did not say by how much it would lower rates, any cut at all will almost certainly cause the dollar to jump from its record lows. The main reason for the dollar's slide over the last month is that many investors have moved their money into Germany because short-term interest rates are so much higher there than those in the United States.
"This should mean an upward move for the dollar," said Robert A. White, director of foreign exchange operations for First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles. He said the dollar, which was at 1.40 German marks early last week, could jump about 10 percent, to around 1.55 marks.
The dollar's recent fall has unnerved America's stock and bond markets as investors feared the dollar's slide would turn into an out-and-out plunge. Today's Bundesbank announcement should go far to reassure financial markets.
"I think the Bundesbank's move will be positive for the U.S. bond market because one of the things undercutting the rally is the fear created by the weak dollar," said Robert Giordano, chief economist for Goldman, Sachs & Company. "The stock markets should also respond favorably."
 
Weak European Economies
 The Bundesbank's high rates -- its most important short-term rate is 9.75 percent -- helped slow Germany's growth to near zero in the second quarter. Because other European Community countries have linked their rates to those of the powerful Bundesbank, Germany's rates have helped keep Britain in a prolonged recession and have also taken the momentum out of France's and Italy's weak economic recoveries.
"Europe's economy is weak right now, and if the Bundesbank had held on with its high rates, we would have had a real serious slowdown in Europe next year," said Professor Fischer of M.I.T. "Now, the chance of a European recovery is better than yesterday."
That bodes well for the American economy. Although Germany's high interest rates helped produce a weaker dollar that normally should spur American exports, those high rates simultaneously hobbled Europe's economic growth. A stalled European economy undermines American exports because European consumers will be able to afford fewer Levi jeans and European businesses will be buying fewer I.B.M. mainframes.
 
Fed May Have More Leeway
 By strengthening the dollar, the Bundesbank's announcement could give the Federal Reserve more leeway to cut interest rates. Many economists say the Fed cut its Federal funds rate by only one-quarter of 1 percent, instead of one-half of 1 percent, on Sept. 4 because it was worried about the weak dollar. The Federal funds rate is the interest rate at which banks lend each other money overnight.
Bush Administration officials have long badgered the Bundesbank to cut its rates, complaining that they were slowing growth in Germany and beyond. Just hours after the Bundesbank announcement, American officials were already taking some credit for the Bundesbank move. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said the German action helped "fulfill President Bush's longstanding efforts to insure the strengthening of world growth."
For weeks, many Administration officials had fretted privately about the dollar's slide. If it had turned into a nose dive, that could have caused the stock market to plunge -- one of the last things any President wants a few weeks before the nation votes on whether to re-elect him.
 
Implications for Unity Vote
 The Bundesbank's move could also prove a boon to President Francois Mitterrand, France's No. 1 supporter of European unity and the Maastricht treaty. The Bundesbank's directors, by showing that even Germany's central bank will make some concessions to help other Europeans, might make French voters feel a little more kindly about unity.
If the Bundesbank had not acted and the French were to vote next Sunday against the Maastricht treaty calling for European unity, many people would have blamed the German central bank and its high interest rates for souring the French on unity and scuttling the treaty.
Many analysts had speculated that one reason the Bundesbank was keeping rates so high was to achieve that end -- to sabotage a treaty that would move control over Europe's monetary policy from the German central bank to a new European Community central bank where other countries had a voice.
But, some analysts say, the Bundesbank decided to cut rates a week before the French vote because its members feared that if the French defeated the treaty a crisis might follow in Europe's foreign exchange markets, maiming the European Monetary System.
While Bundesbank members have little eagerness for a Europe-wide central bank, they are keen believers in the monetary system, which has prevented wild exchange rate fluctuation and created an anchor for Europe's economic growth.
"The Bundesbank has bowed to pressures from other European nations about the need to stimulate growth and put a more positive slant on the Maastricht vote in France," said Mr. White, the foreign exchange manager. "But in the eyes of the market, the Bundesbank will have lost some credibility on fighting inflation."
Many economists had predicted that the Bundesbank would not lower rates for several months. Indeed, officials at the central bank had repeatedly said this year that they would not lower rates until inflation was brought under 3 percent and monetary growth stopped exceeding their targets. With inflation close to 3.5 percent, today's announcement showed the Bundesbank was giving in to external pressure before meeting its internal goals.
"It's a classic case of the Bundesbank coming to grips with outside realities," said William R. Cline, an economist with the Institute for International Economics in Washington.

HEADLINE: Official of I.M.F. Urges More Loans for Russia

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
A senior International Monetary Fund official says Russia will need about the same amount of foreign aid next year -- $18 billion -- that it is scheduled to receive this year to assist its traumatic transition to a market economy.
In a news briefing on Friday that was embargoed for release until Monday, the official, who insisted on anonymity, said he hoped the fund would negotiate a new aid package with Russia before January under which Russia would qualify for $3 billion more in I.M.F. loans. 
 The official said that while Russia had used most of this year's foreign aid to buy emergency items like food and medicine, he hoped the aid next year would go to buy machinery and other equipment to help rebuild the economy.
 
Advice for the Fed
 In his meeting with journalists, the I.M.F. official made numerous other points: he urged the Federal Reserve not to lower rates further to keep the dollar from falling, and he called on the American and German Governments to make sharp cuts in their budget deficits.
The briefing came a week before the monetary fund and World Bank hold their semiannual meeting in Washington. The Group of Seven industrial nations is also scheduled to hold a finance ministers' meeting next weekend. Aid to Russia and the dollar's weakness will certainly be discussed at the meetings.
The official said he hoped the I.M.F. would begin negotiating an agreement with Russia in October. Under Russia's current pact with the fund, which was made final last month, Moscow is receiving $1 billion in I.M.F. loans. That is part of a $24 billion Western aid package, which includes a $6 billion fund, not yet in effect, to stabilize the ruble.
 
Pledge on Inflation
 The official said the new aid package would be more comprehensive and stricter than the existing accord. Russia has promised to reduce inflation to less than 10 percent a month under the current agreement, but the official said he hoped it would pledge to cut inflation to less than 10 percent a year in the new pact.
That is a tall order because Russia's money supply continues to swell as workers demand higher wages to keep up with inflation, and state enterprises clamor for loans to stay afloat and repay debts to other enterprises.
"The money supply is certainly the domain where the problems are biggest," the official said, expressing optimism that Moscow's central bank would act prudently.
He said the new agreement should call on Russia to accelerate its privatizations, asserting that state enterprises that can be converted to viable private companies should be saved while those with dim prospects should be placed into bankruptcy.
Speaking before Germany's central bank announced today that it would cut its interest rates, the monetary fund official said the Federal Reserve should not cut interest rates further because that could weaken the fragile dollar even more and roil the world's currency markets.
Talking cautiously but with unusual directness, the official said: "We recommend prudence. We don't see what good a further decrease in rates can do, but we can see what risks it could entail for foreign currency markets."
The comments were the second instance in recent days in which the I.M.F. had criticized American policy. On Thursday, the organization said the United States Government should trim spending and increase taxes to cut its budget deficit, which it said was undermining long-term world economic growth.
Since December, the Federal Reserve has cut rates sharply to buoy the economy, making its most recent cut on Sept. 4, but the United States remains in an economic slump.
Fed officials said they had no response to the official's comments.
The official urged the United States to commit itself to cut the Federal budget deficit over the next few years by between $240 billion and $300 billion. According to the Congressional Budget Office, the deficit will be $314 billion this year, or slightly more than 5 percent of the gross domestic product.

HEADLINE: U.S.-China Tensions Over Trade

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The war of words between China and the United States appears likely to intensify this week as the two sides meet here for trade talks that have taken on heavy political significance after President Bush's recent decision to sell jet fighters to Taiwan.
For the last several years, the United States has insisted that China do more to open its markets to American exports and provide greater protection for foreign patents and copyrights. Several agreements have been hammered out, generally with little fanfare. 
 But the latest talks, in which Washington is demanding that China lower a number of import barriers, have degenerated into a bitter exchange of threats that escalated sharply after President Bush said the United States would sell 150 F-16 fighter planes to Taiwan, which China regards as a runaway province. China has also complained that the sale violates a 1982 agreement under which the United States promised to reduce its weapons sales to Taiwan.
Sharpening the dispute is the fact that there are several other highly sensitive matters under discussion, leading to testy exchanges that mix economics and politics.
 
Senate to Vote on China
 In Washington, the Senate is expected to vote this week on a bill that would require China to improve its human rights record, limit its arms sales and open its markets before the nation is granted a renewal of its preferential access to the American market, known as most-favored-nation status. China bitterly resents the inclusion of these conditions.
The United States has been concerned about the recent detention of Shen Tong, a former student leader involved in the pro-democracy movement in Tiananmen Square three years ago, who has returned to China to try to establish a human rights movement.
And American officials expressed deep concern late last week after China offered to sell nuclear technology to Iran. Although China and Iran both insisted that the technology would be used solely for peaceful purposes, the United States called the deal "imprudent." The Chinese responded by describing the American comments as "arrogant."
"There are so many things going on right now that are very real issues in the relationship that I'm not sure you can separate them out from the trade negotiations," said John Kamm, a longtime expert on trade with China who is now campaigning to ease China's human rights policies. "It will be very tricky to keep these things apart."
 
Threats and Responses
 The trade issue began to grow tense on Aug. 21 when the United States announced that it was prepared to raise tariffs on a range of Chinese-made goods if Beijing did not accede to American market-opening demands. The tariffs would cover $3.9 billion of American imports, like Chinese-made footwear, toys, electronic goods and electrical appliances.
The United States has been demanding that China lower tariffs, ease its import licensing rules, end import quotas and clarify trade laws.
Last week Chinese officials responded by saying they would increase tariffs to punitive levels on $4 billion of American-made goods that China imports -- including chemicals, automobiles, computers, medical equipment and commercial jets -- if Washington carried out its threat. An agricultural official said that China ought to cut off its imports of American wheat; China has been the largest purchaser of American wheat for the last several years.
The stakes were raised even further when Ira Wolf, an assistant United States trade representative, said that if China did not take the market-opening steps, Washington would bar its entry to the body that regulates world trade, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, known as GATT.
Since China began expanding its foreign trade -- it is expected to buy and sell more than $165 billion worth of goods this year to other countries -- it has sought to become a member of GATT and integrate its economy more with the world trading system.
"If they fail to settle this case, then they are not getting into the GATT, period," Mr. Wolf said. "If they are not willing to make these concessions, there is no way in the world that the United States can allow China into the GATT. And there's no way in the world China can get into the GATT unless the United States goes along with it."
"We are prepared, if we don't settle this by Oct. 10, to retaliate," Mr. Wolf said. "And that's in no one's interest. But we are prepared to do so."

HEADLINE: Senate Race: The Clash of the Cathode Rays;
A Bewildering Barrage for Viewers as the New York Democrats Stump on Screen

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
It was possible to walk mile after mile over the weekend and find not a clue that political war was being waged with wild abandon across New York State. Out on Manhattan streets, conversations wandered over everything from the weather, to the economy, to the proper care and feeding of tarantulas ("Two dozen crickets every six weeks or so and they'll grow as big as your hand").
There was nary a whisper about the poison-filled finale to the Senate primary campaign that ends tomorrow. In Manhattan, along a five-mile stretch of Broadway from Harlem to midtown, the only immediate proof of Campaign Fever was a most unaggressive woman standing at the corner of 80th Street holding aloft a hand-lettered sign inviting New Yorkers to: "Have breakfast with Hillary and Tipper on Oct. 1."
Wrong race. 
 One block south, a leaflet drifted underfoot, its tattered remains the only clue to the storm and stress of the Democratic primary race for Senate. "Geraldine Ferraro is no liberal," the flier produced by a rival, Elizabeth Holtzman, cautioned. Then it promised not just a woman but "a progressive woman" to glide across the polished Senate floors.
 
Running on the Screen
 On Saturday afternoon, pedestrians just let it grind beneath their marching feet. The silence left some voters wondering where all those millions in campaign spending went.
To find out, all they had to do was sit at home. Modern politics is couch politics. Smokey back rooms long ago gave way to the whistle stop, the radio exhortation, the stump speech and the pump after pump of numbing handshakes. Now, if the streets are any measure, the 1992 Senate primary shows that the bitterest fights have moved back indoors.
That makes the remote-control clicker the king to the advertisements' queen. Sometimes they are complementary. Sometimes not.
"I treated them like any other commercial," Lilly Singer, a 69-year-old White Plains social worker, said of the combative political advertisements aired in the final push before tomorrow's voting. "I basically ignored them."
For the politicians themselves, the last days of the campaign, and the avalanche of advertising they unleash, is a multimillion-dollar gamble to win voters' attention and send them to the polls renewed, full of a sense that their candidate and no other is the one who should book the next seat to Washington. Of course, things do not always work out that way.
Across New York State over the weekend, many Democratic voters said they had tuned in to the advertisements and the television news coverage of the final days of the race, but have not been turned on.
"What I do on Tuesday may be affected by the negative ads," said Daniel A. Goulding, a high school teacher from suburban Buffalo. "And I find that disturbing."
Also troubled was Eleanor Golden, a registered Democrat from the East Village in Manhattan. "You turn on the TV and see Holtzman attacking Ferraro one minute, Ferraro attacking Holtzman the next. It's like a made-for-TV movie. You see candidates on TV all dolled up. They don't tell us how to solve the drug problem, the homeless problem, affordable housing and the AIDS crisis."
At 7 P.M. Saturday, it was possible to sit through the local news and hear about the Senate contest only in a cascade of advertisements at the end. The news programs themselves focused on the hurricane in Hawaii, the Presidential race, the weekend's festivals and a hate crime. On several stations, the ads provided the only clue to tomorrow's election. Played back to back, they sometimes blurred. First Ms. Holtzman ran an ad featuring Ms. Ferraro's face in freeze-frame and a list of moral indictments. Then Ms. Ferraro's team retorted with a spot denying all the nasty things said about her.
For the idle viewer, the result could be disorienting: Was that Ms. Ferraro first setting up the negative charges and then batting them away? Or was that a Holtzman ad that led into one by her lighter-haired adversary? The latter was the case. But without giving the glimmering screen one's full attention, it was a little hard to tell.
So many ads. So little time.
 
The Ads Pile Up
 Later Saturday night, the news teams invited the politicians on board. In clips from the day's campaigning on Fox News about 10:15 P.M., Ms. Ferraro called Ms. Holtzman a kamikaze pilot. Attorney General Robert Abrams spoke of the need for better health care. Ms. Holtzman held forth on ethics. The Rev. Al Sharpton, who cannot afford television spots but has won cautious admiration from some for sticking with the issues, appeared too.
There was a lot of slamming back and forth followed by the commentator's question about whether the four could possibly work together after tomorrow night. It was a good question, though rhetorical, and popped up again the next morning in a televised debate.
As the night wore on with reports of the shuttle liftoff, updates on the damage in Hawaii, a spot on malfunctioning seatbelts and an appearance (on WWOR) of Gizmo the weather dog, the political quotient kept rising. The political ads bunched up as well, falling mostly into the breaks at every half hour. By 11:20, WCBS broadcast longer pieces on the race, showing Ms. Ferraro denying that her husband had ever met a reputed mob figure, Mr. Abrams accusing Ms. Ferraro of sending hecklers to disrupt his news conference and other candidates complaining about the bitterness and the sleaze.
 
Litany of Charges
 Then, a moment out for -- the ads. First, Mr. Abrams hit Ms. Ferraro. Then Ms. Holtzman hit Ms. Ferraro. Then Ms. Ferraro announced, "I want to set the record straight." At times, it helped to pause to remind oneself whether it was the attacks accurately reported by the news teams or the attacks videotaped by the advertising teams that were drifting out from the TV screen.
The result, for many viewers, was input without clarification.
Faced with weeks of charges and countercharges and a level of bitterness and bile that she said filled her with "distaste," Mary Ann Winters, a 44-year-old Yonkers resident and a senior executive with a Manhattan marketing firm, described herself as "in a quandary." She said she no longer could tell what was "hyped" and what was real. Nor did she know, just 48 hours before the primary, whom she would vote for. She said she had a slight preference for Ms. Ferraro over the other candidates but then acknowledged, "I've never been this blase."
 
Ferraro Here, Ferraro There
 Yesterday morning's news deluge offered some hope. Yet the advertisements were the same ones that had run the night before and the WNBC debate mostly retraced familiar charges and familiar ground. Only when the moderator, Gabe Pressman, led the conversation into specific questions about what each of the four candidates would do with money generated by a cut in military spending did any new focus or information emerge. Most of the rest of the hour was spent on familiar spats that were repeated in quick succession in the too-familiar advertisements that ran, back to back, at the debate's close.
Still, television sometimes does offer moments that street politics could never match.
Yesterday's twist came in a new and unsettling experience of the perhaps diminishing distance between reality and perception. For several mind-twisting moments, Ms. Ferraro seemed to appear live on WCBS and live on WNBC's political debate. For her Channel 2 appearance, which was actually pre-recorded, the candidate wore beige. On Channel 4, she wore salmon.

HEADLINE: Istanbul Journal;
The Sephardim Give Thanks for 500 Good Years

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 8

 BODY:
For years it was the wisdom among Istanbul's Sephardic Jews that their status as a small minority in a largely Muslim land dictated low profiles and unobtrusive living.
This year, as the Jews here observe the 500th anniversary of their forebears' expulsion from Spain in 1492, the reticence is gone. 
 With visits by American and other Jewish groups, exhibits abroad, a journey here by the President Chaim Herzog of Israel, even the issue of a commemorative postage stamp, the 26,000-member community has embarked on a celebration not only of its own history and identity but also of what many say is the tolerance and harmony inspired across centuries by Muslim Turkish leaders.
To mark the occasion, Istanbul's Jews are restoring one of the city's oldest active synagogues, the 15th-century Ahrida synagogue, which predates the Ottoman capture of the city from the Byzantines in 1453.
 
Synagogue Attack a Factor
 The new self-confidence reflects Turkey's own emergence into a bustling free-market economy in which Jews are less fearful of seeming to be a wealthy elite.
But some Jews also say that the higher profile paradoxically dates from the terrorist attack at the Neve Shalom synagogue in 1986, in which 22 Jewish worshipers were killed. The assault thrust Turkish Jews to the center of international attention.
"A very positive effect was to make us known as a Jewish community," said Nedim Yahya, a leading organizer of the 500th-anniversary celebration. That, maybe, was not what everybody wanted.
This year's celebration, said Avi Alkas, a Jewish businessman, "was a radical move within the community because normally in the past our older generation was not that eager for publicity." By contrast, he said, the exposure to American and European Jews this year has left Istanbul's Jews "feeling more a part of international world Jewry, a feeling of belonging to a bigger family."
Leyla Alaton, the public relations director of a large industrial holding company run by her father, Ishak Alaton, said, "This became like a thank-you message, just to show how thankful we are living so well in Turkey." She added that the frequent visits here by American Jewish organizations had won important new friends in Washington for Turkey, a longstanding Western ally.
Beyond the widely publicized celebrations, though, some Turkish Jews detect changes that in recent years have transformed -- and possibly weakened -- their community.
As Istanbul has spread from its old core athwart the Golden Horn, so have its Jewish residents abandoned areas where they once formed close-knit communities. Now they are dispersed in the sprawl of a city whose residents number some 10 million, or one-sixth of Turkey's fast-growing population.
Since the beginning of this century, the Jewish population in Turkey has fallen from around 120,000 and, some say, it is still slowly declining because the number of deaths is marginally higher than the number of births. Before Israel's creation, the community numbered around 80,000, but many went as immigrants to the new nation. Synagogue attendance is said to dwindling, too.
 
Few Now Speak Ladino
 Moreover, few young Jews these days speak the Judeo-Spanish language called Ladino, which was once dominant among Istanbul's Sephardim. Such is the absence of religious fervor that the city's only yeshiva closed years ago. "There was no single student at that school, not a single one," Mr. Yahya said. "Now, to teach rabbis, we have to send them to Israel or the United States."
Of the decline in the use of Ladino, Mr. Yahya said: "We have never had a schooling in Judeo-Spanish. It was a language that was orally transmitted." The Jewish schools in Istanbul, he said, use Turkish as their language of instruction, "with a couple of hours a week of Hebrew."
"I can still manage with Ladino," said Mr. Alkas, who is 35 years old and part of the younger generation of Istanbul Jews, "but unfortunately not my two sons. I am one of the few of my age that speaks Ladino."
In addition, he said, he had given his sons non-Jewish names -- Emir and Alp -- "to reduce the feeling of being separate and different" that he had experienced while serving Turkey's compulsory military conscription.
The acknowledgment of such sentiment was one of very few in conversations with Jews here, most of whom emphasized the absence of discrimination and anti-Semitism in Turkey.
 
A Comparison Rejected
 Mr. Yahya, for instance, took issue with comparisons between Turkish Jews and oppressed Jews in Arab countries, recalling that non-Arab Turkey had been one of the first countries to recognize Israel in 1948 and emphasizing the Western-oriented secularism of Kemal Ataturk, who founded the modern Turkish republic in 1923. "There has never been anti-Semitism in Turkey," he said. "But, as everywhere, there have been anti-Semites."
That label has been attached most frequently over the last few months to Adnan Hoca, leader of a secretive Muslim sect whose newspaper, Son Mesaji, or The Last Message, routinely tilts at what it depicts as an international Zionist conspiracy headed by Freemasons and Jews.
"But you can't take it seriously," Mr. Yahya said of the newspaper. "In one issue it said the Masons' subcommittees in the conspiracy were three: Rotary Club, Lion's Club -- and Diners Club."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers restoring the 15th-century Ahrida synagogue last week in Istanbul, Turkey, as part of the observance of the 500th anniversary of their Jewish forebears' expulsion from Spain. The normally reticent Jewish community cites the country's lack of anti-Semitism as one reason for celebration. (Reuters for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Rebuilding of South Florida Aids Mobile-Home Orders

BYLINE: By JONATHAN HICKS

 BODY:
As residents of southern Florida look to replace, quickly and relatively inexpensively, homes destroyed by Hurricane Andrew, a boom appears to be beginning in the mobile-home industry.
Makers of mobile homes -- including larger ones that are not truly mobile, since they are fabricated in two or three pieces and assembled on the site -- say their plants are running at capacity. They are working to fill orders not only from mobile-home parks that have been devastated by the disaster, but also from distributors that want to keep their supply intact in anticipation of shortages.
 
One Maker's Orders Rise 75%
 At Fleetwood Enterprises, the nation's largest maker of mobile homes, orders in the last few weeks have risen nearly 75 percent, compared with the period in 1991. 
 "We have found that demand has increased because of people who actually want homes and from distributors who don't want to be caught out there without supplies," said Jon A. Nord, senior vice president of the housing group of Fleetwood, which is based in Riverside, Calif.
That demand for mobile homes, also called manufactured homes, has already started affecting prices, industry officials say.
"We have already seen one memo," from a maker, "saying that a small increase, about $250 per unit, will go into effect," said Daniel L. Vaughn, a sales consultant at the Hamptons Golf and Country Club, a retirement community of manufactured homes in Lakeland, Fla., about 40 miles west of Orlando.
Mr. Vaughn added that his company and other buyers of manufactured homes anticipated that the price would increase at least $500 to $600 a unit because of the tightening supply of many materials that go into the homes. Manufactured homes generally sell for $18,000 to $80,000.
And the makers of manufactured homes say they have already seen tighter supplies of several items, including plywood, roofing materials and certain lumber products.
 
 
New Concerns About Safety
 The large number of mobile homes in Florida and their vulnerability to natural disasters has many public officials worried about the safety issue, and those concerns could have a profound effect on the industry.
The Dade County Board of Rules and Appeals recently adopted a recommendation that sets the same standards for mobile homes as those for traditionally built homes. That recommendation calls for manufactured homes to withstand winds of up to 120 miles an hour.
"I have great concerns about the safety of mobile homes," said Bertram S. Warshaw, chairman of the board, which oversees building codes in Dade County. "They are not structurally capable of withstanding high winds."
Mr. Warshaw added, "We simply want mobile homes to be required to meet the same performance standards as permanent residences."
Jack Kemp, Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, has ordered a full-scale review of the Government's manufactured housing code to insure that it provides adequate protection to residents of mobile homes in hurricanes.
Bruce A. Savage, a spokesman for the Manufactured Housing Institute, an industry trade group in Arlington, Va., said that builders were "committed to building and properly installing homes that are safe, durable and affordable for homeowners."
He added that builders of mobile homes conformed to standards mandated by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. "So if there is a question about manufactured homes, it's not whether they are built to the code, but whether the code is adequate," he said. "We'll build to whatever code they establish."
 
 
Sites Need to Be Cleared
 The convoys of trucks carrying mobile homes to communities in Florida like Homestead have not yet formed. There is still a need to demolish and remove the rubble left by the storm. Moreover, there are more immediate needs in the affected communities, like restoring electricity, sanitation service and water.
Nonetheless, manufacturers of the homes are stepping up production, and retailers and operators of mobile-home parks are increasing their purchases, because mobile homes offer a quick and relatively inexpensive method of providing housing for the tens of thousands of people whose homes were destroyed.
"Before the hurricane, we saw the demand for mobile homes as being sluggish," said Rollin E. Priest, chief executive of Ronlee Mobile Home Centers Inc., an Orlando-based retailer of mobile homes and operator of mobile-home parks. "But now the tempo has picked up."
Mr. Priest added that it would probably be one and a half to two years before damaged homes could be rebuilt in the areas affected by the hurricane, while mobile homes could be set up in weeks.
"You have 50,000 housing units that have to be replaced, and that's not going to happen overnight," he said.
 The Florida Manufactured Housing Association, a state trade association, estimated in a survey that 85,000 traditionally constructed houses and about 10,000 manufactured homes had been destroyed or damaged by the hurricane. Already the Federal Government has requested about 1,000 manufactured homes from storage areas in the South to be sent to areas in Florida affected by the hurricane. And manufacturers like Redman Homes Inc., the Skyline Corporation and Clayton Homes Inc. have begun to gear up for the demand.
The mobile home industry has already had a fairly robust year. The Manufactured Housing Institute said that in the first seven months of the year, production of mobile homes rose to 114,184 units, a jump of 17 percent from the 97,519 produced in the comparable period last year.
Officials of the trade group contend that the recession has made manufactured homes more attractive to home buyers because they generally cost 30 to 50 percent less than homes built by traditional methods.
 
 
Popular in Florida
 Manufactured homes are an important segment of the housing stock in Florida. They accounted for more than 750,000 of the state's 6.1 million housing units, according to the 1990 census, about 12 percent of all homes in Florida. That compares with a national average of about 7 percent.
Mobile home producers typically fill orders with production from plants closest to where the units are needed. "We have already had substantial backlogs in our plant in Florida," said Bill J. Thoma, manager of marketing with Redman Homes, the Dallas company that is the nation's second-largest producer of mobile homes. "Our question is how we can meet some of the extra need that the public will have in an efficient manner."

HEADLINE: Free Trade Batters Mexico's Stocks

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 13

 BODY:
After months in which investors in Mexican equities waited hopefully for a North American Free Trade Agreement, the announcement of an accord has brought only tougher times to the beleaguered Mexico City stock market.
With Mexican domestic interest rates rising and expectations for the economy's growth falling, the exchange fell 7.1 percent, or nearly 100 points, last week to its lowest level since September of last year. It was the second-worst week of the year for the market -- the Bolsa de Valores -- and the fifth straight to register a decline. Since June, values on the Bolsa have fallen 32 percent. 
 Stock analysts in Mexico City and New York tied the problems in part to the trade pact that Mexico, Canada and the United States announced on Aug. 12.
 
Government Criticized
 Increasingly, analysts criticize the Mexican Government for having oversold the agreement by suggesting it would bring a relatively quick economic impact and by playing down the difficulties involved in its ratification in the United States and Canada.
As those difficulties grew more obvious last week, interest rates on long-term Mexican Treasury certificates jumped above 19 percent, their highest level of the year.
But beyond luring foreign investors into the money market, the rise in interest rates also added to the investors' broader concerns about the Mexican economy's prospects for growth, several analysts said.
"The market has really lost its compass in the short term," said Alexander C. Anderson, director of research for the Mexico City brokerage ABACO Casa de Bolsa S.A. "And many people are talking now about sluggish growth next year as well."
The Bolsa began to slip on Tuesday, as United States trade officials made their first effort to defend the trade agreement before angry legislators in Congress. But then things got worse.
At the weekly Mexican Treasury auction the next day, interest rates on 91-day Government certificates jumped to 19 percent. In Washington, the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, leveled the Democrats' most serious attack on the trade agreement yet, saying that it would badly hurt American workers and the environment and that it should be renegotiated. The market here fell 43.89 points, or 3.2 percent.
With equity investors continuing to sell on Thursday in response to the Treasury auction, United States Labor Secretary Lynn Martin's acknowledgment that the trade pact could cost as many as 150,000 American jobs helped send the Bolsa down again, stock analysts said. Values on the market fell 3.03 percent more.
The market scratched back up 8.32 points, or 0.65 percent, on Friday to close at 1,294.09. But for the week it fell 98.55 points.
 
Silver Lining Tarnished
 In contrast to their initial response to the even sharper drop in Mexican equity values in June, brokers proffered relatively little optimistic commentary about a silver lining of good long-term values.
As of this week, average prices were down to about 10.5 times last year's earnings; some companies' stock values were below 8 times their projected 1992 earnings, brokers said. Earlier in the year, the valuations for some Mexican stocks reached as high as 18 times their projected 1992 earnings.
"In the long term, it does look very good," Mr. Anderson said. But like others, he suggested some difficulty in seeing that far into the future.
The authorities reported last week that the consumer price index rose only six-tenths of 1 percent in August, bringing inflation to 7.7 percent for the year. That was the lowest eight-month rise in prices since 1972.
But even from a rate of 18.8 percent last year, inflation is not dropping as quickly as many economic officials and investors would like. And while several economists and analysts said they doubted that the Government would reach its goal of keeping inflation in single digits this year, some predicted that its efforts would push economic growth well below 3 percent both this year and next.
Late last year the Government predicted that the economy would grow 4 percent in 1992; in June it offered an estimate of 3 to 3.5 percent.
After the announcement of a six-month budget surplus that surpassed even the Finance Ministry's year-end goals, the rising interest rates suggest that the Government will continue to slow down the economy in response to its growing current-account deficit, a decline in capital inflows and the effects on Mexico of the recession in the United States, economists said.
Although the policy has raised fears of an eventual devaluation, economists and stock analysts saw as unlikely anything more than a widening of the range within which the exchange rate could fluctuate.
"There is very little money leaving Mexico," said Jacques Levy, executive vice president of the brokerage Banamex/Accival. "It is just shifting from one place to another."
Referring to the benchmark London interbank offered rate, he added, "There are very few investors who can resist interest rates of something like Libor times three."

HEADLINE: BAY SHORE JOURNAL;
It Rained Pennies For Stores

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

DATELINE: BAY SHORE, N.J.

 BODY:
Normally in these days after the big Labor Day weekend, the back room of Melissa Serafin's gift shop here would still be half-full of seashells, mermaid thermometers and other flotsam of the seaside commercial season. But to hear her tell it, the tourists who braved this summer's rainy days and blustery weekends spent the day combing the shops instead of the sodden beach.
"We had one of the best years ever," she said. "I'm empty." 
 While tourist-beckoning resorts like this one counted more motel cancellations and shorter visits than in even last year's recession-battered season, many merchants like Ms. Serafin seemed to be glad for the weather. Too much sun, they said, only brings business to the life-guards, and a downpour ruins everyone's day. But a nice overcast sky, perhaps a bearable mist, even a drizzle, will send the tourists looking for someplace to go besides the beach.
"Our visitors were really in good spirits," said Ms. Serafin, who manages Nautilus Gifts in the Bay Village shopping arcade. "Obviously they were disappointed with the weather. But they were like, we're here, we're committed, we might as well have a good time."
This far down Long Beach Island, beyond the widening ring of commuter suburbs between New York City and Philadelphia, shopkeepers stay open only during the warm months, and they depend on the summer shore season the way farmers depend on a single planting. Three-quarters of most shopkeepers' annual income comes from the months between Memorial Day and Labor Day weekends. For some, those days provide the only income of the year.
That is why Lew and Anna Richards approached their first season as the owners of the Crust and Crumb Bakery with such apprehension. The Richardses bought a bakery last spring. They found themselves in debt and working 16-hour days.
But as soon as their doughnuts and crullers and elephant ears (a New Jersey cookie staple) were laid out under the glass counter, the Crust and Crumb was jammed with customers, Mrs. Richards said.
"We never expected to do so well our first year," she added while taking a break from the flour and the sugar and the butter and the eggs. "People came down, and I guess they just shopped themselves out. Now we've recovered some financially, we'll stay open through the Chowder Festival and then sit back for the winter and consider ourselves lucky."
The worst effects of the poor weather appeared to be on the motels, which reported far more cancellations than normal, said Jeanne DiPaola, executive director of the Southern Ocean County Chamber of Commerce. She said many merchants had hoped the summer of '92 would start a recovery from a slide in business since the mid-1980's.
Ms. DiPaola also reported the resumption of a trend toward shorter stays that had leveled off recently.
"It's the contracting summer vacation," she said. "It has been going on, but it had stabilized lately in a three-or four-night stay, but this year we saw far more requests for one or two nights only."
She did not blame the weather. "Those I spoke to said it was a 'can't afford' kind of thing," she said.
But the backbone of Long Beach Island's summer business is the vacationers who own or rent for a week or more thousands of cottages. Committed by ownership or lease to vacationing by the sea, it was the cottage residents who made the season a good one, Mrs. Richards said.
If there was a complaint from shopkeepers, it was that the visitors opted for less-expensive purchases, said Kelly Coleman, manager of Breezin' Up, a mid-priced beach-wear outlet. Her business was "about the same" as last year, she said, for items that typically started at $15.
At Ms. Sarafina's nearly-sold-out gift shop, most items cost about $3.
"It seemed like people were really conserving their money," Ms. Coleman said. "If you have to buy something, it's easier to buy something to eat than a $15 T-shirt. They'd tell their kids, "No you can't have the shirt, but we'll get some cotton candy.' Kind of a bribe."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Issues: The Environment;
In Timber Country, Bush Will Join Logging War

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Four years ago, George Bush used a campaign swing through the Pacific Northwest to compare himself to Theodore Roosevelt and to highlight his promise to be "the environmental President." On Monday, as the President's schedule calls for him to visit logging communities in Oregon and Washington, Mr. Bush is expected to forget about tree-hugging and embrace the ax instead.
Bypassing the major cities, Mr. Bush will speak to timber workers in depressed rural areas where there has been a virtual civil war over the forests. Aides and supporters say he will speak out against "environmental extremists" and play up his plan to save timber jobs. 
 In advance of the visit, the President has already delivered a gift to the loggers: on Thursday, he ordered Federal agencies to speed up logging of dead timber, bypassing the usual restrictions and appeals from citizens.
But while the attempt to woo voters who are wary of environmental excess could play well in some places, Mr. Bush is in such deep trouble on the West Coast that there may be very little he can do to win here, political analysts from both parties say.
 
Toppling Timberland Myths
 Polls in Washington, Oregon and California -- together, the three states have 25 percent of the electoral votes needed to win -- show the President trailing Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas by 13 to 22 points. Washington and Oregon were the only states in the West to vote against Mr. Bush in 1988, and California went Republican by the narrowest of margins.
Even timber workers, who would seem to be at odds with Mr. Clinton for the environmental leanings of his running mate, Senator Al Gore, instead are angry at Mr. Bush. In his book, "Earth in the Balance," Mr. Gore lamented the cutting of ancient forests in the Northwest and called for protection of more land. The Administration has advocated amending the Endangered Species Act, which has been used to curtail logging to protect the spotted owl.
"George Bush has done absolutely nothing for our workers," said Bill Hubbell, president of the International Woodworkers of America, based in Oregon. "We've had reams of rhetoric from the Administration, but they have never tried to take the bull by the horns."
In a pre-emptive strike, Mr. Clinton last week won the support of the major unions representing 125,000 timber workers by promising to tackle the stalemate between loggers and environmentalists. "This crisis represents yet another example of a White House long on the politics of blame and short on leadership," Mr. Clinton said in a letter to the timber unions.
Mr. Clinton also is planning to be in Oregon on Monday, speaking in Portland and then visiting an out-of-work timber family in Springfield.
The major problem for the President, union leaders said, is that the timber crisis happened on his watch. In the last decade, thousands of timber workers lost their jobs because of the recession, foreign competition and automation. In the last four years, environmental restrictions on Federal forests have hastened the decline. While the Bush Administration has had Cabinet-level committees studying the issue, most logging on Federal lands in the Northwest has been halted because of lawsuits.
The judge who has been most responsible for shutting down logging to protect the spotted owl -- Judge William L. Dwyer of United States District Court in Seattle -- was an appointee of President Reagan. In a ruling last year that blocked Forest Service plans to resume its tree-cutting policy in the Northwest, Judge Dwyer wrote that the Administration had shown a "deliberate and systematic refusal" to follow Federal laws on fish and wildlife.
"Clinton's great advantage here is that all the disarray, inaction and confusion -- they've been like Larry, Moe and Curly -- has come from the Federal agencies run by George Bush," said Representative Les AuCoin, a Democrat trying to unseat Senator Bob Packwood, a Republican.
 
Owls vs. People
 But there may also be an opening for the President to play on fears that environmental restrictions will soon affect the cities as well as rural areas, his supporters say. The majority of votes are not in the dying timber towns, but in Seattle, Portland, San Francisco and Los Angeles. While the core of environmental support is in the cities, there has been some erosion because of the poor economy, particularly in California. Efforts to save endangered runs of Pacific salmon, for example, could lead to rate increases for water users in the major cities.
"Voters don't want to choose between the owl and people, but if they have to, they will choose people," said Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, the principal architect of Republican strategy in the West to paint Democrats as environmental extremists. On Mr. Gorton's advice, President Bush plans to visit a mill town outside Spokane and one in southern Oregon during his visit on Monday.
Craig Berkman, chairman of the Oregon Republican Party, said recent polling suggested that jobs outweigh the environment as a concern among West Coast voters.
"There is a changing dynamic at work: more and more people are looking at these environmental excesses and saying that something is wrong," said Mr. Berkman.
But voters, even in the heaviest timber counties of Oregon, have been sending a somewhat different message. In Jackson County, Oregon, which President Bush plans to visit on Monday, Harry Lonsdale, a maverick Democrat who rails against clear cutting and excessive logging, beat Senator Mark O. Hatfield, the longtime Republican incumbent, last year . This, despite Mr. Hatfield's endorsement from the timber unions.
Political analysts attribute the shift to newcomers, primarily from California, who view the timber industry as a despoiler of the scenery.
"We all know the forests are disappearing and we all know many loggers are going to lose their jobs," said Tim Hermach, head of the Native Forest Council, an Oregon environmental group. "What people really want is someone to respect them, someone who won't lie to them about the future."
