HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
In a Heated Senate Campaign, More Questions Than Answers

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
NEW YORK may still be the only state where being branded a moderate is a political smear. That was merely one of the negatives hurled in this year's Democratic campaign for the United States Senate.
But didn't Bill Clinton's victory herald an ideological shift? 
 In the state's Presidential primary last April, Mr. Clinton handily defeated Edmund G. Brown Jr., who was generally viewed as more liberal. Still, Mr. Clinton got fewer votes than the combined total for Mr. Brown and for Paul E. Tsongas, who drew some liberal Democrats, too. And a number of liberals said their embrace of Mr. Clinton reflected less a philosphical shift than an equally seismic admission that if winning isn't everything, then ideological perfection isn't the only thing.
Voter surveys found that Mr. Clinton did best among Democrats who identified themselves as moderates, but that they were still outnumbered statewide by self-described liberals.
A victory tomorrow by Geraldine A. Ferraro in the Democratic primary for the Senate would not necessarily signal the decline of liberalism either. Her endorsement of the death penalty for the most egregious crimes is the major philosophical fault that separates the four candidates in a largely nonideological campaign. Also, she faces divided opposition from three rivals who consider themselves more liberal than she is. Chances are their combined vote will be higher than hers, no matter who wins.
But if liberals begrudgingly embraced Mr. Clinton as most electable, Ms. Ferraro, her rivals insist, is in just the opposite position: lingering questions about her family's financial affairs might neutralize ethics as a weapon against the Republican incumbent, Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Some politicians suggest, though, that erasing one E-word from the Senate campaign might actually focus attention more clearly on the other: the economy. Unemployment may be the best weapon against an incumbent whose fellow Republicans have run the White House for 12 years.
This is supposed to be the Year of the Woman. Also, the Year of the Challenger. Which is why Mr. D'Amato describes himself as "makin' waves." None of his four potential opponents better exemplifies change than the Rev. Al Sharpton, the poor man's Ross Perot, except that credibility and consistency count, too.
Does character count?
Sure, but for how much? So far, Mr. Clinton has managed to survive bruising personal criticism and innuendo with remarkable resiliency. So had Ms. Ferraro. When she began her campaign, her comeback was widely discounted. Many politicians predicted that she would be unable to transform the celebrity of her historic 1984 campaign for Vice President into electoral support in 1990 after being pelted repeatedly with questions about her family's financial affairs. Tomorrow, New York voters will decide what becomes a legend most.
Did negative campaigning work?
Yes, but for whom? Ms. Ferraro acknowledged that negative advertising by two of her opponents, State Attorney General Robert Abrams and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, had found its target. As a result, last week she relented and made public tax returns that she had resisted releasing, after arguing, as Mr. Clinton has regarding his draft status, that each disclosure would only encourage demands for more.
Mr. Abrams, ahead of Ms. Holtzman in the polls, seemed more inclined to be her second in the verbal jousting with Ms. Ferraro. Ms. Holtzman's role better suited her volatile mix of brains and political brawn, but even in the Year of the Woman, will New Yorkers heed Mr. Sharpton's advice to vote for the one they want -- not who they think can win the primary?
Even Mayor David N. Dinkins complained that the campaign had got too negative. He is an Abrams supporter, but, having confronted similar questions himself, was sensitive to the political damage they could inflict and to the fairness they could violate.
Did Ms. Ferraro respond effectively?
The concealment of her early tax returns, as it turned out, seemed more incriminating than the returns themselves, which makes you wonder why, instead of crying foul, she didn't disclose them earlier.
Also, it is arguable whether even the relatively few Italian-Americans who vote in a Democratic primary will share her professions of shock that she, unlike her rivals, was being subjected to questions about whether any of her husband's business associates had any links to organized crime -- particularly when one of his prominent tenants did.
During last week's debate, she sparred more effectively as a prosecutor than as a politician. She all but shouted, "Gotcha!" when, in marshaling evidence against her, a slightly flustered Mr. Abrams forgot a date and Ms. Holtzman couldn't immediately recall whether anyone had been arrested when the authorities raided a warehouse that a Ferraro family company had leased to a pornographer with ties to organized crime.
Yesterday's debate left the Family of New York looking like the Bickersons. Three follow-up questions were left to the voters: Are the date or the arrest really material to the original charges? Are the charges relevant to the Senate race? Are Ms. Ferraro's responses more revealing than the charges themselves?

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press Notes;
Post Owner Still Hopes to Buy Daily News

BYLINE: By Alex S. Jones

 BODY:
PETER S. KALIKOW, the owner of The New York Post, still considers himself a very serious prospective buyer for the bankrupt Daily News, even though he is in bankruptcy himself.
Mr. Kalikow, a New York real estate developer, said late last week that he fully expected the paper's unions and creditors to come to him eventually. "They know I'm ready to buy it," he said. 
 Last week, rumors flew that Mr. Kalikow was in new difficulty when it became known that the Bankers Trust Company, one of his principal bankers, was seeking a newspaper executive capable of managing a Post-News combination. The initial assumption was that Mr. Kalikow, who is publisher of The Post, would be removed.
But Mr. Kalikow said that this assumption was wrong and that Bankers Trust was seeking such an executive because he was close to refinancing his debts.
For months, Mr. Kalikow has been saying he has been working on an agreement in which Bankers Trust, Chase Manhattan and an unidentified investor would acquire about half his real estate business and, at the same time, deliver him from bankruptcy.
He said part of the deal was that the banks would provide financing to buy The News.
Mr. Kalikow's latest comments follow the decision of Conrad M. Black, who controls The Daily Telegraph in London, to drop out of the negotiations to buy The News.
Late last week, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, a real estate developer and owner of U.S. News & World Report, won the support of most unions at The News in his effort to buy the paper.
Mr. Kalikow said Bankers Trust was looking a replacement for his former top lieutenant, Richard Nasti, who left The Post earlier this year after a scandal in which false circulation claims were made.
Neither Bankers Trust nor Chase Manhattan volunteered information on the situation.
Michael M. Connery, a lawyer advising the newspaper unions in the effort to find a buyer for The News, said Mr. Kalikow was not involved in the process in any serious way.
A reinvigorated News would be a formidable threat to The Post, and The Post's best chance for long-term survival is probably to buy The News.
Mr. Kalikow said he would also consider offers to sell The Post, but Mr. Zuckerman has thus far expressed no interest in buying it.
 
Labor's Outcast
 In a related matter, while 9 of The News's 10 unions have thus far stuck together in one-for-all solidarity in the sale of the paper, the 10th -- Local Six of the former International Typographical Union -- is very much an outcast.
"We are being excluded from the process," complained James Grottola, president of the union, which is now part of the Communications Workers of America, at a bankruptcy hearing on Friday.
Indeed, prospective buyers seem to have concluded that they can save most or all of the $9.5 million in annual wages that go to the 167-member printers' union to satisfy lifetime job guarantees negotiated in 1974.
And the other unions not only do not care, but some union leaders say on condition of anonymity that they think their former I.T.U. brothers will only be getting what they deserve.
Two years ago, the I.T.U. did not support the other unions in striking The News when it was owned by the Tribune Company. The I.T.U. was fearful that striking might jeopardize the lifetime job guarantees.
The bitterness of that break with the other unions has remained.
Mr. Grottola said that language in the 1974 agreement stipulates that successor buyers of The News must honor the job guarantees. But in an asset sale, in which parts of a company but not its stock are sold, a buyer can reject existing contracts, which is apparently what prospective buyers plan to do.
Mr. Grottola said no prospective buyers had sought to negotiate with the printers' union in any meaningful way. The union has filed a grievance procedure and sought arbitration.
 
Thawing Out Foreign Affairs
 With the end of the cold war, that forum of the cold war -- Foreign Affairs -- is rethinking its mission as its 70th anniversary approaches.
"We realize that a significant part of our 110,000 buyers skim, read a little here and there and leave it on the coffee table," said James F. Hoge Jr., who took over as editor of Foreign Affairs last month.
The magazine, which appears five times each year, is engaged in an ambitious circulation-building campaign, including mailed offers that arrive in envelopes demanding in bold black type, "Should you be reading 'the most influential periodical in print' ?"
What the promotion does not say is that the quote comes from a 1962 issue of Time magazine, at the pinnacle of the cold war. Time actually described Foreign Affairs as "one of the most influential periodicals in print," but it also said it was "the most prestigious journal of its kind in the world."
Certainly, Foreign Affairs, which is published by the Council on Foreign Relations in New York, has had some very important moments.
Perhaps its greatest coup came in 1947 when George F. Kennan, in an article signed by the pseudonym X, described what became the policy of containment of the Soviet Union. The article created a sensation, though Mr. Kennan, then a member of the State Department's policy planning staff, refused to confirm he was the author for years.
But with the end of the cold war, Foreign Affairs began to reconsider its approach.
Mr. Hoge said the new Foreign Affairs would become more focused on economics and environmental issues and have shorter articles. Even such aids to readers as subheadings and graphics are being considered, though Mr. Hoge said such radical changes would not be introduced right away.

HEADLINE: Peter G. Treves, 77, Financier, Broker And Writer on Italy

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Peter G. Treves, who fled his native Italy in the 1930's to escape Fascism and became a financier, economist, publisher and author in America, died on Friday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Phoenix, where he was attending a business conference.
He was 77 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla. He died of a heart attack, his family said. 
 Mr. Treves was born in Turin, Italy, to a family prominent in financial and Jewish circles. He escaped Fascism at the onset of war, going to London as a post-graduate student and then to New York to work on Wall Street.
During World War II he worked for the Federal Board of Economic Warfare as a senior analyst, assessing Italy's economy as ill-equipped to fight a lengthy war. In the occupation, he went to Rome to advise authorities on reconstruction and relief.
Returning to New York, he worked for brokerage houses and then formed his own firm and bought a seat on the New York Stock Exchange.
Among his ventures, Mr. Treves was a leader in proxy battles for the control of Twentieth Century Fox and Curtis Publishing. He also financed work that won the patent for the first scanner to identify dollar bills for vending machines.
For 42 years he published newsletters on Italy's economy and its tourism. He also ran a magazine on Italian trade for the American Chamber of Commerce for Trade and he published books on opera. He wrote for Italian newspapers in the United States and Italy and also ran a business distributing hundreds of foreign periodicals in the United States.
Mr. Treves led fund-raising to help Florence after a flood, organized the American Committee on the Centennial for the Unity of Italy and was treasurer of the Italy-America Society.
Surviving are his wife of 51 years, the former Renata Colombo; a son, Charles, and a daughter, Vivian, both of Manhattan; a brother, Gino of Princeton, N.J., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Builders of Houses Fall From Favor

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
MORTGAGE rates are plummeting, which ought to be good news for home builders. But Wall Street is again turning a cold shoulder to the industry, fearing that consumers' lack of confidence will stem the tide of buying.
An index of home-builder stocks has fallen 15 percent since its recent high in early August, and the spurt in prices that followed the last cut in the discount rate by the Federal Reserve Board has evaporated. 
 That Americans are reluctant to buy homes, despite the low interest rates, is shown by statistics maintained by the Mortgage Bankers Association. It reported last week that applications for new mortgages -- not for refinancings -- were down 14 percent from July 24, when the stocks crested on the wave of the enthusiasm generated by the last discount rate cut, which the Fed made on July 2.
"Mortgage rates are the lowest they have been in 20 years," said Ed Yardeni, the chief economist of C. J. Lawrence. "That's the good news. The bad news is that job insecurity, if we could measure it, might be at its highest level since the 1930's."
Moreover, while fixed-rate mortgages now are below 8 percent in many areas, and at 7.5 percent or even lower in some, that rate may not seem as attractive as it once would have, said Gregory A. Nejmeh, who analyzes the home-building industry for Lehman Brothers. House prices, he noted, "are not rising at nearly that pace." Slow price growth has brought about a change of perception on the likelihood of profit from trading up in the housing market.
Hoping to profit is not, of course, the only reason to buy a house. It is primarily a consumption expenditure, and that remains the case. But for many homeowners, the only way to move up to a bigger and better house is to use appreciated equity in the old house. There is a lot less of that around these days.
Whatever the reason, it is clear that Wall Street's on-again, off-again love affair with the home-builder stocks is waning, although hatred toward the group is nothing like it was back in the fall of 1990. A buyer of home stocks at the lows that autumn would have more than tripled his money by the time the stocks peaked in February of this year, amid widespread expectations that the economy was soon to revive. During the same period, the Standard & Poor's 500 index was up just 35 percent.
But after that, the home-builder stocks began to slide, on spreading suspicion that this recovery was not going to be a normal one. The index fell sharply in early spring, regained some of its losses after the Fed acted in July, but then slipped back.
Since the February peak, the index, which includes 11 builders, is down 28 percent while the S.& P. 500 is up 2 percent.
The most controversial home-building stock now is the Lennar Corporation, which has the distinction of being the largest home builder in Dade County in Florida. Unlike the situation in most of America, in Lennar's primary market there will be plenty of demand for houses in coming months, and that fact initially sent the company's stock up in the wake of Hurricane Andrew.
But then word spread that angry owners of homes previously built by Lennar were suing, claiming that more homes would have survived had they been built right. Lennar is now down 24 percent from its post-hurricane peak. It closed Friday at $23.50, down 50 cents. Mr. Nejmeh is a firm bull. "There is an element of earnings visibility that does not exist for other companies," he said.
Other home builders have more prosaic problems. Some of the worst recent performers have been those with big stakes in California, a state where nothing seems to be going right. The Standard-Pacific Corporation, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., has fallen 30 percent since industry prices last peaked, on Aug. 6. Kaufman & Broad Home of Los Angeles is off 26 percent.
It is, of course, unlikely that Americans will stop wanting to move into newer and better homes. But the question confronting Wall Street is when that desire will be converted into action. At the moment, investors are far from confident that the action will come very soon.

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy For Gaylord

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The Gaylord Container Corporation has filed a prepackaged Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition after failing to get a minimum number of bondholders to approve an offer to exchange its debt for new securities.
Gaylord, which has at least $741.7 million in debt, including $496.7 million in junk bonds, needed approval from 95 percent of its bondholders for the package to pass, but only 89 percent of the subordinated debt was tendered, the company said on Saturday. 
 "Clearly, holders of the subordinated debt opted for the prepackaged- plan alternative that binds the bondholders and, therefore, treats all holders equally," said Marvin Pomerantz, chairman and chief executive. The company filed the plan in the United States Bankruptcy Court here.
The company, formed in the 1980's through a series of acquisitions, is being hurt by low prices for its products, high raw material costs and the recession.
Under the terms of the prepackaged plan, Gaylord's bondholders will exchange their subordinated debt for about $378 million in new senior subordinated securities, six million shares of Gaylord class A common stock and 31.8 million redeemable exchangeable warrants to obtain another 31.8 million shares of class A common stock.
The terms of the exchange are the same under the bankruptcy plan as under the exchange offer, which expired on Friday, the company said.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
The Adventures of Geraldo Rivera

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Geraldo Provoked! Geraldo  Strikes Back! Geraldo on Top! Geraldo Busted! Geraldo Booked! Geraldo Bailed Out! Geraldo Cleared! Geraldo Tells All!
If you haven't heard enough of Geraldo Rivera's latest accomplishment, don't despair. Details are available today on the premiere of another season of "Geraldo," the talk show that makes other talk shows seem sensible. The ostensible subject is a gathering of a ragtag bunch of Nazis, Ku Kluxers and skinheads a few weeks ago in Janesville, Wis., where Mr. Rivera was prodded in camera range by a neo-Nazi named John R. McLaughlin, and retaliated. 
 The real subject is Mr. Rivera. He proclaims the meeting a portentous occasion and bustles about interviewing an imperial wizard and some allies ("Neat outfits you have on.") and anti-Klan demonstrators ("Does it outrage you? Does it frighten you?"). The show ends with a cross-burning, behind Mr. Rivera.
The hour has its amusing moments. For example, a Klan historian reports that Abraham Lincoln freed the Jews. But the biggest joke is delivered deadpan by Mr. Rivera. After telling how sweat and blood dripped down his face, he informs the camera: "A professional nightmare had come true. I had become part of the story." One's heart goes out.
Never mind. Think of it as a late-night movie: "The Bully From Beyond Meets Narcissus."
 
'Power, Politics and Latinos' 
PBS, tomorrow at 9 P.M.
(Channel 13 in New York)
Geraldo Rivera does not figure in "Power, Politics and Latinos," which is one of the better things to be said about this earnest and elementary documentary. There are assuredly significant political implications in the fact that Hispanic Americans are fast becoming America's biggest minority, but instead of grappling with them, "Power, Politics and Latinos," co-produced by the National Latino Communications Center, devotes most of its hour to a routine account of a Democratic Party primary fight for a Los Angeles Congressional seat in June, in which a Latino beat out a Latina. You can see volunteers going door to door.
Interesting questions are raised: how do recent immigrants from countries like El Salvador, Nicaragua and the Dominican Republic differ from older generations of Americans from Mexico and Puerto Rico? What is happening to the newcomers' relations with the black minority into whose neighborhoods they are moving? How will the Hispanic combination of Roman Catholic conservatism and economic need play out politically in big states like California, Texas, Florida and New York? Will many of the recent immigrants be able to work their way into the middle class at a time of deep economic difficulties? Is "empowerment," as used by some Hispanic politicians, another term for ethnic separatism? Will the Hispanic-first slogans heard here give way to more conventional politics, as it has with other immigrant groups? The beginnings of answers will have to await more inquiring reports that this one.

Syndicated
(Channel 11 in New York, today at noon)

HEADLINE: Chronicle

BYLINE: NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
For SLAVA ZAITSEV, the cataclysmic changes in the political and economic structure of the former Soviet Union drastically changed the nature of his fashion business and enabled him to show his serious art work as well.
Once Mr. Zaitsev, who is 54 years old, was the only Soviet couturier permitted by the Government to put his name on his designs, and he dressed RAISA GORBACHEV. Now she is no longer a customer, but JANE FONDA is. 
 "The current situation is not making it easier for me as a fashion designer, because prior to the recent changes my fashion house was the largest in Russia and was entirely financed by the Government," he said the other day, speaking from Beverly Hills, Calif. "Now I am entirely responsible personally for all financial and other aspects of running a very large business. I am paying out of my personal income."
Mr. Zaitsev's remarks were translated from Russian by SERGE SOROKKO, president of the Bowles/Sorokko Galleries, which are exhibiting his paintings and drawings this month in both Beverly Hills and New York.
A lifelong painter, Mr. Zaitsev was never free to show his art before "because his work was outside the dogmas of socialist realism," Mr. Sorokko explained. "He was permitted to paint only for his own soul. When I visited his home in Moscow, I saw 20 years of pictorial work on his walls."
Mr. Zaitsev said that he was managing to sustain his fashion house in spite of the economic distress in his country. On Saturday, some of his fashion designs were modeled in New York.
"Yes, the market is limited to just a small group," he said, "primarily the new rich, the new entrepreneurs and the still well-paid cultural elite, actors, writers and the diplomatic corps. And now, a huge amount of the clothes are acquired by foreign tourists from all over the world. Just recently Jane Fonda and TED TURNER bought some clothes from me; so did HERB RITTS, the photographer."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Japan's Barren Diplomacy

BYLINE: By LEON V. SIGAL

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
Japan and Russia are letting four barren islands stand in the way of much-needed aid for Russian reform and a relaxation of tensions in Northeast Asia.
The islands in the Kurile chain, just north of Hokkaido, were snatched by Stalin after Japan's defeat in 1945. Ever since, Japan has hungered for their return. But last week Tokyo's unyielding insistence on the return of all four islands forced President Boris Yeltsin of Russia to cancel a planned visit. Japanese diplomats had ineptly defined the issue in parochial, nationalistic terms. A more moderate approach, using the islands as stepping stones to transform Russia and international relations in the region, would better serve the interests of both sides, and of the United States. 
 Postponement of the summit meeting gives the two sides time to regroup. Tokyo, which has been remarkably grudging about aid to Russia, needs to show more magnanimity. That could enable President Yeltsin to be more forthcoming on the islands. Japan, with some justice, notes that all four islands belonged to it until 1945. But Japan was prepared to cede the two larger ones in 1956 in return for a peace treaty with the Soviet Union. Only the intercession of John Foster Dulles, the U.S. Secretary of State, who feared a blurring of cold war lines, prevented that.
The Soviets later retracted their offer to return the two smaller islands, Shikotan and the Habomais, and to negotiate about the other two, Etorofu and Kunashiri. But the 1956 formula could be revived as a useful starting point for negotiations now. Those negotiations could assure that Russia's security concerns are satisfied.
But Japan has demanded that Russia acknowledge Japanese sovereignty over all four islands before offering economic assistance or investment. And it has failed to deliver on even the modest humanitarian aid pledges already made. That left reformers around Mr. Yeltsin with little to show for their efforts. And it played into the hands of their nationalist opponents who say Japan is taking advantage of Russia's weakness. Under the circumstances, Mr. Yeltsin was better off postponing his visit than risking a debacle.
That leaves him defending a Stalinist legacy that even Stalin's successors were prepared to concede. At the same time, it is perverse for a trading state like Japan, which has worked so hard to transcend borders, to put such a premium on worthless territory. As one Japanese scholar put it, "What do we want these islands for -- to put another Disneyland there?"
His is a minority voice. But others criticize Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe for negotiating in a way certain to offend proud Russians and provide few face savers.
"Japan prides itself on its pragmatism," says one leading Liberal Democratic Party politician. "Our only principle is no principle." Yet Japan managed to turn a negotiating strategy of islands first, economic cooperation second, into a matter of rigid principle. It thereby jeopardized its interests in a reformed Russia and a transformed relationship.
The island negotiations have proven Japan can say no. Japan's task now is to coax Russia to say yes.

HEADLINE: California's Water Wars

 BODY:
On the verge of a seventh consecutive year of drought, California needs a wet winter nearly as much as a lift in its economy. It also needs to shed an archaic water policy.
California is closer to water policy reforms than ever, thanks largely to Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat. He proposes creating a free market for water in which price, not policy, would determine how much would be used on farms and how much in cities. 
 Agriculture uses 80 percent of California's water to produce 10 percent of its income. Under a patchwork of Federal subsidies, some farmers barely scratch out a living while others commute in private planes to their fields from estates in southern California.
Urban water agencies rarely complained as long as the government had the money to build new dams and reservoirs. But with the state broke and the need for drought relief urgent, the mayors have parted company with the farmers. Cities are eager to compete in the marketplace for water that would otherwise be used to grow crops.
Twenty percent of that water is in the Federal delivery network of dams and canals called the Central Valley Project. Federal law prohibits resale of water already under contract to irrigation agencies. It also bars the transfer of water outside the San Joaquin Valley. The Bradley bill, and a companion measure in the House, would abolish those restrictions.
Droughts and earthquakes are California's nightmares. The difference is that droughts can be managed; the Bradley bill provides the tools.

HEADLINE: Yes, Close Homestead A.F.B.

 BODY:
It is difficult to say no to anything that could relieve the devastatation of southern Florida by Hurricane Andrew. But the Senate Appropriations Committee has rightly rejected President Bush's transparent proposal to rebuild Homestead Air Force Base.
Embarrassed by his Administration's slow response to the catastrophe, and desperate for Florida's electoral support, Mr. Bush put $480 million for the base's reconstruction in the aid package he submitted to Congress last week. The base was key to the economy of southernmost Florida. Its restoration would give the area a desperately needed lift. But, hardhearted as it may seem, military need comes first. 
 Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has rightly insisted in the past that the Pentagon is not and should not be "a social welfare agency." The military value of the Homestead base was already in question before Hurricane Andrew. Homestead was on and off this year's list of base closings and has been regarded as a strong candidate for next year's list.
Now 80 percent destroyed by an act of nature, Homestead's closing makes even more sense. By the same reasoning, the Pentagon decided to abandon Clark Air Force Base in the Philippines after its devastation by a volcano.
What's more, the Administration appears to have low-balled the likely cost of rebuilding. According to Senator Jim Sasser, chairman of the Military Construction subcommittee and one of three committee Democrats who favored rebuilding, the probable cost would be $300 million more than the Administration says.
Besides offering to rebuild the base, Mr. Bush told Floridians that Washington would pay 100 percent of the cleanup costs eligible for Federal aid, instead of the normal 75 percent. Then he granted Louisiana equal treatment, even though its losses were much less serious. And then, inspired by the President, Senator Ernest Hollings of South Carolina got the Appropriations Committee to vote retroactive equal treatment for Hurricane Hugo in 1989 -- another $35 million.
In an election year, the political will to relieve suffering knows few limits. All the more credit to the senators -- Democrats and Republicans -- who had the courage to curb President Bush's self-serving generosity.

HEADLINE: Essay

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: Needed: A China Policy WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On the eve of the crucial 14th Party Congress in Beijing, when Chinese reformers behind Deng Xiaoping need all the help they can to wrest control from the totalitarians, the Bush Administration's China policy has disintegrated.
I happen to think it was a bad policy, but at least it was a policy. Throughout his term, President Bush -- claiming expertise based on his experience as our Ambassador to the People's Republic -- has refused to put pressure on China to couple economic and political freedom. 
 After Tiananmen, Mr. Bush pretended to protest by having his Secretary of State say that all subsequent high-level contact had been cut off. Secretary Baker's flat lie -- no other word is accurate -- was to conceal from the U.S. the clandestine visits to China by Brent Scowcroft and Larry Eagleburger. That homage made hypocritical our public protests.
When the Congress voted to remove most-favored-nation trade benefits in retaliation for the crackdown on dissent, Mr. Bush vetoed the bill -- showing Beijing's hard-liners that the advancement of human freedom in China was not high on the American agenda.
The President's rationale for this kowtowing was that it paid to maintain contact, that pressure might backfire, that good business would ultimately produce civilized behavior.
As Vice President a decade ago, Mr. Bush gave impetus to this policy of steady stroking by actively supporting the U.S-China joint communique of 1982. This was our sellout of Taiwan; with Mr. Bush firmly "in the loop," the U.S. promised in writing to limit sales of fighter planes to the island that has resisted Communism for a half-century.
The Chinese set great store by these communiques; this agreement was the third building block in the new relationship begun by Nixon and Kissinger in 1972. It was a great victory on the road to intimidating and taking over the 14 million Chinese on Taiwan, many of whom wish to remain free.
Last week, George Bush stunned the other signatory by abrogating the agreement. Not for any noble cause of human freedom; it was just that there was this plant in Fort Worth, Tex., producing F-16 fighters, that needed Taiwan's business. Votes in Texas outweighed America's word in the world, and Mr. Bush found some phony excuse -- not mentioned in the communique -- to break our solemn undertaking.
The Chinese will pursue nuclear sales to Iran, pay even less attention to our pleas to release dissidents, and might -- if they really want to hit where it hurts at election time -- stop buying wheat from American farmers.
And for what? To buy some votes in Fort Worth? This is a clear case of undermining our national interest and our international credibility to save a candidacy. As a result, the vaunted Bush China policy has run aground; a new tack has to be taken.
This week, the Senate will move to attach human-rights conditions to China trade; this time, the President should refrain from vetoing it. In for a dime, in for a dollar: if we are to stick it to Beijing, at least let's do it for a high purpose.
Today, the Commission on Broadcasting to the P.R.C. presents its report to the White House and Congress. The State Department wants all such broadcasting done by its Voice of America, where editorials are vetted by the mushmouth brigade. Human-rights supporters want the kind of hard-hitting "home service" done by Radio Free Europe, doing the reporting that local media would do if there were no repression.
The commission will come down on the side of a R.F.E.-style Radio Free Asia, though it is willing to defer to Chinese politburo sensibilities by calling it "Asia Democracy Radio." John Hughes, who was appointed by Mr. Bush to chair the commission, once headed the Voice; he tells me, "R.F.E. really knows how to do this stuff, and V.O.A. just doesn't have the experience." In his latest book, Richard Nixon agrees.
State wants control so as not to offend; R.F.E. wants the job to do the job well, which may irritate Beijing. President Bush has been waffling, awaiting the commission's advice.
It's here, in time to be part of a new China policy. We have had four years of no success with secret contacts and one-way trade; this is the time for the President to make the best of his shameful abrogation and to tell the Chinese leaders that the next four years will be different.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Economy and the Family Are the Same Subject

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is a mistake to treat "family values" and the economy as different issues, as you do in, for instance, "Women Get Into Political Football -- as the Ball" (The Week in Review, Aug. 23). The Republican and Democratic parties are both playing the old domestic ideology card, a game that goes back at least to Aristotle in creating a pretense of a separate public realm for men and a private one for women. The realms are integrated. Public policies controlled by elite men establish the conditions of our private lives. 
 The point of the game nowadays is not, as then, to isolate almost all women at home. Our society couldn't function if many women were not out in the labor force. But employers easily rationalize giving women low-paying jobs when well-publicized propaganda proclaims that women belong at home, devoted primarily to child rearing, husband care and home management. Most women, even during economic expansion, get dreary jobs in factories and offices.
The propaganda preserves men's dominance in the economy, in politics and at home. At the same time, men are pressured to stay at jobs, no matter how distasteful; men need work and wages better than women's in order to feel masculine. If enough women and men buy into the game, the structure of the political economy is sustained, even in deep recessions and even when a few women earn good incomes or enter politics.
The Republican National Convention headlined the wives of the candidates at the top of the ticket and struck out the choice of abortion. For the Democrats, Gov. Bill Clinton's wife promised to model women's domestic role if he is elected.
Meanwhile, both parties avoid important public policy changes that would expand the limitations on women's (and men's) choices. Neither party offers pay equity, universal child care, paid maternal and family leave, national health care, regulation of technological developments and management practices to diminish their oppressive qualities or restructuring work, hours and pay -- changes that would promote the value of individuals and families. For such changes, we will need a new party.
 
BEATRICEKACHUCK
New York, Aug. 30, 1992
The writer is a professor of educational psychology and women's studies, CUNY Graduate School.

HEADLINE: Too Soon to Extol Africa for Wisdom

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Wisdom of Africa" (editorial, Sept. 3) extols African regimes as examples for the rest of us: they have kept their colonial borders intact through the more than 30 years since empire. Eastern Europe, on the other hand, has in the less than three years since the fall of the Berlin Wall atomized, and it continues to do so. You recommend that we should learn of the wisdom of African ways. 
 Only those schooled in the simple-minded feel-good of today's multiculturalism could fail to see through the simple-mindedness of your editorial. You pay scant attention to a more prominent fact of African life and politics: the violence and brutality that has so bloodily marked the postcolonial history of much of the African continent. This is certainly deserving of more mention than you are willing to make.
Recall such instances as the pogrom against "Asians" (as subcontinental Indians are called in Africa) in Idi Amin's Uganda, tribal-inspired power struggles in pre- and post-Ian Smith Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe), the Angolan war and many others too numerous to list.
There is no reliable count, but the number of deaths since 1960 attributable to violence between factions of despots fighting those of future despots has been estimated by reliable journalists as easily more than 15,000. A few of those victims contributed choice bodily parts to the freezer of President for Life Amin. And then there are the food shortages and famines that are results of war and disastrous economic planning. So much for the "wisdom of Africa."
Africa has suffered much injustice and hardship under foreign domination, but do not go overboard with guilt-inspired praise for the status quo. Stable national borders are good, but do not equate such stability with good government. Mapmakers are not the Maytag repairman. An easy time for cartographers does not mean that all is well and that virtue has prevailed.
 
BOO TION KWA
Princeton, N.J., Sept. 4, 1992

HEADLINE: Rivals Hope Redistricting Cuts Bill Green's Edge

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
Four Democratic candidates are vying for the right to challenge Bill Green, the Republican Congressman who for 14 years has kept his grip on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the area known as the Silk Stocking district.
Mr. Green has no challengers in his party's primary this year, but the Democratic primary, and the new lines that have thrown sections of Queens and Brooklyn into what is now the 14th District, make the outcome of the general election this November less certain than in the past. 
 "The unknown element in the race is the places that have been added on," said Norman Adler, a Democratic consultant. "None of the candidates, including Green, are known there."
The four Democrats are Carolyn B. Maloney, a City Council member who is best known for her investigations of the city's sludge contracts; Abraham J. Hirschfeld, a real-estate developer; Charles W. Juntikka, a personal bankruptcy lawyer, and Frederick D. Newman, a psychotherapist and a founder of the New Alliance Party.
 
Running More Against Green
 Ms. Maloney, the only candidate who has held public office in New York before (Mr. Hirschfeld did serve as a Commissioner of Miami Beach), is generally considered the front-runner in the primary.
As she tours the district, paying particular attention to its newest neighborhoods -- Roosevelt Island in Manhattan; Astoria and Long Island City in Queens, and Greenpoint, Brooklyn -- Ms. Maloney seems to be running more against Bill Green than against her fellow Democrats.
"People are upset over the economy, and the Bush-Quayle-Green team got us there," she said. "Bill Green has voted lock, stock and barrel for economic measures that have harmed this city. He's voted his party, not his city."
The three other Democrats are focusing on Mr. Green, too, but they are also battling obscurity.
 
'Only a Builder Can Do It'
 Mr. Hirschfeld, a flamboyant figure who has been known to spit at reporters when he disagrees with them, is better known than the others, having amassed a considerable fortune in real estate. He ran for Lieutenant Governor in 1986 (he was thrown off the ballot after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo challenged his petitions, and now says that Mr. Cuomo "behaved very badly"), for the United States Senate in 1974 and 1976, and for the City Council in 1977.
The 72-year-old Mr. Hirschfeld lives lavishly, on 63d Street and Fifth Avenue, and considers Elaine's his favorite restaurant. Indeed, it was when walking home from Elaine's one night this summer that he decided to run for Congress.
"I was on 86th Street and I couldn't believe it," he recalled over lunch recently. "Every store was closed, the homeless were sleeping in the sidewalk, and bums were roaming the streets. I didn't intend to run for this office, but when I saw how bad the area was doing I thought something must be done, and only a builder can do it."
Mr. Juntikka, 38, is also concerned about the city's economy, but from a different perspective -- as a lawyer handling personal bankruptcy cases. "I think people of good will have to step forward to run," said Mr. Juntikka, who describes himself as "Jerry Brown with a smile."
Refusing to accept PAC money ("not that PACs are bending over backwards to donate money to me," he admitted) and vowing that if elected, he would not accept the $40,000 raise that Congress approved for itself, Mr. Juntikka supports a universal health-care system and hopes to spend some $100,000, much of it his own, on the race.
"It's maybe better not to rely on the Democratic machine, but on someone who has the right ideas and a good heart," he said in a telephone interview last week.
 
Opportunity for Independents
 The fourth candidate, Mr. Newman, ran on the New Alliance Party line for Mayor in 1985, for Senator in 1986 and for Attorney General in 1990.
"The fundamental issue is the issue of democracy in our electoral process," said Madeline Chapman, a party spokeswoman. "He's running because this year is an opportunity for independent Democrats, Independents, and insurgency candidates to make a mark."
Mr. Newman practices a form of therapy known as social therapy, which holds that society itself can cause people's problems. He favors election law reform and term limits for elected officials. He also believes, Ms. Chapman said, that there should be sexual parity in politics -- that a woman should be elected from a district every other term.
A short trip with Ms. Maloney to the Village View housing development on the Lower East Side the other day showed the difficulty of campaigning in a district where the incumbent is extremely well known and in a race that few people seem to have heard about.
 
'Not Really Familiar'
 As Ms. Maloney dispensed her literature, praising her record on the City Council contracts committee and on women's issues, the people sitting on shady benches said tentatively that they had maybe heard of Bill Green, but that was about it.
"I'm not really familiar with this race," said Rebecca High, putting down her groceries to peer at the pamphlets. "Is this the one that Ferraro and . . . "
Ms. Maloney had heard the question before. "That's the Senate," she said.
Most of the residents seemed to have a vague, benign attitude toward Mr. Green. "This is the first time I've seen this lady," said Rose Beron. "Bill Green -- he's a nice man; he comes down to the neighborhood here."
She asked a question that makes Ms. Maloney, and all the other primary candidates, cringe: "He's a Democrat, isn't he?"

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Clinton Readies Answer to Bush On Draft Issue

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EUGENE, Ore., Sept. 14

 BODY:
Choosing to confront an issue he had declared himself finished with three weeks ago, Bill Clinton abruptly altered his campaign schedule and flew from here today to defend himself against an anticipated attack by President Bush on the subject of Mr. Clinton and the draft during the Vietnam War.
It was not at all clear that Mr. Bush would attack Mr. Clinton directly. One Bush campaign official, Leslie Goodman, a deputy director of communications, said she firmly expected it. But Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, obviously pleased by Mr. Clinton's consternation, was deliberately vague. 
 And privately, Bush aides traveling with the President in Oregon suggested this evening that Mr. Bush would probably not attack Mr. Clinton's draft record directly -- at least not now.
 
Feeling Vulnerable
 What was clear was that the mere fear of an attack was enough to send his Democratic rival rushing to counter any possible move by the President, underscoring how vulnerable the Democratic nominee feels about his escape from military induction in 1969, and his changing explanations of his actions that year.
Mr. Clinton, who had earlier declined an invitation to speak before the National Guard Association meeting in Salt Lake City this week, changed his mind this morning after learning that Mr. Bush had decided to replace Vice President Dan Quayle as the convention's schedule speaker on Tuesday morning, Clinton campaign aides said.
Ms. Goodman said in a telephone interview that the President would discuss Mr. Clinton and the draft on the issue of trust.
Bush campaign operatives see Mr. Clinton as vulnerable not so much because he did not serve in the military during the Vietnam War but because his explanations of why he did not have followed such a tortuous path since the issue arose this year.
In the early days, Mr. Clinton had a simple story: After a four-year deferment at Georgetown University, he was exposed to the draft for a relatively brief period and was lucky. He was never called.
In the months since, that story has become much more complex. Incrementally but overwhelmingly, a picture of Mr. Clinton has emerged as a young man who went to great lengths to avoid the draft and to equally great lengths to minimize that politically awkward fact in the years afterward.
The anticipation of this sort of assault led Mr. Clinton to rush to try to speak in Salt Lake City at 10:30 A.M. Tuesday, after the President's 9 A.M. speech.
The arrangement is the second such in a month; three weeks ago Mr. Clinton followed Mr. Bush in speaking before the American Legion, an occasion on which the Democrat delivered what he said was his final statement on the Vietnam War and the draft.
 
Stomping Out the Fires
 "We're not going to take any guff off of George Bush," said Paul Begala, Mr. Clinton's chief speech writer. "We are not going to let his little brush fires get started. We're going to go there and stomp them out quick."
Mr. Clinton declined to acknowledge the reason for his trip to Salt Lake City, saying only that he had always wanted to go to the National Guard convention, because he was concerned with issues that affected the guard.
When asked if he planned to respond to any attack by President Bush, Mr. Clinton replied: "I have no idea what he's going to say. I only know he's going to go there. But I expect inconsistency."
Mr. Clinton's decision to fly to Salt Lake City interrupts a scheduled three-day West Coast political tour.
The candidate was enthusiastically received by tens of thousands of people in a morning rally in downtown Portland, Ore., where he focused on the economy, which he regards as Mr. Bush's great weakness.
 
Interview With Don Imus
 What may have been a preview of Mr. Clinton's remarks to the National Guard Association came in an early morning interview today with a New York talk-show host, Don Imus.
This morning, as he sat in his kitchen after his daily jogging session, Mr. Clinton was interviewed by Mr. Imus through a telephone hookup. It was Mr. Imus's friendly interview during the New York primary in April that helped Mr. Clinton retool a badly damaged public image.
Now, after several weeks of more questions about the draft, at the beginning of a week in which the Republicans are expected to redouble their attack on the subject, Mr. Clinton turned to Mr. Imus again.
"Let me ask you about the draft," Mr. Imus said. "Anything you wish you did differently back in 1969 or that you said differently during the campaign?"
The candidate replied: "In terms of whether I could have handled it better in the beginning of the campaign, I think there's no question about that. You know, I'd like to explain why I didn't do such a good job of it. I didn't go back through all my letters, notes, to try to put this all back together again because this issue has been raised on me before in Arkansas. And, when it had, everybody involved back when all the players were still living, everybody who had been involved in it, said that I did nothing wrong. And no one involved in it in all the years I was running ever suggested I did anything wrong until the beginning of this year.
"And so I think I was always kind of playing catch up because I gave a lot of answers to questions kind of off the top of my head, halfway on the run when the press would hit me. And you don't remember everything after 23 years, every detail and every specific."
 
Blaming His Enemies
 He went on at far greater length than he had in addressing the issue in recent weeks, blaming assorted Republicans and political enemies for spreading stories about him.
When the question first began making national news last spring, Mr. Clinton stayed with the story he began telling in 1978 when the matter was first raised, during the Arkansas governor's race that year. His political opponent accused him of having avoided the draft by gaining a deferment through enrolling in the Reserve Officer's Training Corps program at the University of Arkansas in 1969.
Mr. Clinton replied that after a four-year deferment from the draft granted while he was a undergraduate student at Georgetown University, he was eligible for induction while a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University in England but had been fortunate enough to never receive the call.
The matter rested largely unexplored until February 1992, when The Wall Street Journal printed a lengthy article asserting that Mr. Clinton had in fact gained a crucial deferment by promising in the summer to enroll in the Reserve Officers Training Corps program at the University of Arkansas in 1969. The article said Mr. Clinton's promise to attend the University of Arkansas Law School and participate in the R.O.T.C. program there had won him a change in his draft status, shielding him from the draft.
Having secured the deferment, Mr. Clinton broke his promise, choosing not to enroll at the University of Arkansas after all, or to join the R.O.T.C. program, but to remain another year in Oxford and then go to Yale Law School, The Journal said.
In response to the article, Mr. Clinton said he decided in September or October of 1969 that it would be wrong for him to take the R.O.T.C. deferment, when other young men he knew were taking their chances on the draft. "I had high school classmates who were already dead," he said. "I decided it was an inappropriate thing to do."
So, he said, he informed Col. Eugene L. Holmes, the director of the R.O.T.C. program, that he would not participate in R.O.T.C.; he did this in September, or early October, he recalled. On Oct. 30, his draft status was changed from 1-D deferment to 1-A eligibility.
It is not, however, entirely clear when he told the R.O.T.C. program that he would not attend. While he said he told Colonel Holmes in the early fall, Lieut. Col. Clinton D. Jones, Colonel Holmes's deputy and the director of procurement for the University of Arkansas R.O.T.C. program, said in an interview last week that neither he nor Colonel Holmes knew of Mr. Clinton's change of heart until they received a letter in December, after he drew a high number in the draft lottery, protecting him from being called up.
Within a few days of the first article, The Journal challenged Mr. Clinton's explanation with the December letter. In the letter, Mr. Clinton offered an explanation for his decision to risk exposure to the draft that contradicted what he had told The Journal.
"I decided to accept the draft despite my political beliefs for one reason: to maintain my political viability within the system," the 23-year-old Mr. Clinton wrote.
 
A Friend's Letters
 The story turned another corner in April, when The Los Angeles Times printed excerpts from letters Clifford Jackson wrote to friends in the spring of 1969. Mr. Jackson, a Little Rock lawyer who was a Fulbright Scholar at Oxford when Mr. Clinton was a Rhodes Scholar, says he and others helped Mr. Clinton put together an aggressive campaign to secure the R.O.T.C. slot after Mr. Clinton received an induction notice in late April 1969.
The excerpts from Mr. Jackson's letters described a young Mr. Clinton in the spring of 1969 as "feverishly trying to find a way to avoid entering the Army as a drafted private," with Mr. Jackson enlisting "several of my friends in influential positions, trying to pull strings on Bill's behalf," and with Mr. Clinton ultimately "wiggling his way back to Oxford."
More importantly, the excerpts also contained this line: "Bill Clinton, friend and Rhodes received an induction notice." This forced Mr. Clinton to make his third significant amendment to his explanation, admitting that he had received an induction notice.
Previously, in dozens of interviews on the subject of the draft, Mr. Clinton had never mentioned the induction notice, and at least twice he had denied having ever been called up.
In acknowledging his induction, Mr. Clinton said that he had received the notice late after the call-up date had passed and that he had therefore been able to secure a delay until July 28, which gave him time to return to Arkansas and secure the R.O.T.C. deferment. "I gladly would have told you this, if it had even occurred to me that this was relevant," he told reporters.
Mr. Jackson's assertion that Mr. Clinton arranged a campaign of political influence to secure the delay and the R.O.T.C. slot is unproven and has been denied by Mr. Clinton.
After dropping from public view for several months, the draft issue came back two weeks ago, when The Los Angeles Times published an article asserting that Mr. Clinton's uncle, Raymond Clinton, had led a political lobbying effort to gain his nephew a slot in the Naval Reserve program in Hot Springs, Ark., in an effort to help protect Mr. Clinton until he secured the R.O.T.C. deferment.
In his immediate responses to questions on the matter, Mr. Clinton said repeatedly that the assertions in The Times article were a surprise to him. "It's all news to me," he said, and "I know nothing about it."

HEADLINE: Doctors' Group Offers Plan To Curb Health-Care Costs

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
The American College of Physicians, the largest medical specialty group in the United States, said today that there should be an overall national limit on health-care spending, with new restrictions on the amounts charged by doctors and hospitals.
The proposal signals a turning point in the debate over the future of the American health-care system because it indicates that significant numbers of doctors now support an approach favored by many labor unions, big businesses and Democratic members of Congress. 
 Under the proposal, all employers would be required to provide health insurance for their workers or to pay a new tax to finance a public health plan in which the employees could enroll. Private and public health insurers would offer a uniform set of benefits, covering "all medically effective and appropriate care." Hospitals and doctors would negotiate payment schedules with insurers and others who pay for their services.
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic Presidential nominee, also favors a comprehensive budget for all health-care spending, public and private alike. President Bush vehemently opposes the idea, saying it will lead to stringent rationing of health care, and he regularly denounces the idea in campaign speeches.
 
'Times Have Changed'
 The college, which is composed of 77,000 doctors who specialize in internal medicine, unveiled the proposal today in its journal, The Annals of Internal Medicine. In the plan, it goes further than the American Medical Association, which wants to require employers to provide health insurance but does not support a national health-care budget with limits on doctors' fees.
Historically, doctors have opposed efforts by Government, insurers and businesses to regulate their fees. But Dr. Willis C. Maddrey, president of the American College of Physicians, said, "Today we acknowledge that times have changed."
Nonetheless, Dr. Raymond Scalettar, chairman of the American Medical Association, sharply criticized the proposal. "The college's plan is a thinly veiled Clinton-style proposal, a radical approach rather than the incremental reform that is necessary," he said.
In May, the Journal of the American Medical Association published an editorial saying that the United States should set an annual limit, or ceiling, on health-care spending, "no matter how distasteful or politically dangerous that may seem to be." But the editorial did not reflect the official position of the association.
Many medical groups have issued blueprints for the nation's health-care system, but the college's plan is the most specific about how to control costs.
The college said many doctors would accept lower fees in return for more professional freedom and less second-guessing by insurance companies. "Physicians will accept the constraints necessary in a reformed system, particularly to control costs, if there is an end to the overwhelming regulatory intrusion that dominates practice today," it said.
 
Consulting on Many Sides
 In developing the plan, the college's 28-member board consulted a wide range of business and labor groups, circulated questionnaires among 4,500 members of the college and met with its chapters from all 50 states. Officers of the organization said the proposal accurately reflected the members' growing concern about health costs.
Dr. John R. Ball, executive vice president of the college, said his group's proposal embodied five years of work and was not intended as an endorsement of Mr. Clinton. "I don't think this is a Republican or a Democratic plan," said Dr. Ball. "It's a bipartisan plan."
 
'A Matrix' of Controls
 To control costs, the college said: "We must limit total health-care spending through a national health-care budget and a matrix of national and local controls on the price, supply and demand for health services. We must adopt a national health-care budget -- a ceiling on total health expenditures."
It did not say exactly how it would calculate the national health budget. But it said that current spending on health care, $800 billion, or 14 percent of gross domestic product, was enough for this year.
The plan suggested that state officials would develop a health-care budget for each state. Dr. Ball said the medical profession would police the new limits on spending and doctors' fees. If doctors failed to enforce compliance, then Federal and state officials might become involved, he said.
While requiring employers to buy health insurance for employees, the college would lighten the burden in three ways. If employers chose to provide private insurance, they would not have to cover retirees or employees 60 years old and over, and they would not have to pay catastrophic costs, defined as those exceeding $50,000 a year for one person. The new publicly sponsored health program, consolidating Medicare and Medicaid, would pay such costs.
These elements of the college's proposal address President Bush's concern that new Federal mandates for health insurance would impose a crushing burden on small businesses and would lead to job losses.
Gail R. Wilensky, deputy assistant to the President for policy development, said the proposal was "absolutely contrary to what we are doing." Asked if the President could endorse cost controls of the type proposed by the college, Dr. Wilensky said, "Not a chance."

HEADLINE: GERMAN RATE CUT;
GERMAN RATES CUT, SETTING OFF SURGE IN WORLD MARKETS

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Germany's powerful central bank cut its high interest rates slightly today -- less than many political leaders and economists had hoped -- but even the small cut was enough to provoke a strong worldwide rally in stocks.
The modest cuts, a half-point in one rate and a quarter-point in another, were the Bundesbank's first in five years and seemed as much a nod to the French vote on Sunday on the treaty on European unity as a change in Germany's long-term strategy. 
 Because the high German interest rates have drawn off money from other countries and stifled business investment, even the small step today was seized on by investors as cause for optimism -- that rates might come down more but certainly would not go higher. After the announcement, the German stock market rose 4.4 percent, and the French, Belgian and Italian markets gained more than 3.5 percent each. [In the United States, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 70.52 points, or 2.1 percent.] Bonds and the dollar also rallied in world markets.
 
German Rates Remain High
 But the gains today and the optimism surrounding them would almost certainly evaporate if the French reject the unification treaty.
And even with the cuts, German rates remain high. The Lombard rate, the Bundesbank's ceiling on short-term rates, was cut to 9.5 percent from 9.75 percent; the discount rate, at which commercial banks borrow from the central bank, was cut to 8.25 percent from 8.75 percent.
These cuts by themselves are not sufficient to jump-start the economies of Europe or the United States, economists said. Rather, they said, it would take a series of interest-rate reductions, in Germany and in other nations, at a time when most governments are grappling with large fiscal deficits as well as their monetary problems.
 
Tightfisted Policies
 But the symbolism seemed as important as the actual size of the cuts. The Bundesbank is famed for its tightfisted, anti-inflationary policies and its independence from political pressures, and it has been willing to hold German interest rates at high levels with no regard for the effect on its fellow members of the European Community and the rest of the world economy.
The high German rates had been blamed for snuffing out any chance of economic recovery in Europe by forcing other nations to keep their rates high to defend the value of their currencies. Even the modest drop in German rates gives other nations more flexibility to lower their own rates, or at least avert an increase. In the United States, for example, the Federal Reserve might feel it has the freedom to nudge the already low interest rates lower, hoping to stimulate the economy.
Because lower rates improve the outlook for economic recovery, they foster optimism among investors, rallying the stock markets.
A healthier Europe would be beneficial to the United States by increasing demand for goods from American companies.
The high German rates also attracted investments from other countries, strengthening the mark against other currencies and contributing to the slide of the dollar, the Italian lira and other currencies.
 
The Markets' Hope
 "It looks pretty clear that the Bundesbank has done the minimum it can get away with," said Nigel Gault, the chief European economist for DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic forecasting firm. "But the markets seem to be looking at it with the hope that German rates have peaked and will now trend down."
The Bundesbank had shocked the financial markets with its statement on Sunday night that it would reduce rates today. But it did not reveal then how large the cuts would be. Its commitment to reducing rates was made as part of a coordinated effort in the European Community to stabilize currency markets by devaluing the Italian lira, the weakest of the leading European currencies.
In currency trading today, the dollar posted solid gains and the lira surged. Indeed, Europe's central banks were forced to buy British pounds because that currency slipped so sharply against the lira.
"There may have been some disappointment in the markets because there had been some people saying that the Bundesbank might push down rates 1 or 2 percent, but in my opinion that was never realistic," said Ulrich Beckmann, an economist at Deutsche Bank A.G. in Frankfurt. "Otherwise, the markets have reacted very positively."
 
Sign of Cooperation
 Proponents of closer European unification seized on the shift as a sign that nations could put aside their conflicting economic agendas to work together.
With just six days left until the French referendum on the European union treaty, which was agreed to by the leaders of the 12 European Community nations in the Dutch town of Maastricht last year, Government officials campaigning in favor of a "yes" vote portrayed the move as proof that Germany, Europe's economic engine, could be counted on as a partner in a more unified community.
"The spirit of Maastricht has prevailed over purely national interests," Prime Minister Pierre Beregovoy of France said.
Opponents of the Maastricht treaty, however, said the modest size of the reductions and the continuing uncertainty in the markets simply proved that it was unwise to allow Germany, in effect, to set monetary policy throughout Europe.
 
'Bit of a Cosmetic Exercise'
 "This proves that this was perhaps just a bit of a cosmetic exercise, and it underlines the fact that the European finance ministers have little control on the market," said John Carlisle, a Conservative member of the British Parliament.
Economists were divided on the significance of the decision by the Bundesbank to cut rates within days of reasserting its longheld position that vigilance against inflation precluded moves to spur more economic growth.
Some said the bank was making a historic change in policy by putting international considerations ahead of its inflation-fighting mandate. But others said it was probably motivated by a recognition that the German economy had slowed even more than the bank had earlier recognized, and that a small reduction could be justified.
If the French reject the Maastricht treaty on Sunday, economists said, the currency markets will plunge into turmoil. If the push for European unification ends, they said, currency traders would no longer put so much faith in the determination of European nations to keep inflation low and exchange rates stable -- and will pull investments out of vulnerable currencies like the pound.

 BODY:

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The German Rate Cut
Germany's powerful central bank cut its high interest rates slightly. The cuts were less than many political leaders and economists had hoped, but because high German rates have drawn money from other countries and stifled business investment, even the small step was welcomed around the world. [Page A1.]
Germany's action was interpreted as a new willingness to respond to outside pressures and has opened a debate about whether the central bank has lost its independence. [D6.]
The Bundesbank move was hailed as one that will spur world growth. But economists do not expect a quick turnaround. [D6.]
Despite a devaluation of the lira by 7 percent, Italy's Prime Minister got no relief from critics of his economic policy. [D6.]
 
 Markets
American stock prices took their biggest leap since December, with the Dow industrials rising 70.52 points, or 2.1 percent, to 3,376.22. The jump came on heavy volume. [D1.]
Bond prices gained, but not as much as those overseas. Analysts said many traders were disappointed in the modest size of the German interest rate cuts. [D16.]
Precious metals futures leaped on hopes that Germany's interest-rate cut would ignite higher inflation. [D17.] The dollar climbed against most currencies in New York and overseas. [D17.]
 
 International
The defense lawyer in a bank fraud trial accused the Bush Administration of manipulating the case to conceal "blunders" in its relationship with Iraq before the invasion of Kuwait. [D1.]

HEADLINE: 11-Year-Old Boy Finds Parents Dead In Bronx Apartment

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
An 11-year-old Bronx boy arrived home from school yesterday afternoon to discover his mother and father shot to death in the living room of the family's apartment. His 2-month-old brother lay unharmed in a stroller inches from the bodies, the police said.
Investigators said last night that they had no idea why the couple were killed. The man, Nestor Julio Puente Mello, 31 years old, was shot in the head and abdomen, and his wife, Isabel Perez, 34, was shot in the head and neck. 
 Lieut. James Malvey, the commanding officer of the 44th Detective Squad said there was no sign of a forced entry at the apartment, on the top floor of a six-story building at 306 East 171st Street in what he described as a violent section of Morrisania plagued by killings and drug-dealing. There was no indication that robbery was the motive, the lieutenant said; the orderly apartment was virtually undisturbed and cash and jewelry remained untouched.
Adding to the mystery,the lieutenant said, was that there was no sign of struggle, even though Mr. Mello was a prize-winning body builder.
For this reason, Lieutenant Malvey said, "We have reason to believe they knew who the shooters were."
The police and neighbors said they knew little about the family, which had moved in about six months ago. Both parents were believed to be Dominican immigrants. Mr. Mello was unemployed, Lieutenant Malvey said, and Ms. Perez was living on welfare. The children were moved to the home of a relative last night.

HEADLINE: THE GERMAN RATE CUT;
German Cut Not Seen as Quick Cure

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
The Bundesbank's decision to cut German interest rates was hailed in dozens of world capitals as a move that will spur growth in Europe and beyond. But the cuts are not so sizable that economists expect them to fuel a quick or strong turnaround.
Where the rate cuts might help most, Bush Administration officials and economists said, is by steadying volatile exchange rates and calming the world's jittery markets. 
 The consensus is that the world is in for at least one more year of sluggish growth. Still, every bit of stimulus helps, and even a modest German rate cut cannot be sneezed at.
 
Prelude to I.M.F. Meeting
 The Bundesbank's decision came just days before the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank here, where the more than 150 member nations had been expected to cast Germany as the villain for slowing world growth. Now some of the heat is off.
For the United States, any slightly faster growth in Europe could nudge America's sluggish economy ahead a bit faster. But such effects are not likely to be felt for several months.
"We won't get a healthy European economy instantaneously," said Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. "This will help solve it, but it will take some time." He added that "a healthy European economy will in the medium term be good for American exports" because European consumers and businesses will buy more American goods once Europe's economy picks up.
The Bundesbank move, along with Japan's decision last month to pursue an $86 billion fiscal stimulus program, are steps toward ending the global slump. But there seems no question that the Japanese have taken the bolder move.
With its ability to stimulate the American economy hamstrung by the $320 billion Federal budget deficit, the Bush Administration can do little more than put pressure on other nations and encourage the Federal Reserve to cut rates at home.
But the German interest rate cuts should give the Fed new flexibility. On Sept. 4, the Fed settled for a rate cut of one-fourth of a percentage point rather than a larger one, economists say, because of concerns that the dollar was near record lows against the mark.
In a news briefing today, a senior Administration official who insisted on anonymity said the Bundesbank's move showed that nations still cooperate to foster growth. He said the German central bank had listened to repeated appeals from the Bush Administration and Europe.
"This is a pretty good example of successful policy coordination," the official said.
To be sure, a German rate cut of 1 percent would do considerably more.
"It's a mistake to think that a rate cut of half a point is going to be enough to bring about a resumption of rapid global growth," said Lawrence H. Summers, chief economist at the World Bank.
Jacques Delors, the president of the European Community's executive commission, welcomed the Bundesbank move but said it was just a "gesture." It seems only a matter of time before the United States and Germany's European partners start putting pressure on the Bundesbank to ratchet rates still lower.
"The Bundesbank rate cut still leaves the countries of Europe with rather little room for maneuver," said William R. Cline of the Institute for International Economics.
Many economists say the Bundesbank will not cut rates much more until the German Government slashes its budget deficit, which is stoking inflationary pressures. The deficit mushroomed largely because of Bonn's efforts to finance the reconstruction of eastern Germany.
But cutting budget deficits is the kind of painful step that many countries, the United States pre-eminentamong them, are reluctant to take in the name of international cooperation. For years, Washington's allies have pressed it to cut its deficit sharply to help bring down long-term interest rates around the world and to provide more money for private investment.
While Americans do not seem willing to swallow the bitter pill of deficit reduction, many still hope the Germans will take this medicine.
