HEADLINE: Fond Memories of the Bronx of Yore;
Many of Its Natives Are Long Gone, but the Old Borough Is Not Forgotten

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
Charles Medwin was like many people who grew up in the Bronx in the 40's, 50's and 60's: He couldn't wait to get out. But now that Mr. Medwin, a retired New York City police sergeant, lives in Las Vegas, Nev., he drives a car with "BRONX4" on the license plate. He is also a card-carrying member of the Bronx Historical Society, and eagerly looks forward to news clippings about the Bronx sent by friends in New York.
"I get people honking at me all the time, even the cops," Mr. Medwin said. "There's a common bond. See, you didn't really appreciate it when you were there, but you appreciated it later."
 
Down Memory Lane
 
 Like former Bronxites scattered all over the country, Mr. Medwin revels in Bronx nostalgia. Never mind that his is a memory Bronx, that many former residents wouldn't think of walking the streets of the real thing these days. Mr. Medwin and his fellow enthusiasts are wistfully calling up memories of their old neighborhoods, hunting down friends they grew up with, even creating a cottage industry in Bronx memorabilia.
One childhood resident, who now lives in Scarsdale, N.Y., has begun publishing a nostalgia magazine, Back in the Bronx. A retired gift shop owner in Kansas City works in his daughter and son-in-law's deli, called "D'Bronx" in tribute to his home turf. A medical billing clerk in Houston, who during her last visit to the Bronx would not even get out of the car to snap a picture of her old building, is planning a Bronx reunion.
The Bronx nostalgia buffs yearn for a time before the Cross Bronx Expressway tore through the heart of the borough north of Manhattan, before the wave of Puerto Rican and black families prompted white flight in the 1970's and before Co-op City sapped away many of the remaining middle-class families.
Nevertheless, when it comes to playing the nostalgia game, Bronxites have it over every other group of New Yorkers, except perhaps Brooklynites.
"Being from the Bronx and from Brooklyn meant something," said Clint Roswell, a Bronx native who is also the spokesman for the Bronx Borough President. "Being from Queens didn't mean anything. It was an outpost. Maybe I'm just a Bronx snob. Or is that an oxymoron?"
The self-anointed voice of the movement is Back in the Bronx, a kitschy, gossipy magazine that reads like the personals and whose style is part high school year book and part hometown booster.
One issue of the magazine -- which has a circulation of 2,500 and is published sporadically, but more or less quarterly -- featured the winner of the 1962 Miss Bronx contest held at the Freedomland amusement park. There are reminiscences of the Loews Paradise Theater on the Grand Concourse, with its elegant lobby and painted ceiling. And there are endless lists of famous Bronxites like Red Buttons and Ralph Lauren, the comedian Robert Klein and the boxer Jake La Motta.
Steve Samtur, who publishes the magazine with his wife, Susan, said the idea came to him two years ago, after a reunion of Bronxites (held in the Catskills) attracted 1,200 people.
"They'll come from anywhere for these reunions," he said. "And when you come back, it's like you never left. You start up where you left off 30 or 40 years ago."
 
Claiming the Neighborhood
 All of this, Mr. Samtur says, has helped many Bronxites realize it is now acceptable to say they grew up in the much-maligned borough.
The film director Penny Marshall would not want to overdo it. "I would never call the Bronx chic, but I'm happy to say I'm from there," she says.
So happy, in fact, that Ms. Marshall, who has directed films like "A League of Their Own," "Big," and "Awakenings" -- which was filmed in the Bronx -- named her company Parkway Productions, a nod to her old Bronx neighborhood near Grand Concourse and Mosholu Parkway.
The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, the symbol of Bronx present and probably its biggest booster today, said that while he welcomed the nostalgia for the borough's past, he wished that former Bronxites would be as hopeful about the its future as he is. He also said he was weary of outsiders, especially former Bronxites, dumping on his borough.
 
A Top Booster
 "Why I go nuts when a lot of people say stuff like that is that, one, they don't know the Bronx of today," he said. "Two, they never set foot in it and three, if it's so bad, it begs the question of why there are so many wonderful people who got their start here."
Mr. Ferrer said he would allow that there have been changes in the Bronx. "It's not good nor is it bad," he said. "It's different."
When Jeffrey Silber, who was born and raised in the Bronx, moved to Los Angeles years ago to join his brother's real-estate business, he longed for his home so much that he organized a picnic of former Bronxites. Nine hundred people showed up.
"They were looking for each other," he said. "There was a wholesale transition, and this makes the Bronx completely different from any other urban experience in America, where there isn't anybody in a 50-block area still left that you grew up with.
"There's no way for them to go back to it or to look someone up," he said. "That's what they were looking for at this picnic. They were looking for their past."
 
'Cities Within a City'
 During the period just after the Depression and before the 1970's, the Bronx was made up of neighborhoods that, while self-contained, were like one another in many ways.
"We had little cities within a city, neighborhoods within neighborhoods," said Lou Moses, who left the Bronx in 1942. Mr. Moses now lives in Kansas City, where he works at his daughter and son-in-law's deli.
"It was a big little hometown. You had all your services on one block, a bakery, candy store, and so on down the line," said Mr. Moses, whose father owned a bakery in the Tremont section.
Lloyd Ultan, a historian, said the Bronx of that era was defined by the shared aspirations of those looking for a better life, many of them leaving behind the immigrant communities of Manhattan's Lower East Side.
The Bronx was also very homogenous then. The 1930 Census, Mr. Ultan said, showed that 49 percent of the Bronx' population was Jewish. There were also large numbers of Italians and Irish. "But all were middle class in their thoughts, in their ideals, in their attitudes and thus there was a shared community in the best sense of the term."
 
Major Social Changes
 Even then, however, those who "moved up" to the Bronx looked to move on once they got there.
But in the 1970's, major social and economic forces reshaped the borough, and some former residents speak of the changes with bitterness.
"They burned it, welfared it, gouged it and then Co-op City finished it," Charles Medwin, the former Bronx police officer, said. "I blame my fellow Jews for helping to destroy the Bronx because they were afraid of the black people and they ran. They ran to Co-op City and Long Island.
"This used to be a little piece of prosperity, but they destroyed it," he said. "But we do have memories of when we were young, and they were good memories," he said.
 
Still Worth Revisiting
 Not all former Bronxites have such a grim view of its future. When Susan Hemus Hugele of Houston, who is planning a reunion of people from her neighborhood next month, returned to 1927 University Avenue in 1981, she photographed it from inside her car. After she had the film developed, she cried at what she saw.
The ground floor, which had housed a butcher's and a candy store when she was growing up, was burned out. The apartments were vacant, and the building covered with graffiti.
But when she returned last fall, the building was being rehabilitated, as was much of the Bronx, she said.
"We can't go back and relive it in the neighborhood, but we can go through and see that they're trying to make it better."
Nevertheless, when Ms. Hugele's neighborhood chums gather to reminisce next month, it will be in New Jersey, not in the Bronx.

HEADLINE: Stocks Leap by 70.52, Biggest Jump of Year

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Stock prices in the United States took their biggest leap of the year yesterday, following sharp rallies in Europe, after Bonn loosened its interest-rate tourniquet.
The Dow Jones industrial average, the main gauge of the market's strength, rose 70.52 points, or 2.1 percent, to 3,376.22, its biggest jump since an 88.10-point gain Dec. 23. Trading was the heaviest in more than six weeks, with 252.8 million shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange, up from 180.6 million Friday. 
 Investors especially favored large industrial companies, including makers of chemicals, autos and electrical equipment, which are most likely to benefit from a stronger recovery. The rally was broad enough, however, to lift the Standard & Poor's 500, which tracks the wider market, 5.69 points, or 1.4 percent, to a record 425.27.
The Dow's gain propelled it to within 37 points of the record 3,413.21 reached June 1.
 
'Catalyst for Higher Prices'
 Economists still say that no matter what the Germans do, the United States cannot even hope for brisk economic growth until well into next year. But market analysts said the German rate cuts, and the ensuing bond market gains in the United States, were only some of the reasons for believing that stocks will continue to advance.
"What the German central bank provided was just a catalyst for higher stock prices, which were going to emerge anyway," said Charles I. Clough Jr., chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch. "This rally is sustainable."
The advances on Wall Street followed gains of more than 2 percent in Tokyo and London, 4 percent in France and 4.4 percent in Germany. The Mexican Bolsa rose 48.72 points, or 3.76 percent, to 1,342.81, for its sharpest jump this year.
In the United States, market watchers saw a scene of lackadaisical investors startled into action. "Mutual fund managers have too much cash to be easily invested," said Laszlo Birinyi, whose investment consulting firm bears his name. "Anytime managers make one of these bets and it goes awry, they scurry."
Andrew Midler, who manages Fidelity's Growth and Income Fund, denied reports that his fund group had been an especially active buyer yeterday. "Yeah, Germany dropped rates by a quarter of a percent," he said. "I didn't see too much change in the world." Business conditions remain disappointing, he added.
Instead of concentrating on today's stagnant economy, Mr. Birinyi advised looking at the longer range record of a bull market that has plugged along for two years despite scant economic growth. "The stock market's like a movie, not a series of pictures," he said.
Another scene from this movie had short-sellers, who sell borrowed stock on the hope of buying it back later at lower prices, running for cover. Gene J. Seagle, director of technical research at Gruntal & Company, said that New York Stock Exchange short sales had recently reached 900 million shares -- "the largest in history," he said.
Many analysts view heavy short sales as a favorable sign because all those shares have to be bought back later. When the market rises, leaving short-sellers with losses, Mr. Seagle said, "These people run very fast."
Four stocks accounted for more than a quarter of yesterday's advance in the Dow: Caterpillar, up 3 5/8, to 53; Minnesota Mining, up 3 5/8, to 103; Allied-Signal, up 2 1/2, to 55 7/8, and General Electric, up 2 3/8, to 77 1/2.
Auto makers also jumped on hopes that lower interest rates here and abroad would enliven the economy. General Motors gained 1 1/4, to 34 7/8, Ford 2 5/8, to 42 7/8, and Chrysler 1 1/8, to 22 1/2, with all three among the 10 most active stocks on the New York exchange. Ford also benefited from several recent reports highlighting the Taurus model's challenge to the Honda Accord for the top spot in United States sales.
Many of the companies that appreciated the most yesterday also depend heavily on sales abroad, which would improve if the German rate cut brings stronger growth abroad.
Banks also did well yesterday, with J. P. Morgan up 2, to 62 3/8, and Chase Manhattan, the nation's second busiest stock on dividend-related trading, up 7/8, to 23 1/8.
Broader indexes did not keep pace with the large industrial stocks in the Dow, as the Nasdaq average gained 1.92 percent. The Dow Jones utility average fell 0.44, to 221.39, as investors moved their money to stocks more likely to gain in a recovery.
Investors still dumped stocks whose prospects darkened. Symantec, the most active issue yesterday, fell 4 3/8, to 11 1/8, when it warned that said second-quarter earnings would not meet analysts' estimates. Biomet fell 1 1/4, to 16 3/4, as a Lehman Brothers analyst said profits would grow more slowly than expected.
The market rose 35 points for about half the day's gains in the opening minutes of trading, after investors heard the news from the Bundesbank and the European markets.
As the day ended, analysts spoke less of the economic than the psychological impact of Germany's move. Investors had feared that record German rates and a plummeting dollar left the Federal Reserve no more leeway to massage the American economy. The stock market's response to the German rate cuts "reflects a turn in investor expectations," said Steven G. Einhorn, chief strategist at Goldman, Sachs and Company. "At least now there is light at the end of the tunnel."
So what if economists still predict slow growth? As Mr. Clough of Merrill Lynch put it, "I've never seen an economic forecast engraved in stone."

HEADLINE: Shaking Up Old Ways of Benevolence

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
They are not Rockfellers or Mellons. But they do have money, dividends from a family business or perhaps a modest inheritance, and they want to do good with it. They do not see themselves as philanthropists, a description that they find pretentious or condescending. They prefer to speak of "sharing," rather than "giving," and they often want to get actively involved with a group in addition to writing a check.
These people, many of them in their 30's and 40's and the majority of them women, are causing new ripples to spread through conventional charitable giving. What sets them apart from past contributors is the fact that they are not going it alone, that they are seeking out other donors who share their view of society's problems -- shaped in many cases by events of the 1960's, and using this network to channel their money to groups that in many cases are too small, too radical or too inexperienced to attract help from the established philanthropies. 
 Their typical individual donations amount to no more than $50,000 annually, and their main beneficiaries are local groups that run shelters for battered women, train jobless youth, organize tenant coalitions or fight crime, drugs, racism or environmental ills.
Some are like Barbara Winslow, a Hunter College professor, who decided to use a windfall to organize an "overground railroad" helping poor women living outside New York come to the city for abortions.
 
Giving Time
 "We want to give these women transportation, get people to open their homes to them if they need a place to stay for the night and mainly see they receive safe and good medical care -- not wind up with a back-street butcher," she said.
Annette Holloway, a television producer, made a similar choice, saying, "I received this chunk of money I didn't need and seeing the city's homeless made me decide to spend some of it in my own backyard."
All of them give their money; in addition some of them give their time. Ms. Holloway works as a volunteer at New York Cares, a group that helps employed people find ways to fit community service into their crowded schedules by working evenings at food kitchens or spending weekends with students. "I don't feel I do that much, spending a day I enjoy with children from a shelter."
Both she and Ms. Winslow channel their money to the North Star Fund, a 14-year-old group based in lower Manhattan whose motto is "Change, not charity." North Star, which describes itself as an alternative to traditional foundations, like Ford, Rockefeller or Carnegie, channels aid through a board of community leaders.
Thirteen other groups like North Star operate around the country in a loosely linked network called the Funding Exchange, and most report a rise in new donors, said Cecilia Rodriguez, the exchange's executive director. Together they gave away $7 million last year, a relatively small sum measured against the $182 million that the Ford Foundation, the country's wealthiest foundation, spent last year.
"The exchange was started by a generation of men and women who were children of the 60's, people who grew up in the midst of social ferment and the civil rights movement," she said. "We're seeing another generation joining in now and they too have a passionate involvement."
Marjorie Fine, executive director of North Star, said that in the last 18 months, the number of donors who give $1,000 annually to become members has jumped from 100 to 200. And she said the organization has received a substantial number of larger gifts in the $50,000 range, enabling it to give away $600,000 last year, for example, to groups organizing new immigrants, teen-agers from low-income families and South Asian women who suffered from domestic violence .
"Most donors insist on anonymity," said Ms. Fine. "But we can draw a profile: More often than not, the recent donor is a woman with a professional career in her 30's or 40's who received income from a family business, an inheritance, a legal settlement or some unexpected source. We also are seeing older, 'mom' donors coming with their daughters and even grandparents introducing nieces and nephews to giving."
A similar increase in donations from women in the Boston area is expanding giving at the Haymarket People's fund, which operates much like North Star. Haymarket, like North Star, runs workshops for potential donors, and has seen participation by women increase from 582 to 709 in the last three years while male participation remains around 200, said Hillary Smith, director of development.
"We see women taking a leadership role today and altering the face of traditional philanthropy," she said. "Older white men historically dominated philanthropy, focusing their interest on buildings bearing their names, on getting seats at the symphony and maintaining the status quo. That's all changing as more women get control over money."
There are those prepared to provide guidance to young women and men who say that the money they have received, but not earned, clashes with their social values, their commitment to a more equitable distribution of wealth and power. One such guide is Christopher Mogil, who was working and living modestly as a community organizer in West Philadelphia when he learned he had a $275,000 inheritance. His reaction: shock and embarrassment.
Inquiring how others coped with such situations, he and his wife, Anne Slepian, uncovered a network of wealthy people committed to social change, including several at Haymarket. They related their experiences in a recent book "We Gave Away a Fortune" published by New Society Publishers in cooperation with the Funding Exchange. Mr. Mogil, who received a second inheritance, has given away $250,000, about a third of his inheritance, setting up the "Chutzpah Fund," to do it.
Some, like Edorah Frazer, a teacher in New Hampshire, gave away most of their inherited fortune, cheerfully violating what Mr. Mogil calls "The 11th Commandment: 'Thou Shall Not Invade Thy Principle."
The day she signed over most of her $450,000 inheritance in stocks and bonds to the Funding Exchange, Ms. Frazer said, "everything fell into place."
 
'Part of That Imbalance'
 "I would encourage people who care what their money represents to look deep inside," she said, adding, "I had to travel by myself, observe people, and pay attention to the earth. I noticed my unhappiness with the imbalanced state of the world, and drew my conclusions -- that I am part of that imbalance, but I can choose to shift the balance a little bit by my own actions."
Grace Ross, a founder of the Women's Alliance, which helps low-income women in the Boston area, inherited $650,000 and then invited a group of community advocates to help her decide what to do with it.
"Whatever is decided, we will come away with good feelings because it's an experience of the human spirit struggling for betterment of the world."
The average charitable giving by Americans is 1 or 2 percent of their income, according to the Independent Sector, a Washington-based coalition of foundations, corporations and nonprofit organizations. Five years ago the coalition began campaigning to increase giving to 5 percent -- without marked effect so far.
While foundations and corporations gave $14 million to charity last year in this county, the bulk of all giving comes from individual Americans. Their contributions added up to $111 billion, mostly to support mainstream institutions in religion, education and the arts. It is this pot of money that is being affected, in small but significant ways, by the decisions of people like Ms. Winslow and Ms. Holloway.
Ms. Winslow describes herself as a "classic kid of the 60's" who was active in the antiwar and civil rights movements and now, in the 90's, campaigns for women's reproductive rights and advocates opening academic ranks to more women from minority groups. The money that she gives to charity comes from family wealth. "My father was a hosiery manfacturer and he wanted to help my grandmother who hated wearing bulky, ugly support stockings and so developed Supp-Hose," she said.
The major concerns of Ms. Hollway, who estimates she gives away at least 10 percent of her nonsalaried income, are the homeless and adequate child care.
"Until you get a system that works, you can yell and scream about family values all you want but to no avail," she said. "You need parents who have the energy and time to spend with children and not be pressured on all sides by work commitments and they do not need some politicians telling them how to live their lives."
Anne H. Hess, another longtime contributor to North Star, said she hopes her children will continue the family tradition of giving. She recalled how her grandmother, Edith Stern, a daughter of Julius Rosenwald, the philanthropist, had prepared each of her grandchildren to play an active role in support of liberal causes.
"My 13-year-old daughter is noticing people have different life styles and opportunities," she said. "Some take taxis and others don't. Their clothes are different. She's asking relevant questions. I'm looking for appropriate answers for her."

HEADLINE: U.S. OFFERS RUSSIA AID IN BUYING FOOD

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
The Bush Administration offered Russia $1.15 billion in loan guarantees and food aid today to help it buy American grain and livestock feed over the next six months.
Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan said 30,000 export-related jobs and $3 billion in economic activity would be created by the credits and assistance, raising immediate suggestions in Congress and among agricultural organizations that the decision was primarily motivated by politics. 
 Two weeks ago, President Bush announced in the Midwest that he was authorizing export subsidies for up to 30 million metric tons, or 1.1 billion bushels, of wheat.
But one agricultural expert said today that if the Administration had wanted to make a stronger impression on many farmers, officials would have found a way to increase exports of meat or processed dairy products, which have a higher value. Food processing also creates more jobs.
 
Who Will Benefit Most?
 Russia has been offered up to 30,000 tons of pork at subsidized prices, but has yet to buy any.
The package announced today consisted of $900 million in loan guarantees and $250 million in food aid or other assistance.
Mike Dunn, vice president for government affairs at the National Farmers Union, said it might have also come too late to help farmers on small holdings.
Mr. Dunn, whose union's political branch has endorsed Gov. Bill Clinton for President, said in an interview that because most of the grains sought by Russia had already been harvested, middlemen and not farmers would profit most.
"Announcing it this long after the harvest means a real boom for the export companies, grain handlers and processors, with only a little dribble down to farmers and ranchers," he said. "If this wasn't politically motivated, it could have been more timely and helpful to family farmers."
In Congress, there is some concern about the ability of the Russians to repay about $4.4 billion in credits outstanding now. Credits have a way of turning into outright aid, a Congressional agricultural expert said.
 
Secretary Cites Russia's Need
 According to the Agriculture Department, Russia will have access immediately to $100 million in credits, which it will use to buy $66 million in feed grains, $24 million in soybean-based protein meal and $10 million in wheat. Russia also has $18 million in previous credit guarantees to buy wheat this fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30.
The remaining credits will be released in two installments: $500 million on Oct. 1 and $300 million on Jan. 1.
"These measures will assure that United States agricultural exports to one of our largest markets continue at a normal pace," Secretary Madigan said. "Although Russian agricultural production is higher and reforms are well under way, we know there is need for this kind of assistance."

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Partisan Doctors In Campaign '92

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
THIS year's Presidential election could well be a watershed event for doctors. Many physicians think it could determine the future of the nation's troubled health-care system, perhaps radically changing their profession. And so, abandoning their usual stance on the sidelines in Presidential races, many doctors are volunteering to assist in the Bush-Quayle or Clinton-Gore campaigns.
The doctors' concerns reflect national sentiments: recent public surveys have found health-care to be second only to the economy as the most important issue. 
 President Bush's proposals include a system of health insurance networks, which he said would reduce costs for small businesses. Under this proposal, insurers could not refuse to cover an employer or place limits on people with pre-existing medical conditions.
Governor Clinton's plan includes national spending limits for hospitals and doctors, uniform community health insurance rates for small businesses, guaranteed basic coverage for everyone, and limits on prescription drug prices.
Doctors have long been seen as conservatives, but campaign officials say the health debate is mobilizing people on both sides. "The medical profession is aware that this will be an election of change and that there are two very clear choices in reforming the health-care system," said Dr. Peter B. Collis, an emergency-medicine specialist in Washington who heads the Health-Care Coalition for Bush-Quayle. "A lot of people have picked a position and are becoming politically active."
The American Medical Association does not endorse Presidential candidates, although its political action committee, Ampac, distributes about $4 million in election years to an array of House and Senate candidates. But this year the association has called for a Presidential candidates' debate on health care, and it is encouraging members to work in the campaigns, referring them either to the Republican Dr. Collis or, on the Democratic side, Dr. Stephen Gleason, a Des Moines osteopathic family practitioner. Both are A.M.A. members.
Although it did not endorse a candidate, one of the largest medical specialty groups and a voting member of the A.M.A., the American College of Physicians, called yesterday for a national limit on health-care spending similar to a Clinton proposal.
Dr. Gleason said he had contacted about 4,000 doctors who were joining Clinton campaign committees, raising money, giving speeches and supporting Congressional and local candidates.
Dr. Collis predicts that most of the nation's 500,000 physicians will support President Bush for re-election. Public opinion experts noted that most surveys include too few physicians to justify separate reporting on their views.
But Dr. Collis cited a write-in straw poll in The Medical Tribune, a biweekly newspaper based in New York, which has a national circulation of 130,000. Bill Ingram, the paper's editor in chief, said that 450 doctors participated after The Tribune published the candidates' health proposals, up sharply from fewer than 300 in 1984 and 1988. This year they favored Bush, 44 percent, over Clinton, 20 percent, with 4.7 percent for Andre Marrou, a Libertarian candidate, and 15 percent for "none of the above." Many said that they would still vote for H. Ross Perot, who was favored by 24 percent before he left the race.
"Physicians have received some kind of wake-up call," said Dr. Irwin Redlener, a New York pediatrician who is chairman of the National Health Leadership Council for Clinton/Gore '92. The council's 100 members include medical, public health and nursing deans and professors, hospital executives, state officials, health policy experts and private practitioners.
"We found ourselves surrounded in an ocean of paperwork, bureaucracy and intrusion into how health care is practiced, and in a system that has gone very much out of control," Dr. Redlener said. "Doctors have always objected to any kind of government regulation or paperwork."
A Bush supporter, Dr. Beverly Carpenter, a Cincinnati internist specializing in rheumatology, agreed that "the paperwork and hassle is getting ridiculous."
"I don't want the Government to own me," she added. She contends that the Clinton proposals would "take away some of the patient's choices" and give the Government too much control over health care. "I am the artist here, creating what is best, and having to deal with a national bureaucratic system," she said. "Medicine is too specialized to have the Government interfering."
Spurring interest among doctors, The New England Journal of Medicine published summaries last week of the Bush and Clinton health-care proposals. The Bush summary was signed by Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, while the Clinton plan was signed by the Governor. Commenting in the journal, two health-policy experts, Alain C. Enthoven of Stanford University and Uwe E. Reinhardt of Princeton University said that both proposals left many issues vague -- notably, how to pay for coverage for 37 million Americans without health insurance.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Reaction Soft to German Rate Cut

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Germany's interest rate cuts yesterday should have been good news for the American bond market, but investors and traders did not act like it was.
While prices on the domestic market rose, the gains were not as big as those in Europe and Tokyo after the surprise announcement Sunday that Germany would cut its rates. 
 Moreover, the difference between the yield on the 2-year Treasury note and the 30-year bond rose to a record high, indicating in part that worries about the Presidential election may be growing and that concerns about inflation, despite positive news lately, have not been put to rest.
 
Increase in 30-Year Bond
 The 30-year bond was up 13/32 , to 99 30/32 for a yield of 7.25 percent, down from 7.29 percent Friday. But in trading in Tokyo, the bond was up to 100 16/32 , a rise of a full point. The gain in New York did not wipe out the loss on Friday. While shorter maturities faired better in New York yesterday, they gave up some of their gains during the day.
"I am a little disappointed," said Nicholas S. Sargen, the chief investment officer for Prudential's Global Fixed Income Advisers in Newark. "It was good news."
But the cut does not mean that German rates will tumble in a hurry. Mr. Sargen said he would not expect another German cut before the end of this year.
Neal M. Soss, the chief economist at the First Boston Corporation in New York, added: "The bond market does not yet appreciate how bullish this is; that you are in an environment where central banks all over the world can't tighten interest rates and are embarked on a path of easing." .
One of the reasons for the middling performance yesterday was that investors, traders and speculators often have unreasonable expectations. On Friday, no one would have predicted that the German Bundesbank would cut interest rates yesterday. The expectation was that this might happen by the end of the year at the earliest.
When it did come, the market seemed to be dissappointed that the cut was not bigger. The Bundesbank knocked half a percentage point off its short-term rate that is equivalent to the Federal Reserve's Federal funds rate on loans between banks.
There are also some worries -- like the Presidential election and the Federal budget deficit -- that are beginning to cloud the prospects for much lower interest rates in the months ahead. This raises the question of whether the rally is over, especially now that yields on bills are at their lowest in 29 years and other maturities, like the two-year notes, are at their lowest ever.
"I am not a bear on the market," said Terrence Crowe, a vice president at Nikko Securities Inc. in New York. "But the movement down in rates does not have to be a straight line. And we may now go through a period of six months where there is more growth than people are counting on."
Any dose of good news on economic growth could stop the rally for now, especially given the uncertainity of the election and the prospect of some deficit-increasing Government plan to stimulate the economy regardless of who wins in November.
 
Clear Signs of Concern
 One clear sign of concern was the widening yesterday of the differential in the yield between 2-year Treasury notes and the 30-year bond.
This closely watched difference in yields increased yesterday to 349 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, the widest ever.
"Beyond the near term, investors don't believe that inflation can remain low under normal circumstances," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers in New York, explaining why long rates have not come down more. "This is a leap they have not made yet."
Analysts also said the widening of the spread reflects in part the buying of shorter-term maturities because investors and speculators are betting that the Federal Reserve may now be able to cut short-term interest rates another notch. With the German rate cut there will be less downward pressure on the dollar. Fed officials had said that the concern about the falling dollar restrained their recent cut of one-quarter of a percentage point in the Federal funds rates.
Another consequence of the German rate cut may be the expectation that the domestic economy might begin to grow faster than expected. The reasoning is that the interest rate declines in Europe that are likely to follow the German move will help revive the European economy and buying of American products. And that buying would help spur growth in the United States.
Mr. Sargen of Prudential believes that the interest rate cut will have this impact. But he said it is way too early to begin changing the forecasts of slow growth here. "The stimulus from the German rate cut?" he asked. "That is a story for late in 1993."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Climbs in a Reaction To Lower Rates in Germany

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar climbed yesterday against most major currencies after Germany lowered its high interest rates, which had sent the dollar to historic lows in recent weeks.
Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, cut its key Lombard rate to 9.5 percent from 9.75 percent. The move came as Italy said it would devalue the lira by 7 percent. 
 The unexpected German action gave rise to optimism that global investors would stop their move into marks and mark-denominated securities, investments that have been made attractive by the large difference between German and American interest rates. The move into mark-denominated investments had battered the dollar in recent weeks.
Though the dollar strengthened on the German move, it retreated a bit by the end of the trading day in New York. Some traders said the dollar's initial response may have been an overreaction.
"It was a small rate cut," said John McCarthy, chief currency dealer at Algemene Bank Nederland in New York. He said the German move was much more oriented toward easing tensions within the European Monetary System and did not signal a Bundesbank policy change.
In Asian trading, the dollar rose as high as 1.505 marks, up from 1.45 marks late Friday in Europe. The dollar finished in London at 1.486 marks. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.4845 marks, up from 1.4485 Friday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.88 yen, up 0.8 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 124.35 yen. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 124.3 yen, up from 124.25 late Friday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8918, down from $1.9241 late Friday. In New York, one pound cost $1.8935, cheaper than $1.9225 late Friday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Up Sharply; Grain Prices Show Losses

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metals futures prices leaped yesterday on hopes that Germany's interest-rate cut would ignite a global economic recovery and higher inflation. Market analysts were skeptical.
The action by the German central bank also contributed to a decline in grain futures prices. On other commodity markets, oil and livestock futures rose. 
 Gold for October delivery surged $5.90 on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $347.30 an ounce. It was gold's biggest one-day gain since Jan. 9.
Silver for delivery this month rose 9.2 cents on the Commodity Exchange to $3.771 an ounce; October platinum moved up $3.90 to $361.50 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
 
Rally Discounted
 William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch Futures in New York, said the rally in the metals was overdone.
"One token rate cut in Europe is not a convincing reason to believe we're headed for a period of economic prosperity and inflation," he said.
Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber, said gold's rally was minor compared with the more than 70-point jump in the Dow Jones industrial average and rallies on overseas stock markets.
"It's the biggest move we've seen in gold in a long time, he said,"but in the bigger scheme of things, it doesn't necessarily mean we're out of the woods yet."
Energy futures prices rallied on the New York Mercantile Exchange ahead of a meeting of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries beginning Wednesday in Geneva to set an output ceiling for the rest of the year.
Light crude oil for October delivery rose 30 cents to $22.31 a barrel; October heating oil rose 0.73 cent to 63.54 cents a gallon; October unleaded gasoline climbed 1.15 cents to 60.93 cents a gallon and October natural gas rose 3.6 cents to $2.184 per 1,000 cubic feet.
The German rate cut also prompted a rise in the dollar's value against European currencies, which put pressure on grain and soybean futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade. Favorable crop weather in most growing areas also contributed to the modest losses in most crop markets.
A stronger dollar makes American goods more expensive overseas, which could reduce export demand for the nation's grain, said Victor Lespinasse, assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds.
Traders ignored news that the Bush Administration will give Russia $900 million in loan guarantees to buy American farm products and $250 million in direct food aid. The assistance had been widely expected in the grain markets.
Wheat for September delivery settled 1/4 cent lower at $3.21 a bushel; September corn slipped 1/4 cent to $2.24 a bushel; September oats ended 3 cents higher at $1.43 1/2 a bushel and September soybeans fell 3 1/2 cents to $5.54 1/2 a bushel.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Does HBO Tell Showtime? In This Campaign, It Does

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
IMAGINE Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola joining forces to try turning around the decline in cola consumption. Or McDonald's and Burger King teaming to counter health claims against meat. Or Bloomingdale's and Macy's getting together to encourage shoppers to leave specialty stores and return to department stores.
An actual version of those hypothetical examples of marketing's lions lying down with its lambs is being developed by the nation's two rivals in pay cable television, Home Box Office and Showtime Networks Inc. 
 As part of a settlement of a $2.4 billion antitrust suit that Showtime's parent, Viacom Inc., had filed against HBO's parent, Time Warner Inc., the Avis and Hertz of premium cable channels agreed to undertake joint marketing and advertising programs aimed at reversing viewers' waning interest in their services.
Growth in pay television has stalled the last two years, a victim of the sour economy and the popularity of videocassette recorders. Perhaps an even more fundamental problem has been competition from basic cable, the entry-level package of programming that subscribers begin getting when they sign up for service.
As viewers continue to perceive improvements in basic cable -- networks like CNN, Discovery, Lifetime, MTV, TBS and TNT -- pay cable seems to be getting relegated to the status of a luxury.
"People with three pay services are dropping the third or, if you have two, you're dropping the second," Larry Gerbrandt, a senior analyst at Paul Kagan Associates, a cable television industry consulting company, said in a telephone interview yesterday from Carmel, Calif.
"At a time when neither service is growing," he added, "it makes sense to see if cooperation won't benefit both. It's not like both of them are making so much money they can afford not to cooperate."
Still, the $64,000 question -- as they used to say on the old television show that might one day rerun on cable -- is whether the two archrivals can overcome their traditional antipathy and cohabit peacefully. At this point, as the two sides meet to plan five joint promotions during 1993, they are expressing optimism about working in tandem.
"Everybody's feeling pretty positive about it," said Denny Wilkinson, senior vice president of consumer marketing at HBO in New York.
"Once people got over the shock of coordinating a campaign with Showtime," he added, "we all felt this was a good thing."
In a separate interview, Nora Ryan, senior vice president of marketing at Showtime in New York, said: "The first couple of meetings have been interesting. Who'd ever sat down with a competitor and shared enough information to build a campaign together?"
Though "it felt funny," she added, "actually, there's been a lot of camaraderie."
For the five promotions, each lasting around six weeks, HBO and Showtime will spend the largest sum ever devoted to cable promotion. The amount, which the services declined to disclose, will pay for television and radio commercials, direct-mail brochures, free previews, print advertisements and other pitches.
The promotional periods are a blend of when each service has usually run its separate promotions. They will run from Jan. 4 through Feb. 14, March 15 through April 25, June 28 through Aug. 8, Sept. 6 through Oct. 17 and Nov. 1 through Dec. 12.
Both companies' agencies in New York will cooperate on the promotions. HBO uses BBDO for image advertising and Kobs & Draft Advertising for direct response, while Showtime uses Amil Gargano & Partners for image advertising and Wunderman Worldwide for direct response.
Mr. Gerbrandt of Kagan Associates said one fact that augured well for the joint venture is that HBO and Showtime have been cooperating on operating a basic-cable network, Comedy Central, which was formed by a merger of their competing comedy-programming services.
In addition to the joint promotions, each pay-cable service will continue its own separate advertising. Later this month, for instance, Kobs & Draft will introduce a campaign for Multiplex, HBO's multichannel service that was created to broaden programming variety -- thereby attacking the nagging problem that no matter when a viewer tunes into pay television, one of the "Porky's" movies seems to be on.
The settlement of the antitrust suit, reached on Aug. 20, ended legal wrangling that began when Showtime sued HBO in May 1989, accusing its larger rival of predatory practices like putting pressure on the operators of local cable systems to favor HBO's services over Showtime's. HBO had always denied Showtime's charges; both companies said the settlement, which also included a "material" cash payment to Showtime by HBO, estimated at $75 million, was not an admission of wrongdoing.
HBO has around 17.3 million customers, plus 6.3 million for its sibling service, Cinemax; Showtime has about 7.3 million customers, plus 2.6 million for its sibling service, the Movie Channel.

HEADLINE: New Storm Brews On Whether Crime Has Roots in Genes

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
THE cancellation of an academic conference on genetics and crime this month has cast into the spotlight a long-simmering scientific debate on the roots of crime and how it can best be prevented.
The conference, "Genetic Factors in Crime: Findings, Uses and Implications," was to have been held beginning Oct. 9 at the University of Maryland. The National Institutes of Health withdrew funds, saying the conference too readily accepted the notion that violence and crime had genetic causes. 
 But interviews with many of the experts invited to the conference and with others doing research on the roots of crime suggest that had the conference been held, it would have focused on the ethical issues raised by research seeking to link genetics and crime, not on promoting such studies.
And the scientific consensus among these experts seems to be that any inherited personality traits related to crime make a mild and indirect contribution, at best, to the broad mix of life circumstances that lead to a criminal career.
"No one would have claimed there are anything like crime genes," said David Wasserman, a lawyer at the Institute for Philosophy and Public Policy, who organized the conference. "Our purpose was to look at the implications of the genetic research."
Indeed, the first session was to have reviewed a criminological fad of the 1970's, the notion that an extra Y chromosome led some men to be highly aggressive and prone to violent crimes. Later research showed that there was no relationship between having the XYY pattern and criminality.
The objections to the conference were led by Dr. Peter Breggin, a Washington psychiatrist who charged that the meeting was part of a "violence initiative," a Federal research agenda that he said included finding a genetic marker that would identify children at high risk of becoming criminals, and plans to deter them through medications.
But the conference prospectus notes that should genetic markers one day be found for tendencies, like impulsivity, that are loosely linked to crime, they would probably "have little specificity, sensitivity or explanatory power: most people with the markers will not be criminals" and "most criminals will not have the markers."
Dr. Breggin said his accusations were based on remarks made by Dr. Frederick Goodwin, director of the National Institute of Mental Health, at a meeting of the National Mental Health Advisory Council on Feb. 11. Controversy over a statement by Dr. Goodwin at that meeting, which seemed to compare inner cities to jungles, led to his resignation as head of the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration.
At the meeting, Dr. Goodwin spoke of planning for a "violence initiative," which, among other goals, would seek to find biological correlates of violence in males, detecting them early in life, and seeking to prevent their expression. He also asserted that adoption studies had shown that genetic factors in violence and aggression were "very strong." Dr. Goodwin declined to be interviewed.
But Dr. Susan Solomon, chief of the Violence and Traumatic Stress Research Branch of the mental health institute, said, "None of our research on violence deals with genetics, and I don't know of any research program in a Federal agency that fits" Dr. Breggin's description, which she said seem to have distorted Dr. Goodwin's remarks.
Dr. Solomon is head of the agency's "violence consortium" which coordinates research on the topic. She said that genetic research "showed that if biology played a role, it was minor in crime and nonexistent in violence, and it is such a poor predictor of crime that it is useless for intervention."
The issue of Federal violence research will be examined on Sept. 25 by a panel led by Representative John Conyers, Democrat of Michigan, at a meeting of the Congressional Black Caucus, whose members have been critical of the genetic research.
The bulk of the genetic studies have been done in Scandinavian countries, where there are meticulous records of adoptions, twins and crimes. However, because social and economic inequalities are far more pronounced in this country, these factors are likely to be much stronger influences than genetics on criminality in America, several experts said.
"It's questionable whether genes would have much effect on crime among people who live in an American city," said Dr. Gregory Carey, a behavior geneticist at the University of Colorado who has just finished a review of studies that have tried to link heredity to crime. His review will be published as part of a report by the National Academy of Sciences in November.
"There's no DNA segment that codes for crime," said Dr. Carey, one of the researchers invited to the University of Maryland meeting. "There's a multitude of social, personality, cognitive and other variables that intercede between the level of DNA and a complex behavior like crime. My view is that the idea there could be a genetic marker for crime is wild-eyed speculation or science fiction."
Still, biological research on crime has its proponents. "It's difficult to find any form of behavior without some biological basis," said Dr. James Q. Wilson, a professor of management and public policy at the University of California at Los Angeles. "It's a very promising line of research."
 
Complexity of Criminal Behavior
 "What's farfetched is the notion that investigating this is going to lead to some test to spot proto-criminals in the third grade," Dr. Wilson said. "Criminality is far too complex a behavior to try to predict. But once you find a biological basis for a behavior, you can try to find out how to help people cope. Suppose the link is impulsivity, an inability to defer gratification. It might be you could design education programs to teach criminals to readjust their time horizon."
The most commonly cited study supporting the links between genetics and crime was published in the journal Science in 1983 by Dr. Sarnoff Mednick, a psychologist at the University of Southern California. In that study, Dr. Mednick compared criminal convictions of 14,427 men adopted in Denmark between 1927 and 1947 with the criminal records of their biological parents.
Dr. Mednick found there was a genetic effect for property crimes like stealing. Biological fathers of adopted men who had several convictions for theft were also likely to have had many such convictions.
But he found no direct inherited tendency for violence from parent to child. "If there were any genetic effect for violent crimes, we would have picked it up," said Dr. Mednick, who was also to have attended the canceled meeting.
Instead, he found that rather than having a violent parent, those men who committed violent crimes tended to have a mother who was mentally ill and a father who committed property crimes.
The findings puzzle Dr. Mednick. "I don't know what's being inherited when it comes to violence," he said. "It may be a lack of responsiveness in the autonomic nervous system, which impairs moral learning in the adopted children. But I wouldn't try to suppress such a trait, even if we could find a marker for it. Doing so sounds repressive to me. You might also suppress other more positive qualities, like creativity."
Geneticists see more sense in seeking a genetic basis for biological conditions, like diseases, than for social phenomena like crime.
Dr. Jonathan Beckwith, a geneticist at Harvard Medical School, said, "There's a spectrum from clear-cut biological diseases, where genetics is a sound avenue of research, to very complex behavior like criminality, where the social components are clearly so strong and genetic research is not fruitful." Dr. Beckwith is a member of the Human Genome Project's Group on Ethical, Legal, and Social Implications, which was helping finance the canceled conference.
Many criminologists shy away from biological explanations of crime, in part because criminal careers seem largely the outcome of a long chain of psychological and social events, and in part because there is a long history in the field of debunked claims like those for the XYY chromosome.
One of the first such theories was put forth just before the turn of the century by Cesare Lombroso, an Italian anthropologist who asserted that facial features, like eyebrows that grow together, were signs of a criminal character. In the 1920's and 1930's, the eugenics movement in America claimed that immigrant groups like the Irish, Italians, Jews, and Southern Europeans had higher crime rates because they came from genetically flawed stock. And in the 1950's, a psychologist, W. H. Sheldon, proposed that "mesomorphs," with a heavy-boned, muscular body type, were predisposed to crime.
 
New Zealand Study
 "Every 30 years or so biological explanations of crime come back into fashion, but then fade," said Dr. Terrie Moffitt, a psychologist at the University of Wisconsin, who was also to have attended the meeting.
In a study of 500 boys in New Zealand who were followed from infancy to age 18, Dr. Moffitt said she had found that "only 4 percent or so of boys are antisocial at all ages," though if infractions like drinking were included, almost all boys broke the law at one time or another.
Dr. Moffitt added: "While it's plausible that there's a biological basis to the lawbreaking of the most delinquent boys, they also come from the most troubled homes and worst neighborhoods. You really can't say if it's a genetic or social cause."
That problem, said Dr. Moffitt, clouds the interpretation of findings reported this year by Dr. Allen Beck, a demographer at the Justice Department, that more than half of imprisoned juveniles and a third of adult inmates have immediate family members who have also been imprisoned. There is no way to tell, from these findings alone, whether it is genetics or family environment -- or both to differing degrees -- that pass along a tendency to crime.
The biological and social views can have vastly different implications for how to prevent crime. If a criminal nature is genetically predetermined, society might seek to identify those who carry the problem genes and intervene early -- perhaps by the methods to which Dr. Breggin objects -- in order to nip a budding criminal career. But if criminals are shaped by adverse life circumstance, then preventive measures are to be found in improving those conditions.
The bulk of studies on the roots of crime have examined social factors. For example, "harsh and erratic discipline is three to four times more common in the family history of children who become delinquents than those who do not," said Dr. Felton Earls, a psychiatric epidemiologist at the Harvard School of Public Health. "And being from certain neighborhoods rather than others puts kids at a six to eight times greater risk for becoming criminals."
Another key factor, said Dr. Earls, is a child's verbal I.Q. "Criminals, on average, have a verbal I.Q. at school age about eight points lower than the norm."
The typical route to a criminal career for a child born in an American inner city, said Dr. Earls, begins with prenatal factors like a mother "who drinks alcohol and takes drugs like crack, which have a damaging effect on the central nervous system of the fetus, leading to later cognitive deficits."
Another common hazard of early life in inner city neighborhoods is exposure to high levels of lead from peeling paint and auto fumes. "Lead exposure seems to lower I.Q. and impair concentration, and make children hyperactive, exactly the pattern we think predicts crime in adolescence," said Dr. Earls.
When such children arrive at first grade, "they are unprepared to learn," said Dr. Earls. "They are more aggressive than other kids, have conduct problems, and low reading achievement, a pattern that solidifies by third grade, at which point these kids get marked as problems and put in special education classes. As early as third grade, they are stigmatized, and at a social disadvantage."
It is during the years from 14 to 18 that most crimes are committed. By late adolescence, among teen-agers who manage to get jobs, finish their education or get married, there is a sharp dropoff in the numbers of young men who commit crimes. Those who fail to find such a rudder in life are far more likely to continue their criminal careers into adulthood, Dr. Earls said.
Researchers like Dr. Earls are seeking to find the points at which some extra help might shift youngsters away from a path toward a life in crime. "We need to find out where in this process we can intervene most effectively," Dr. Earls said.


GRAPHIC: Historically, various theories have posited a biological or hereditary basis for crime or criminality.
Chart: "Discerning "Nature" in Crime"
 "Darwinism." Sir Francis Galton, Charles Darwin's cousin, studied how humans inherit physical and behavioral traits and coined the name eugenics.
 1857. Degeneracy. "Traite des Degenerescences" contended that criminality, alcoholism, insanity and feeblemindedness werfe manifestations of a single entity: hereditary degeneration. Originating in one generation through drink, poor working conditions or moral violations, it could be inherited.
 1876. Physiognomy. Cesare Lombroso published "L'Uomo Delinquente," stating that criminals were the products of heredity and could be recognized by features like small restless eyes (thieves) or bright eyes and cracked voices (sex criminals).
 1874. The Jukes study. Richard L. Dugdale produced a very influential study of an Irish family he called Jukes in which he traced what he called hereditary crime. He unearthed 709 members, of whome 18 kept brothels, 128 had been prostitutes, more than 200 had been on relief, and 76 were convicted criminals.
 1905-1930. Eugenics. Eugenicists who believed that much crime is hereditary successfully campaigned in many states for the sterilization of criminals. Although eugenics attracted many prominent people, including scientists, most eugenics research was later rejected as careless and inaccurate.
 1970's. XYY. A later discredited study associated crime and violence with this chromosomal configuration.
 
(Source: "Eugenics," Heller (Rutgers University Press) (pg. C7)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Their Own Words

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

 BODY:

PRESIDENT BUSH
 In a speech in Colville, Wash., yesterday.
"Technology is key not just to our economic future, but our environmental future as well. . . . Command and control regulation locks this old technology in place. You need incentives -- you need investment -- to make new breakthroughs possible. These programs all reject the old command-and-control mentality that drove up the costs, reduced jobs and never achieved the environmental progress that we desired. 
 Under Governor Clinton, Arkansas ranks 50th -- worst in the country -- for utility and state environmental initiatives, according to an independent analysis by the Institute for Southern Studies. But in his zeal to capture his party's nomination, Governor Clinton has made every promise to every environmental group that sent him a survey. And he and his running mate are advancing a philosophy that goes back to where command-and-control regulation is the only solution -- a philosophy that not only cuts jobs, but could impede technology, environmental progress, not promote it. And when it comes to the environment, I believe extremism on either side is no virtue. Cooperation, innovation, a faith in technology -- these are the virtues that will allow us to protect both jobs and nature."
 
VICE PRESIDENT DAN QUAYLE
 In a speech to workers at at the J. R. Simplot Company, a potato processing concern in Caldwell, Idaho, yesterday.
"This free trade agreement is good for the U.S., it is good for Idaho, it is good for you. And the reason it is good for you is because we will create more jobs and more opportunity. According to our statistics, 170,000 new jobs will be created. We should welcome a stronger Mexico. A stronger Mexico will give us more export opportunity. By having more export opportunity we will have more jobs here in Idaho and more jobs in America. And that's why this free trade agreement is a good agreement. We're now in the post-cold-war era and it's a big question of which way the United States and which way the world's going to go. Are we going to go back to the days of protectionism, where we create barriers or are we going to go the way of the future where we knock down barriers, knock down tariffs and if in fact we become protectionist you know what's going to happen. There's going to be a whole lot of people put out of work because protectionism, it may sound good, in the short term it may be something that you would want, but in the long term it is bad for America."
 
SENATOR AL GORE
 In a speech to workers at Bell Textron in Fort Worth yesterday.
"Bill Clinton and I support a strong national defense and we're not going to make any unwise cut. But, of course as I said before, whoever is victorious in this election in November you're going to see reduction in defense spending. I think everyone understands that with the collapse of Communism and the end of the Soviet Union, that's just in the works. The difference is that Bill Clinton and I have a defense conversion program and we have a sense of what is useful to the United State of America in terms of infrastructure to take the men and women who have helped to win the cold war and instead of leaving them out in the cold, use their talents and energies and expertise and experience to build up this country."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Movement on Debates Reflects Shifting Needs

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUBBOCK, Tex., Sept. 14

 BODY:
The sudden proposal by the Bush campaign to open direct negotiations with Gov. Bill Clinton's staff on the subject of Presidential debates means more than just a realization by Republicans that their strategy of holding out was hurting them politically.
It is, perhaps, also an indication that they sense their campaign is listing, and that a dramatic event is needed to right the ship. 
 But the letters sent by the Bush campaign chairman, Robert M. Teeter, to the Commission on Presidential Debates and Mickey Kantor, chairman of the Clinton campaign, also mean that after weeks of curious silence by all parties involved, the debate about debates will move toward center stage this week.
That movement seems impelled by two factors: President Bush's inability to get within hailing distance of the Arkansas Governor in the polls and the awakening of the Democrats from their slumber on the debate issue.
When the President decided on Sept. 3 to reject the debate format set up by a bipartisan commission, he knew he was running a political risk. Such last-minute wrangling was supposed to have been ended in 1988 by the establishment of the commission, which is jointly headed by Frank J. Fahrenkopf, the former Republican Party chairman, and Paul G. Kirk Jr., the former Democratic Party chairman.
The commission interviewed former candidates, academics and news media critics and developed a proposal, immediately accepted by the Democrats, for three Presidential debates and one Vice-Presidential debate. Seeking a more freewheeling discussion, the commission recommended that all four debates be led by a single moderator, rather than a panel of reporters who, in the past, seemed more interested in trying to come up with the most unusual question than in pressing a candidate for clarification.
Assuming that all parties return to the commission's timetable, the first of the three Presidential debates is scheduled for East Lansing, Mich., a scant eight days from now.
Mr. Bush's decision to reject the commission's format was covered with the fingerprints of James A. Baker 3d, his new White House chief of staff, and reflected tactical considerations. Four years ago, as he negotiated the debate format with the managers of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's campaign, Mr. Baker told them he believed that as debates approach, the campaign becomes "frozen." Voters who are undecided, or only leaning one way or the other, become trapped in amber, waiting to see what the debates will show.
With his candidate trailing in the polls, Mr. Baker probably felt he could ill-afford such a freeze at this stage. Putting the debates on hold gives the Bush forces time to close the gap before the a pre-debate freeze sets in.
Meanwhile, Mr. Bush's activities have been intended to close that gap: ladling out Federal pork at every opportunity, approving the sale of military hardware to Taiwan and Saudi Arabia while talking about the job-creating benefits of such sales, raising the issue of Mr. Clinton draft record and releasing a new economic plan.
But even with these moves, Mr. Bush seems unable to make major headway. Even here in his adopted home state of Texas, polls conducted by the Democratic Party and The Dallas Morning News show the race to be a tossup. Given his standing in the polls, Mr. Bush may feel he needs a defining event -- like the serious wounding of Mr. Clinton in a nationally televised debate.
But while the President has been taking his time on the debates, he has not been pushed very hard by the Clinton campaign.
Indeed, until last weekend, when they announced they were sending advance teams to East Lansing to prepare for the scheduled debate, the Democrats seemed content to maintain a front-runner's stance.
"Every minute spent talking about debates is a minute taken away from the issues," George Stephanopoulos, the Clinton campaign's communication's director, said last week. "We've not going to make this the center of our campaign."
For the Democrats the question of the debates is not as straightforward as first appears. "I think the Clinton people are of two minds on the issue of the debates," said Susan Estrich, who managed Mr. Dukakis's campaign four years ago. "They have an opportunity to show that they can hold their own, that they are not a risk and they are a safe vote for change. On the other hand, they're ahead, and debates are always risky. If Clinton were behind, he would be pushing like hell for debates."
But even as the Democrats nudge the process forward, they will feel no need to push too hard for debates. The polls and the Bush campaign may do the pushing for them.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush, in Far West, Sides With Loggers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLVILLE, Wash., Sept. 14

 BODY:
President Bush rushed today to side with Far West loggers in a war with environmentalists over a threatened owl, vowing to block renewal of the Endangered Species Act unless it takes into account jobs and the economy while protecting vanishing creatures.
The President's position, long implicit but not formally announced until now, would force a basic change in the 19-year-old law, one of the strongest environmental measures ever enacted. 
 "The Endangered Species Act was intended as a shield for species against the effects of major construction projects like highways and dams, not a sword aimed at the jobs, families and communities of entire regions like the Northwest," Mr. Bush said. "It's time to put people ahead of owls."
The law now requires the Government to take steps to protect threatened wildlife, regardless of the economic effects on towns or regions where the wildlife live.
 
Effort to Change Law
 Mr. Bush's statement marked a significant step in what has become an election-year transition from advocate of strict environmental laws to a candidate who sees economic benefits in relaxing environmental restrictions.
In the first two years of his Presidency, Mr. Bush pushed through a Clean Air Act that strengthened controls on virtually every source of air pollution in the country, barred construction of a new dam in Colorado, halted oil exploration off both coasts and ordered a Government-owned electric utility to reduce pollution that clouded the Grand Canyon.
And his Administration added plants and animals to the endangered species list at an annual rate faster than any President since Richard M. Nixon.
But since last summer, when Mr. Bush approved a proposal that would open half the nation's wetlands to development, the President has favored an approach to environmental policy aimed at protecting jobs. In January, he halted new environmental regulations that he said would be too costly, and he speeded up those the White House considered friendly to business. He removed restrictions on logging in the national forests, approved efforts by the Justice Department to relax enforcement of strip-mining laws and negotiated out of an international treaty's restrictions on American production of carbon dioxide.
 
Decades of Bitter Debate
 The Endangered Species Act has been a point of contention between conservative and liberal political interests for decades, precisely because it is so unbending. In the past, Federal courts have halted billion-dollar dams to save tiny snail-darters in the waters below them, and have limited subdivisions to save desert kangaroo rats.
Here in Washington, where timber companies are struggling in court with environmentalists over the fate of a threatened bird, the northern spotted owl, Mr. Bush assailed the act as a "broken" law that he pledged "will not stand." He offered no details of his favored replacement, except to say that it should give "greater consideration to jobs, families and communities." But his sentiment was clear.
The challenge to put people ahead of owls drew cheers from nearly 5,000 people crammed into a chilly local lumberyard here, although residents said none of the forests in this part of the state are home to the owls.
Colville, near Spokane, is a Republican stronghold in nominally Democratic Washington. The dispute over the owls is centered mostly in far western Washington and Oregon, where the logging industry is badly depressed and Mr. Bush is far less popular.
It also was not clear what Mr. Bush's threat to block renewal of the endangered species law actually means in practical terms. Congress has not sought to re-authorize the act this year, in part, Republicans charge, because it would force Democratic lawmakers to take a stand on the spotted owl.
The White House is seeking instead to place language that would reinterpret the act in the $7 billion Interior Department appropriations bill, which is now in a House-Senate conference.
A spokesman for the department, Steve Goldstein, said Mr. Bush's challenge was technically aimed at a future re-authorization of the act, but he refused to rule out a Presidential veto of the Interior bill if his language was rejected.
The Endangered Species Act, signed by President Nixon and enacted in 1973, prohibits the Government, with very rare execeptions, from considering economic factors in identifying animals and plants that are threatened with extinction. The law allows the President to name a Cabinet-level committee, popularly known as the God Squad, which can approve plans to save a species even if the palns take into account economic considerations like the number of jobs affected. But that has only been done twice: this year and in 1979. The first time, the committee approved a dam in Wyoming near a habitat of the endangered whooping crane. Last May, the panel voted to allow logging in Oregon on 1,700 acres that are a home of the spotted owl.
Environmentalists swiftly assailed Mr. Bush's remarks today.
"A cost-benefit analysis would gut the Endangered Species Act," said Eric Glitzenstein, a Washington environmental lawyer who has been an adversary of the Interior Department. "It would substitute an economic judgment for a scientific and biological judgment on the status of species."
 
Popular Stand Here
 But Mr. Bush's comments were cheered by hundreds of members of the Alliance for Freedom, a national group that hopes to roll back environmental restrictions.
"This is extremely encouraging to those of us who have been a besieged community the last four years," said Larry Mason, executive director of the Washington Commercial Forest Action Committee, in Forks, Wash. "Finally, there is a discussion on the Presidential level of the appropriateness of a law like the Endangered Species Act."
In his remarks today, Mr. Bush sought to depict his position on the act as a moderate one, saying Congress had always contemplated a balance between environment and economy.
"Not far from here is a timber town called Forks," Mr. Bush said. "Like Colville, Forks supported a mill, and the mill supported a community. Because of a lack of timber, the mill had to close. Today unemployment at Forks is at 20 percent. The car dealership has closed. The clothing store is gone."
Mr. Bush maintained there was a single reason for the economic devastation: "The balance has been lost" between economics and environmental needs.
"Today," he asserted, "when harvesting on Federal timberland is stopped outright by 13 different lawsuits under 7 different statutes, each inconsistent with the others, the balance has been lost. It's time to fight for jobs, families and communities."
Flying by helicopter into this town of 5,500 people deep in the foothills of the Cascade Mountains, Mr. Bush also opened his Federal grab-bag again, as he has repeatedly in recent weeks, to strengthen local industry.
He said he would not sign a new species law unless he is given a specific plan "to harvest enough timber to keep timber families working in 1993 and beyond." He also promised to mandate that all logs cut from Federal lands in Washington be processed at local mills, rather than exported uncut to foreign ports. On Thursday, the President moved to keep idle timber mills open by waiving Federal rules that slow the cutting of dead and dying timber in the West, where drought and disease are rampant in forests.
The exporting of uncut logs, productivity improvements in lumbering and a shift of the industry to the South have contributed to a large loss of jobs in the Western timber business.
Washington and Oregon are at the center of the debate over saving the spotted owl, a subspecies now reduced by logging to about 3,000 nesting pairs in Washington, Oregon and California. The owl lives mostly in the dwindling stands of old-growth forests that are among the last areas untouched by timber firms.
