HEADLINE: Fernandez to Let Students Transfer to Any District

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez will let parents send their children to any school outside their district throughout New York City's five boroughs next year, giving the city one of the largest school-choice arrangements in the nation.
The plan will let a Staten Island parent shift a child as far away as the north Bronx or a parent from a shabby quarter of Jackson Heights, Queens, send a child to a tidy suburban patch of Bayside, Queens. Parents who live in boroughs outside Manhattan but work there will be able to drop their children off at schools near their offices, as long as space is available. 
 The plan, which applies to elementary and junior high schools but not to high schools, requires no formal approval by the Board of Education, said Robin Willner, Mr. Fernandez's director of strategic planning.
A nine-page draft has been circulating among the city's 32 district superintendents for their suggested revisions, but Mr. Fernandez, who has long advocated the principle of choice, is committed to going ahead with the basic ideas in the plan in time for next September's schools opening, aides said.
School choice is perhaps the most talked about idea in education today, with both Presidential candidates endorsing the concept in different forms. Since 1988, 13 states have adopted some version. Advocates of choice say that it will stimulate competition among schools, forcing less successful ones to improve their instruction or risk losing their students.
How many of the city's 700,000 elementary and junior high school pupils might take advantage of such a plan is unclear. Moreover, the plan will be limited by several unshakable realities, including no money for transportation, overcrowding in many of the best schools and a reluctance by some superintendents to participate.
Experience in the states that have adopted plans for choice has shown that relatively few parents will send their children to places where they may encounter unfamiliar streets or cultures. In Minnesota, for example, less than 1 percent -- roughly 20,000 children -- took advantage of a statewide open-enrollment plan.
However, the denser urban landscape of New York, with its sprawling subway and bus system, suggests that the experience of relatively rustic Minnesota may not be conclusive. Indeed, tenacious parents have always been able to find ways of sending children to preferable schools outside their immediate zones, often using relatives' addresses as their own in hopes of getting into a school they want in what one superintendent called a "black market economy."
"The people who are more knowledgable and able to manipulate the system have had better access to that economy," said Anthony J. Alvarado, superintendent of District 2 in Manhattan. "What the regulation does is put the rules on the table for everybody."
 
Popular but Overcrowded
 Some choice is already available. Mr. Alvarado is among a handful of the city's superintendents who have experimented with letting parents choose any school within their district, and who have accepted students from outside the district as well.
Still, the New York plan faces some obstacles. Many of the system's 633 elementary and 179 intermediate schools are overcrowded and cannot squeeze in students from other districts. Other popular ones like Public School 87 on the West Side of Manhattan already have to turn back scores of students from inside and outside their districts.
The Fernandez plan still guarantees enrollment to children who live in a school's geographic zone, leaving only unfilled seats for inter-district transfers. The plan also says that children who live within the district, though not within a school's immediate zone, have priority over children who live outside the district.
With the system's threadbare budget, there is no money available for large-scale bus transportation, though children will still be able to use bus and subway passes given to students who live more than a mile and a half from their schools. But Ms. Willner said that Mr. Fernandez asked officials on Monday to study the rerouting of some bus routes for inter-district transfers.
A key to the plan's effectiveness is the cooperation of the district superintendents, who must approve any transfers into their districts. Some superintendents of stable districts are reluctant to ruffle the calm by opening their doors to outsiders who may include unruly or laggard students. Max Messer, superintendent of District 8 in the east Bronx and the head of the Association of Superintendents, said he saw merits to the plan but was worried that some schools seeking to entice students might offer deceptive advertising. Other superintendents are said to be worried about having students lured away.
 
Concept of Choice Legitimized
 Nevertheless, the mere fact of the existence of a choice plan is guaranteed to change the city's schoolgoing patterns and traditions.
"The Chancellor has legitimized the concept of choice, which we accept in every aspect of our life," said Sy Fliegel, a former district superintendent who has become a nationally known champion of choice. "People will no longer say, 'I don't want to be in this school.' Now you are here because you want to be here."
Some parents are concerned that mediocre schools will be stripped of their best and brightest students, who will seek out other schools. Others, however, are delighted.
"We should all have the choice of sending our children where we think it's more fitting," said Nadine Dominique, a Brooklyn parent. "If you don't live in a nice area, your child is stuck going to a school even if it's not up to par."
Her family, of Haitian origin, already provides an illustration of how choice would work. She lives in Midwood, but did not like the crumbling classrooms of one school near her home and the small number of black teachers at another. She now drops off her 6-year-old, David Ashley Dominique, at the Midtown West School on West 47th Street -- a vest-pocket school whose multicultural approach she favors -- then continues by subway to her job in the Wall Street area.
Members of the Board of Education have been consulted, and none objected to the concept, said H. Carl McCall, the president. Sandra Feldman and Donald Singer, presidents of the teachers and principals unions respectively, said they liked the plan overall, but had some misgivings about what could happen to schools that students began to forsake.
Ms. Feldman said she hoped the school system would offer help to schools that lose substantial enrollment, while Mr. Singer said the plan should begin in a only a few pilot districts to test its impact.
"Otherwise schools that need resources will wind up with less and less," Mr. Singer said.
Some districts, particularly in Manhattan, already informally permit transfers when space allows. At P.S. 41 in Greenwich Village, many students are children of workers at St. Vincent's Hospital nearby who do not live in the district and, said Mr. Alvarado, lend the school diversity.
The new plan says nothing about transferring children between schools within the same school district, since those decisions are up to local school boards. Districts like 2, 3 and 4 in Manhattan already permit children to enroll in any school within the district. The plan also says nothing about the high schools, which are controlled by the central Board of Education and already permit options for enrollment far from home.
 
2 Permissions Not Needed
 The plan was described in a detailed nine-page draft that was provided to The New York Times by a high school official who is in favor of the plan. There have been earlier news articles in which Mr. Fernandez spoke about his plans to broaden choice for parents and to let parents send children near where they work.
The plan's major departure is that it permits a transfer with only the permission of the so-called "receiving" district, not the "sending" one. Until now, permission of both superintendents was required. Many superintendents were reluctant to release students because the loss meant an accompanying loss of city, state and Federal dollars.
The plan says that students can transfer out of the district to a school closer to a parent's workplace, to a school offering a "more appropriate" curriculum, to a school that offers better health or safety conditions or has a more robust guidance program, or for "other special circumstances." Mr. Fliegel said that in those four reasons most parents should be able to find a valid pretext for a transfer.
The plans forces superintendents to provide a valid reason for rejecting applicants, and it restricts the ability of principals or superintendents to weed out students or parents they don't like. It discourages interviews and home-made tests, for example, though it permits the use of standardized tests or auditions for so-called gifted and talented programs.
 
Recruiting Is Possibility
 Ms. Willner said the Chancellor preferred that school use random selection systems or "first come, first served" as a basis for admission.
Any recruitment program, the plan says, would have to be reviewed by the board's office of zoning and integration to make sure it does not increase the numbers of segregated classes in the system.

HEADLINE: Economists View Election

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 15

 BODY:
A poll published on Monday by the National Association of Business Economists found two-thirds of the membership expecting that the Democratic nominee, Bill Clinton, would be elected in November and that economic growth under him would probably be higher than during a second Bush term.
 Of 243 respondents to the survey, 52.8 percent said growth would be better under Mr. Clinton, 22.7 percent said it would be worse and 24.5 percent said it would be the same. A majority, 52.8 percent, also said that regulation, inflation, the budget deficit and interest rates would be higher than under Mr. Bush while the dollar and the stock market would be lower. 
 A majority also held that the trade deficit under Mr. clinton would be either higher than during a second Bush term or would be no different than under Mr. Bush.

HEADLINE: Letter: On Trade;
Just a Push to End Arab Boycott of Israel

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"In Israel, for the First Time . . ." (editorial, Aug. 30) refers to the procedures of the Arab boycott of Israel but fails to distinguish between the primary and the secondary boycotts and glosses over the capricious way in which they are enforced.
The primary boycott refers to the concerted policy of all 20 Arab states to refrain from diplomatic, political, economic and cultural relations with Israel. The secondary boycott is an effort to punish commercial companies all over the world with economic ties to Israel. Only 12 Arab nations, principally the Persian Gulf states and Libya, participate in that boycott. 
 States joining in the secondary boycott are listed by the U.S. Treasury Secretary, as required by our Export Administration Act. The secondary boycott is administered by the Arab League from Damascus.
The Arab League boycott regulations forbid dealing with private companies that violate any of 13 specified prohibitions. These include establishing a factory or general agency in Israel, providing technical advice to Israeli companies, investing in Israeli enterprises or being controlled by "pro-Zionist natural persons."
Curiously there is no specific ban on the purchase of Israeli goods or the sale to Israel of foreign goods. The boycott regulations do not, as you state, refer to "strategic goods" in prescribing which products may or may not be sold to Israel.
A company violating boycott regulations may be placed on the Arab blacklist, which theoretically denies it contracts with Arab countries or customers. In practice, however, the Arab states ignore the regulations when it is to their advantage.
Thus, Saudi Arabia allowed the Coca-Cola Company to build a plant in the kingdom although it was on the Arab League blacklist. General Electric, which sells Israel fighter-plane engines, has never been blacklisted, nor has any other prominent military contractor, for the simple reason that the Arab states rely on these contractors for their own military supplies.
The Arab boycott is weakening. Kuwait, which had been most energetic in enforcing boycott regulations, quickly dropped its boycott, at least against American companies, after Desert Storm. It would require only a slight push from the Bush-Baker team to persuade Saudi Arabia to follow Kuwait's example. If Saudi Arabia, the largest Arab market for Western goods, abandoned its secondary boycott, the boycott would quickly collapse. Such a move would of course be a help to American companies that must compete with foreign companies not subject to anti-boycott restrictions in their own countries.
There is a widespread sentiment in Congress for an end to the boycott. The Wirth amendment forbidding the award of defense contracts to foreign companies complying with the boycott was adopted last September by a vote of 99 to 0. More recently the Republican Party platform adopted last month specifically called for an end to the boycott. A slight push should topple this outstanding obstruction to the principle of free trade.
 
WILL MASLOW
Gen. Counsel and Editor, Boycott Report, American Jewish Congress
New York, Sept. 1, 1992

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
Great Expectations

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
When liberal Democrats talk about the Presidential election these days, they seem a bit like the bride determined that the groom not see her before the ceremony. They fear a jinx -- the jinx of optimism in this, their best-chance year in many years.
Which goes some way toward explaining why, if Bill Clinton wins -- don't say it, don't say it, don't even say it, they keen in certain circles, afraid of the unfamiliar feel of hope -- he will take office with the enormous curse of great expectations. 
 You can sense it even now, one enormous what-if intake of breath in a body politic. Like some Arkansas Atlas with other people's stuff sitting on his shoulders, Mr. Clinton will have traded in his own considerable baggage for the weight of a party that has been waiting to take power for a generation, a generation that has wondered how one of its own would shape public policy, and a public that is tired of more of the same.
Someone should make the guy a sampler: Be careful what you wish for; you might get it.
It is true that Mr. Clinton could make an enormous impact with certain constituencies early on. And he could do it with one hand tied behind his back. With the other, he could sign the Freedom of Choice Act, making access to abortion a legal right for American women, and the family leave bill, which provides for time off to care for a newborn, a sick child or a failing parent.
He could end the indefensible ban on gays in the military and order the F.D.A. to consider RU-486, the French abortion pill, purely on its medical merits, which would likely lead to its approval. President Clinton could make Mario Cuomo, Laurence Tribe or someone less showy but equally inclined to civil liberties a justice of the Supreme Court.
But those acts do not a hundred days make. Too moderate for some liberals, too liberal for some moderates; too business-oriented for environmentalists, too environmentally hip for big business types; too busy being preternaturally ambitious to be a true child of the counterculture, too hamstrung by political realities to make the sweeping changes implicit in the generational and party differences between him and his opponent -- Bill Clinton has a historic opportunity to disappoint.
This is partly, too, because the big issue of this campaign may be one that no one can crack. Mr. Bush's original problem with the economy was not inaction. It was reaction. He insisted that things were O.K.
I don't know why no adviser told the President that nothing makes a working person idled by a recession madder than being told everything is fine, except maybe hearing members of Congress moan about their salaries. Even today Mr. Bush is constitutionally incapable of talking about how bad things are without a chirpy addendum that recovery is right around the corner.
But the irony is that expectations for Mr. Bush, should he be re-elected, would be comparatively low; he need only do better than his first term, which would not be difficult. Many Americans, even some of his supporters, have accepted that the economy is an alligator and Mr. Bush is no alligator wrestler.
But empathy with our hard times will not be enough for Mr. Clinton, should he win. He has said he can wrestle the alligator, and he will be held to it. Caught between party stalwarts who never met an entitlement program they didn't like and long-view guys like Paul Tsongas, who say it's time to get serious about the deficit despite the sacrifice required -- and who admit that this is a difficult thing for an elected official who likes the sound of the words "second term" -- Mr. Clinton is certain to let part of his constituency down.
You can tell that some voters are hearing "Happy Days Are Here Again" in the poll figures and focus groups. People who feared they would not see a Federal abortion statute or an end to discrimination against gay citizens in the armed forces in their lifetime try to stop themselves from hoping too much.
Hoping too much can be a problem. While Mr. Clinton and his people are concentrating on the first Tuesday in November, they need to wrestle soon with how to mute and milk the sweeping expectations that accompany their unexpected good fortune. Otherwise the background music might well be Fred Astaire: "I'm Building Up to an Awful Let-Down."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Federal Reserve Goes Astray on Recession

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the third year of the recession, Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, is still fighting inflation. Yes, the Fed is supposed to fight inflation. William McC. Martin Jr., Fed chief under five Presidents, said in effect: "Our job is to lean against the economic winds. If an inflationary wind is blowing, we lean against that. If a deflationary wind is blowing, and prices fall, we do the opposite."
But the Fed's actions affect the economy in many ways, and it should do more, within its powers, to help the whole economy. This, Mr. Greenspan did not do. For example, the Fed, through its open market committee, could have bought more Treasury securities from the banks, giving the banks additional cash reserves for more generous loan policies toward business. This would have acted as a powerful stimulant for business to hire more people and give more jobs. 
 Instead, Mr. Greenspan relied on incrementally lowering the bank discount rate, thereby lowering interest rates generally. In a short-lived recession, like those from World War II up to the Bush Administration, this would stimulate business. But this is not a mercifully short recession.
Mr. Greenspan's policy of lowering the bank discount rate (and the whole complex of interest rates, and doing nothing else) had the effect of causing savers to transfer their savings out of the savings institutions because interest rates became so low. Savings then went into the stock market, boosting the value of stock shares, but not creating jobs.
 
BEVERLY KITCHING
Springfield, Ill., Sept. 1, 1992
 
The writer is professor emeritus of economics at City College of Chicago.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Insurer to Buy Olympia Office Tower

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Four days after New York City signed a bill granting tax breaks to property owners who modernize aging office buildings, Mutual of America said it had reached an agreement to buy and improve a vacant office tower on 320 Park Avenue from Olympia & York Developments Ltd..
The building, which has an asbestos problem, formerly served as the headquarters for the ITT Corporation and has reportedly cost Olympia & York about $20 million a year in taxes, upkeep and interest payments in the two years since it has had a prime tenant. 
 Mutual of America, the New York-based life insurer, intends to move from its leased space at 666 Fifth Avenue. It said it would need only a third of the 34-story building to house some 600 employees. It plans to fill the rest by investing $70 million into the building to remove the asbestos, improve its energy efficiency and give the facade a face lift.
 
Deal Aided by Law
 The purchase price was not disclosed, but Olympia & York has a $147 million mortgage on the property and had been asking $130 million to $150 million. One person involved in the deal said the price was in that range but fell short of the mortgage. That wrinkle complicated the negotiation, because Olympia & York had to work out an arrangement to deal with any shortfall with the syndicate of lenders, led by First Chicago, which holds the mortgage.
The deal, under negotiation for months, would reportedly never have been concluded without the passage on Friday of a bill giving strong financial incentives to property owners who buy and improve office towers south of 96th Street over the next two years. Owners who qualify for the program will see no change in their tax bills for eight years, after which the adjustments will be phased in.
Though Mutual of America's president, Thomas Moran, declined to estimate the value of those future tax benefits, real estate executives said that they would be worth the equivalent of $20 million today.
Mutual of America, which had spent five years searching for new headquarters in New York State so it could remain under the supervision of New York's insurance regulators, was believed to have lined up an attractive counteroffer on Long Island, and had conditioned any deal with Olympia & York on approval of the bill.
"We thought Mutual of America was at significant risk of leaving the city and we're delighted about their commitment to stay here and make a long-term commitment," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, a quasi-government agency.
 
Others to Benefit
 Other companies that are expected to benefit from the package of tax breaks are Prudential Securities and Barney's, though the tax breaks were not believed to be as crucial to their deals. Prudential, for instance, recently agreed to take space at One New York Plaza, in part because the building's owners agreed to pass along some of the expected tax benefits to it in the price of its lease. Barney's, a retailer with a strong downtown presence, was already renovating a midtown property where it hopes to open a new store when the new bill was signed.
"We're thrilled that the revised industrial development program, which the Mayor signed last week, has played such a critical role, exactly the kind of role we had hoped it to play," Mr. Weisbrod said, noting that the Mutual of America deal alone was expected to create 1,000 construction jobs.
The pending sale comes on the heels of another deal last week in which Olympia & York agreed to transfer control of a troubled property it owns at 55 Water Street to its bondholders. By pruning those portions of its American holdings that are in poor financial health, Olympia & York hopes to keep its healthier American properties out of a messy bankruptcy filing.
Until the recent office glut, both buildings, 55 Water Street and 320 Park Avenue, had been among the trophy properties in Olympia & York's glittering real estate empire.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
A Cheaper Way of Linking Offices

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Anticipating adoption of the North American Free Trade Agreement, the Mexican telephone company is about to initiate a sophisticated network service that should make it easier for multinational corporations to do business with, and within, Mexico.
The service, known as virtual private networks, is already wildly popular among business customers in the United States, allowing corporations to link far-flung branch offices with voice and data-communications circuits that can make phoning from coast to coast almost as fast and easy as calling a co-worker across the hall -- and at rates much lower than those on the regular long-distance network. 
 Extending such service south of the border could be a boon for business callers, because telephoning is notoriously frustrating in Mexico City and other large urban areas in Mexico. Only about one of two phone calls within the country is completed, and success in international calling is even more random.
The recently privatized Mexican phone company, Telefonos de Mexico, says it expects to sign within a week or so agreements with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the MCI Communications Corporation and the Sprint Corporation for establishing virtual private networks that would very likely allow businesses to connect multiple sites in Mexico as well as the United States.
The agreements will cover technical standards and the fees that carriers will pay each other for passing calls between their networks.
Telmex, as the Mexican phone company is known, said it had already signed Aereoboutique, a Mexican chain of duty-free shops at airports, to test such a network.
Hector Carlos, marketing vice president for Telmex in Mexico City, said the company was moving quickly to make life easier for corporate customers. In 1980, 10 percent of its long-distance market was international, he said. In 1990, it was 20 percent, and this year, it will be 23 percent, or some 1.5 billion minutes. That is the equivalent of more than 2,850 years of lucrative telephone talk, mostly to the United States. "So we are very interested in improving this market," Mr. Carlos said.
Virtual private networks are the successors to the private networks that beginning in the 1960's became the province of large corporations with the wealth to afford them and enough branch offices to provide sufficient calling volume. Without such critical mass, private networks do not warrant the expense of leasing dedicated telephone circuits from the phone company and devoting management resources to their design and supervision.
The large volume of calls that makes a private network feasible can lead to cost savings. Among other advantages -- and the one most noticeable to users -- is abbreviated dialing. Instead of dialing 10 numbers on a long-distance call, for example, a user can dial one digit -- say, an "8" -- wait for a dial tone, then dial four or five more digits. A high-speed computer, searching through a data base of telephone numbers and their shorter counterparts, might recognize that 8-1234 represents a company's Los Angeles office, whose phone number is actually 213-555-1234.
Virtual private networks, available in the United States for the last seven years or so, offer many of the same advantages, but at lower cost and with little of the technical and maintenance problems of a private network. (Still, anyone with a phone bill less than $50,000 a month might not find the service economical.) Through high-speed computers and sophisticated data bases, telephone companies can create the illusion of a private network, using their regular public-network equipment.
The market for such virtual private networks is already huge. The Yankee Group, a market research firm in Boston, estimates that 1992 revenue to carriers like Sprint, A.T.& T. and MCI will total $2.86 billion for virtual network services. Next year's projection: $3.9 billion.
To date, nearly all of the market is within the United States and the revenue has come from voice communications. But companies like General Electric, Olin, United Technologies and Xerox are using such networks for both voice and data communications, which can send electronic mail and computer-generated blueprints quickly across the country.
The Gartner Group, a research firm in Stamford, Conn., expects an explosion in foreign business. By 1996, the firm sees a $12.5 billion market for voice and data, with about 30 percent of revenue generated abroad, especially in Mexico and Canada.
Using the regular public telephone network, a business call from New York to Mexico City goes from the office's phone to a New York Telephone public line to a long-distance carrier like Sprint. Sprint then carries the call across the country and across the Mexican border to a Telmex public line in Mexico City. The telephone companies' central-office switches along the way find available circuits and route the call.
By contrast, the traditional type of private networks employs dedicated circuits -- sophisticated versions of a string running between two tin cans (but with lots of strings and numerous pairs of cans). The number of strings in a private network increases exponentially, so that 10 offices in a private network require 45 telephone lines; 50 offices need 1,225 lines and 100 offices take 4,950 lines.
 
Disadvantage of a Flat Rate
 Such complexity requires a great deal of equipment and a large telecommunications staff for maintenance and repair. And companies pay the same flat rate for each line -- whether they use it 24 hours a day or only a minute a day.
As computers became cheaper and more efficient, and the software more supple and nimble, the telephone companies realized they could offer customers the advantages of a private network, including price, without the profit-killing labor costs of caring and feeding such networks.
They could also charge by volume, albeit at an attractive price, rather than at a flat rate, making more efficient use of the public network that the telephone companies had spent billions of dollars to build.
 
Cutting Down on Dialing
 In a virtual private network, a company employee can still enjoy abbreviated dialing. But instead of the call going over lines the company has leased purely for its use, the call goes mainly over public lines, guided by sophisticated computers.
In Mexico, providing virtual private networks will be a little more complicated. For such networks to perform properly, Mexico must improve its creaky telephone system, a task Telmex has pledged to do in a series of huge modernization programs. An $8 billion project that comes to a close next year involves, among other things, installing modern telephone switching computers in some 2,000 central offices serving 10,000 cities and towns.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Assessing the Network Choices"
 
The Public Switched Network
 
Advantages: Calls can be placed to any other phone on the public network; customer has little equipment to maintain.
 
Disadvantages: Can be expensive if many calls are made each day; no guaranteed access to an open line during peak periods.
 
A Private Network
 
Advantages: Guaranteed access to an open line at all times; lower prices based ona flat rate, rather tha a charge for each call; abbreviated dialing.
 
Disadvantages: Same flat rate, even if network is not used full time; labor intensive for repairs and maintenance.
 
A Virtual Private Network
 
Advantages: Guaranteed access; discounts based on calling volume; lower maintenance costs than a private network.
 
Disadvantages: Costly for smaller businesses with low calling volume.
 
(Source: A.T.&T.)

HEADLINE: THE PURPOSEFUL COOK;
For a Simple End to Summer, It's Fish the Light Basque Way

BYLINE: By JACQUES PEPIN

 BODY:
IN this simple, light menu still suggestive of summer, whiting is featured in a main dish inspired by the cooking of the Basques, the people of northern Spain and southwest France. Whiting, or merluza, as the Basques call it, is plentiful and inexpensive in that region and in most parts of the United States. If you can't find it, substitute another economical species -- perhaps porgy or bluefish, providing it is fresh.
I prepare the fish in the Basque style, en cazuela. The term refers specifically to a type of earthenware cooking pot common to that region, but it is also used in a broader context to describe the airtight, moist cooking, or braising, that is done in these and similar pots and that is a speciality there. 
 I achieve the same results with a Dutch oven, and cook my dish a l'etouffee, or "smothered," with the fish and accompanying vegetables cooked in a tightly covered casserole with very little fat or liquid. Potatoes are cooked on their own for a while, and beans are added and cooked until they are very tender. This is not a dish in which the vegetables end up crunchy. It is more like a satisfying and flavorful stew.
We begin the menu with a salad of iceberg lettuce, tomato and blue cheese. Even though fancy restaurants turn up their noses at iceberg lettuce, it is still an occasional favorite at our house. We especially like it cut into large wedges, as it is here, and served cold with tomatoes -- still good and inexpensive -- with blue cheese crumbled on top.
You can use almost any good-quality blue cheese, ranging from more expensive imported varieties to domestic specimens. A mozzarella would also be quite good with this type of vinaigrette, if blue cheese is not appealing. This is a great starter salad, especially on a hot September night, with crusty bread. The crunchiness of the iceberg lettuce goes well with flavorful tomatoes and the accented taste of the blue cheese and dressing.
We finish this meal with a simple but elegant mango and cognac dessert that is a sure winner, but only if it is made with a ripe mango. Mangoes are available year-round but are a little less expensive at summer's end. With a bit of cognac, pear brandy, rum or even whisky to flavor this concoction, it makes a great finish to this early-fall menu.
With this meal, I would suggest an Alsace pinot blanc, many of which are inexpensive. Albert Seltz, for example, is a creamy, soft, fruity wine from that region that is attractively priced.
 
Spread Thin
 If you have any of the mango dessert left over, puree it in a food processor and use it as a jam on toast for breakfast the following morning.
 
Iceberg and Blue-Cheese Salad
Total time: 10 minutes
 
1 tight head iceberg lettuce (about 1 1/4 pounds)
3 ripe tomatoes (about 1 1/4 pounds)
1 4 1/2-ounce piece blue cheese (Danish, Stilton, Gorgonzola or Roquefort)
1 1/2 tablespoons Dijon-style mustard
 3/4 teaspoon salt
 3/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
2 tablespoons red-wine vinegar
6 tablespoons canola or corn oil.
1. Discard any damaged outer leaves from the head of lettuce and cut it into 6 wedges. Core the tomatoes and cut each into six wedges.
2. Arrange a wedge of lettuce and three wedges of tomato on each of six salad plates. Crumble the cheese and sprinkle it over the lettuce and tomatoes on each plate.
3. Mix the mustard, salt, pepper, vinegar and oil in a bowl to make the dressing. (Don't worry if the ingredients separate; the mixture is not intended to be homogenized.) Spoon the dressing over the lettuce and tomatoes, and serve immediately.
Yield: 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 235 calories, 20 grams fat, 15 milligrams cholesterol, 675 milligrams sodium, 7 grams protein, 7 grams carbohydrate.
 
Merluza en Cazuela (Braised Whiting With Potatoes)
Total time: 30 minutes
 
 1/3 cup olive oil
1 1/2 pounds potatoes, peeled and sliced thin
2 onions (about 1 pound), peeled and sliced thin (about 3 1/2 cups)
1 pound broad, runner or string beans, cleaned and cut into 1 1/2-inch pieces (about 3 1/2 cups)
6 cloves garlic, peeled and sliced thin
6 medium whiting, with heads removed, scaled and gutted (about 2 1/2 pounds ready to cook)
1 teaspoon salt
 1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
1 cup dry white wine
4 tablespoons chopped parsley.
1. Heat the oil in a Dutch oven or large skillet or saucepan with a tight-fitting lid. When the oil is hot but not smoking, add the potatoes and onions and saute them, covered, over medium heat for 5 minutes.
2. Add the beans and garlic. Cook, covered, for another 5 minutes. Add the whiting, salt, pepper and wine and cook, covered, for 10 more minutes. Sprinkle with the parsley and serve immediately.
Yield: 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 435 calories, 15 grams fat, 125 milligrams cholesterol, 565 milligrams sodium, 40 grams protein, 35 grams carbohydrate.
 
Mangoes With Cognac
Total time: 10 minutes, plus 2 hours for chilling (optional)
 
2 ripe mangoes (about 1 pound each)
 1/4 cup sugar
2 tablespoons cognac, brandy, rum or whisky
 1/4 cup lime juice.
1. Peel the mangoes, cutting deep enough into the fruit so that any green-colored flesh is also removed. Then cutting inward toward the pit, slice each mango into slivers about 1/2-inch thick. Discard the pits.
2. In a bowl, combine the mango slivers with the sugar, cognac and lime juice. Serve immediately or, for added flavor, chill before serving for at least 2 hours, stirring occasionally. Serve in chilled glasses.
Yield 6 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 145 calories, 1 gram fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 3 milligrams sodium, 1 gram protein, 35 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sending Officials to Balkans as Monitors

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The United States is sending a small contingent of officials to the Balkans to take part in international efforts to end the Yugoslav conflict under an agreement worked out at a peace conference last month in London.
The dozen or so officials, who will stay outside the war zones, represent the first involvement of United States personnel other than diplomats since the fighting in the Balkans broke out in late June 1991. 
 The main United States effort is in tightening economic sanctions on Yugoslavia, especially Serbia, which is the dominant component of the truncated nation and is perceived as the principal instigator of the fighting. A senior Administration official said the sanctions, imposed by the United Nations in June and endorsed by the conference in London, had stopped about 80 percent of Serbia's imports.
The official said that in an effort to increase this percentage, nine specialists in border traffic, including members of the United States Customs Service, would be sent to Romania and Hungary next week to assist in intercepting Serbia's imports, particularly oil, which is being smuggled by barge up the Danube to refineries in Serbia.
In line with the London conference's call for protection of minorities in the region, two United States officials are to join international monitors in areas of Serbia with large minorities. These are Kosovo, the home of 1.7 million ethnic Albanians; Vojvodina, with 350,000 ethnic Hungarians and various other minorities, and the Sanjak, a region with more than 200,000 Muslims.
Their task, the official said, will be to evaluate the threat posed by the Serbian nationalists in power in Belgrade and to report on attempts to drive the minority populations out of Serbia.
In addition, the Administration has stationed an official in Macedonia, the southernmost former Yugoslav republic, to report on threats to its sovereignty. He is Robert Frowick, a retired ambassador with considerable experience in Eastern Europe; he arrived last week in Skopje, the capital.
Warren Zimmermann, the last United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia, is to coordinate Washington's involvement in the Balkans.
On leave from his new post as director of refugee programs at the State Department, Mr. Zimmermann is also Washington's representative on the 22-nation steering committee set up to implement the decisions taken in London. The committee, based in Geneva, is led by Cyrus R. Vance, a former Secretary of State, representing the United Nations, and Lord Owen, a former British Foreign Secretary, representing the European Community.
A senior Administration official said stronger enforcement of sanctions is intended to increase pressure on the president of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic. The official said the Administration hoped this pressure would generate support for Milan Panic, a Serbian-born American businessman and opponent of Mr. Milosevic's policies who was named Prime Minister of Yugoslavia in July.
Some Administration officials had dismissed Mr. Panic as a puppet of Mr. Milosevic. Now, they note with satisfaction that Mr. Panic has beaten back an effort by Milosevic supporters to oust him, has dismissed the chief of Mr. Milosevic's secret police and has forced the resignation of Vladislav Jovanovic, the Foreign Minister forced upon him by the Milosevic camp.

HEADLINE: Crisis Is Seen for Sub-Saharan Africa

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
As the world grapples with starvation in Somalia, American and international aid officials say they are looking ahead to a crisis many times larger building across sub-Saharan Africa, where drought and civil war may put millions more at risk over the next few months.
"Something like 110 million people live in the countries affected by the drought," said Andrew Natsios, Assistant Administrator for Food and Humanitarian Assistance at the United States Agency for International Development. 
 "The U.N. estimates that 30 million of them will suffer in some way -- 18 million are at risk and could die if we don't intervene," Mr. Natsios, who is also President Bush's coordinator for relief in Somalia, said in an interview today. "The people most at risk are in Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Malawi, Angola and Swaziland."
Mr. Natsios said that the United States prepared an action plan for the region in March, and has committed nearly 2 million tons of food for the southern drought region.
Many experts still believe that a greater national and international committment is needed. Private donations are running far below expectations and aid experts expect to face enormous logistical problems delivering aid to half a dozen or more countries.
"Internationally, there is no mobilization," said Jeffrey Clark, a consultant on relief assistance in Africa at the U.S. Committee for Refugees. "There is no master plan. There is nobody saying, 'Somalia cannot be repeated in Mozambique or southern Sudan.' There is nobody saying, 'We have to raise a billion dollars and get food on the boats and get going.' "
An Administration official said today: "Southern Africa has fallen off the scope publicly. But we are starting to face the crunch there. We are beginning to hear about starvation in Mozambique."
In Mozambique, a regional shortage of food is being worsened, as in Somalia, by the refusal of armed rebels to honor agreements to distribute aid.
 
Century's Worst Drought
 Today, the Agriculture Department said that $33.6 million in surplus corn would be donated to African relief. The Agriculture Department said priority would be given to Somalia, Kenya and other countries in Africa where civil strife, drought and the resulting needs of refugees have put a severe strain on local food supplies.
Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Malawi, Angola, Swaziland, Botswana, Lesotho and South Africa are all suffering from what experts are calling the worst drought in a century in southern Africa. Millions of animals are dying. At least 2 million people have become refugees in search of food.
For the countries of southern Africa, the tragedy is compounded by the threat of long-term damage to political and economic development in the region with the brightest hopes on the continent, said Alison Rosenberg, Assistant Administrator for Africa at the United States Agency for International Development.
"Here we have all that is good about Africa in its prospects for democracy and economic growth colliding with a disaster not of their own making," she said. "It is setting back what they all had worked hard to achieve."
A drought has also affected Kenya, where may thousands of Somalis have taken refuge.
 
Donations Plummet
 On the west coast, Liberia is facing famine born of a simmering civil war. In Zaire, local commerce is collapsing along with the currency as the country struggles to emerge from three decades of rule by Mobutu Sese Seko.
In the face of a continent-wide crisis, leaders of relief organizations and some Administration officials who work day-to-day on relief say that donations to African causes have plummeted since the Ethiopian crisis of the mid 1980's.
"Only three percent of the public contributions donated for relief efforts in Africa in 1984-1985 have been raised for this humanitarian crisis," Tom Getman, director of government relations for World Vision, a private development organization, told a news conference here this week. "Private voluntary organizations face serious financial shortfalls."
Mr. Clark, a former staff member of the House Select Committee on Hunger and director of Project Africa at the Carter Center in Atlanta, was sharply critical in an interview of top officials of Bush Administration, whom he accused of using the Somalia crisis for political ends, and of the United Nations, whose response to the growing crisis in Africa he called "hapless, hopeless and criminally negligent."
 
U.N. Effort Criticized
 "The U.N. ought to be held publicly accountable for their failure to galvanize their own agencies, let alone the public," he said in an interview.
Private groups also say the public should not be dissuaded from making donations by reports of difficulties in delivering aid.
"Despite the barriers in Somalia -- the violence, the looting, the wackos with guns out there -- the cause is not totally hopeless, and some good is being done," Mr. Clark said. "People can indeed make a contribution to a private relief group and have confidence that some children will be reached.
Officials at the Agency for International Development say that they have been tracking the situation in southern Africa since early this year when spring rains did not come, destroying a season of crops and depriving grazing animals of food.
A senior Administration official said that although an international donors' conference in the summer drew pledges of support for southern Africa, a transportation system into vast areas of the interior of the continent will have to be arranged.

Map of sub-Saharan Africa.

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN EUROPE;
Europe's Turmoil May Aid the U.S.

 BODY:
The turmoil in Europe's financial markets is primarily a European affair and the United States will not get involved, officials of the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve said yesterday. In fact, the turbulence could help the American economy, they said, by lowering interest rates and spurring growth in Europe and the United States. Beyond that, Europe's trauma has given the Fed more flexibility to lower interest rates because it has strengthened the dollar, they said.
Business Day, page D8.

LENGTH: 940 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media;
Secrecy Over TV Ads, or, the Peculiar Logic of Political Combat

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton put a new commercial on the air last week, hoping it will be seen by millions of people somewhere in America. But the Clinton campaign will not say where.
President Bush, too, is preparing advertisements that could go on television any day now in crucial states. But even after the commercials go on, the Bush campaign will not be telling in which states. 
 With seven weeks to go before the election, the media campaign has entered its cloak-and-dagger phase.
Though there is no campaign tactic more public than advertising, no information is more closely guarded than what the candidates plan to put on television, and where. This is because at this stage of the race, every advertising dollar spent represents a clue to a campaign's deepest hopes and a potential revelation about its priorities.
 
Political Triage
 "Analyzing the media buy is some of the most important strategic information you can get," said Tad Devine, a top aide to Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas in his 1988 Vice-Presidential campaign. "When you go in and you plunk that money down, you say, 'This is our strategy for winning the Electoral College.' "
Like triage, every Presidential advertising strategy involves a set of grim decisions: this state can be saved, this one cannot. But it is triage with a twist. Each candidate wants to use his own resources most efficiently while at the same time forcing his opponent to squander his.
Such complex calculations can lead to peculiar results, like candidates' broadcasting commercials in states they have no hope of winning. "If you're going to write off a state but you know that your opponent needs to win that state, you still might put up an attack to get them to waste resources," one Bush campaign aide explained.
 
Spend Here, Lose There?
 In this world of feint and counterfeint, the more expensive a state's media markets are, the more likely that state is to be used for campaign sabotage. The Bush team, for example, is worried that the Clinton campaign will go on television in Texas, a state with several high-priced markets that falls into the "must win" category for the President.
A few well-timed attacks could be a sign that the Clinton camp really believes it can win Texas, or just a ploy to get the President to spend money in the state he calls home.
"That would be a big deal if you make Bush spend a couple of million dollars in Texas, because it might mean you win Michigan," Hank Morris, a Democratic consultant, said.
The Clinton team, meanwhile, has similar fears about California. Earlier this summer the President's aides put out the word that they were considering an advertising push in California, a push that so far has not occurred.
Most analysts say that at this point the President has little hope of winning California; still, a Bush campaign advertising blitz there could throw the Clinton campaign's plans into disarray, forcing it to take money that had been earmarked for the Midwest and spend it in the expensive West Coast.
 
Daily Calculations
 At this point, neither side has arrived at its final strategy; calculations are fluctuating not only in response to the opposition but also in response to new data. Almost every day, top staff members for the Bush and Clinton campaigns receive updated lists of states that are not yet in their column but could be.
At the same time, battles are still being waged within each campaign over advertising tactics. At Bush headquarters, the fight is between those aides who believe the campaign should tailor different advertising messages to different media markets and those who believe it should spend most of its money sending out a unified message on network television. (On Sunday, the campaign began an advertising campaign on the networks, broadcasting a 60-second commercial on the President's economic plans.)
 
Positive and Negative
 Within the Clinton camp, the debate centers on whether to continue to run positive ads, like the one it put on the air yesterday on Mr. Clinton's economic plan, or to switch to more negative ones that focus on President Bush's record. Mr. Clinton himself was reported last week to be favoring the latter approach but was talked out of it, at least temporarily. (Anticipating attacks from the Bush campaign on the Governor's own record, Mr. Clinton's media team has already prepared a series of response ads.)
Since time is of the essence, both campaigns are happy merely to keep their opponents guessing for a few extra days, or even hours. Once a commercial goes on the air it is, of course, public, but even before that a campaign's plans can fall into enemy hands: when a candidate for public office buys advertising time, television stations are required to make this information available to anyone who requests it.
What keeps the spy-vs.-spy game going is the fact that the information is not available in a centralized location. To keep tabs on the other side, the campaigns have to rely on word of mouth from their media buyers or else employ legions of volunteers to check the records of the television stations in every media market in the country.
Last week, when the Clinton campaign put a new commercial about welfare on the air, the Governor's aides assumed that the Bush campaign would know within a few days where it was showing. (Among the states where it was broadcast, according to one Bush aide, are North Carolina and Georgia.) But the campaign was not about to give information it could make its opponent work for.
As Mr. Clinton's media adviser, Mandy Grunwald, put it, "Why make it easy for them?"

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Overview;
Bush and Clinton Lob Economic Plans

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The Presidential race moved into a transcontinental bidding war on the economy and compassion today as President Bush offered a $500 million tax credit to companies that provide family emergency leaves and Gov. Bill Clinton outlined a $1.5 billion program to revive the inner cities.
Campaigning at opposite ends of the country -- Mr. Bush in the Oval Office and Mr. Clinton in Los Angeles -- both candidates tried to focus attention on their economic proposals. 
 Trying to move beyond questions about his draft status in the Vietnam War, Mr. Clinton traveled to the precincts of Los Angeles that were shattered by rioting last spring and sought to put flesh on the economic proposals he has outlined in recent months in vague terms.
 
Subsidized Savings Accounts
 The Democratic Presidential nominee offered a plan to "move people from welfare to payrolls to businesses," which would include the creation of banks to stimulate investment in urban areas and federally subsidized savings accounts for the urban and rural poor. Mr. Clinton backed up his appeal with a new television commercial that showed him sitting on his desk with an American flag behind him, declaring that "government just isn't working for the hard-working families of America."
Mr. Bush, taking a day off from the stump, remained in Washington, where he put the final touches on what aides said would be a "major economic speech" that he would make on Thursday. His aim, they said, is to draw a point-by-point contrast between his ideas and Mr. Clinton's.
Pursuing the White House's effort to undermine public trust in his opponent, the President "will point out the economic consequences if you follow the Clinton plan -- higher taxes, re-regulation among them -- and make the case that Americans can't afford to take those risks," said Judy Smith, deputy White House press secretary.
This morning Mr. Bush called Republican lawmakers to the White House to provide a forum for announcing his own family leave plan -- to give companies with fewer than 500 employees a tax credit of up to $1,200 if they give their workers leave for personal and family emergencies.
 
No Expectation of Passage
 Mr. Bush called on Congress to take up his bill immediately. But White House officials acknowledged that the President was sending the measure to Capitol Hill at this late date with no expectation that it would get any real consideration, much less actual passage, before Election Day.
The bill, which the White House was still drafting as Mr. Bush announced it at the hastily scheduled meeting with the Republican lawmakers, was primarily intended to give the President political cover if he carried out his threat to veto another family leave measure that was passed by Congress last week and would require companies to give their workers unpaid emergency leaves.
Clearly vexed at being cornered on such a politically popular issue as family leave so close to the election, Mr. Bush complained testily about the timing of the family-leave bill that was sent to him by Congress, calling it "very peculiar and highly political."
The Congressional bill would require businesses with more than 50 employees to provide unpaid leave in family emergencies. The President has threatened to veto it, and he accused Congress today of trying to force him into a politically embarrassing position by sending him the bill so close to the election.
But the White House seemed hard pressed to explain why Mr. Bush was sending up his own bill now. The President vetoed a family leave measure in 1990, saying he opposed the idea of requiring businesses to provide leaves, but he did not offer any alternative bill.
Mr. Bush's proposal would cost $400 million to $500 million, the White House said, promising to offer cuts in other programs to avoid increasing the Federal budget deficit.
It would provide credits of up to $20 a day for as many as 60 days of leave in any 12-month period, or a maximum of $1,200 per employee, and would cover companies with fewer than 500 workers, the White House said.
Mr. Clinton wasted no time attacking the Bush proposal. He called it part of the President's "continuing pander parade" and said the President "has no idea how he'll pay for it."
Mr. Clinton, who was called the "pander bear" by former Senator Paul E. Tsongas in the Democratic primaries, also has done little to explain how he would pay for his own ambitious economic plans.
Speaking at a job-training center in South-Central Los Angeles to a mostly black and Hispanic audience of about 1,000, Mr. Clinton promised a series of programs that his issues director, Bruce Reed, said would cost $1.5 billion a year. They include these steps:
*Adding 95 federally supported "community development banks" to the five that now exist in poor rural and urban areas, at a cost of $150 million a year for four years.
*Establishing 1,000 "micro-enterprise programs," which are smaller versions of the community banks where poor people could get loans of $500 or $1,000. The cost: $50 million.
*Creating "individual development accounts" at a cost of $100 million a year for five years. Families with incomes of up to $28,000 a year for a family of four would be allowed to deposit up to $1,800 a year in an account earmarked for education, job training or starting a small business; the Federal Government would match their savings.
*Creating 75 to 125 enterprise zones in urban areas.
There are significant points of convergence between Mr. Clinton's plan and the ideas that Mr. Bush put forward after the Los Angeles riots. Enterprise zones, through which businesses would receive tax breaks and other incentives to locate in blighted neighborhoods, are central to Mr. Bush's economic policy.

(Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 456 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail;
2 Champs, Bush's Man and Quayle's Man, Quietly Slug It Out

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

 BODY:
Nothing brings on power plays at the White House like an election year. The latest word out of the East Wing is that one of the smartest political in-fighters anywhere, James A. Baker 3d, the President's chief of staff, is trying to keep another world-class infighter, William Kristol, the Vice President's chief of staff, out of the decision-making loop.
But before the main event, some perspective: 
 These two men have more in common than brains and titles: They are wily, charming, ambitious and promoters without peer.
So what's the problem?
Neither man is talking, but according to some Administration officials, Mr. Baker does not like all the good ink and air time that Mr. Kristol has recently been getting, portraying himself, or being portrayed, as the brains and power behind the new, improved Dan Quayle. Mr. Baker is no Quayle fan, but he is said to believe that it is unconscionable that Mr. Kristol is promoting himself and overshadowing his boss at this crucial political juncture.
So much for Answer No. 1.
Answer No. 2, from other Administration sources, goes like this:
It takes one to know one.
 
A Plane, for Sure, But the Meaning?

Whether a campaign is gaining momentum can be measured in any number of ways, all inexact.
For years the addition of a second plane to a campaign entourage for a swollen press contingent has been taken as a solid sign of political progress.
This week, the Clinton campaign added a second plane.
Momentum?
Maybe. Maybe not.
In years past, a campaign that was rolling well would have added a second plane weeks ago. On the other hand, this is not a typical year. News organizations have been hit hard by the recession, and not in recent memory have there been so few reporters out on the trail.
 
Kernels of Truth From Campaign Life

By his own admission, Gov. Bill Clinton has been running for office most of his life, whether for class president or President of the United States. So it would follow that he has accumulated a lot of wisdom about politicking and has concluded that there are certain political verities.
Late the other night, as he winged wearily toward still another campaign appearance, he stopped looking ahead for a moment and turned reflective.
Herewith, verbatim, Bill Clinton's "Laws of Politics:"
1) Always be introduced by someone you've appointed to high office.
2) When you're starting to have a good time, you're supposed to be someplace else.
3) There is no such thing as enough money.
4) If someone tells you it's not a money problem, it's someone else's problem.
5) When someone tells you it's not personal, they're fixing to stick it to you.
6) Nearly everyone will lie to you given the right circumstances.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN EUROPE;
The High Cost of Unity

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The currency systems of Western Europe were thrown into disarray today when speculators took hold of exchange markets. They sold weaker currencies like the British pound, the Italian lira and the Spanish peseta, and bought the strongest currency in Europe, the German mark.
But more fundamentally, the chaos occurred because of an underlying crisis afflicting the economies of Europe. The crisis is rooted in the high cost of German unification, which is driving up German interest rates at a time when other European countries need lower rates to help them out of their economic slowdown. 
 The immediate spur of the buying and selling by currency speculators over the last 10 days was a growing fear that France will vote on Sunday to reject the Maastricht treaty on European union -- in the process sinking the European Community's plan to create a single currency by the end of the decade.
Many currency traders believe that a French "no" in the referendum would put on hold plans for a single European currency and disrupt the community's system of linked exchange rates.
 
Winners and Losers
 Their concern was that in this disruption, Britain and other countries with weak currencies would be forced to devalue, letting the worth of their money drop even further in relation to the German mark. By rushing to buy marks, the speculators thus engaged in self-fulfilling prophecy.
The Italian lira was the first to give way when the lira was devalued by 7 percent on Sunday. Today, Britain was forced to cut loose the pound from the fixed values of other European currencies, allowing it to "float" and effectively devaluing it. And the peseta also came under market pressure.
Currency devaluations are anything but an academic exercise in Europe. The value of money is a much greater political issue than, for example, in the United States because European consumers depend so heavily on imports. A devaluation raises the price of foreign goods, bringing higher living costs and inflation.
Currency gyrations may slow in coming days once the French referendum on the European treaty is decided and some of the current uncertainty is eliminated. But the underlying forces in the current crisis, the high cost of German unification and the European-wide economic slowdown, will not disappear even if French voters approve the treaty.
This slide into recession follows a burst of rapid growth in the late 1980's. Through much of Europe, unemployment is on the rise, investment is down and business confidence has evaporated.
French approval of the European union treaty would therefore give the community a much-needed psychological lift by preserving the principal blueprint for the future, including the goal of a single currency by 1999. But it would not mean that the 12 nations in the community had turned the corner economically or were secure from new currency crises.
[The European Community's monetary committee decided in Brussels early Thursday that further steps were necessary, It voted to let Italy set the lira free from the exchange-rate system and to allow Spain to devalue the peseta by 5 percent.]
In recent months, most European economies have become hostage to the unexpectedly high cost of German unification. Germany has long had the region's strongest economy and currency and, in the 1980's at least, its monetary discipline proved to be a stabilizing influence.
But it has become clear that the financial burden of trying to develop the former East Germany is much greater than many Germans and other Europeans had expected. By some accounts, the cost could be $100 billion in the next few years.
 
Enforcing Frugality
 This burden has spawned new inflation in Germany. To fight this, the German central bank, the Bundesbank, has raised domestic interest rates as a way of persuading people to save rather than spend -- the theory being that, with less money circulating, inflation will come down.
The Germans have also had to raise interest rates to attract the large amounts of money needed to carry out the reconstruction of the east without raising taxes.
Adopted for purely German reasons, this policy was bound to have an impact on Western Europe's interdependent economies. And as German interest rates went up, foreign investors abandoned currencies that offered less attractive returns and rushed to buy marks to take advantage of these higher rates.
Under free-market conditions, the mark's value would normally increase until investors considered it too expensive to buy. And this is what has hurt the dollar: Its value against the mark has tumbled in recent weeks, not least because interest rates are so much lower in the United States than in Germany.
Within Europe, the situation is more complicated since the major currencies are linked. Under this system, they can fluctuate only within narrow margins of their basic value, as expressed in European Currency Units, or ECU's. The value of the ECU against, say, the dollar reflects the weighted values of all the European currencies.
As a result, as German interest rates began drawing investors and pushing up the mark's value, other community governments had to bolster their own currencies to keep them within the permitted margins of the so-called exchange rate mechanism. And they had to do this by raising their own interest rates to make them competitive.
In other words, community members found themselves importing Germany's economic problems. For example, although French inflation is low, high interest rates began driving the French economy into a slump. And Britain, which had succeeded in lowering inflation, found that its high interest rates stood in the way of a resumption of economic growth. Italy was particularly vulnerable because of a huge budget deficit.
Part of the deal was that Germany would take the pressure off the other currencies by lowering its rates. But when the Bundesbank reduced key rates by only 0.25 percent on Monday, foreign-exchange markets concluded that it was not sufficient, and the attack on the pound stepped up.
Today, announcing Britain's temporary withdrawal from the community's linked currency system, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont, pointed his finger at the culprits. "As a result of uncertainties caused by the French referendum," he said, "massive speculative flow have continued to disrupt the functioning of the exchange-rate mechanism."
After the Bank of England had raised interest rates by five percentage points in two stages earlier in the day to sustain the pound, speculators no longer believed that the British currency could avoid devaluation.
With the shadow of the French referendum hanging over the community, exchange markets are certain to remain unstable.
It is not clear whether today's sterling crisis will have any effect on the result of the French vote. After German interest rates were slightly lowered on Monday, Finance Minister Michel Sapin held out the carrot of lower French interest rates -- if voters say yes on Sunday.
Supporters of the European union treaty have insisted that the current crisis is itself proof of the need for a single currency, arguing that without competing currencies, community governments would not have to engage in interest-rate wars.
France also sees a single currency managed by a regional central bank as the best way of breaking the Germans' grip on its monetary policy. In other words, as only one of several countries represented in a regional central bank, Germany would presumably be unable to impose its will on the community.
For this very reason, many senior Bundesbank officials are less than enthusiastic about a single currency. And if France approves the union treaty, German concern about "losing" the mark seems certain to surface when the treaty comes up for ratification in Parliament this fall.
If France rejects the treaty, however, most financial experts anticipate a new wave of currency speculation, perhaps against the French franc, as well. And in that case, the only way of restoring market stability could be to carry out a broader realignment of currencies within the exchange-rate mechanism -- something European governments are eager to avoid.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Senate;
PRIMARY IN HAND, ABRAMS SETS OUT TO OUST D'AMATO

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The general-election campaign for the Senate from New York began in earnest yesterday as the Democratic nominee, State Attorney General Robert Abrams, squared off for a bruising battle against the Republican incumbent, Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Mr. Abrams claimed victory after defeating former Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro by 11,000 votes, or 1 percentage point, in unofficial returns. Ms. Ferraro made no public concession, but her aides acknowledged privately that she had lost and that she supported the nominee. 
 Mr. Abrams used the morning after his victory to stump at a subway stop on the Upper West Side of Manhattan at breakfast time, where he called Mr. D'Amato "one of the roughest, toughest customers ever to come down the political pike." Mr. D'Amato repaid the compliment by beginning to broadcast television commercials deriding Mr. Abrams as "hopelessly liberal" on taxing and spending.
 
2 Landmarks Bruised
 The primary drew just under 30 percent of the state's registered Democrats to the polls -- half again as many as forecast by some experts -- after an extraordinarily rancorous campaign. It left two landmarks on New York's political landscape -- Ms. Ferraro and one of her opponents, Elizabeth Holtzman -- badly bruised and pondering their futures after what many feminists had hoped would be a year of triumph for women turned instead into a harsh and unforgiving fight between them. [Page B5.]
With 99 percent of election districts reporting, this was the tally:
 
Robert Abrams . . . 411,072 (37%)
Geraldine A. Ferraro . . . 400,084 (36%)
Al Sharpton . . . 161,691 (15%)
Elizabeth Holtzman . . . 140,884 (13%)
Absentee and paper ballots will not be counted for at least several days and the final returns will not be certified until Sept. 30. A spokesman for the State Board of Elections, David Flanagan, said a spot check with county boards around the state showed 16,778 uncounted absentee ballots yesterday, with more to filter in before the deadline next Tuesday. But election-law experts agreed that it appeared impossible that Ms. Ferraro, who in 1984 was the Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, could win enough votes to reverse the outcome.
After a brief morning meeting with her campaign staff, Ms . Ferraro retreated to her home in Queens. "We're not saying anything," said her press secretary, Frank Wilkinson. "We're not doing anything. We're just sitting tight."
While the election was a blow to Ms. Ferraro, it propelled the Rev. Al Sharpton to new prominence. The often flamboyant leader of civil rights protests was making his first run for political office and outpolled Ms. Holtzman to win third place. He won the support of two-thirds of black voters, whose help Mr. Abrams will need in November.
 
An Awkward Position
 That puts the Attorney General in the awkward position of courting the help of a man being prosecuted by his office on income-tax evasion charges in a trial scheduled for January. Mr. Sharpton said the two of them would talk, and Mr. Abrams said he wanted the help of all his old rivals, but both men said they would keep the two issues separate.
"It would be asking him to lose the election," Mr. Sharpton said, referring to any possibility that Mr. Abrams might drop the prosecution. "I would be more concerned if he was going to represent the interests that would help my community."
It was the looming fight between Mr. Abrams and Mr. D'Amato, a two-term incumbent who has withstood official inquiries into his ethical conduct in office and styled himself as a fearless crusader for the common man, that dominated the political discussion yesterday. And in that fight, Ms. Ferraro's silence -- however temporary -- did not help Mr. Abrams on the morning after an election in which she drew the votes of 4 in 10 women while he drew support of 3 in 10.
In addition to accusing Mr. Abrams of supporting tax increases on the middle class to finance a national health insurance program -- which the Attorney General denies -- Mr. D'Amato is using two other television commercials that feature a 10-second pitch from one of the state's most prominent Democrats, former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who smiles into the camera and says: "Two years ago, you didn't re-elect me. Don't make the same mistake twice. Re-elect Al D'Amato for the Senate."
 
Party Loyalty
 As Mayor, Mr. Koch was friendly with Mr. D'Amato but said the constraints of party loyalty prevented him from taking sides. Earlier this year, he said he no longer faced such strictures and endorsed him. Yesterday, Mr. Koch said he had agreed to make the commercials because "Bob Abrams has the political courage of a gnat."
Mr. Koch faulted Mr. Abrams for refusing to say flatly until the Persian Gulf war was over whether he would have favored the use of military force as a member of Congress. Eventually, Mr. Abrams said that "with hindsight," force was necessary.
"He did that because he knows that his support is the radical left in the Democratic Party, and they dominate the primary, and he didn't want to alienate them," Mr. Koch said. "I'm not opposed to the radical left being part of the Democratic Party, but I'm not part of them. They don't vote for me and I don't support them."
In fact, Mr. Abrams ran in the primary as an unabashed liberal, seeking to point out his differences with Ms. Ferraro over the death penalty, cuts in military spending and a national health insurance plan, to be financed by a new payroll tax on employers, which he says would replace the cost of the private insurance coverage they now bear. But in a televised debate among the four candidates, Mr. Abrams was also careful to avoid supporting any tax increase for individuals.
Even before he won the Democratic Senate nomination, Mr. Abrams held the nomination of the Liberal Party, without whose support no Democrat has won statewide office in the half-century since its founding. But the party's leader, Raymond B. Harding, said yesterday that "I think Bob knows what balance he has to strike."
Mr. Harding said Mr. Abrams should "position himself in terms of a Clinton-Gore situation, in a dynamic at work where if you link Bush and Quayle and D'Amato, there'll be a synergy that'll damage the other side."
 
'Family Values'
 By contrast, with the national Democratic ticket running strongly in New York, Mr. D'Amato will probably have to outpace President Bush and draw the crossover conservative Democrats who have backed him in the past, in order to win. He has already moved to distance himself from the President, criticizing his economic advisers and saying the emphasis on "family values" at the Republican National Convention was misplaced.
"It's going to be an interesting election," said the state Republican chairman, William D. Powers. "I think people will make a choice between somebody who has been in Washington and done the job for them, and somebody who has sat in Albany and enforced the law."
He added: "I think Al's principles are well known to people. They know what he is."
Mr. D'Amato begins the race with a war chest of $3.7 million, about five times the amount Mr. Abrams has on hand. The Senator's aides said he planned to spend about $700,000 on his television advertising campaign alone.
 
Rechecking of Tallies
 While the Democratic primary was unsually close, election experts said yesterday that it was virtually certain the results would stand. Inspectors will now conduct a routine "recanvass," required by law, in which the tallies on sealed voting machines are checked against the written records of election workers for any discrepancies.
Local election boards will also count absentee ballots and the paper ballots of voters whose registration cards were not on file at polling places on Tuesday, and they must forward those tallies to Albany for official certification by the end of the month.
But absentee ballots historically reflect the general trend at the polls, election lawyers said. After factoring out the votes likely to go to Ms. Holtzman and Mr. Sharpton, Ms. Ferraro would need roughly two-thirds of the remainder to have even a chance of beating Mr. Abrams -- in other words, a lead far greater than the one that separated them in either the actual results or polling in the days before the election.
