SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 757 words

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Agility Counts in Currency Chaos

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
The world's currency markets, it seems, are no longer governed by central bankers in Washington and Bonn, but by traders and investors in Tokyo, London and New York, as the chaos in the currency markets this past week has shown.
The lucky, the canny and the nimble among them have found ways to gain an advantage even as they confront the worst monetary crisis of their lives. "I haven't seen such turmoil and uncertainty and fear in the years I have been a central banker and in the private markets," said Peter O'Shea, who served for the Irish central bank and now works in London as a managing director in foreign exchange for Morgan Stanley & Company. 
 From a trading room the size of a soccer field in Manhattan's Rockefeller Center, Lawrence Weinman, head of currency-options sales for North America at Societe Generale, a major French bank, can profit even as central bankers panic. The more jagged the markets, the more the bank's options portfolio appears to be worth.
The central bankers propose, the markets dispose. "We have the tails wagging the dogs," Mr. Weinman said.
As of February 1990, the daily worldwide volume of currency trading had reached $650 billion, more than the market value of the 10 largest American companies, according to the most recent figures from the Bank for International Settlements in Basel, Switzerland. Improved technology, new financial instruments and the growth of international investment have combined to make the currency markets ever more fluid.
But not everyone at the banks and investment firms is quite so cheerful as Mr. Weinman about the latest turn of events. Those who bet on the wrong currencies or failed to hedge their risks are now counting their losses. Several American mutual funds designed to exploit higher interest rates abroad became victims of volatile currencies.
Often, surviving the currency wars means passing up a profitable offensive to avoid further risks. Even those who are boasting today could be crying tomorrow.
As manager of Dreyfus Strategic World Limited Partnership and the Dreyfus Global Investing Fund, Fiona Biggs can invest in United States or foreign bonds, stocks and cash. On Friday, she put about 20 percent of her money in German bonds to take advantage of high interest rates. Then she hedged nearly all her funds' currency risks on fears that lowered German rates would knock down the value of the market.
She sold December futures contracts for marks, pounds and yen, which locked in the value of these currencies in dollars. As the dollar's value rose this week, she avoided losses, but not her continuing fears. "It could change tomorrow," she said. "Tomorrow I could look like an idiot."
Strategists have tried to avoid the temptation to chase high yields -- 15 percent in Britain, 18 percent in Italy, 500 percent in Sweden -- for fear that devaluations could more than wipe away their income. "Do you really want to borrow Swedish kronor?" said David Roche, a global strategist for Morgan Stanley. "The interest rates are surreal, but then the market conditions are surreal."
Managers and traders have several choices for hedging risks besides avoiding the weaker currencies. They can deal in options, which give them the right to buy or sell a certain amount of a currency at a given price and time: say, the right to buy British pounds for $1.75 in three months. Futures and forward contracts create obligations to buy or sell. All these devices can be used like insurance, and all have become especially costly now that investors need them most.
Many money managers have piled these instruments up like sandbags. Thomas J. Berger, the London-based manager of the $1.4 billion Blanchard Short-Term Income Fund, said that the cost of buying forward contracts was eating into the fund's income, but he had few regrets. He has kept the fund's value at between $1.89 and $1.91 a share most of the year, he said.
Yesterday afternoon in London, Mr. Berger noted that he could buy pounds for 2.73 marks to take advantage of the Bank of England's obligation to buy them the next morning at 2.78. "But we're not doing that because we think there is some danger of a devaluation," he said. "It could be tonight, it could be next week. But I suspect there are a lot of aggressive foreign exchange dealers who are buying."
A few hours later, he triumphantly called back with news that the British had abruptly backed out of their obligation to stabilize the pound. "I would expect the pound to drop like a stone," he said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Ad Campaign;
Clinton Addresses Unemployment

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Ad Campaign: Clinton Addresses Unemployment"
The Clinton campaign yesterday began broadcasting a 30-second commercial about the Arkansas Governor's plan to create jobs. The advertisement is appearing in about 20 states around the country; the campaign would not say which states or how often the spot would appear.
 
ON THE SCREEN The words "The Clinton Plan," followed by Mr. Clinton in a jacket and tie leaning on his desk. An American flag and an ornamental eagle are in the background. As Mr. Clinton speaks, the camera moves closer. At the end, an (800) number appears for people who want a copy of Clinton's plan.
 
PRODUCER Clinton/Gore Creative Team.
 
SCRIPT Mr. Clinton: "Government just isn't working for the hardworking families of America. We need fundamental change, not more of the same.
"That's why I've offered a comprehensive plan, a real plan to rebuild America, create eight million new jobs, invest in education and job training, insure quality, affordable health care for all.
 "We're going to ask the rich to pay their fair share so the rest of America can finally get a break. A plan to put Government back on your side. Read it yourself. Together we can make America work again."
 
ACCURACY It is not certain that the plan would create eight million jobs. It is an ambitious program and could be hard to sell in Congress. While there are many questions about how the plan would be carried out, it is conceivable that eight million jobs could be created under the right economic conditions.
 
SCORECARD The commercial is a direct appeal to the Democrats who voted for Ronald Reagan and George Bush four years ago but are toying with returning to the Democratic fold out of dissatisfaction with the unmployment rate and the troubled economy. Mr. Clinton looks like a statesman as he is pictured in a dignified office setting; the idea is to portray him as having a workable plan to pull the country out of economic doldrums. Mr. Clinton has used (800) numbers before to push his proposals, but Mr. Bush did it for the first time in an advertisement on the economy last week. [Photo of Bill Clinton]

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Turmoil in Europe
Britain left the European Monetary System, a cornerstone of European unity, after a futile day of trying to defend the value of the pound by raising interest rates. The move left Europe's program of economic coordination in tatters. [Page A1.]
The causes of Europe's currency crisis lie as much in the conflicts between domestic and regional political priorities as they do in the basic economics of international finance. [A1.] 
 Speculation that France would reject European unity in a vote Sunday helps explain the timing of the monetary crisis. [A1.]
The U.S. will not get involved in trying to help steady Europe's jitters, Administration and Fed officials said. [D8.]
Britain's Prime Minister, John Major, is facing a crisis that may imperil his political future. [D9.]
 
The Economy
Business and academic leaders chided the Presidential candidates on the deficit and said a tax increase might be needed. [D1.]
The F.C.C. will propose rules to gradually free a wide range of radio frequencies for new pocket-telephone services. [D2.]
Seven people face charges of trading on inside information obtained from the office of a company planning a takeover. [D6.]
Industrial production dropped 0.5 percent and the plant-use rate declined to 78.5 percent of capacity in August. [D7.]
Earnings at savings institutions slipped in the second quarter but the first half was the most profitable since 1986. [D12.]
 
International
General Motors and four other large foreign companies will stop selling their shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. [D1.]
Attacks on the North American Free Trade Agreement continued in Congress, with Democrats leading the criticism. [D2.]
The world economy will expand only 1.1 percent this year and to a merely respectable 3 percent next year, the I.M.F. said. [D7.]
American and Chinese negotiators concluded a third day of trade talks but remained far apart on many issues. [D13.]
 
Companies
Lufthansa and the financier Marvin Davis submitted a $400 million bid for Continental Airlines. [D1.]
The Transportation Secretary said he would not link approval of British Airways' $750 million investment in USAir to a lowering of barriers to American carriers in Britain. [D5.]
American Airlines' chairman suggested he might dissolve a simplified fare structure, analysts who met with him said. [D5.]
Apple Computer will recall some of its Macintosh notebook computers because of a potential safety problem. [D5.]
A turnaround specialist has been named president and chief executive of Phar-Mor, the bankrupt drugstore chain. [D6.]
Sony will introduce a portable multimedia player that marries a compact disk player, video player and computer. [D6.]
 
Markets
Stocks lost more ground as traders tried to sort out Europe's monetary turmoil. The Dow lost 8.11, to 3,319.21. [D14.]
Long-term bond prices were knocked lower by the uncertainty in Europe but shorter maturities rose. [D21.]
 
The pound tumbled despite moves to defend it. [D22.] Gold rose as investors sought haven in precious metals. [D22.]

The world's currency markets are no longer governed by central bankers but by traders and investors. Market Place. [D1.]

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Revival for Toys That Bridge the Generations

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
A wave of nostalgia is sweeping toyland, where high-technology video games no longer rule the toy store shelves or children's wish lists. In their place are favorites of bygone days -- jacks, jump ropes, marbles, trolls.
Retailers are even having a hard time keeping stocked up on plastic lacing, used to make necessities like key chains and bolo ties. 
 To take advantage of this passion for the familiar, toy companies are feverishly poring over old catalogues, searching for toys that can be profitably resurrected. Thus the rebirth of Creepy Crawlers, the rubbery bugs made by pouring Plasti Goop into a mold, and the larger, 12-inch models of G.I. Joe, who last saw action at this size in 1978.
 
Charm on the Cheap
 Behind the back-to-basics movement is the weak economy: Many of the newly revived toys are inexpensive -- priced at less than $10, compared with the major capital expenditure program needed to finance a child's start-up in Super Mario land.
That makes parents and grandparents -- the toy buyers -- very happy. And they hope the children will go along, perhaps lured by the charm of playing with the same toys their parents did.
"I used to play with trolls when I was little," said Edie Sullivan of Bellevue, Wash. "Trolls are nonsexual, nonthreatening and portable."
And Mrs. Sullivan's 6-year-old daughter, Carly, is now enchanted by trolls, too. "I want to be a cheerleader," said Carly, the proud owner of 17 trolls, some of which dress like cheerleaders. Carly's sister, 9-year-old Jenny, owns 41 of the little plastic gnomes.
Michael Goldstein, vice chairman and chief financial officer of Toys "R" Us, the nation's biggest toy seller, said: "In recessionary times people tend to buy things that are simpler and that they are accustomed to. People are more averse to taking risks."
Marketing experts say the toy industry is simply responding to the same cautious consumer mind-set that has made the Gap one of the nation's fasting-growing retailers. The Gap recently introduced a line of coats based on the letter jackets popular in the 1950's.
"I don't want to say there is a return to basic values -- that sounds so much like Dan Quayle -- but toys are simply a reflection of the times," said Saul Gamoran, executive vice president of the Ace Novelty Company, the nation's largest seller of trolls, which were big hits in the 1960's.
There are demographic reasons as well. The main toy buyers are the baby boomers, who have made a near religion of worshiping and recycling the music and television shows of their lost youth.
Sean P. McGowan, a toy industry analyst with Gerard Klauer Mattison & Company, said: "There is a general disposition for the 'me generation' to associate happiness with their own childhood. There is a sense that the only toys worth having are the ones we had as kids."
He added, "I find it ironic that the women who burned bras will buy Barbie dolls in droves for their kids and the generation of men who burned their draft cards are buying G.I. Joes."
 
Memories and Economies of Scale
 Toy executives acknowledge that reviving defunct products can produce warm memories. Kirk Bozigian, vice president of marketing for boys' toys for Hasbro Inc., which makes G.I. Joe, played with the doll as a child. "My son is now 5," he said. "It is a toy I want him to have."
For the toy companies, rediscovering the old makes good economic sense. In some cases, there is no need to remake expensive molds and machinery. There is no payment to inventors and it is not as costly to advertise a familiar product to consumers.
Ace Novelty of Bellevue expects to sell $125 million in trolls this year. In the toy industry, anything that passes the $100 million mark is spoken of with the reverence and hushed tones generally reserved for Ninja turtles or for Barbie dolls, whose sales will surpass $1 billion this year. Including versions made by other companies, Ace expects 100 million trolls to be sold this year.
Company officials say they are definitely benefiting from the weak economy. A standard-issue troll costs $2.
"The low price helps a lot," said Robert Abramowitz, a vice president of Ace. "For so many years, in the toy industry, everything was so expensive."
Retailers say they are having trouble keeping trolls in stock. "Trolls are huge," said Roger Glazebrook, manager of one of the three Penny Whistle Toys stores, in New York City. "We've been sold out for weeks," he said.
 
The Pipe Cleaner's Comeback
 Financially pressed parents are also looking to do-it-yourself toys as an inexpensive way to amuse their children.
Maxwell Wellington Group, a craft supplier in Chicago, expects to sell a record 20 million feet of plastic lacing -- sometimes known as lanyard -- this year, enough to make key chains for most of the aunts and uncles in the country.
Stan Kitzes, national sales manager of the Westrim Crafts Corporation, another large craft supplier, said, "As the economy dips, we tend to strengthen."
Mr. Kitzes said pipe cleaners, popsicle sticks and other basic craft components, were also selling briskly.
 
Good Clean Fun
 Michaels Stores Inc., based in Dallas, a 160-store chain of craft stores, said its new Kids Clubs, which gives discounts for supplies, already had 70,000 members.
"It's the economy," said Carol Dillon, general craft buyer for Michaels Stores. "People are making things instead of going out and buying."
Jake Mechling, a 17-year-old from Bloomington, Ind., picked up on the lanyard craze this summer at Boy Scout camp, and came home and taught his three siblings. "We make choker collars, wrist and ankle bracelets and belts," he said.
But it's not just old toys for children that are flourishing.
Scrabble is expected to sell 1.7 million copies this year, up from 500,000 in 1989. E. David Wilson, president of the Milton Bradley company, a division of Hasbro, said, "At times like these, people look at home entertainment as opposed to other forms of entertainment."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Children and their parents are rediscovering such old-fashioned toys as marbles, trolls and games of Scrabble. The playthings appeal to adults as less expensive and more charming than high-technology video games. (Naum Kazhdan/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Fewer Mandates, Fewer Votes

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
READ his lips: no new mandated benefits. President Bush, tarred as a congenital flip-flopper, is making a stand. The catch, at least from the perspective of his supporters, is that the President is manning the ideological barricades against a very popular piece of legislation passed last week by Congress -- legislation that practically screams family values.
The bill, requiring big companies to grant unpaid leave to full-time employees with newborns or seriously ill family members, has drawn fire from the Republicans' traditional allies in business. But Mr. Bush's stance is hardly likely to win votes in the suburbs, where stay-at-home mothers are becoming as rare as wood-paneled station wagons. 
 And ironically, the principle Mr. Bush is defending -- the right of labor and management to haggle freely over compensation and working conditions -- is one he has largely honored in the breach. William Alpert, an economist at the University of Connecticut, notes that the President signed a bill increasing the minimum wage and enthusiastically supported legislation that requires employers to accommodate the disabled.
The family leave bill, timed by Congressional Democrats to maximize the President's pre-election embarrassment, is virtually identical to the one he vetoed in 1990. It gives employees the option of taking up to 12 weeks to tend a new baby or care for a family member who is seriously ill.
Employers would be obliged to pick up the tab for any existing medical benefits and guarantee leave-takers comparable jobs on their return. But the law would apply only to businesses with at least 50 employees. And a company's highest-paid 10 percent of workers would be exempted.
The coverage, then, would largely affect employers who could cope by hiring temporary workers or shuffling job assignments. A 1990 report commissioned by the Small Business Administration and written by Mr. Alpert and Eileen Trzcinski of Cornell University estimates that the annual cost to business would be no more than $825 million, or about $7 a year per worker. Or perhaps nothing at all: a study for the Families and Work Institute in New York concludes that the costs would be more than offset by savings in reducing labor turnover.
Indeed, Lawrence Katz notes that the bill would exact far less from business than is demanded in other affluent countries. In Canada, for example, women have a right to 10 months off the job for pregnancy and newborn care, with the first 15 weeks at 60 percent of salary. And the Eurocrats in Brussels are aiming at a European Community standard of 14 weeks with 80 percent pay.
Why, then, the fuss here? Republican dissenters on the House Labor Committee offer a laundry list of objections. Few Americans, they say, rank parental leave as a high priority. And Federal meddling would undermine initiatives by states in setting their own labor standards. Moreover, family leave requirements would give employers incentives to discriminate against women of child-bearing age.
This last sally draws blood. There is some evidence that paid family leave requirements in Germany and Sweden have undermined women's opportunities. But Mr. Alpert scoffs at the idea that the tame American law, which exempts all employees in small businesses and senior managers in large ones, would deepen the ruts on the mommy track. And Mr. Katz suggests that a uniform standard might actually reduce discrimination in companies that already provide a leave option: With just one-third of corporate America providing the benefit today, generous companies must worry more about attracting employees inclined to use it.
The core conservative argument, one that unites libertarians and business lobbies, is blanket opposition to government mandates. "One aspect of American economic life that should remain private," writes Doug Bandow, a senior fellow at the Cato Institute, "is the negotiation between employers and employees regarding the terms under which they will cooperate."
Still, family leave seems an odd place to dig in. Federal law is full of workplace standards on everything from overtime pay to the vesting of pension rights. And while the threat of the big enchilada of mandates, employer-financed health care, has given business a new reason for concern, Mr. Katz thinks it is "absolutely ridiculous" to think a penny-an-hour family leave mandate would serve as the edge-of-the-wedge to $2-an-hour compulsory health insurance.
One former Bush Administration official not present at the creation believes it was, in fact, the innocuous quality of the family leave mandate that undid the White House. The Administration's initial stance on a seemingly unimportant measure, he speculates, was left to policy nerds more concerned with principle than the President's popularity in the shopping malls. And once articulated as a matter of principle, the White House was stuck with it.

HEADLINE: Industrial Production in U.S. Declined by 0.5% in August

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
United States industrial production declined five-tenths of 1 percent in August, suffering from Hurricane Andrew, a strike at General Motors and weak consumer spending.
The Federal Reserve also reported that the plant-use rate, a separate indicator of industrial strength, declined to 78.5 percent of capacity during the month. 
 The drop in industrial production was the largest since a decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent in January. Today's disappointing report, along with other recent indicators of the economy's weakness, provides the Fed with added reason to cut short-term interest rates again, analysts said.
 
Figures Weaker Than Expected
 "It's just a matter of timing," said William Sullivan, an economist at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York. "Most of the data we've gotten for August have been weaker than expected."
The Federal Reserve's policy-making Open Market Committee next meets on Oct. 6, and many Fed watchers look for the central bank to lower rates then, if not sooner.
"This is an economy which is staggering ahead, and every once in a while it staggers backwards," said Robert Dederick, chief economist at Northern Trust in Chicago.
Stuart Hoffman, an economist at PNC Financial in Pittsburgh, predicted that the effects of Hurricane Andrew and the nine-day General Motors shutdown, which ended on Sept. 5, would spill over into September, producing another weak report.
Steve Wood, an economist at the Bank of America in San Francisco, said, "The factory sector of the economy is not doing well," which he said was crippling consumer spending.
As corporations scale back operations, workers are losing jobs. Manufacturing payrolls declined by 97,000 jobs in August amid widespread concern about the economy. Most of those who have not been laid off have been unable to get significant pay increases. As a result, retail sales declined five-tenths of 1 percent last month.
By category, factory output declined three-tenths of 1 percent in August, mining output dropped 1.3 percent and utility output decreased 1.2 percent.
Despite the losses, there were some pockets of strength. "Overall motor vehicle output still posted a 1 percent gain last month because increased truck production more than offset a drop in auto output," the Fed said.
During July, total industrial production increased by six-tenths of 1 percent, earlier reported as a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent, and the plant-use rate increased to 79.0 percent, earlier reported as 78.9 percent, the Fed report said.
Separately, the Commerce Department said business inventories had risen one-tenth of 1 percent in July after a revised increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in June. This reflects lackluster demand and the hesitancy of businesses to build stockpiles of goods, said Marco Babic, an analyst at Evans Economics in Washington.

HEADLINE: 1.1% Growth in World Economy Seen

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
After experiencing no growth last year, the world economy will expand only 1.1 percent this year and accelerate to a merely respectable 3 percent next year, the International Monetary Fund predicted today.
But even that 3 percent means that the recovery will be weaker than most other postwar rebounds, the fund added in its semiannual economic forecast, making clear that the global economy would largely parallel the ups and downs of the United States, which accounts for 25 percent of world output. 
 "Notwithstanding signs of recovery in the industrial countries, the expansion continues to be slow and uneven, and the balance of risks remains on the downside," the report said.
 
Debt Burdens Pose Risks
 Those risks include depressed consumer confidence and the large debt burdens that have discouraged many households and businesses in the wealthy nations from increasing spending.
These factors helped push the monetary fund to revise downward the estimates for world growth it made in May. At that time, the I.M.F. said the world economy would expand by 1.4 percent this year and 3.6 percent in 1993.
The report, called the World Economic Outlook, said the United States economy was being spurred by low interest rates and would grow by 1.9 percent this year over last year, and by 3.1 percent next year. Because of stronger than expected growth in the first quarter, the fund raised its estimate for American growth this year from the 1.6 percent estimate it made in May.
The fund said inflation in the United States would be 2.7 percent this year and 2.9 percent next year, down from 4.1 percent last year.
The fund forecasts a 16.8 percent plunge in output in the countries of the former Soviet bloc this year, a big factor depressing world growth. The fund said growth in several of these countries would soon start to pick up, and it foresees a 4.5 percent drop in output for them next year.
The brightest news in the report was the strong growth anticipated for the developing world, which the fund said would grow by 6.2 percent this year and the same next year, compared with 3.3 percent last year.
That compares with a forecast of 1.7 percent growth in the industrialized world this year, and 2.9 percent next year.
 
Growth in Developing Nations
 Developing nations have grown strongly, despite the weak international environment, because many have adopted successful reforms like reducing inflation, privatizing state industry and creating incentives for private investment.
"During the recent period of sluggish global growth, the successful reformers have registered sustained and relatively rapid increases in output," said report. "They key to their performance has been determined efforts to reduce fiscal deficts and to control inflation."
Those countries have also been helped by agreements that have reduced their debt burdens and by lower short-term interest rates that have lightened their debt service.
Pointing to the link between economic reform and growth, the report said Latin American countries that had made widespread changes -- many of which had been prescribed by the monetary fund -- would grow by 4.4 percent this year, while those that had not were expected to grow by 1.8 percent. In Africa, countries that have pursued reforms are expected to grow by 4.1 percent, while those that have not will grow by 1.7 percent, the fund said.
"There are very great regional differences in the performance of developing countries," Michael Mussa, the fund's chief economist, said at a news conference today. Developing countries in Asia are expected to grow by 6.6 percent, those in Africa by 3.3 percent.
In blunt language, the report urged the United States to slash its $320 billion budget deficit, which it said was undermining growth by sapping consumer and business confidence and pushing up long-term interest rates in America and beyond. The report called on Washington not just to cut spending to reduce the deficit, but also to raise taxes.
The deficit "is a factor that is limiting investment and growth in the U.S. economy and is having similar effect on the world economy," Mr. Mussa said.

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN EUROPE;
Fed Action On Europe Not Expected

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
The turmoil in European's financial markets is primarily a European affair and the United States will not get involved in trying to help steady Europe's jitters, officials of the Bush Administration and the Federal Reserve said today.
In fact, the turbulence could actually help both the American and the European economies, the officials said, because it could lead to lower interest rates and thus spur growth in Europe that would ultimately give the United States a boost as well. 
 Beyond that, Europe's foreign exchange trauma has given the Federal Reserve more flexibility to lower interest rates, because the trauma has strengthened the dollar, they said. The dollar's extreme weakness early this month prevented the Federal Reserve from cutting rates by more than the one-quarter point cut it announced on Sept. 4.
 
Fed Under Pressure
 In a speech today in Los Angeles, David W. Mullins Jr., the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, said the present European turmoil was essentially a European phenomenon.
"We're staying on the sidelines," said one Fed official.
But clearly the United States is not unaffected. Since the election season began, the Fed has been under intense pressure from both Congress and the White House to lower interest rates even further than they have. The rates are now the lowest they have been in three decades.
Fed officials acknowledged that if they had wanted to lower rates this week, they probably could not have done so. The step would have been be akin to throwing a great rock into an already unsettled pond.
An American rate cut would probably strengthen the German mark, and increase tensions in Europe, pressuring other nations to raise their interest rates and protect their currencies against the mark.
 
More Flexibility for Fed
 "What's happening in Europe gives the Fed a little more flexibility," said Geoffrey Dennis, an international economist with James Capel Inc. in New York. "They certainly won't cut rates this week, but they might do it in early October when the September employment report is released. I expect unemployment to be higher in that report."
One senior Administration official praised the idea of devaluations in Europe, saying that they would spur growth there. Faster growth in Italy or Britain should ultimately mean that those countries would import more American goods.
That official also said that such devaluations would lessen the need for these devaluing countries to jack up interest rates to defend their currency from falling against the German mark. Under the European Monetary System, member nations are required, barring a formal devaluation, to keep their currencies from falling against the mark.
Lower interest would spur growth in the devaluing nations and help spur their growth -- and growth throughout Europe.
 
Rooting for German Cuts
 European Community finance ministers are expected to announce more devaluations along the lines of the devaluation of the Italian lira.
[In Brussels early Thursday, the European Community finance ministers agreed to devalue the Spanish peseta and suspend the lira from the exchange rate system.]
"We want more of the same," said John Williamson, an economist with the Institute for International Economics. He said he feared that the Europeans might decide to keep some currencies at unrealistically high levels against the mark and that this could hinder growth by forcing some countries to raise rates. He was also rooting for further rate cuts by Germany's central bank.
American officials said the devaluations in Europe were not unalloyed good news because they could strengthen the dollar vis-a-vis the pound and lira, and thus make American goods less competitive versus British and Italian goods. But these officials said the devluations might help strengthen the mark against the dollar, and that could help America's competitive position.
 
Market Plunge Feared
 The big fear that American officials expressed was that the commotion in Europe could cause American stock and bond markets to plunge. One official said the fact that the New York Stock Exchange slid today while the dollar strengthened showed that the European situation was undermining investor confidence.
American officials said Europe's exchange rate markets will be at or near the top of the agenda when the Group of Seven's finance ministers meet Saturday in Washington. Originally, the weak dollar was scheduled to be topic No. 1.
Some economists suggested that the United States might push the Europeans to structure their monetary system in a way that countries other than Germany do not repeatedly have to jack up their interest rates to defend their currencies, thus slowing their economic growth.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Uncertainty Widens Bond Spread

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The long end of the American bond market was knocked lower by the turmoil in European currency markets yesterday, but shorter maturities, including two- and three-year notes, rose.
The behavior of the market was a classic reaction to uncertainity and pushed the spread or differential between the two-year note and the 30-year note to a record level. 
 The new record was the surest sign in a day of volatile and thin trading that the troubled outlook for Europe had battered traders, investors and speculators in New York, although the consequences of what is going on abroad could actually benefit the bond market.
"I get the strong sense that people don't know what to do," said Robert Di Clemente, an economist at Salomon Brothers in New York. "It is just not clear where the balance comes out and it is not clear-cut what the market should do or what the implications are for our markets."
 
Figuring Out the Impact

All eyes are now on Europe as analysts and investors try to figure out the probable impact of Britain's surprise decision to suspend its participation in the European Monetary System, which links the currencies of 11 European countries in fixed trading bands. The system was designed to bring, and had brought, stability to European foreign-exchange trading.
But the system came under severe strain this summer as the German mark rallied because of concern over the outlook for the economic union of Europe.
With polls showing that a French referendum on Sunday might turn down the next steps to an economic union, the pound and the Italian lira plummeted. And even a hasty lira devaluation and small German interest-rate cuts on Monday could not relieve the pressure.
And when the British pound slipped below the bottom of its allowed trading floor despite a five-percentage-point increase in Bank of England interest rates yesterday, the Government of Prime Minister John Major apparently had no choice but to devalue the pound by withdrawing from the monetary system.
 
System's Future Uncertain
 The British decision calls into question the future of the monetary system, and until it is clear what happens next, investors may be leery of taking positions, which means thin trading and volatile moves like those in New York trading yesterday.
In late trading in the secondary market for Treasury securities, the price of the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was off 7/32 to yield 7.32 percent, up from 7.30 percent Tuesday.
The bond had been off sharply in the morning and then rallied up to a few seconds before the British announcement. Barbara L. Kenworthy, portfolio manager of fixed-income funds at the Dreyfus Corporation, said the morning decline had been caused in part by central-bank selling of Treasury securities to raise the cash needed for the futile effort to support the British pound and Italian lira.
But the price of the two-year 4.25 percent note was up 3/32 to yield 3.79 percent, compared with 3.84 percent the day before. And the price of the 4.625 percent three-year note was up 4/32 to yield 4.31 percent, down from 4.35 percent. The spread between the yield on the two-year note and the 30-year bond rose to 353 basis points or hundredths of a percentage point, eclipsing the mark of 349 basis points set Monday.
 
A Possible Positive Side
 When there is uncertainity in the market, investors tend to get out of longer maturities because they are more volatile and subject to greater losses if some unexpected event occurs.
The discount rates on three-month, six-month and one-year Treasury bills also fell yesterday. The move, and the fall in yields on the two-year and three-year notes, also reflect one of the positive beneifts of the turmoil in Europe -- the possibilty that the Federal Reserve will gain the freedom it needs to lower short-term interests here further.
Already the dollar had risen since the German rate cut Monday and it rallied again yesterday. An eventual agreement among European members on a broad devalualtion of currencies against the German mark could also mean a further rate cut by the Germans, helping the dollar more. And the uncertainity in Europe is likely to bring some foreign investors to the United States, where the basic economic fundamentals are good for the bond market.
"When the dust settles, we will find that this is a net plus for the United States," said Stephen Slifer, financial market economist at Lehman Brothers.
 
Foreign Bonds
 Foreign bonds markets were in turmoil but closed before the final British decison to devalue the pound. Ms. Kenworthy of Dreyfus said it was hard to get prices in the cash bond markets, which means that traders were unwilling to take a position in the face of such uncertainity.
In London, in a sign of the turmoil, the futures contract on the 10-year bond ended higher despite the interest-rate increases while the price of the active active 10-year bond closed down.
But in Germany and France, in heavy trading, bond prices rose on the expectation that the Germans would eventually have to lower interest rates to calm financial markets.

HEADLINE: Erratic Day Sees Stocks Drop Again

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock prices lost more ground yesterday, bouncing erratically as traders tried to sort out the outlook for foreign-exchange markets and interest rates worldwide.
The Dow Jones industrials, down 48.90 points on Tuesday, lost another 8.11 points, to 3,319.21. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 5 to 4 on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume climbed to an estimated 231.6 million shares, from 211.9 million Tuesday. 
 The stock market rallied sharply at the start of the week as German authorities cut interest rates, presumably breaking a logjam of conflicting monetary policies among major industrialized countries. But by Tuesday, investors took a much less ebullient view, noting a variety of unresolved issues and questions, and sent stocks lower.
 
Defending the Pound
 Yesterday began with news that British officials had raised interest rates to defend the pound. Later, they said they would suspend the currency from the system known as the European Exchange Rate Mechanism. That posed uncertainties for the campaign to set up closer monetary and economic ties among European nations, which faces an important referendum in France on Sunday.
Amid the confusion, many American depository shares of European companies ran into selling pressure. Imperial Chemical, for example, fell 7/8 to 78 1/2; Fiat 1 1/8, to 14 3/8; British Telecom 1 5/8, to 62 7/8; British Air 7/8, to 49 5/8, and Montedison 1/4, to 9. But Hanson of Britain rose 1/4, to 19 5/8, and Royal Dutch Petroleum added 1, to 86 3/4.
Analysts said the potential effects on individual businesses and industries of a scrambled European political and economic picture would be complex and widely varying.
Whatever course events take in Europe, brokers also caution, the effect on any economic recovery in the United States was unclear.
 
Outlook at First Interstate
 Losers among the blue chips included I.B.M., down 2 3/8 at 83 1/8; General Motors, down 5/8 at 33 1/4; Boeing, down 1 at 35 3/4; Du Pont, down 1 1/8 at 46 3/4, and A.T.& T., down 1/2 at 44 1/8.
First Interstate Bancorp rose 2 1/8, to 38 3/8. The bank holding company raised its earnings forecast for 1992 and lowered its projected nonperforming assets as of year's end.
Syntex edged up 1/8, to 28 1/2, in active trading. The company said directors had approved a plan to buy back as many as seven million shares.
Proteon, traded over the counter, fell 3 3/4, to 11 1/4. The company said its third-quarter earnings would be below expectations, and added that fourth-quarter results could disappoint as well.
Topps, another Nasdaq issue, fell 3/4, to 16 3/4. The company posted quarterly earnings that came in a shade below what most analysts had been expecting.
The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter issues dropped 1.97 points, to 585.89. At the American Stock Exchange, the Market Value Index was down 0.21 at 385.52.

HEADLINE: OPEC Meets on Output

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GENEVA, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met today, hoping to find a production accord that will nudge crude oil prices up this winter.
Prices for crude oil pumped by the 13 OPEC members have been rising as customers buy oil ahead of the cold weather and analysts expect that growing demand could bump up prices by $1 to $2 a barrel in the coming months. 
 "Whatever is decided here -- unless there is a breakdown in the negotiations -- prices will continue to move up somewhat," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. "The trend now is upward."
The ministers met for about two and a half hours before adjourning to bargain behind closed doors.
Secretary General Subroto of OPEC said they discussed the world economic situation and noted the continued weakness of industrialized economies.
"The expectation of a recovery in the second half of 1992 has not materialized," he told reporters. "On top of that, there is this turmoil in the foreign exchange market."
The OPEC members are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

HEADLINE: U.S.-China Rift at Trade Talks Is Still Wide

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 16

 BODY:
American and Chinese negotiators concluded a third day of talks today on a number of contentious trade issues, but the two sides remained far apart on what could prove a landmark trade agreement.
The United States has given China until Oct. 10 to agree to lower a range of import barriers or face punitive tariffs against $3.9 billion worth of Chinese exports to the United States. China has threatened to retaliate by raising tariffs on $4 billion worth of imports of American goods if the United States imposes sanctions. 
 "Although there is still a sizable gap between the positions of the two sides, and much work remains, I remain hopeful that an agreement can be reached by the Oct. 10 deadline," said Michael Moskow, the deputy United States trade representative who is part of the negotiations.
 
Trade More Crucial for China
 Mr. Moskow dismissed China's threat to impose its own sanctions since, he said, China sends about a fourth of all its exports to the American market but takes less than 2 percent of America's exports.
"I think it's clear the impact would be much more significant on China than on the United States," he said.
Although Mr. Moskow tried to put the discussions in a positive light, American officials said that none of the substantive issues had been resolved. These include American demands that China provide more information on its trade polices and rules, that it remove import prohibitions and quotas, that it stop the practice of requiring importers to obtain Government licenses and that it change testing requirements that keep out some imports.
The Americans reported that the Chinese had not pressed the most sensitive issue, President Bush's decision to sell 150 F-16 jet fighters to Taiwan. China has insisted that the sale violates a 1982 agreement in which the United States agreed to phase out its weapons sales to the Nationalist Government on Taiwan, which the Chinese regard as a renegade province.
"They may have commented about the fact that this had happened, but it was never a serious part of the discussion," Mr. Moskow said.
Discussions at the technical level will continue here one more day, then will resume in Washington on Oct. 1. They are expected to continue to Oct. 10, and perhaps after that.
American officials have made it clear that if the talks fail, in addition to imposing the sharply higher tariffs, they will also block China from membership in the body that oversees the world trading system, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, known as the GATT.
That raises the stakes significantly for China, since its economy has grown increasingly reliant on trade for its rapid growth rate and growing prosperity.
Trade as a percentage of China's gross national product has risen from 9.9 percent in 1978 to 31.3 percent in 1990, according to official figures. China's trade surplus with the United States has soared, too. It was $12.7 billion last year and is expected to run at $15 billion to $19 billion this year.

HEADLINE: S.& L.'s Earn $2.81 Billion In Best 6 Months Since 1986

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Earnings at the nation's savings institutions slipped a bit in the second quarter but the first half was the industry's most profitable six months since 1986, the Government said today.
Profits at the 2,013 so-called private sector institutions -- those that have not been seized by the Government -- totaled $1.27 billion in the second quarter, down 18 percent from $1.54 billion in the first three months of the year, the Office of Thrift Supervision said. 
 But net income for the first half of 1992 was more than triple the $885 million earned during the first half of 1991. It was the best six months since October 1985 through March 1986.
 
Bad Loans at HomeFed
 Officials at the office attributed about half of the second-quarter deterioration to the write-off of bad loans by HomeFed Bank in San Diego, which was seized by regulators in early July, just after the closing date for today's financial data.
Timothy Ryan, the director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, attributed the improvement this year to the extremely wide gap between interest rates paid on deposits and those earned on mortgage loans, and to the Government's program of shutting down insolvent institutions.
Mr. Ryan warned institutions not to depend on current low interest rates, which he said would inevitably rise. About 40 percent of the industry is vulnerable to losses if rates rise by two percentage points, he said.
Mr. Ryan also asked Congress to supply money to the Resolution Trust Corporation, which has lacked the funds to shut down insolvent institutions since April 1. The delay in financing has already added $750 million to the cost of the savings and loan bailout, he said.
Only 26 institutions with $19 billion in assets remain in the group of savings and loans the office considers likely to become wards of the Resolution Trust Corporation.
"To be at the end of the process and to be on hold is very frustrating," he said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields on Taxable Funds Drop Under 3%

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Yields on taxable money market funds fell below 3 percent for the first time since 1975 in the week ended Tuesday, The IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.
The drop in taxable yields was a continuation of the decline that began last week, when yields fell in response to the Federal Reserve Board's quarter-point cut in the overnight Federal funds rate on Sept. 4. 
 The drop in taxable yields stood in marked contrast to the performance of yields on tax-exempt money market funds. For the second straight week, heavy issuance of new municipal bonds pushed up yields on tax-exempt funds, IBC/Donoghue said.
 
Assets Are Down
 According to IBC/Donoghue's, the assets of 309 tax-free money funds fell by $799 million in the week, to $95.1 billion. The average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios fell by two days, to 65.
The seven-day average compounded yield on the tax-exempt funds rose 5 basis points, to 2.44 percent, and the simple yield rose a similar amount, to 2.41 percent. Over a 30-day period, the average compounded and simple yields rose by 7 basis points and 8 basis points, respectively, to 2.33 percent and 2.31 percent. A basis point in a hundredth of a percentage point.
Not assuming state taxes, the taxable equivalent yield on the seven-day compounded yield is 3.39 percent for investors in the 28 percent bracket, up 7 basis points. The equivalent for investors in the 31 percent bracket is 3.54 percent, up 8 basis points.
In its weekly survey of tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue said the Dreyfus Basic Municipal fund was the best-performing fund, with a return of 3.25 percent.
 
Taxable Funds
 Meanwhile, yields in taxable money market funds fell sharply for the second straight week, even though total assets held by those funds rose slightly.
Through Tuesday, 553 taxable funds held assets of $499.4 billion, up $43 million.
The average seven-day compounded yield on these taxable funds was 2.94 percent, down 7 basis points for the week. That is the lowest yield level on a taxable money market fund since IBC/Donoghue began tracking money market funds in 1975. The seven-day simple yield was 2.90 percent, down 6 basis points.
For a 30-day average, the compounded and simple yields fell by 4 basis points and 3 basis points, respectively, to 3.02 percent and 2.98 percent.
Since changes in money market fund yields generally lag behind movements in the Federal funds rate, Mary Sue Hoban, a spokeswoman for IBC/Donoghue, said that compounded yields on taxable money market funds will probably fall another 10 basis points from current levels before they reflect the Fed's 25 basis- point cut in the funds rate on Sept. 4.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in portfolios rose by one, to 64.
The Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund was the best performer among large general purpose funds, with a yield of 3.77 percent. But including funds with assets of less than $100 million that invest only in Government securities, the United Services Government Securities Savings fund, distributed by United Services Advisors in San Antonio, was once again the top performer, with a yield of 4.09 percent.
By comparison, the average bank money market account slipped 6 basis points this week, to yield 2.92 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Broad Rally for the Dollar On the Upheaval in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The pound tumbled yesterday despite dramatic moves by the British Government to defend it, deepening the monetary crisis in Europe and sharply lifting the dollar's value as a safe-harbor currency.
"It's been a very hectic day," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the New York branch of the Bank Leumi Trust Company. "There was a lot of blood in the sterling pits today. A lot of people were very confused." 
 Britain's actions were only part of a frenetic day marked by dramatic government interventions elsewhere in Europe. Sweden's central bank raised a key lending rate to a staggering 500 percent in an attempt to defend its currency the krona, while Italy's central bank bought lire to support that currency's value.
In response, many investors fled to dollar-denominated investments as a haven, temporarily ignoring the dollar's unattractiveness in terms of the United States economy's own economic malaise and the uncertain outcome of the Presidential campaigns.
"With Europe in such a big mess, the skirmish between George Bush and Bill Clinton doesn't matter for the time being; so I go into the currency that I know," said Zlatko Glamuzina, chief trader at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia.
 
Dollar Up Against Yen
 In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 124.30 yen, down 0.58 yen from Monday; Tokyo markets were closed for a national holiday Tuesday. But later in London it rose to 124.90 yen. And in New York the dollar fetched 125.15 yen, up from 124.25 yen late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with levels late Tuesday, were: 1.5140 German marks, up from 1.4910; 1.3230 Swiss francs, up from 1.3195; 1.2236 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2172; 5.1528 French francs, up from 5.0640, and 1,257 Italian lire, up from 1,205.50.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday, were: 1.5185 German marks, up from 1.4855; 1.3210 Swiss francs, up from 1.3145; 5.1325 French francs, up from 5.0450; 1.7055 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6733; 1,246.50 lire, up from 1,193.48, and 1.2200 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2187.

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN EUROPE;
Why the Currency Crisis Erupted: A Primer

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
A currency crisis is something that is not supposed to happen these days. The very idea evokes images from old newsreels, with grave statesmen in top hats emerging from limousines to urge calm in gravelly voices. But suddenly Europe is up to its eyebrows in one. And while the immediate impact on most people's daily lives will be slight, it could derail the drive to European unity that only a few months ago seemed as inevitable as tomorrow's sunrise.
How could something so important have happened with so little warning? And why are elected officials who have staked their careers on the currency arrangement known as the European Monetary System seemingly powerless to prevent its meltdown? The answers lie in the basic economics of international finance -- and the even more basic conflicts between domestic and regional political priorities.
 
Trading Francs for Pounds
 Francs are the coin of the realm in France. But when a French company wants to import machinery from a producer in Manchester, England, it must pay the bills in British pounds. And to obtain the pounds, the company must find someone willing to exchange British currency for francs. 
 The exchange rate is thus the price of pounds in francs, or francs in pounds. And it must roughly reflect the relative purchasing power of the two currencies in their home markets. If, for example, a drill press costs 1,000 francs in Paris and 200 in London, the exchange rate had better be more or less 5 francs to the pound. Otherwise, both the British and the French will buy all their drills presses on one side of the Channel.
But like life, economics rarely works out so neatly. In the short run, currency exchange rates are influenced by many factors, including the behavior of governments. And since the rates have enormous impact on where goods that can be traded are made and how much they cost, exchange rates are a matter of great interest to the people in charge of national economies.
Most countries (including the United States) allow their currencies to "float" against others. Voluntary transactions between private buyers and sellers determine a currency's value. That suits many politicians, since setting a fixed exchange rate would force them to balance the interests of domestic producers against those of consumers buying goods from abroad.
But European leaders are immensely taken by the idea of maintaining very stable exchange rates within the greater European economy, and for two reasons. First the system eliminates uncertainty, greasing the wheels of commerce within Europe. A German truck maker can set a price for its trucks in Italian lira, for delivery in six months, because it knows what the exchange rate between marks and lira will be.
More important, a fixed exchange system imposes a collective discipline on all the national economies linked to the system. If, for example, Italy allows inflation at home to drive up production costs at its factories, a fixed exchange rate with the mark (and pound and franc) will make Italian products from those factories too expensive to sell abroad.
Indeed, from this perspective, the only other thing better than maintaining fixed exchange rates among European currencies is the adoption of a single currency for the whole European economy. And that is just what European Community leaders proposed to do in the Maastricht agreement on European political and economic union, which they signed last December.
The signatories at Maastricht, visionaries who generally speak of the agreement in political terms, appeared to comprehend that a successful currency union -- or for that matter, a stable fixed exchange rate system -- demanded coordination of virtually all aspects of national economic policy. But they were unable to accomplish that before the currency crisis erupted.
 
Price of Unification
 Two years ago, West Germany took on the burden of paying for German unification. But the price of bringing eastern Germany up to snuff and subsidizing the easterners' living standards in the meantime has been far higher than anyone guessed. And the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl has balked at raising taxes sufficiently to keep Germany's budget in balance.
Germany's inflation-wary (and very independent) central bank reacted by jacking up interest rates. Foreigners responded by purchasing tens of billions of dollars' worth of German marks and investing the proceeds in German bank deposits paying as much as 9 percent interest -- a far higher interest rate than they could get by depositing their money in New York.
Not surprisingly, the price of the mark soared with respect to the dollar as traders found it evermore difficult to find people to sell them the German currency. What should not have surprised anyone, but somehow did, was the reaction in currency markets in the rest of Europe.
Since, by government agreement, all the leading European currencies were tied to the mark, they, too, rose sharply in value relative to the dollar. But in the last month, the banks and corporations that control much of the worlds' currency in private hands wondered whether these agreements would stick. And with good reason.
 
Last Thing They Wanted
 To maintain fixed exchange rates with Germany, other European countries were forced to raise their interest rates to make it as attractive for investors to hold these nations' currencies as it was to hold German marks. But with Britain deep in recession and other European economies heading there, the last thing that European leaders wanted to do was to discourage domestic spending by raising interest rates.
Check that: the very last thing they wanted to do was to allow their currencies to remain high against the dollar for very long. Much of their trade, after all, is with the United States. And a strong pound or franc or lira makes their goods more expensive and harder to sell in the country that pays its bills in greenbacks.
The more traders thought about it, the less they wanted to take the chance of being caught holding currencies other than German marks on the day that European governments were unable to defend fixed exchange rates. Britain tried to bluff, effectively arguing that it would do anything to hold the line. But in the end, the traders' prophecy proved to be self-fulfilling.
The economic damage is likely to be modest. Indeed, the currency realignment forced by the German policy of tight money and high interest rates could do a lot of good in the short run.
The longer-term impact is harder to assess. In the best of worlds, it will teach Europeans a relatively painless lesson about the importance of coordinating their economic policies.

HEADLINE: Twice as Many Families Seek Space in City Shelters

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
The number of homeless families entering New York City's troubled shelter system this summer is almost twice last summer's level, causing a backup that has left more than 100 families a night sleeping on floors and tables in city welfare offices.
Most of the families flooding the system this summer have sought emergency shelter before -- an indication that they are having a tougher time finding permanent housing they can afford or staying doubled up with friends and family in the recession, city officials say. 
 "It's an explosion," said Ken Murphy, deputy commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration. "Two or three years ago, we had to place maybe 75 families each night. Last night, we placed 210 families and still had 143 left over in the offices at 8 A.M."
During July and August this year, 13,994 families went to city offices seeking shelter, he said. Last year, only 7,526 did.
Homeless families, usually mothers with children, often churn in and out of the shelters, staying with friends of family whenever they can. Despite the constant movement, the system has reached an all-time high. The number of families in the system is now 5,376, city officials said.
The backup of families in offices where they apply for shelter has provoked a bitter exchange between state and city officials who are blaming each other for the system's failures.
State welfare officials have ordered the city to improve conditions quickly for the families or face financial sanctions.
For their part, city officials are blaming the problem on the state's housing allowance for welfare families, saying it is too low to allow families to pay rent in the city.
Advocates for the homeless appear to have helped set off the feud between the city and state by threatening a new lawsuit if nothing is done to help the families.
The Legal Aid Society said in in a letter to the state last month that it was considering going to court to try to force it to run the city's vast, overburdened shelter system. The lawyers said the state had failed to enforce its own rules that require families to be promptly sheltered in decent housing.
"For at least two years, the state has sat back and permitted the city on a nightly basis to harm hundreds of families with children," said Steve Banks, coordinating attorney for the Legal Aid Society's Homeless Family Rights Project.
Less than two weeks after the Legal Aid Society wrote the state, the state's Commissioner of Social Services, Mary Jo Bane, fired off an ultimatum to the city insisting that the city immediately end the practice of overnight stays in offices.
"Further delay cannot be accepted," she wrote on Sept. 10.
Ms. Bane said her action was not a response to Legal Aid's threatened suit, but to the surging number of families stuck in city offices. But she conceded that the prospect of the state running the city's shelter system "was not a happy thought."
"It is certainly not something we aspire to do," she said. "Anybody who tried to run the shelter system would find it quite difficult."
 
Fingers of Blame
 City officials have responded angrily to Ms. Bane's letter. They say the state's shelter allowance has not kept pace with rising rent costs. In 1975, the monthly allowance of $218 a month for a family of four covered the rental costs of 95 percent of families on welfare in the city, while this year, the rental allowance of $312 a month covered the rents of only a third of the families.
"This is a continuation of the myopic state public policy which has brought us to the present crisis situation," Barbara J. Sabol, who heads the city's Human Resources Administration, wrote in answer to Ms. Bane.
As city and state officials point fingers of blame at each other, hundreds of homeless families are now spending the night on tables, in hard plastic chairs and even on the floors of the four city offices where the homeless initially apply for emergency shelter.
It is not clear why the numbers have jumped so suddenly. "That's the question of the hour," said Terrance M. McGrath, a spokesman for the State Department of Social Services.
City and state officials speculate that the worsening economy has contributed to the rise. This July, the number of New Yorkers on welfare surpassed one million for the first time since the 1970's.
The backlog is likely to be made worse over the coming year because the number of units of permanent housing the city has to give to homeless families in its shelter system has declined. Three years ago the city provided 5,000 units of housing. That number has steadily declined to about 3,600 this year.
"People are having a harder and harder time getting out of the system," Mr. Murphy said.
 
Fewer Apartments Found
 The city's public housing authority, worried that too many troubled homeless families were destabilizing its projects, recently negotiated a reduction in the number of homeless families it will place from 2,000 to about 1,400.
And the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which usually produces about 75 to 100 apartments a month, is behind schedule. In August, it came up with only three apartments, city officials said. More apartments will begin becoming available in November, but the delay has made it more difficult for the city to move families out of the shelters into permanent housing.
Mr. Murphy speculated that families on hard times who have cycled in and our of the shelters over the last couple of years have progressively worn out their welcome with the friends and relatives they stay with when not in a shelter.
The city's Human Resources Administration developed a new plan this spring for handling homeless families coming into the system. It proposed consolidating the four offices, one in every borough except Staten Island, where homeless families apply for shelter into one office at 325 Hudson Street, at King Street, in Manhattan.
The goal is to centralize all the services and to make it easier for the city to keep track of all the homeless families entering the system. The consolidation would also save the city about $400,000 a year through staff reductions. Several prominent advocates for the homeless, including Anna Lou Dehavenon, an urban anthropologist, supported the plan.
But it has suffered repeated setbacks, the latest one yesterday when Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan came out against it. Community Board 2, as well as several prominent advocates for the homeless who served on the Mayor's commission on homelessness, strongly opposed the consolidation plan.
 
Lobbying Effort
 Andrew Cuomo, who headed Mayor David N. Dinkins's blue-ribbon commission on the homeless, said the consolidation was meant to make it more difficult for families to enter the system.
Last month a group of residents and business people near the Hudson Street project hired Sid Davidoff, the lobbyist who is a close friend of Mayor Dinkins, to represent them in their battle against the project.
Then at a hearing before Ms. Messinger on Sept. 9, part of the city's convoluted land-use process, the Human Resources Administration did not come forward to make the case for its own proposal.
The administration's officials said they were in the audience at the public hearing but chose not to come forward. They had already made their case at earlier meetings. But Ms. Messinger said in her 10-page decision on the issue, released yesterday, that she interpreted the administration's silence as a lack of enthusiasm for its own consolidation project.

HEADLINE: Public and Private Mix at Columbia

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Amid whirling flashing gadgets of the future, political and academic leaders gathered at Columbia University yesterday to dedicate a research center that they hope will help create thousands of new jobs over the decades.
The Morris A. Schapiro Center for Engineering and Physical Science Research, an amalgam of state, Federal and university research programs -- most of whose $115 million cost was financed by the state -- is intended to promote greater cooperation between scientists from academia and corporations by encouraging them to work side-by-side on projects. 
 At a time when New York is suffering from its most severe loss of jobs since World War II, the hope is that such a collaboration will make the state, and the country, much better at something in which it has been deficient in recent decades: turning important scientific discoveries into the kinds of sellable high-technology products that can reverse the decline in manufacturing jobs.
 
More Than Gleam in Eye
 The center's research will focus on telecommunications, microelectronics and computer science. As a tour of the laboratories revealed, many of these potential products are already much more than the gleam in a scientist's eye.
There were robotic hands that could twirl balls, turn knobs and sense the things they touched much like the real thing. There were computerized eyes that could keep tabs on moving objects and feed the information to a robotic arm. And there was an embryonic telecommunications system that used light to transmit conversations, images, faxes and computer data simultaneously; a prototype will soon be installed at Columbia.
"Our prosperity and national strength depend increasingly on research like that taking place here," Frank Press, president of the National Academy of Sciences, said at the dedication ceremony on the upper Manhattan campus.
The Schapiro center -- named for an investment banker and Columbia alumnus who donated $10 million to the project -- is not new in one sense; the building is merely providing a bigger home for several existing cooperative research programs established by the state and Federal Governments at Columbia, as well as some of the school's research efforts.
 
'About Being Intelligent'
 New York has established nine centers for research in advanced technology since 1983 at universities across the state. At a time when the role of governments in improving industrial competitiveness and stimulating the economy is being debated heatedly across the nation, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo made it clear where he stands.
Ridiculing the extremists in the debate, he described himself as a "progressive pragmatist" who believes that business alone cannot not summon the resources needed to compete against the likes of the Japanese and the European Community.
"In a world like that, you had better get your government a little bit involved," he said at the dedication. "I'm not talking about neo-socialism. I'm not talking about being intrusive. I'm talking about being intelligent and doing the things collectively what you could not do at all or so well individually: helping research, helping science, helping education."
In an interview, Yechiam Yemini, director of the state center for advanced technology at Columbia, said research at his unit had led to the creation of more than a dozen companies, eight of which still existed. The eight -- including computer hardware and software companies and securities-trading companies -- employ more than 500 people, about 200 of them in New York, he said.
A 1991 study of the impact of nine centers found that they had led to the creation of 47 companies.
The state has invested $61 million in the research programs, excluding the investment in the new building, said Theresa A. Walker, manager of university-industry programs at the New York State Science and Technology Foundation.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Women;
For Feminists, It Wasn't What They Had in Mind

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
The New York Senate primary, one of the highest visibility races in this political year, turned into a crushing disappointment for the feminist movement yesterday. There were bitter divisions. There were wounds to be healed. And there were questions about the damage to the political careers of two feminist heroines, Geraldine A. Ferraro and Elizabeth Holtzman.
For Ms. Ferraro, who spent the day in seclusion, her loss after attacks on her family's finances and ethics was a wrenching reprise of the 1984 Vice-Presidential race. After eight years of obscurity, she made a bid for redemption only to watch a strong lead evaporate once again under a barrage of questions about her husband's business dealings and accusations that he was associated with organized crime figures. 
 Ms. Holtzman, the steely City Comptroller who had longed for 12 years for a second attempt at the Senate seat she narrowly lost in 1980, came in dead last, behind the Rev. Al Sharpton. In the process she waged a campaign so negative that some politicians are now asking if she has damaged herself for the future.
Once the Democratic primary for the right to challenge Alfonse M. D'Amato had been seen by feminists as almost an agonizing embarrassment of riches in what they call the year of the woman. Here was Ms. Ferraro, the charismatic pathbreaker, and Ms. Holtzman, the feminist purist, both seeking the same office. Many women's groups gave the two idols joint endorsements, and then watched anxiously as the heroines faced off in a race that turned ever more bitter.
 
'Missed Opportunity'
 In Washington yesterday, leaders of the major women's groups could only express dismay that it was a man, Robert Abrams, who had narrowly won the Democratic race.
"It's a terrible disappointment because New York is a state that was ready to and would elect a woman to the United States Senate," said Harriett Woods, president of the National Women's Political Caucus. "It's a great missed opportunity."
But in New York, where each candidate had devoted female followers, the post-election debate among feminists was poisonous.
Letty Cottin Pogrebin, a founding editor of Ms. magazine, denounced the tenor of Ms. Holtzman's campaign, which consisted of unrelenting attacks on Ms. Ferraro's ethics. "In my view and the view of many other people with whom I have spoken, I will never support her for anything again," she said. "Her turn would have come. It was clear she never could have won this race. It was hubris that kept her in."
But Betty Friedan, the feminist author, said Ms. Ferraro's supporters had only themselves to blame for their defeat. "What is this, for God's sakes?" she asked, almost shouting. "Why should Holtzman be blamed for Geraldine Ferraro's defeat?"
 
Settling Old Scores
 "How dare they try to blame Liz Holtzman for the question marks about Geraldine Ferraro," she said. "Blame the people who put forward a candidate about whom they knew these questions existed."
For both Ms. Ferraro and Ms. Holtzman, this Senate race had a special resonance. For each, in a way, it was the race she should have had against Alfonse M. D'Amato.
Ms. Holtzman was narrowly defeated by Mr. D'Amato in 1980 when Jacob K. Javits, the toppled Republican incumbent, persisted in seeking re-election on the Liberal line and drained liberal and Jewish votes from her.
Four years later, at the moment Ms. Ferraro, then a six-term Congresswoman from Queens, was tapped by Walter Mondale to be his Vice-Presidential running mate, Ms. Ferraro had been talked about as Mr. D'Amato's next challenger. And even if the Democratic ticket lost, she would only be helped in a Senate race, the pundits said.
 
Ms. Ferraro's Chance
 But that was before Ms. Ferraro became the first woman to be put through the fire of running on the national ticket of a major party. It was before anyone understood how a breadwinner spouse would be scrutinized and how Ms. Ferraro's campaign would be pummeled with questions about her husband's business dealings and associations.
At one point during that tormented campaign, she said, "Whatever happens in this campaign, I'm going to spend the rest of my life making it up to my husband, who I love dearly, who's a very honest man, who's put a lot of aggravation into this thing."
But eight years later, after extensive polling, she thought she and her family could withstand another barrage and that she had a strong chance to win office in a year of voter concern about the economy and women's issues, like abortion rights. She said she expected the questions of 1984 to be raised again. But not by Democrats. And not by Liz Holtzman.
And when it was Ms. Holtzman who led the barrage in order to shake Ms. Ferraro's status as a front-runner, women in the feminist movement began to turn on each other, publicly demanding whether it was somehow uncharacteristic of a feminist to fight dirty. Others retorted that this was an invidious double standard to ask a woman to fight, but not hard, not to win.
 
Holtzman as Spoiler
 For Ms. Ferraro's staff and supporters, many questions remained yesterday: Why did Ms. Holtzman go after their candidate alone, when all her campaign attacks only seemed to help Mr. Abrams? Why, at some point, didn't she subsist in the interest of electing a woman instead of Mr. Abrams?
"In the year of the woman, I want to get a woman," said Teresa Vilmaine, Ms. Ferraro's campaign manager, calling Ms. Holtzman's campaign strategy "irrational." She accused Ms. Holtzman of playing the same spoiler role against Ms. Ferraro than Mr. Javits once played against Ms. Holtzman.
Back in the City Comptroller's office, a somewhat subdued Ms. Holtzman showed no remorse for knocking out the other female candidate.
"Well, I was hoping a woman would win this race, and I was hoping it would be me," she said. "I waged a tough and hard campaign and I think it's a traditional New York campaign. I don't think we broke any new ground in that respect."
 
Koch on Holtzman
 Ms. Holtzman added: "I think to extract that somehow when a woman runs for office she is not entitled to try to win, that's real unjustifiable and unfair. I entered this race to win."
Other politicians weren't so sure that she took the right approach. "Just as Ed Koch so damaged himself in 1988 with his stridency against Jesse Jackson, I think she did it to herself now in this race," said Lawrence Mandelker, who had been the campaign treasurer to former Mayor Edward I. Koch. "I think she's going to get a primary next year and then she's going to have to argue that you've got to keep a woman as the comptroller."
Mr. Koch himself said, "I don't think she'll ever be able to run for anything other than re-election as comptroller ever again with any feeling that she's secure in the women's vote."
Ms. Ferraro was also being described in past tenses, with Ms. Pogrebin speaking bitterly of how the candidate's political career had been "destroyed."
And in Washington, the women's movement was moving on, pointing to other victors to symbolize the struggle, like Patty Murray, who in September won the Democratic nomination to run for the Senate from Washington State. "Even with this defeat we still have heroines," said Ms. Woods. "We may grieve over New York but we have other battles ready to be fought."
