HEADLINE: Millicent Fenwick, 82, Dies; Gave Character to Congress

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Millicent H. Fenwick, a retired Republican Congresswoman renowned for her political independence and championing of liberal causes, died yesterday at her home in Bernardsville, N.J. She was 82 years old.
She died of heart failure, her family said. 
 "Millicent Fenwick was the Katharine Hepburn of politics," said Charles Millard, a former aide and now a Republican New York City Councilman. "With her dignity and elegance, she could get away with saying things others couldn't."
Mrs. Fenwick, whose colorful personality inspired cartoon characters, had a varied career, including stints as a fashion model, an author and editor and decades of public service in local, state and Federal elected and appointed posts.
She was perhaps most widely known for her wit, zest and idiosyncrasies like pipe smoking, a habit she adopted when her physician discouraged her from cigarettes. Tall and patrician, but down-to-earth and pungent, she inspired the Lacey Davenport character in Garry Trudeau's "Doonesbury" cartoons.
 
Watchdog of Helsinki Accords
 On her substantive record, she won the respect of her political peers, sometimes grudgingly, for her advocacy on a wide variety of issues, including civil rights, peace in Vietnam, aid for asbestos victims, help for the poor, prison reform, strip-mining controls, reduction of military programs, urban renewal, campaign spending limits, gun control and restrictions on capital punishment.
Among Mrs. Fenwick's proudest achievements was being a lead sponsor of the resolution creating the commission to monitor the 1975 Helsinki accords on human rights.
Her views often placed her at odds with her party's leaders and seemed anomalous for the wealthy district in New Jersey's horse country that she represented. Fighting for bathrooms for migrant workers won her the nickname of Outhouse Millie. Others called her the Bella Abzug of Somerset County, a nod to the outspoken former Congresswoman.
She so frustrated Representative Wayne Hays, a Democrat of Ohio, that he once threatened to withhold her staff's paychecks "if that woman doesn't sit down and keep quiet."
 
Hail and Farewell and Oink
 Although Mrs. Fenwick was strong willed, she often charmed her ideological adversaries.
In a debate over equal rights for women, she once recalled, a male legislator said: "I just don't like this amendment. I've always thought of women as kissable, cuddly and smelling good." Her reply was classic Fenwick: "That's the way I feel about men, too. I only hope for your sake that you haven't been disappointed as often as I have."
When she left the State Assembly, one man kissed her, saying: "We male chauvinist pigs all will miss you, Millicent, because you're a wonderful woman."
Mrs. Fenwick's political career flourished with age. She first ran and won a seat in the State Legislature at the age of 59 and in Congress at 64. The Congressional primary rival she beat was Thomas H. Kean, later elected Governor.
Gov. William T. Cahill appointed her as New Jersey's first director of consumer affairs in 1972. Among her efforts were to protect car buyers from deceptive advertising and to require funeral homes to itemize bills in advance.
 
Lost Narrowly to Lautenberg
 Her Congressional tenure ended in 1982, when she ran for the United States Senate and lost narrowly to Frank R. Lautenberg, a Democratic millionaire whose big-spending campaign portrayed her as a doddering eccentric. She refused political-action committee money.
After her loss, President Ronald Reagan appointed her as the first American envoy to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in Rome. She retired from that post in 1987.
After a heart problem in the 1970's, she had several operations for a pacemaker and a bypass of a leg artery.
Mrs. Fenwick was born in Manhattan to a prominent family with a tradition of public service and grew up in a 50-room mansion in Bernardsville. Her father, Ogden H. Hammond, was a financier and state legislator. When Mrs. Fenwick was 5, her mother, the former Mary Stevens, drowned when a German submarine sank the liner Lusitania. She was on a mission to Paris to create a hospital for war victims.
 
Scandalized Her Family
 Mrs. Fenwick attended the Foxcroft School in Virginia but left to accompany her father to Spain when he served as the American ambassador under President Calvin Coolidge.
Although she never received a high school diploma or college degree, she studied philosophy under Bertrand Russell at the New School for Social Research and studied at Columbia University. She was fluent in Italian, French and Spanish.
As a young woman, she scandalized her family by falling in love with a married businessman, Hugh Fenwick. They later married, but it lasted only several years. Mrs. Fenwick was left with two children and her husband's debts. Refusing money from her family, she scraped by on her own.
She inherited a fortune when her father died in 1956 but remained frugal, counting her change from coffee, using one lamp to work by and driving a Chevrolet that stood out in a community of luxury automobiles. She placed her assets in a blind trust to avoid political conflicts of interest.
She modeled briefly for Harper's Bazaar, then worked as a writer and editor at Vogue magazine and compiled "Vogue's Book of Etiquette" (Simon & Schuster, 1948), which sold a million copies.
Surviving are her son, Hugh Jr. of Bernardsville, 11 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Millicent Fenwick, who was the model for the Representative Lacey Davenport character in Garry Trudeau's "Doonesbury" comic strip. (Associated Press, 1982; Universal Press Syndicate)

HEADLINE: In Test of G.O.P. Leader, Loyalist Wins in Nassau

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 16

 BODY:
Although shaken by a string of recent losses to Democrats, the Nassau County Republican Committee and its chairman, Joseph N. Mondello, came up big winners in Tuesday's primary.
Republican voters resisted a call for a change in party leadership and supported Mr. Mondello's candidate, David A. Levy, a Hemsptead Town Councilman and party loyalist. Mr. Levy easily won the party's nomination in the newly redrawn Fourth Congressional District, defeating an insurgent, Daniel Frisa, a four-term State Assemblyman. 
 "The media said that this was going to be a referendum on me, and so be it," Mr. Mondello said to the cheers of campaign workers as he and Mr. Levy celebrated the outcome of the race.
The lingering recession, loss of jobs and a shrinking tax base in Nassau County have led to cuts in county services and an unresolved $150 million budget gap that has prompted critics to raise questions about the Republican Party's management of county government.
Mr. Levy, 38 years old, said his victory should make future candidates think twice about challenging the Nassau G.O.P. organization. He said of Mr. Frisa, "You can lie to the people, and you can send them mail, but if you don't have the organization behind you on Election Day, there is no way you can be successful."
Unofficial returns gave Mr. Levy 12,557 votes to 9,690 for Mr. Frisa. A third candidate, Francis Lees, a 61-year-old economics professor at St. John's University in Queens, received 1,757 votes.
 
Leadership Was an Issue
 Mr. Frisa, 37, had called for new party leadership, citing heavy losses to Democratic candidates last year, particularly in the towns of Oyster Bay and North Hempstead. Those losses have undermined Republican control of the Nassau County Board of Supervisors, dominated for more than four decades by the Republican Party from its base in Hempstead.
Mr. Frisa rejected charges by Mr. Mondello and Mr. Levy that his major backer was Joseph Margiotta, the former chairman of the Nassau County Republican Committee who went to prison for 14 months after his 1982 conviction on Federal extortion and mail-fraud charges. Mr. Mondello was chosen by Mr. Margiotta to succeed him as party leader, but they have since had a falling out.
The Republican leadership's next big challenge is the general election this fall and next year's race for County Executive, when the incumbent Republican, Thomas S. Gulotta, is expected to seek re-election.
In November, Mr. Levy will face Philip Schiliro, 36, a congressional aide to Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat. Mr. Schiliro won a narrow victory over a political newcomer, Joan F. Axinn, 62, of Port Washington, in the Democratic primary in the Fourth District. Unofficial returns gave Mr. Schiliro 11,699 votes to 11,273 from Mrs. Axinn.
 
Incumbent Wins Primary
 The race for the redrawn Fourth District became wide open earlier this year when the incumbent, Raymond J. McGrath, a Republican, announced his retirement. The district stretches from East Norwich, south to Atlantic Beach, and takes in all or part of Uniondale, Roosevelt, East Meadow, North Bellmore, Valley Stream, Lynbrook, Rockville Centre, the Five Towns, North Merrick, Hempstead and North Wantagh. Republicans outnumber Democrats by nearly 2 to 1.
In the neighboring Fifth Congressional District, which includes parts of northern Queens and Nassau and Suffolk counties, five-term incumbent Gary L. Ackerman of Jamaica, Queens, won the Democratic nomination. He defeated Rita Morris, a 68-year-old librarian at Nassau Community College. Mr. Ackerman received 24,297 votes to 17,881 for Mrs. Morris.
When Mrs. Morris telephoned Mr. Ackerman at his campaign headquarters to concede, Mr. Ackerman told her that she had "run a very spirited race" and that he "admired her for the kind of effort and energy" she had put into the race.
Mr. Ackerman won with the backing of the Democratic Party leadership in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk. He said he went into the contest "in a year that promised a tremendous amount of upsets for those of us who have been in this business for a while.
"But we were able to prove some of the pundits wrong," he said, "especially those who said this was going to be the sleeper race to watch."
In November, Mr. Ackerman will face Alan Binder, a Suffolk County legislator, who was the only candidate for the Republican nomination.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: 12th District
Woman in the News;
Loyalty and Labor; Nydia M. Velazquez

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Two years ago, Nydia M. Velazquez found herself the focus of attention at festivities to celebrate the mayoral primary victory of David N. Dinkins, when she was described as the engine behind a large and ultimately crucial Hispanic voter turnout. 
 Though officially nonpartisan in her role as the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico's representative in New York, Ms. Velazquez solidified her reputation that night as a street-smart and politically savvy woman who understood the value of solidarity and loyalty to other politicians, community leaders and organized labor.
Since then, relations between the Mayor and some of the city's Hispanic political leaders have suffered, making such affiliations risky. But on Tuesday, Ms. Velazquez clearly played those loyalties to her own advantage in an important test of Hispanic political coming-of-age. Despite competition from four other Hispanic candidates that threatened to split the Hispanic vote, she upset an influential House veteran, Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn, and virtually assured that she would become the first Hispanic woman to represent New York City in Congress.
 
'Cementing Relationships'
 "While the other candidates may have guts and talent, she went about cementing relationships with everybody," Representative Jose E. Serrano of the Bronx said yesterday. Her victory, he said, was as much a statement about her strength as a candidate as about coalition building with Mayor Dinkins and his allies, including Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan and Dennis Rivera, the head of Local 1199, the politically powerful health-care workers union, whose members were everywhere on Primary Day, boosting Ms. Velazquez at the polls.
Ms. Velazquez, running in the new 12th Congressional District drawn to concentrate Hispanic voting power, won largely because of overwhelming Hispanic support in Brooklyn and strong support from the black community. A second Hispanic candidate, Elizabeth Colon, weakened Mr. Solarz by drawing many of the white and Asian votes he needed for victory.
With her election almost certain to go unchallenged in November in the heavily Democratic district, Ms. Velazquez stands to become the second Hispanic member of the New York delegation, after Mr. Serrano. She would be the second Hispanic woman in Congress from any state, following Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Republican and a Cuban-American from Miami, who was first elected in 1989.
Such distinctions, however, are nothing new for Ms. Velazquez (pronounced veh-LA-skehz), who is divorced.
Born in Yabucoa, P.R., on March 28, 1953, one of nine children of a sugar cane worker and his wife, Nydia Margarita Velazquez was the first member of her family to get a high school diploma. She graduated magna cum laude from the University of Puerto Rico in Rio Piedras in 1974, and two years later, received her master's in political science from New York University.
 
Representing Puerto Rico
 In 1984, Ms. Velazquez, at the time a special assistant to Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn, became the first Hispanic woman to serve on the New York City Council after being selected to fill a vacant seat.
In 1986, Ms. Velazquez was asked to represent the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico in the United States, first as National Director of the Migration Division, then as the head of community affairs for Puerto Ricans living in the United States.
Though her critics wonder if her ties to Puerto Rico make her too parochial to serve the polyglot Hispanic community in New York and if her ties to Mayor Dinkins compromise her independence, her supporters praise her as a hard worker with a progressive agenda who understands poverty and other urban ills.
During her primary campaign, she promised that, if elected, she would focus on jobs, housing and education in the district and would block unwanted Federal projects and help fight against AIDS. She called for more Federal funds to increase economic developent, in part through stepped-up urban aid initiatives.
 
Known as a Protester
 Considered compulsive by friends, who say she may call in the middle of the night with ideas about how to solve particular problems, Ms. Velazquez is also known as a protester. She supported the Daily News workers during their strike -- a cause strongly supported by Mr. Rivera -- and helped take down a wall at a school in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that separated Hispanic and Hasidic children.
Though she continued to campaign with Mayor Dinkins even after he pushed plans for a new incinerator in the Brooklyn Navy Yard last month, Ms. Velazquez has testified against it before the City Council and has vowed to continue to fight it.
"For me, she has epitomized a fierce pride in self and community, a commitment to bridge the street with the corporate suite, and a tenacity in leading movements," said Luis Garden-Acosta, chief executive of El Puente, a Hispanic community organization in Williamsburg. "She's a fighter."
Ms. Velazquez's triumph on Tuesday was also seen as a significant victory for Mayor Dinkins, as Mr. Solarz and her other opponents drew backing from the Mayor's political rivals, including Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx and two likely mayoral challengers, Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council President Andrew J. Stein.
As she thanked voters at a subway stop in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday afternoon, Ms. Velazquez attributed her victory to the get-out-the-vote efforts of more than 500 members of Local 1199 and of the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and to the endorsements of Mr. Dinkins and others. "This campaign was based on a coalition," she said.

HEADLINE: Democrats on Senate Panel Attack the Free-Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
Using the conservation provisions of the North American Free Trade Agreement as a political cudgel, Congressional Democrats pressed their attacks on the pact today, accusing the White House of negotiating an accord that could damage the environment and cause thousands of American jobs to be shifted to Mexico.
During the Senate Finance Committee hearing, John Danforth of Missouri was the only Republican lawmaker who strongly defended the agreement, chiding his Democratic colleagues for "using environmental and health standards as a guise for protectionism." 
 The United States, Mexico and Canada completed the agreement last month, and in the days since, Democrats have questioned how it might affect the environment, American wages, factory workers, and growers of fruit, vegetables and grain.
 
Criticism of the Negotiators
 Democratic lawmakers from the South, the Middle West and the Great Plains cited concerns their constituents have raised about the agreement. These senators -- John B. Breaux of Louisiana, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan and Thomas A. Daschle of South Dakota -- asserted that the Bush Administration had not worked hard enough to obtain tough measures that would prevent companies from exploiting weak enforcement of environmental laws in Mexico to gain a competitive advantage.
Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Senate Finance subcommittee on international trade, called for the Administration to reopen talks to strengthen the environmental provisions.
"The main reason that the Bush Administration chose not to adequately address the environmental issues in the North American Free Trade Agreement," Mr. Baucus said, "was that the growing tension between environmental and trade issues had never before been addressed. The Administration was timid in the face of the new challenge."
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, assumed a surprisingly small role today, in contrast to two previous hearings in which Mr. Bentsen had been the committee's most aggressive questioner. He appeared for just a few minutes to make an informal statement and then issued a prepared statement in which he seemed to endorse the agreement's environmental provisions.
 
Defense by the E.P.A.
 In his second consecutive day of Congressional testimony, William K. Reilly commended the agreement as the "greenest" trade pact ever negotiated. Mr. Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that the accord would over all be a bonus for the environment by encouraging the development of more wealth in Mexico, giving the nation the money to monitor and enforce its environmental laws.
But Mr. Reilly also seemed to confirm Mr. Baucus's assertion. He said the accord's environmental protections were a new legal and diplomatic frontier that had presented the negotiators with challenges they could not solve.
Mr. Reilly said more specific protections had been considered, including provisions allowing countries to issue sanctions against products to prevent excessive pollution during their manufacture. But negotiators were unable to work out language for how such provisions might work.

HEADLINE: Managed Care Is More of What We Have Now

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Half Right on Health" (editorial, Aug. 31) favors the so-called "Jackson Hole global budget" -- referring to the health-care experts who invented the term for a system that sets "only the premium that providers would be allowed to charge for basic coverage" and remove incentives for "unnecessary services." This plan is a thinly disguised attempt to consolidate control of the country's sickness-care industry among those few health insurers who promote health maintenance organizations. It is not health care reform. 
 If Gov. Bill Clinton is serious about being the candidate of change, and if, as the polls indicate, health care is a major concern of the American people, he will be well advised to avoid burdening American business with the cost of dealing with the nationalized or regionalized H.M.O.'s proposed at Jackson Hole.
H.M.O.'s are no-change economic medicine: In an age of global competition, they perpetuate the archaic system that forces employers to add health-care costs to their products and pensions. Barely a day passes without a major corporation announcing cuts in benefits for employees and retirees. An economic program that creates jobs for Americans will relieve American industry of this expense and help make us competitive with the rest of the world.
H.M.O.'s are no-change social medicine: Adoption of a managed-care plan, rather than promoting the general welfare, would increase the separation between the haves and have-nots by maintaining a multitiered system. There is no good reason for the United States to be the only major country with different health benefits for people who work in major companies, those in small companies, the self-employed, the unemployed, the underemployed and the government-employed.
H.M.O.'s are no-change political medicine: By pandering to the health-insurance lobby, the managed-care proposals will perpetuate a system that costs each American twice as much as each of our Canadian neighbors before we have to pay for the 40 million among us who have no coverage. Any candidate serious about the health-care system will recognize the value of a plan that insures everyone at half the costs of ours.
Adoption of the Jackson Hole proposals would force Americans to swallow some new medicine by removing the choice of physician for most Americans and straining physician-patient relationships; by increasing tax advantages to the insurance industry; by expanding Medicaid costs; by creating administrative nightmares through contrived programs that require each patient to be formally qualified, and of course by relieving physicians of the responsibility for choosing medical procedures by turning that function over to an insurance carrier.
Governor Clinton is well advised to avoid jumping on the Jackson Hole bandwagon. "Save the H.M.O. industry" is hardly a popular or useful battle cry.
 
RICHARD H. HANNEMAN
Houston, Sept. 1, 1992
The writer is a retired insurance executive and management consultant.

HEADLINE: Halt the Verbal Abuse Of 'Special Interests'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In this campaign season, everyone -- especially Christoper Georges in "The Clinton Plan (Thanks to Dukakis)" (Op-Ed, Aug. 24) -- talks about special-interest groups, but nobody defines them. 
 The concept of special interests is a leftover from a time when a clear majority of Americans (and people in other countries as well) depended directly or indirectly on the land for their livelihoods. Anyone not so dependent could legitimately be described as representing an economic special interest, because his or her economic interests differed from the clear majority of the population.
Nowadays, people make their livings from all kinds of sources, and therefore everybody belongs to one or more economic interest groups, all of which are more or less equally special. (Some are, by percentage, slightly less special -- that is, bigger -- than others, but none command a majority or anything close to one.) When Americans today talk about "special interests," they mean those they don't share or approve of.
A moratorium on "special-interest" rhetoric should be declared for the duration of this electoral campaign.
 
STEPHEN P. DUNN
Berkeley, Calif., Sept. 2, 1992
The writer is director of research, Highgate Road Social Science Research Station.

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN EUROPE;
EUROPEANS' CURRENCY SYSTEM SHAKEN AS BRITAIN CUTS FREE

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 17

 BODY:
After a futile day of trying to defend the value of the pound, Britain dropped out of the European Monetary System on Wednesday, at least temporarily. Its departure from the monetary system, a cornerstone of greater European unity, left the program of economic coordination in tatters.
Before taking that unexpected step, which effectively allowed the pound to drop sharply in value, Britain desperately tried to pump up the currency. First it raised one of its key interest rates to 12 percent from 10 percent. Only hours later -- after the pound had sunk still further -- it announced another increase, to 15 percent. By raising rates so sharply, Britain hoped to make the pound more attractive to investors and stop concerted selling by speculators that was pushing it down. 
 Early this morning in Brussels, finance officials from the 12 European Community nations attempted to restore some order to the chaotic currency markets by devaluing the Spanish peseta by 5 percent and allowing the Italian lira to fall freely. The lira had been devalued 7 percent on Sunday.
 
Currency Restrictions
 Like the other European members of the monetary system, Britain has been obliged to keep its currency within certain bounds relative to other currencies -- and particularly the German mark, the strongest of the group. It was the pound's decline below that limit on Wednesday that forced Britain's costly measures: first to bolster the pound, then to pull out of the system altogether.
The situation prompted only mild concern outside Europe. United States officials said the turbulence could actually benefit European and American economies, leading to lower interest rates that would spur growth in Europe and eventually give the United States a lift.
While Britain's decision to depart, at least temporarily, from the monetary system raised problems for Britain's allies, it also created a political crisis for Prime Minister John Major. While Margaret Thatcher had only reluctantly agreed to greater integration with the rest of Europe, Mr. Major embraced the prospect. He has staked the credibility of his Government on maintaining the pound's value at almost any cost, as a willing participant in the monetary system. [Page D9.]
 
New Questions for Europe
 And with France set to vote on Sunday on whether to approve the treaty outlining the next stages of European unification, the shift by Britain raised new questions about whether Europe can or should continue its push for monetary union.
The British move came at the end of a day in which speculators sold huge amounts of Europe's weaker currencies, including the pound, the lira and the peseta, and plowed funds into the German mark, traditionally the strongest and most stable currencies. The shifts threw out of whack Europe's strategy for closer economic ties.
As Britain raced to defend the pound on Wednesday, Italy and Sweden were also struggling to maintain their own weak currencies.
Italy spent large sums selling marks and other currencies in return for lira in an attempt to bid up the lira's value. Sweden, which is not yet a member of the European Community but is trying to get its finances in order in preparation for joining, pushed the rate for its most expensive loans to banks to an almost unheard of 500 percent.
But in the face of the overwhelming movement of funds out of the weak currencies, even those strategies accomplished little. As the pound slipped, so did the lira, despite having already been devalued by 7 percent. And from London to New York, the markets degenerated into something akin to a feeding frenzy, with speculators convinced they could profit by pushing the mark higher.
"The markets have become a monster, and the reason is the disastrous mistake of devaluing the lira," said William Ledward, an economist at Nomura Securities International in London. "In agreeing to a 7 percent devaluation, you gave the speculators a big profit, and these people are like vampires. Once they taste blood, they have to have it again."
In Brussels, the European Community's monetary committee convened shortly before midnight Wednesdya in an emergency session called by the British.
Six hours later, representatives of the central banks and finance ministries of the European Community nations issued a communique noting the British decision to pull out of the European Monetary System and a subsequent move by the Italian authorities to allowing the lira to fall freely rather than be supported by government intervention. They then disclosed the 5 percent devaluation of the Spanish peseta within the exchange rate system.
The actions mean that the German mark and its closely associated currencies, like the Belgian franc and the Dutch guilder, will be stronger within what remains of the exchange-rate system while the weaker currencies, which had been under heavy speculative pressure, would lose weight.
In their communique, the finance officials tried to put the best face on the proceedings by saying that Britain and Italy had stressed "their unanimous commitment to the European Monetary System as a key factor of economic stability and prosperity in Europe."
They urged a return of the pound and the lira to the exchange rate system "as soon as possible."
 
Little Choice for Major
 While detaching the pound from the other European currencies and letting it drift lower was an outright reversal of his stance -- as well as an unpopular step that would increase the cost of Britain's imports -- Mr. Major had little choice. Politically and economically, he was unable to raise interest rates any higher. Higher rates will be poison for Britain, already in the grip of recession. And the country was running out of foreign currency reserves to defend the pound. This evening, he gave in to the markets.
The reversal came in the form of a decision to withdraw from the agreement among 11 of the 12 European Community nations to keep currency values within a relatively narrow range. Instead, the Government said, it would allow the pound to float freely, its value set by market forces.
The decision was tantamount to a large devaluation, a step that both Mr. Major and Norman Lamont, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, had repeatedly ruled out. Soon after the announcement tonight, the pound was trading at 2.70 German marks, far below its lower limit under the European exchange rate mechanism of 2.778 marks.
"What was supposed to be the centerpiece of the Government's economic policy has been removed at a stroke and Britain, having wanted to be at the heart of the new Europe, is now thrown off again to the periphery," said Nigel Gault, the chief European economist in London for DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic consulting firm.
Theo Waigel, the German Finance Minister, said he thought Britain would soon rejoin the monetary system and that there would not be a devaluation of any other currencies.
But there were clearly strains within the European Community over Britain's decision. British officials openly criticized Helmut Schlesinger, the head of the powerful German central bank, the Bundesbank, for reportedly suggesting in an interview on Tuesday that he favored further revaluations with the exchange rate agreement. Although Mr. Schlesinger said he never made the remarks, currency traders took the reports as a signal that the Bundesbank would not act to halt a slide in the pound or the lira by cutting interest rates. The Bundesbank cut rates slightly on Monday in a failed attempt to stabilize the currency markets.
Sir Norman Fowler, the chairman of Britain's governing Conservative Party, said, "The fact is that the turmoil on the foreign exchanges has been caused by the uncertainty over the French referendum result and unnecessarily by the Bundesbank president's remarks."
The Spanish and Portuguese currencies are expected to come under severe pressure today, as will the currencies of nations like Sweden that are likely to become European Community members within a few years. Analysts said that if there were wholesale readjustments in the values of currencies to each other beyond the bounds now called for, the credibility of the exchange rate system would be seriously wounded.
At best, they said, it would be a long time before the currency markets took the commitment to stable exchange rates seriously even if France approves the unification treaty on Sunday.
"The very existence of the European Monetary System is in doubt," Mr. Ledward of Nomura Securities said.
 
Two-Tiered System?
 Some analysts, however, predicted that the process of unification might now proceed on a two-tiered basis, with Germany, France and a handful of other nations moving toward a single currency and monetary policy, while others, including Britain, watch from the sidelines.
Devaluation makes one nation's currency worth less in relation to that of another nation. The process has certain advantages, including making a nation's exports less expensive, and therefore more desirable. But it tends to cause inflation because it makes imports more expensive and because it leads investors, wary of further devaluations, to demand higher interest rates.
The devaluation of the pound does not eliminate the basic pressures that set off the currency speculation. Interest rates in Germany remain at very high levels, making the mark attractive. Rates in Germany are high because the Bundesbank is fearful that the higher-than-expected costs of reuniting East and West Germany will ignite inflation, and because higher rates attract the capital that Germany needs to fund the reunification.
At the same time, the world's other major currency, the dollar, remains relatively weak because interest rates in the United States are at their lowest point in decades, making investments in dollars relatively unappealing. The United States is more insulated from other currency moves because it imports considerably less than the nations of Europe, and because oil, a critical import, is priced in dollars.
The uncertainty over the outcome of Sunday's vote in France on the Maastricht treaty outlining the course of further European unification has only hurt the situation. Investors are fearful that French rejection of the treaty would end efforts at monetary union.
Without the goal of monetary union to motivate them, some nations might choose to abandon the exchange-rate ties and the need to maintain fiscal and monetary discipline that goes along with them. Without that discipline, the investors fear, nations like Britain might once again pursue inflationary policies, making their currencies less valuable.

HEADLINE: Executives Urge Focus On Deficit

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16

 BODY:
A group of business executives and academic leaders chided the two Presidential candidates today for failing to make substantial proposals to cut the budget deficit and said tax increases would probably be necessary.
The group, headed by A. W. Clausen, chairman of the executive committee of BankAmerica's board, urged the Government to eliminate the deficit in five to ten years, saying the United States had to nurse its economy back to health to strengthen its world leadership role. 
 The group, the Council for Economic Development, said slashing the deficit "should be the highest domestic economic priority." It said the deficit had helped reduce the nation's savings rate to a paltry 2 percent and was limiting the amount of money available for the private investment needed to make the economy more competitive.
"The United States should get its own house in order by eliminating the structural deficit within the next decade and cutting its savings rate to 8 percent," Mr. Clausen said.
 
Importance of Tax Increases
 The committee said deficit reduction should focus on cutting spending, looking especially at military expenditures, but also pointed to the importance of tax increases. The report said "carefully designed tax increases that do not discourage private saving and investment will do less harm to the economy than persistent" deficits.
During a news conference today in Washington, committee members said President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton, the Democratic nominee, had not addressed deficit reduction seriously.
The committee includes Harold A. Poling, chairman of Ford Motor; Richard D. Wood, chairman of Eli Lilly; Robert C. Winters, chairman of Prudential Insurance; James J. Renier, chairman of Honeywell; Owen B. Butler, retired chairman of Procter & Gamble; Donna E. Shalala, chancellor of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and Arnold R. Weber, president of Northwestern University.
Calling for a consumption tax, Mr. Clausen said taxes that discouraged investment would be unwise.
'We need government policies that provide a more appropriate environment for investing in the future," he said. "The U.S. consumes far more of what it creates than other major industrial countries and reinvests less than 5 percent in our future. Other countries -- Germany and Japan -- are consuming far less of what they create and investing a lot more in their future."
 
Role of World Leader
 Urging the nation not to shirk its international responsibilities in this time of economic troubles, the business group said the United States was the only nation that could play the role of world leader to foster international cooperation to promote growth and security.
"We need to become a rallier of nations, a catalyst helping to define international priorities and motivating cooperative action," Mr. Clausen said. "In this new world, only the United States has the unique mix of attributes -- economic power, military might, political dexterity and moral stature -- necessary to lead."
To strengthen America's position as world leader, the report said Washington should increase foreign aid outlays, continue pushing to eliminate trade barriers and honor its monetary commitments to the United Nations and other international organizations. The report urged Washington to move the issue of family planning back onto the international agenda because fast population growth slows per-capita income growth in many developing nations.
The report made numerous proposals to improve America's competitiveness, calling for education reform, increased Federal support for business investment in training, and removing regulations that discourage joint research.
Leonard Silk, a former economics columnist for The New York Times, was the chief author of the report.

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about a group that called for cuts in the budget deficit misidentified the group. It is the Committee for Economic Development.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Florida Poll;
Florida Emerges As Crucial State In the Campaign

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 16

 BODY:
After voting Republican in every Presidential election but one over the last 40 years, Florida has emerged as an unexpected battleground in the race between President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton, according to new polls.
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, taken Thursday through Monday, gave Mr. Clinton a slim advantage in Florida, 48 percent to 42 percent, with 10 percent undecided. Another poll, published today in The Miami Herald, gave Mr. Bush a slight advantage, 48 percent to 41 percent, with 11 percent undecided. 
 Given the margins of sampling error in the two polls, the state and its 25 electoral votes, viewed by Republican strategists as essential to the President's re-election, are plainly up for grabs.
 
Rating on Storm Relief
 The Times/CBS News survey in Florida, the nation's fourth most populous state, showed that while a majority of those polled approved of Mr. Bush's handling of the crisis after Hurricane Andrew, the President got little political benefit from his actions in the storm's aftermath and his decision to support the rebuilding of Homestead Air Force Base at an estimated cost of nearly $500 million.
Over all, 61 percent of Florida residents interviewed for the poll, and 65 percent of those in Dade County, which bore the brunt of the most expensive natural disaster in American history, said they approved of Mr. Bush's handling of the hurricane crisis. But only 40 percent described the Federal response as "adequate" and 62 percent said the response should have been faster.
 
Complaints About Economy
 The survey indicated that Mr. Bush's high marks for his handling of the hurricane were severely undercut by dissatisfaction with his management of the nation's economy. More than 70 percent of those polled said they disapproved of his handling of economic matters, which most of those polled said ought to be the issue that the Presidential candidates talk about most.
"Well, I lost two jobs during the last two years, and I directly relate that to Mr. Bush," said Elizabeth White, an unemployed 35-year-old Clinton supporter from the Miami suburb of Kendall. "Because the economy is so bad around here, my job was eliminated."
Even the President's supporters faulted him on economic issues. Juan Boitel, a 51-year-old maitre d'hotel, said he would vote for Mr. Bush "because of the way he has handled international politics, especially the way he took care of Saddam Hussein," but he described the economic situation as "terrible."
"There's no money in the streets anymore," Mr. Boitel said. "The restaurants are empty, the unemployment rate is high and people are not buying cars and clothing like they used to."
 
Race Is Dead Heat
 The Times/CBS News survey is based on 1,112 telephone and face-to-face interviews with adult Florida residents, including 785 who said they were registered voters. The margin of sampling error is plus or minus four percentage points, meaning that the race in Florida is a statistical dead heat.
To compare the Miami area with the rest of the state, 355 interviews were conducted in Dade County, of which 270 were face to face because of hurricane damage to many individual homes and to the telephone system.
The Miami Herald poll, conducted by Mason-Dixon Political/Media Research Inc., was based on telephone interviews with 804 registered voters and has a margin of sampling error of between three and four percentage points. While it showed Mr. Bush with a slight lead, in statistical terms the race was a tossup.
Since President Harry S. Truman carried Florida in 1948, no Democratic Presidential nominee except Jimmy Carter in 1976 has won the state, and Mr. Carter was Governor of neighboring Georgia at the time. The Bush campaign attaches so much importance to keeping Florida in the Republican column that the President's son, Jeb Bush, is chairman of the statewide campaign.
"Intuitively, I think we are ahead and in a close race," Jeb Bush said today when asked to comment on the poll results. "That's my own feeling, but how does one really know? The good news for us is that our Republican base is back and we're doing well in conservative Democratic areas, and that is enough to win in this state."
"It doesn't matter what Bill Clinton does," the younger Mr. Bush added, because "we are going to use phones, mail and door-to-door to turn people out."
It appears, however, that the President will face a race down to the wire, requiring a substantial commitment of time, money and campaign workers to a state he won by nearly a million votes in 1988.
Nationwide, according to the Times/ CBS News poll, Mr. Clinton has the backing of 49 percent of the voters, compared with 37 percent who say they support Mr. Bush.
The President's support appears firmer in Florida than nationwide. Only 35 percent of his supporters here say they harbor reservations about Mr. Bush, compared with 44 percent of those in the national sample.
"Clinton refused to go to war," said Adelfa Braker, 58, "and he doesn't know what it means to fire a shot, so I could never vote for him."
"President Bush has done so much for this country, even though his hands are tied by Congress," added Ms. Braker, who operates a small apparel business from her home, "but many people simply refuse to see this."
But in a state where questions of foreign policy, particularly toward Cuba, Israel and Haiti, are often indistinguishable from local affairs, Mr. Bush has derived no extra benefit from his tough stance against President Fidel Castro of Cuba and Haitian boat people. Approval of his handling of foreign affairs is virtually the same here, 58 percent, as in the nation as a whole.
In some other respects, Florida residents have a more favorable image of Mr. Bush than is the case elsewhere in the country, and that gives the Bush campaign a base upon which to build.
Nationwide, 44 percent of registered voters polled said they thought the President "cares about the needs and problems of people" like them. But in Florida, half the respondents said they thought Mr. Bush cared.
For Mr. Clinton, 67 percent of the nationwide sample said they thought he cared about their problems, as against 62 percent in Florida.
Republicans can also find encouragement in voter sentiment in favor of their party's candidates for the House of Representatives in a state whose House delegation rises by four seats, to 23, next January as a result of population gains in the 1990 census. Nationally, voters favor Democrats over Republicans by 10 percentage points, but here the two parties are in a dead heat.
The poll indicates that blame for the perceived slowness and inefficiency of the hurricane relief effort has fallen not on Mr. Bush, who made two trips to Dade County after the storm, but on the Federal Emergency Management Agency, whose performance was described as adequate by only 31 percent of Floridians. Insurance companies were also widely criticized, with only 32 percent of those polled saying that the industry's response was adequate.
The military's work after the hurricane won the approval of 92 percent of Dade County respondents and 83 percent of those statewide. The performance of Florida's state government, which is controlled by Democrats, was considered to be better than the Federal Government's, with 39 percent of those polled saying the state's response was adequate.
Seventy-five percent of the registered voters in Dade County, and 82 percent of those statewide, said Mr. Bush's actions after the storm would not affect their vote in November.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 19, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about the standings of President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton in the latest public opinion polls in Florida misstated the state's voting record in Presidential elections. Democrats have won the state twice in the last 40 years. President Johnson carried Florida in 1964, and so did Jimmy Carter in 1976.

How the 2 Polls Were Conducted
 The latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 9 through 13 with 1,329 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, of whom 1,006 said they were registered voters.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers.
In addition, interviews in Florida were conducted Sept. 10 through 14 with 1,112 adults, of whom 785 said they were registered voters. So that residents of Dade County could be compared with the rest of the state, 355 interviews were conducted there; because of hurricane damage to homes and the local telephone system, 270 of these interviews were conducted in person. The results were then adjusted to reflect Dade County's share of Florida's population. Respondents were interviewed in English or Spanish.
The sample of Florida telephone numbers was provided by Survey Sampling Inc. of Fairfield, Conn. The in-person interviews were conducted by Belden and Russonello Inc. of Washington in 31 locations in Dade County.
For both polls, within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll. The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations relating to region, race, sex, and age. The national poll was also weighted by education.
In theory, in 19 of 20 cases the results based on such samples will differ by no more than a few percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all registered voters in the population. For the national poll it is plus or minus three points; for the Florida poll it is plus or minus four points.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for residents of Dade County it is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. (pg. A20)

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Connecticut;
Johnson Begins Uphill Struggle vs. Dodd

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 16

 BODY:
Brook Johnson, a Greenwich millionaire, opened his general-election drive for the United States Senate today after a victorious Republican primary campaign built around generous financing and calculated spending on television commercials.
Mr. Johnson, a political newcomer who reported an income of $2.4 million last year as chairman of a towel and bedding company, spent $900,000, compared with about $500,000 by his rival for the nomination, State Representative Chris Burnham, who had received the party endorsement. Commercials for Mr. Johnson crowded the airwaves in this small state, while Mr. Burnham, who held similar positions on many issues, did not run a single television ad. 
 Mr. Johnson defeated Mr. Burnham 59 percent to 41 percent, with pluralities in blue-collar cities as well as Republican strongholds like Greenwich and New Canaan.
 
The Role of TV
 Television advertising made the big difference, in the view of Dr. Everett C. Ladd, executive director and president of the Roper Center for Public Opinion Research at the University of Connecticut.
"Here was a race in which almost nobody was listening," Dr. Ladd said. "You had two candidates, both largely unknown as far as the state electorate is concerned, with no previous experience at anything approaching the level of the United States Senate. Those candidates find an enormous difficulty breaking through and getting any recognition from a significant portion of the electorate, so any advantage in securing recognition can be rather important."
Television advertising offered an advantage to Mr. Johnson, Dr. Ladd said. "It was enough in the context of this kind of race," he said, "but the fundamentals of the Republican side of this election look the same as they did a month ago."
 
Dodd Ahead in Polls
 Polls conducted by the center's Institute for Social Inquiry have consistently shown the incumbent, Christopher J. Dodd, far ahead of both Republicans.
The Republican choices appealed to different voters for different reasons. Mr. Burnham "seemed like an honest guy who would try to help the people, versus the polished, packaged look of Brook," said Georgia Siomkos, a corporate recruiter here who voted for Mr. Burnham but now plans to support his rival. Her husband, Michael Caradimitropoulo, voted for Mr. Johnson, whom he had followed in newspaper articles about the race, because, he said, "He's an outsider, he's independently wealthy, and he's not out there to rip off the people."
But such opinions may have had less impact than the very low voter turnout. Only about 100,000 Republicans cast ballots, out of a total of 461,000. In Waterbury, for example, only 1,495 Republicans voted in a city where there are more than 10,500 Republicans registered, giving the race to Mr. Johnson, 894-601.
Mark Rivers, Mr. Johnson's campaign director, said the credit given to television for the victory overlooked other aspects of the campaign.
 
'Grass-Roots Support'
 "We've got vast grass-roots support," he said. "The media made an impact because it got Brook Johnson's message out, about reforming Congress and the economy. But we've also got small towns where a real-estate office was converted into a phone bank, and that doesn't have a lot to do with TV ads."
Mr. Burnham, who plans to return to work on Thursday as a public-finance specialist at an investment bank, said he planned to urge all his supporters to help elect Mr. Johnson. As for how his campaign succeeded or failed, he noted that until late this spring, he was running against Robert G. Jaekle, a longtime state legislator, who dropped out of the race in June and swung his support to Mr. Johnson. "We did beat him, not knowing Brook would get into the race," he said.
Today Mr. Johnson was darting around the Hartford area, making appearances at campaign stops as well as at a unity rally for winners and losers backed by his party. Mr. Burnham said he was looking forward to resuming a normal life after the frequent long days that the Senate campaign required. He is even looking forward to commuting between Stamford and Manhattan. "I'll be on the 7 o'clock train tomorrow morning," he said.

HEADLINE: Hugo's 3-Year Wake: Lessons of a Hurricane

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: McCLELLANVILLE, S.C.

 BODY:
Three years after Hurricane Hugo's screaming winds and 17-foot storm surge left this town torn to pieces and buried under five feet of water and mud, life here seems almost back to normal, right down to the regrown Spanish moss hanging from the oak trees on Pinkney Street.
But for hurricane-ravaged residents of South Florida, Louisiana and Hawaii starting to rebuild their lives, a journey along the South Carolina coast and into the rural hamlets ravaged by Hugo provides a complicated picture of equal parts loss and renewal. Like McClellanville, South Carolina has recovered sooner than many thought possible, but its experience is a vivid lesson both in how much man can and cannot do to repair a world that nature blew apart. 
 Three years after what was the costliest storm in American history -- Hurricane Andrew, which struck South Florida and Louisiana last month, has since passed it -- South Carolina still is full of harsh reminders of Hugo's fury. They include the ghostly, denuded remains of what used to be the lush Francis Marion National Forest, the demons haunting children like Matthew Mable of Summerville who are terrified whenever a stiff wind blows, and the quiet despair of the rural poor like Viola Reed of South Santee who are still waiting to get their houses repaired so they can return home.
There are also harsh memories of the faltering Federal relief effort after Hugo, and an often-voiced resentment about the billions of dollars in election-year aid being rushed to Florida, Louisiana and Hawaii, as opposed to the $500 million spent in South Carolina at a time when no Presidential election was pending.
An economic analysis of the storm indicates that despite the rebuilding boom it brought, the storm overall was a severe economic drain on the state.
Still, South Carolina is the scene of remarkable recovery from the pastel town houses of Charleston, to the working-class trailer parks in Copahee to the rebuilt seaside communities like Pawleys Island and Folly Beach, where homes wrecked by the storm were not just rebuilt but improved so much that people on Pawleys Island, who used to playfully bill the town as "arrogantly shabby," now say they are still arrogant but no longer shabby.
To some the recovery is the most telling lesson to come out of Hugo.
"I would say the state's recovery from Hugo has been nothing short of miraculous," said Luther F. Carter, executive director of the South Carolina Budget and Control Board.
 
Estimate of $6 Billion Toll
 Still, interviews along the coast made it clear that how people recovered from the storm had a lot to do with their financial circumstances before it hit. Many of the poor took hits they may never recover from. Many of those better off were cushioned by insurance that allowed them to replace homes with more modern ones.
Everyone who was here after Hugo roared ashore on Sept. 22, 1989, can identify with those trying to rebuild after Andrew and Hurricane Iniki, which ravaged the Hawaiian island of Kauai last week.
"I remember flying the coastline right after the storm, looking down on Charleston and thinking, 'Will we ever recover?' " Mr. Carter said.
Economists are still poring over the storm's ultimate toll, a job made difficult by the fact that the devastation was followed by a huge influx of aid and a construction boom.
Douglas P. Woodward, a University of South Carolina economist who has analyzed the storm's economic impact, said the storm did $6 billion in damage, about half of it in real estate and half in natural resources, particularly timber. Of that only half was reimbursed from any source. It also created a building boom that over two-and-a-half years created about $500 million in added income, enough to forestall the recession's arrival in South Carolina for more than a year.
"It was a net economic loss to the state, which may seem obvious, but you'd be surprised how many thought for a time it might be good for the economy," Professor Woodward said. "Eventually, the artificial boom ended, and when the recession came, it was like a cold bath. In the end it was the poor who really got hurt, and a lot of them are hurting still."
There are poor people in Charleston whose homes have never been repaired from the storm, but the worst toll can be found in hundreds of rural communities that were poor before the storm and poorer now.
Miriam Green, who heads the rural Berkeley County Electric Cooperative's project to deal with housing problems left behind by Hugo, is still working to get aid to people like Mrs. Reed, a 71-year-old widow, whose house is still an uninhabitable morass of broken sheetrock and pools of water, and James Vanderhorst, a 74-year-old widower here, who was victimized by a shoddy contractor and left with a house jacked up on cinder blocks, but not high enough to meet local codes.
But just as common are stories of remarkable renewal. To this day, Lloyd McClellan and her husband, James McClellan, are amazed at the volunteers who rebuilt their home that was inundated by the storm.
"You see on television about babies starving and people firing bombs at each other in the streets, and think how lucky we are to be in a country where when you need help, people come and help," Mrs. McClellan said.
Still, even many of those whose lives seem back to normal are still carrying heavy financial burdens.
"I tried to get assistance from the Small Business Administration and got nothing," said Buster Brown who owns one grocery store here. Largely uninsured at the time of the storm, he estimates he lost $200,000 on his home and business.
But Professor Woodward's study found that while only 45 percent of residential losses were covered by insurance, about 80 percent of business and commercial losses were covered.
And, particularly near the waterfront, many people are now living better than they were before the storm because insurance payments allowed them to rebuild seaside homes into more modern structures that have higher building standards.
To some experts on coastal development property, there is no small bit of folly beneath the renaissance here.
Peter Sparks, an engineering professor at Clemson University, said many structures were hurriedly rebuilt with roofs less able to withstand a storm than they were before Hugo. In addition, new flood insurance regulations that require buildings in flood-prone areas to be at least eight feet off the ground have left a slew of trailer homes sitting on eight-foot concrete blocks, more vulnerable to hurricane winds than they were before.
"I wouldn't want to be in one of those things in a thunderstorm, Mr. Sparks said. "Overall, Hugo was a warning unheeded."
But homeowners say many beachfront homes have been rebuilt to standards that far exceed the ones they replaced. And in places like Folly Beach, where the waves almost lap at the front porches of beachfront houses, it is clear one thing that was not altered by Hugo was the desire of people to live by the shore. In fact, the city is spending $16 million -- 85 percent of it in Federal money -- on a beach renourishment project that will create 150 feet of beach at high tide.
Overlooking the ocean at the home he rebuilt, James Kennedy readily acknowledges that Folly's shifting sand may well be the kind of place that should not be built on.
But having said that, he adds that he never gave a thought to not rebuilding, especially when insurance paid for everything but his $20,000 seawall.
Josephine Humphreys, the Charleston novelist, is aware of many changes that linger after Hugo. She misses the endearing shabbiness of old Charleston blown away and replaced by something more sanitized.
She is also aware of the haunting, indelible memory of the wind that will haunt so many lives from here to Homestead, Fla., and from the bayous of Louisiana to the beaches of Hawaii.
"If you've ever been in a car wreck, you remember the sound of it for years and years and it just gives you the creeps," she said. "That's how I feel about the wind now, the sound of wind. It was just terrifying, and it's something you don't forget."

HEADLINE: Zuckerman Seems Clear Choice to Buy Daily News

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the New York real-estate developer and owner of U.S. News & World Report, yesterday became all but assured of acquiring the bankrupt Daily News.
Mr. Zuckerman has still not reached agreement with the paper's creditors or with the Newspaper Guild, which represents news, advertising and clerical workers. But the paper's board endorsed his proposal late Wednesday night and, as dawn broke yesterday, the negotiating logjam with the guild was cleared away. A final understanding will probably not be reached until next week. 
 With the endorsement by the newspaper's board and the unions, including tacit approval from the guild, many of those in the negotiations said it was highly unlikely that anything could derail Mr. Zuckerman's bid to acquire The Daily News.
"I would say that Mort Zuckerman is the new owner of The Daily News," said George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella union organization.
And James P. Willse, editor and publisher of The News, said, "As far as we're concerned, it's done."
For the beleaguered Daily News, the selection of Mr. Zuckerman would be expected to end the tremendous anxiety about the paper's fate and raise the curtain on an era of rebuilding after a disastrous strike two years ago and the unexpected death last year of Robert Maxwell, the paper's owner, whose economic collapse pushed The News into bankruptcy.
The proposed deal would mean a new color printing plant for The News and a wealthy buyer who could afford to finance future growth.. In exchange, the unions would give Mr. Zuckerman significant work-force reductions, and he would invest very little of his own cash to purchase the paper.
 
Further Staffing Cuts
 Mr. Zuckerman's deal will eventually reduce The News's work force, which was already cut when Mr. Maxwell acquired the paper, by 25 percent more, but most of that will come after the new color plant is built in two years.
The arrangement gives Mr. Zuckerman the incentive to build the plant and gives the unions more assurance that such a plant, which is considered essential to The News's longterm survival, will be built.
Mr. Zuckerman offered few specific plans for the paper yesterday, but said he wanted to strengthen its investigative reporting and "make it into a vibrant, energetic, populist, popular newspaper -- the pulse and heartbeat of New York City."
He said that by making such improvements as introducing more color and better reporting to the paper, he expected circulation and advertising to grow.
During the strike two years ago, The News's daily circulation dropped to about 300,000 from 1.2 million. Though the paper has rebounded since then to about 750,000, its future depends on broadening its readership and advertising base.
Mr. Zuckerman, who is 55 years old, yesterday characterized the status of the deal more cautiously than Mr. McDonald and Mr. Willse, recognizing the remaining issues and the reality that in a bankruptcy sale the unexpected can happen.
 
Uncertain Value of Offer
 "We're within the 10-yard line with a first down," he said.
The value of Mr. Zuckerman's offer is still undetermined. He has said that he hopes to have a new color printing plant in operation within two years. The price of such a plant could range from about $100 million to $250 million, which he will probably finance through the paper's earnings without personal out-of-pocket expense.
In effect, his actual cash outlay seems to be between $16.5 million and $17.5 million, which will be used to pay creditors and settle other obligations.
In theory, two obstacles remain unresolved for Mr. Zuckerman. They are reaching agreement with the creditors and forging a guild contract. But neither the guild nor the creditors are believed capable of stopping the sale.
Mr. Zuckerman's strategy has hinged on the assumption that the best way to win ownership of the paper was to win over its unions, because the paper would be worthless without them. He has offered concessions to major unions, like allowing the drivers, the only union thought capable of stopping publication in a strike, to deliver all copies of The News, rather than using wholesalers for some deliveries.
During round-the-clock negotiations Wednesday, at the prodding of union leaders and advisers, Mr. Zuckerman and the Newspaper Guild managed to bridge critical differences and come close enough to agreement to make an eventual contract -- and hence union unanimity -- all but assured.
From the start, Mr. Zuckerman has said that he viewed rebuilding the news operation of The News to be a top priority to restoring it as a viable business, and he has sought broad power to hire and fire in the newsroom, which the guild has denounced as union busting.
While the final agreement remains uncertain, those on both sides of the negotiations said that the essential compromise seemed to be a willingness on Mr. Zuckerman's part to drop his demand that advertising employees be removed from union jurisdiction and to offer enhanced severance to employees who volunteer to resign and, if necessary, to dismiss others in a layoff by seniority. Mr. Zuckerman also dropped his wish to restrict severance on some essential newsroom employees, in order to prevent their leaving.
In exchange, according to a union leader who spoke on condition of anonymity, Mr. Zuckerman will probably win new powers over what union leaders term "the unborn," meaning new employees. Mr. Zuckerman has sought the right to dismiss new employees without arbitration and a probationary period of a year rather than 90 days.
Barry F. Lipton, president of the guild, said that many aspects of the agreement were still subject to negotiation, including the number of people who will lose their jobs, but he expressed optimism that a contract can be reached.
 
Offer to Creditors
 And even if the guild should once again deadlock with Mr. Zuckerman, the process has now gone so far that the other unions are thought likely to proceed anyway.
To the creditors, who have outstanding claims against The News of about $35 million, Mr. Zuckerman has offered from 14 to 17 cents on the dollar, compared to as much as 40 cents offered by the Whitman Group, a New York firm that specializes in bankruptcies.
The creditors demonstrated that they still hope to wring a better offer from Mr. Zuckerman by making as much trouble for him as possible.
On Wednesday, the Whitman Group mounted a strong effort to block Mr. Zuckerman by making a clearly superior offer to the creditors and volunteering to provide a $3 million loan to the paper provided the creditors and the paper's board endorsed them as buyers of The News.
But the Whitman offer was bitterly denounced by Douglas LaChance, president of the drivers union, as a last-minute effort by an unknown buyer to derail the agreements that Mr. Zuckerman and his representative, Fred Drasner, had spent months negotiating.
When the paper's board endorsed Mr. Zuckerman's proposal about midnight, the Whitman offer effectively became moot.
At the urging of the creditors, Judge Tina L. Brozman of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan postponed until next Wednesday her ruling on Mr. Zuckerman's proposal to provide up to $3 million loans to The News, whose continuing losses have created a critical cash shortage. She also delayed until Wednesday a motion to guarantee Mr. Zuckerman $2.7 million in compensation for his expenses should another buyer ultimately acquire The News.
Because of Mr. Zuckerman's loan offer, the paper's management withdrew its request for an across-the-board 10 percent wage cut, saying the paper had sufficient funds to last until Wednesday.
Under his proposal, Mr. Zuckerman would be committed to providing an immediate loan of up to $500,000, up to $1 million when all nine unions ratify contracts with him, and up to $3 million when the court formally approves the acquisition, which could take place within 30 days.
Mr. Zuckerman said that a delay in court approval until Wednesday would have no effect on the situation.
Because of bankruptcy procedural requirements of bringing a company out of bankruptcy, Mr. Zuckerman probably could not actually close the sale until late November. And in such a bankruptcy sale, another buyer could come before the court with a higher and better offer, though the prospect that such an offer would block Mr. Zuckerman is considered remote.
The next step would presumably come in 30 days when the bankruptcy court would consider formally approving Mr. Zuckerman's proposal. If approved, closing would follow in another 30 days.

HEADLINE: Democrats Scale Back Aims In Congress to Win at Polls

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Eager to return to their districts to soothe angry voters, Democratic lawmakers have decided to scale back their legislative agenda.
Party leaders are plotting a strategic retreat on seven appropriation bills to forestall a new flurry of vetoes by President Bush, which would probably have forced Congress to stay in Washington through most of October. They have also jettisoned plans to press health-care legislation and a bill guaranteeing abortion rights because Democratic members have been unable to agree on which version to support. 
 Pressures to end the session by Oct. 4 grew on Tuesday when Peter Hart, a Democratic poll taker, struck fear in a meeting of the House Democratic Caucus by predicting that incumbents faced mounting resentment on Election Day. He urged them to act quickly to re-establish personal rapport with their constituents as people with deep roots in their districts, not as members of an institution discredited by scandal and at loggerheads with the President over policy.
 
Push for Quick Action
 For weeks, campaign aides to Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas have been quietly urging Congressional leaders to finish their work quickly, contending that the Democratic Presidential candidate is in a better position to challenge President Bush than a Democratic Congress held in low regard.
Mr. Hart's warning, and the response of disquiet among the membership, further persuaded Congressional leaders to back away from their independent strategy of underscoring their differences with the President. Accordingly, Democratic chairmen of the House and Senate appropriation subcommittees are now consulting to decide what programs to cut from the seven bills so they can keep the spending levels of each appropriation bill consistent with Mr. Bush's requests.
Democratic Senators do not face the same re-election pressures as their colleagues in the House, but they have deferred to them and agreed to make the necessary cuts, amounting to more than $10 billion. Democrats had contended that the threat by Mr. Bush to veto individual appropriation bills that exceeded his requests was hollow, since the total financing of the 13 appropriation measures already approved by the House was $13 billion, or nearly 3 percent below White House requests.
"There is only one person who can confront the President and that is Bill Clinton," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn. "Most members are liked in their districts. It is only when they are away from their districts that these hobgoblins arise."
Democratic leaders have also pushed aside plans to sharpen their differences with the White House over health care and abortion rights because their members have been unable to resolve internal differences over policy and details.
They say they would now be content to pass two bills that Mr. Bush is likely to sign, one to encourage investment in depressed urban areas and the other to increase energy efficiency. They feel that such successes would allow them to argue that the 102d Congress had an adequate record of accomplishment, considering the long series of vetoes and unsuccessful override attempts.
"Members are real concerned," said Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Westchester Democrat who faces a bitter re-election race against former Representative Joseph J. DioGuardi. "This is no time to play political games. We might as well go home and work toward a new administration and a new session where we can make real progress on health care and the economy."
With primaries still left in Hawaii and Louisiana, a postwar record of 19 House incumbents have already lost in primaries this year. Many more incumbents are expected to lose on Election Day because their districts have been redrawn, or because of overdrafts at the House bank and an anti-incumbent mood that has turned seniority into a liability in many states.
Mr. Hart's presentation helped resolve a debate over two divergent tactical lines proposed by various Democratic lawmakers. Some had argued that the Democrats were poised to gain from Presidential vetoes of spending bills, which include money for veterans, health and the elderly, even if a deadlock over appropriation legislation temporarily shut down the Government. But the majority concluded that the President was in a better position to blame Congress for continued deadlocks.
 
Division Among Democrats
 The Democratic decision to de-emphasize confrontation with the White House was also based on the realization that the Democrats themselves are divided on important social issues like health care.
Congressional Democrats had long sought to exploit widespread unhappiness with the current health insurance system as an issue to embarrass Mr. Bush. They had hoped to pass a national insurance plan before the Presidential election. But they have been unable to agree on a plan.
Similarly, Democratic leaders said they wanted to underscore their differences with the Administration over abortion rights by passing the Freedom of Choice Act, which would codify the Supreme Court ruling of Row v. Wade, which legalized abortion in 1973. But when they found that they could not pass the bill without the including amendments that would place new restrictions on abortion rights, they dropped their plans.
