HEADLINE: Finally, Stamford Arts Center to Open

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 17

 BODY:
After more than a decade of grand plans and false starts, cost overruns and acrimonious disputes, the Stamford Center for the Arts next week will open the performing-arts complex that its creators have called, with a good bit of hyperbole, the Lincoln Center of Fairfield County.
The Rich Forum -- a $15.3 million concrete-and-glass structure named for the center's president and Stamford's master builder, Frank D. Rich Jr. -- makes its official debut with a $1,000-a-ticket gala next Friday, although its first season will be a thin patchwork of performances interspersed with corporate meetings. 
 The Forum's producer, Alexander Cohen, envisions it as a major regional theater, yet the main theater's odd size and the region's economic woes may make it difficult for the Forum to thrive. And some community arts organizations that have benefited little from the public and private spending on the center fear that it will be an elitist institution serving only the well-to-do.
"The Forum is an expression of confidence in Stamford's future," Mr. Rich said. The developer was the key player in transforming Stamford during the 1970's and 1980's into a hub of sleek corporate headquarters, although parts of his own real-estate empire are now threatened by foreclosure proceedings.
 
Debate Over Priorities
 But Mary Hawe, a Stamford Republican leader and advocate for the poor, said: "Over the long years of construction delays, the center did nothing to foster arts in the community. Instead, public resources were sucked up by the center and not going where they were needed."
The Forum's plush Truglia Theater, named for the late State Senator Anthony Truglia, will begin its first, truncated season on Dec. 22, when the Broadway production of Brian Friel's "Dancing at Lughnasa" opens for a two-week run. Three other works also will be presented for two weeks each -- "Falsettos," "Lost in Yonkers" and a new Marsha Norman work called "Loving Daniel Boone." The Forum's second, smaller theater will present the Broadway spoof "Forbidden Broadway."
"This schedule is just designed to get the theater open," said Mr. Cohen, a veteran Broadway and television producer. "I don't intend to book this as a road house."
"Next year I plan to produce six to eight new plays with a company of our own and establish Rich Forum as one of the best regional theaters in America, like the Steppenwolf, Arena or Mark Taper," he said, referring to prominent regional theaters in Chicago, Washington and Los Angeles. He predicted that affluent residents of Fairfield and Westchester Counties would enthusiastically support Stamford productions that feature some of the more prominent actors from the area, like Glenn Close, Jason Robards and Richard Kiley.
 
Doubts in the Arts Community
 Despite Mr. Cohen's optimism, the Forum has had more than its share of doubters and critics.
"If it had been finished as scheduled, in the mid-1980's, when the economy was booming, its fortunes might be better," said Ralph A. Antonacci, who heads the Stamford Community Arts Council, a producing and advocacy group, and a longtime critic of the center's management.
He also said that the Forum had backed away from its initial plan, as proposed by Mr. Rich in 1979, for a "center for the arts that's affordable for all."
George Moredock, the managing director of Stamford's Palace Theater, which the center also operates, said the idea that the Forum would be built for community use "was a misconception from Day 1." He added: "The building was supposed to be built for 1,000 reasons over the last 13 years. But the key reason was economics, to promote Stamford, not as a home for community groups."
Even the Forum's design and setting present a welter of contradictions. The building is in an area now all but deserted by night, near Stamford's poorest, toughest neighborhoods. Inside, beyond the shimmering, 28-foot-high lobby windows, is a plaster-cast reproduction of the old Stamford Theater, which was razed to make way for the Forum.
 
Small Audience, Big Stage
 The Forum's main performance venue, the Truglia, has just 723 seats but a huge 48-foot-deep stage. The 150-seat Leonhardt Studio is meant for smaller performances and use as a studio for Connecticut Public Broadcasting.
"We would have loved the Rich Forum to be a grand concert hall," said Barbara Soroca, executive director of the Stamford Symphony. "But financially it doesn't make sense to put a 90-piece orchestra onstage and have only 700 people in the audience." The symphony performs at the Palace but will present several chamber-music and pops concerts at the Forum.
While the Truglia is too small to attract orchestras or large theater companies, producers say it is too large for a viable regional theater or smaller Stamford ensembles like the Young Artists Philharmonic. Mr. Cohen acknowledged that even with a large subscriber base and major grants, the center's 1993-94 budget may be several million dollars in the red.
Furthermore, Mr. Rich has said that if the Forum does not succeed as an arts center, its board of directors should consider using it for other purposes, like a conference center -- a suggestion that is chilling to local artists.
The center's history began in the late 1970's, when Mr. Rich and two Stamford-based companies, Pitney Bowes and Champion International, bought the Stamford Theater, intending to transform it into a year-round center for music, plays, opera and visual arts. Construction was to begin in 1985, at a cost of $6 million, with much of the financing coming from a city agency created to disburse state hotel-tax revenues for tourism.
 
An Expanded Role
 Between 1985 and 1989, the center's management shifted direction, buying the 1,500-seat Palace and demolishing the Stamford Theater. While they focused on the Palace -- booking popular performers like Johnny Cash and Itzhak Perlman -- they scaled back plans for a new complex, and decided to gear it toward touring national productions rather than local performing companies.
Construction began in 1989, but its scheduled spring 1991 opening was delayed as the center's mission again was broadened to include space for video productions and corporate gatherings.
What has particularly rankled many local performance companies is not only what they view as the center's apparent shift from its initial commitment to community artists but also the fact that it received $9 million in public money for operations of the Palace before the Forum even opened, plus $5 million toward its construction.
 
Testing Openness
 William Macklin, a co-founder of Stamford's Black Artists Theater Company, said: "The original concept was supposed to be that community groups like ours would have access to it. To get state funding, they had to say that community groups would benefit; otherwise, it would be discriminatory." He said he planned to test how open the center is by proposing a performance featuring rap artists.
While Mr. Rich pledged that the Forum would "welcome all" groups, and Mr. Cohen and Mr. Moredock have patched up relations with Stamford performance troupes, some remain wary.
As Mr. Antonacci said: "We want to put the disputes behind us, but this is a point in Stamford's arts development that bears very careful attention."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats;
Given a Good Lead, Clinton Is No Longer Talking Tough

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KELLY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The other night, the Democratic Presidential nominee entertained a group of reporters on his campaign plane with a run-down of Bill Clinton's Laws of Politics.
Mr. Clinton's laws speak of a deep and somewhat cynical understanding of the line of work he is in: "When you're starting to have a good time, you're supposed to be someplace else," and "Nearly everyone will lie to you, given the right circumstances." There was one well-known political law, along the same lines, that the candidate did not mention: Give the people what they want. 
 But if Mr. Clinton does not preach that particular law, increasingly he seems to be practicing it. The candidate who once sounded like a Dutch uncle, with his stern talk of cutting Federal spending and the need for sacrifice, now sounds more like a sugar daddy.
Speaking on Wednesday to an audience composed mostly of poor black residents of South-Central Los Angeles, Mr. Clinton promised "to put education and skills and money in your hands," "a job for everybody who wants to work" and for every American adult "the education and training they need to compete in a global economy."
Speaking here today to an audience composed mostly of middle-class and upper-middle class white people, Mr. Clinton promised to spend "every dollar by which we reduce defense in building an economy for the 21st century here at home, in environmental cleanup, in new technology."
He promised a "a new energy policy that will improve the environment, increase employment and make Americans more secure," and, more to the political point, would make a federally subsidized natural energy research center in nearby Golden, Colo., "flourish like a flower in the desert."
Back in the days before he was sitting on a 15-percentage-point lead over President Bush, Mr. Clinton used to make a point of talking tough. He warned about the dangers of the massive Federal deficit. He made a special point of taking his hardest messages directly to those who would least enjoy hearing them, lecturing a white audience in Georgia about racism and telling off the Rainbow Coalition for honoring the rap performer Sister Souljah.
Now, even when Mr. Clinton brings up such unpleasant subjects as cutting Federal spending, he does so in a way that makes something most experts on the Federal budget say would have to involve deep and painful cuts seem almost pain free.
"My idea for the deficit is to cut inefficient spending, reduce by attrition Federal employment by a 100,000 and give it to the cities to put 100,000 police officers on the streets in the next five years," he said today.
Similarly, in speaking to a group of 500 or 600 people at the Maxine Waters Employment Preparation Center in South-Central Los Angeles, Mr. Clinton never went anywhere near the themes of self-discipline and personal responsibility that have in the past characterized some of his speeches before black audiences.
The riots that began in South-Central Los Angeles last April were mentioned only in passing, described as "disturbances."
Mr. Clinton suggested his support for the point of view that blames the riots largely on economic conditions in South-Central Los Angeles.
"Don't you know we could diminish the racial tensions in this community, don't you know we could diminish the tensions between rich and poor in this community, if everybody thought that if they worked hard and played by the rules they could get ahead," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Greeting supporters in Denver, Gov. Bill Clinton, center, was joined by Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, left, and Mayor Wellington Webb. (Associated Press)

Turmoil in Europe
Europe's currency markets stabilized one day after the system of economic cooperation nearly collapsed. But few ideas emerged to solve the problem of Germany's high interest rates. [Page A1.]
U.S. policies contributed little to the crisis in Europe and there is not much Washington can do to alleviate it, economists say. [A1.] 
 European consumers face the realization that their currency crisis may mean cutbacks in their spending. [D4.]

HEADLINE: In Hawaii, Salvaging What the Hurricane Didn't Take

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WAIMEA, Hawaii, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Creeping gingerly through their devastated bedroom today, the Shea children, survivors of Hurricane Iniki, came upon a familiar sight in an unfamiliar setting: their mother's hand-lettered house rules, buried among the debris of their collapsed ceiling.
They read them aloud as if discovering evidence of a long-lost era: 
 "Every morning fold blankets without being told and wash your own dishes.
"Rice cook 5:00. Little ones come home 5:00. Big ones come home 6:00.
"If don't do chores, don't ask to sleep over at a friend's house on Saturday."
Since the storm ripped the roof and two walls from their ramshackle green wooden house last Friday, scattering their belongings for miles across the countryside, the Shea family has slept on the floor of a high school classroom where, rather than house rules, a bulletin-board notice proclaims: "Our changing world."
 
Emotional and Physical Toll
 Like many of the 8,000 people made homeless by the storm, their new routine at a Red Cross shelter includes food handouts and daily visits to their ruined home, which are trying as much for the emotional toll they take as for the hard work of salvaging their possessions.
"The first time I saw my house I just got sick," said the father, Maynard Shea, a 36-year-old security guard. "This is an exhausting thing. The mind really breaks down. I fell down on this mattress here and just slept."
Mr. Shea said he had lived in the house since he had been 5 years old. Last Friday the eye of Hurricane Iniki roared across Kauai's southern coast and over his house, 25 miles southwest of the capital, Lihue. "Our address used to be 4781 but the numbers blew away," he said.
Since the storm, Mr. Shea, his wife, Marla, and their seven children have created a large pile of refuse in front of their home and locked their few salvaged belongings inside a parked van for safekeeping.
"I kind of wish the storm had cleared everything away, had taken it all into the river," Mr. Shea said. "But it did just half the job and left the other half to me."
Cleaning up will be just the first difficult stage for the thousands of victims of the hurricane, which caused an estimated $1 billion in damage to this tropical island of 55,000 people.
With its winds of 160 miles an hour sweeping across the landscape -- like a supernatural hand, in Mr. Shea's image -- it devastated the farmland and the tourist hotels that are the basis of the island's economy.
 
Facing an Uncertain Future
 Mr. Shea comes from a family of hotel workers and tour drivers, and his wife is from a family of sugar plantation workers. The future for all of them is now uncertain.
Asked how long it would take to put the island's economy back on its feet, Kauai's Mayor, JoAnn Yukimura, pressed her fingers against her temples in weariness and said: "I don't think we know that right now. It's going to take a long while to recover from this."
She said the island, always hospitable to strangers, must now rely on the largess of government agencies.
 
House With No Insurance
 Mr. Shea said his only hope to avoid homelessness would be government loans or grants. "Nobody wanted to insure this house; it's too old," he said.
His father-in-law, Francis Furtado, said the devastation put in jeopardy his job as a crane operator at a sugar mill.
"Sugar has been slowly going down and they've been trying to fill in by planting coffee and macadamianuts," said Mr. Furtado, 57.
"But now everything's been affected. Papayas are wiped out," he said. "Bananas are wiped out. We lost pineapples already. With sugar down, it's, pow! And if the tourists stop coming, we're done for. We'll have to move to the mainland."
Mr. Shea's work as a security guard is at the Barking Sands missile testing range a few miles from here, and it is a source of family debate.
Mrs. Shea is one of a growing number of islanders who oppose the range, which tests "Star Wars" technology, because of fears that it could pose dangers to residents.
But the work pays well, and Mr. Shea noted that this is hardly a time to give up one's livelihood on principle. "If they close it down I'd be out of a job," he said. "I try to get her to remember that: who's feeding us for now."
As the shock of the disaster has begun to sink in across the island and people have found themselves living without electricity, running water or fresh food, a new edge of irritability is setting in.
 
Even Cars 'Don't Feel Right'
 Even mechanical objects seem to be balky, like the Sheas' Volkswagen, in which the driver's-side lock has jammed for no good reason. "A lot of people's cars are in shock," Mrs. Shea said. "They don't feel right."
Some looting has begun to be reported, a crime that Mrs. Shea attributed more to anger and restlessness than to need. One young man from Waimea was seen today wandering the streets of the island's capital with a machete inexplicably under his arm.
"There's a lot of tension now," Mrs. Shea said. "I see it in everybody. The children are starting to get a little irritated. I wish school were on."
As she spoke, military relief helicopters flew noisily back and forth above her ruined home -- one more annoyance.
"I wish I could leave everything in there," she said with a glance at her house, which looked somehow rakish without its roof or back wall. "I wish I could just tell the guys with the tractors to knock the whole thing down."
Her husband and their daughters, Kimberly, 13, and Jocelyn, 11, were inspecting the remains of her bedroom, exposed to all the world now without walls or ceiling.
On a shelf, Jocelyn's plastic cheerleading trophy was still in its place, but Kimberly's was gone. The championship trophy for Mr. Shea's Kaimanas basketball team was still there; his hustle award trophy and his cherished Mayor's trophy were gone.
 
'Bills Didn't Fly Away'
 "You'd be surprised what stayed," Mr. Shea said. "My church clothes: my white shirt and good pants. But my work clothes went.
"My bills didn't fly away. What I wanted to fly away, it stayed."
In happy surprise he pulled a basketball from a closet and tossed it into the air, exclaiming, "Look what's still here!"
After each discovery during the inspection of their house, Mr. Shea and his daughters carefully replaced the item as if there were still some order to be preserved here.
Mrs. Shea's hand-written house rules were tucked back among the sodden insulating material and strip of patterned curtain that littered the floor.
"Homework every day: do it all," the list of rules read.
And finally, just so nobody would forget who was in charge: "Do not let your friends convince you to break these rules!"
Mrs. Shea said her children sometimes tell her they feel like bums as they roll up their sleeping mats and stand in line for Red Cross handouts.
"I tell them we all feel like bums," she said. "You don't know what it feels like to be a street person until you lose your home. I tell them we are not in this situation alone. There are other people that are also suffering."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ethnic Voters;
Cold War's End Opens Battle on Domestic Issues

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
The end of the cold war has provoked a new competition for the allegiance of urban ethnic voters who have supported Republicans in the last three Presidential elections.
For the last decade these conservative, fervently anti-Communist, blue-collar populations of Polish, Lithuanian, Ukrainian, Armenian, Serbian and Croatian extraction, many of whom live in the crucial swing states of the Midwest, have been among the staunchest "Reagan Democrats." With the passing of the cold war, both the Bush and Clinton camps agree that these constituencies are up for grabs. 
 When the Soviet empire collapsed, the Republicans lost the unifying force that bound these diverse descendants of refugees from "captive nations" and kept them on the Republican side. Instead, the Bush forces are emphasizing their conservative social agenda and their stewardship over the disintegration of Communism.
For the Democrats, the same factors represent a chance to use their traditional economic appeal to reclaim middle-class voters who abandoned them.
 
No More One-Stop Shopping
 The problem for both parties is that this Eastern and Central European ethnic bloc has shattered, often into hostile factions, which makes appealing to them increasingly complicated.
"Instead of one-stop shopping at the captive nations supermarket, you have to visit all of these ethnic boutiques," said Kevin Phillips, the Republican consultant.
For instance, Croatian-Americans and Serbian-Americans, who stood shoulder to shoulder at Reagan rallies in Eastern European neighborhoods in Milwaukee, Cleveland or Pittsburgh, are now fighting one another across the very same sidewalks. No one knows that better than Representative Jim Moody, a Democrat who ran unsuccessfully for his party's Senate nomination in Wisconsin this month.
Mr. Moody was a relief volunteer in Yugoslavia in the 1950's, and he learned Serbo-Croatian and made many friends there. Last December on a return visit, he met, among many others, a Serbian guerrilla leader in a Serbian-held area of Croatia. That led to pictures in the hometown press with the caption: "Moody inspects Serbian Troops in Croatia."
 
Wisconsin's Family Feud
 This infuriated the 8,000 Croatian-Americans in Wisconsin, who began picketing his rallies, disrupting his public debates and flooding his radio call-in shows. This then drew out the 10,000 Serbs in his defense, and the police had to begin separating them at all his public appearances.
"We got caught in the middle of a family fight, and there is nothing worse," said Marcus Kunian, Mr. Moody's chief of staff. "At one of our rallies in front of a hotel in Milwaukee the two sides were separated by a police barricade, and at one point one of the Serbians, a young guy, shouted across the street at one of the Croats: 'And Milo, I am sorry I ever dated your sister.' "
Suddenly ethnic voting maps, which once might have grouped all sorts of Eastern and Central Europeans, are being divided and subdivided.
Another major structural change that candidates have to deal with is the fact that during the cold war, ethnic groups like Poles, Ukrainians and Armenians played the role of shadow governments for their captive homelands behind the Iron Curtain. Their main focus was raising money for opposition parties and underground newspapers and lobbying Congress and the executive branch to open emigration to their compatriots.
 
America First Is No Comfort
 "Now the Poles have their own legitimate Government and embassy to do that, and so do the Ukrainians, Armenians, and Serbians," said Adrian Karatnycky, assistant to the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., who deals with international affairs. "So now you see the Polish-American Congress reassuming the role of being the voice for community concerns, the elderly, pensioners, community centers. It makes them much more interested in the domestic side of the agenda."
All of this has been good news for the Clinton campaign, said Stephanie Solien, Mr. Clinton's national political director. Instead of the unifying threat being Communism abroad, which played into Republican hands, she said, "the unifying threat is now the state of the economy at home," which plays into Clinton's hands.
With these Eastern European communities clustered in the battleground states of Ohio, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Michigan and Illinois, Mr. Clinton is aggressively courting them not only with his economic arguments, but also with his standard lines about healing the divisions in the country.
Bush campaign officials say they are trying to hold these Eastern European communities with several new appeals. One is to argue that only an internationalist like Mr. Bush will remain interested in the affairs of the "old countries." Another, as Mr. Bush demonstrated to Polish-Americans in Hamtramck, Mich., is to take as much credit as possible for the fall of Communism in Eastern Europe, or as Mr. Bush put it: "I called for an end to the cold war, and thank God the cold war has ended." Still another, which Mr. Bush tried out in a speech on the economy in Detroit on Sept. 10, is to offer free-trade agreements with Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia.
There were, of course, issues other than foreign policy that converted these voters into Reagan Democrats, including economic expansion, tax cuts, quotas, the death penalty and, to some extent, abortion.
But the problem now, said the Republican consultant Roger Stone, is that just when the single unifying theme of anti-Communism has been removed, another element -- economics -- has become all consuming. While the Republicans tried at their convention to use a basket of extraneous cultural issues, like gay marriages and single mothers, to hold these constituencies, without anti-Communism, it has been hard to get them to overlook the economy.
"In the past it was enough for the Republican candidate to make the strongest possible anti-Communist appeal and then win the votes of three-quarters of Ukrainians," said Taras Bazyluk, a Ukrainian lawyer in Washington. "That is simply no longer the case. It just doesn't cut it anymore. This time, people are going to vote their pocketbooks."

HEADLINE: Reaching for The News;
Mortimer B. Zuckerman: Power, Wealth, Controversy

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
On Aug. 16, just about the time that Mortimer B. Zuckerman became the front-runner in the derby to purchase The Daily News, he gave a wedding at his estate in East Hampton, L.I., for the son of a longtime friend who died in February. By the accounts of several guests it was a terrific time, a warm and sunny event, even though it rained. Mr. Zuckerman toasted the young couple "almost as a father would," one guest said.
Warm and fuzzy is not the image most people have of the 55-year-old Mr. Zuckerman, now on the threshold of an opportunity to reverse the sliding fortunes of the 73-year-old tabloid. Indeed, it is fair to say that over the last two decades and up and down the Northeast Corridor, Mort Zuckerman has made more than a few people mad while making himself rich. 
 A real-estate developer who became a multimillionaire in the 1970's and turned publishing mogul in the 1980's with his purchases of The Atlantic and U.S. News & World Report, Mr. Zuckerman's path has generated a consistent wake of contention.
He has also proven himself a man drawn to the spotlight personally as well as professionally. As a lifelong bachelor with a history of high-profile female companions -- Gloria Steinem most notable among them -- his exploits have been fodder for gossip columns as well as business pages.
People who have known and worked with him paint a picture of a many-sided man possessed of a genuine warmth and capacity for friendship. But even his staunchest defenders concede that his reputation for flamboyance and self-promotion always precedes him. As more than one said, he is a man people love to hate.
 
Boston Properties
 Mr. Zuckerman owns 50 percent of Boston Properties, a development company that controls more than 80 properties in Boston, Washington and in the Philadelphia, San Francisco and Los Angeles areas, as well as the one-million-square-foot building at 599 Lexington Avenue in Manhattan, which is its only New York building, but its largest. His net worth was estimated by Forbes magazine in 1990 as $375 million, though in the current soft real-estate market that figure has most likely declined. In an interview yesterday, Mr. Zuckerman would only say of his fortune, "It's enough to support the investment the Daily News will require."
In the interview, Mr. Zuckerman called himself "an urban alcoholic."
"I've always loved city life, and I've always been passionate about public policy and politics," he explained. "As soon as I started work, I turned to real estate as a way to be involved in urban life. And in journalism, the second world in which I live, there is no better opportunity to focus on city life -- and the city that I love -- than The Daily News."
He described his politics as "moderate, conservative" and said he had voted for President Bush in 1988, but he had been "extremely disappointed" with his performance as President. He made no comment about New York politics, but he added, "Obviously, we'll have an editorial position before the election, but it's too soon to consider that."
What signals this sends about his stewardship of The News are unclear. He has, in the past, been known as an owner who has tried to impose a heavy hand on editorial content, particularly in the first couple of years at U.S. News, where he has gone through four editors in eight years. Even those who ran afoul of him, however, give him credit for improving the magazine, both financially and editorially, and for becoming more prudent in his editorial actions.
 
'He's Smart'
 "Mort may be egotistical, but he's smart," said Roger Rosenblatt, who left the magazine in 1989 after what he called "substantive disagreements" with Mr. Zuckerman. "The lesson he may have learned is that a publication is not only a property -- it's a trust. I don't think he understood that at the beginning, but I think he understands it now."
Born in Montreal in 1937 -- he became a United States citizen in 1977 -- Mr. Zuckerman is a graduate of McGill University and Harvard Law School. At 24, he went to work at the old-line Boston development firm of Cabot, Cabot & Forbes, where he developed a reputation as both a boy wonder and a brash outsider.
In 1970, he left Cabot with a colleague, Edward Linde, to form Boston Properties, and almost immediately became embroiled in a bitter dispute with his former firm, suing them over ownership interest in a developed property -- and winning.
A decade later, after he purchased the Atlantic Monthly Company as his first foray into publishing, Mr. Zuckerman refused to pay five of the major stockholders their second installment of the purchase price, claiming they had misrepresented the company's finances; the legal battle stretched on for years.
 
Two Big Battles
 In between, Mr. Zuckerman found himself at the center of two of the decade's biggest political brouhahas in Boston. One, the building of the Marriott Long Wharf Hotel, resulted in the resignation of the executive director of the Boston Redevelopment Authority when Mayor Kevin White selected Boston Properties as the developer against the recommendations of the agency.
The other was a seven-year wrangle over the development of Park Square, a largely rundown tract in downtown Boston. The project, known as Park Plaza, never happened, having drawn the ire of environmentalists and residents of nearby neighborhoods who objected to the prospect of shadows falling on Boston Common, among other things.
A decade later, a similar fate would befall Mr. Zuckerman's proposed development of the Coliseum site at Columbus Circle in Manhattan, though the concern over shadows darkening Central Park was just one among many things that have thus far undermined the project. Boston Properties still has a contract with the city to purchase the site, but in the current economy it is not likely that a favorable deal will be made soon.
Through all the bickering and litigation, Mr. Zuckerman has garnered a fair amount of resentment, for both his celebrity status and his success. (Boston Properties has, in a down market, maintained an occupancy rate in its holdings of more than 90 percent.) Nonetheless, he has also seemed to retain a reputation for probity.
"In this business, many deals are basically handshakes," said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. "People get known for either living up to or not living up to those agreements. He's somebody whose word can be counted on."
Mr. Zuckerman's word on The News: "I won't be trying to turn The Daily News into The New York Times. The Daily News is the newspaper for the people of New York. It's a popular newspaper. I'm looking to keep it that way."

HEADLINE: Cable TV Regulation Advances

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17

 BODY:
Armed with the powerful support of television broadcasters, the House of Representatives today approved by a wide margin a measure to regulate cable television prices.
The size of the vote, 280 to 128, means the House can probably muster the two-thirds majority needed to override a veto by President Bush, who immediately attacked today's measure as full of "costly, burdensome and unnecessary requirements." 
 But the legislation, which emerged from a House-Senate conference committee last week, still faces a big hurdle in the Senate, which is expected to act on the final version of the bill early next week.
 
Tougher Fight in the Senate
 Advocates conceded today that they would face a more difficult fight there. Some former supporters are said to be wavering, in part because of heavy lobbying from the White House, the cable industry and Hollywood producers.
The House vote increases the chances for the first override of a Bush veto. It also puts the President in what could be a no-win situation. Proponents of the legislation say it is the biggest consumer initiative in recent years and would both rein in prices for basic cable service and erode the monopoly franchises that cable companies enjoy in all but a handful of cities.
Nationwide, prices for basic cable service have climbed by about 50 percent, or three times the rate of inflation, since 1987, when rates were deregulated by Congress in an effort to promote the fledgling industry.
But critics of the bill, including some Democrats, argued that it would actually raise rates because it would entitle over-the-air broadcasters to demand a new stream of royalties from cable systems that retransmit their programs.
Whatever the eventual impact, most consumers are not likely to notice any difference in monthly bills soon. Most customers subscribe to a broader array of services, from Cable News Network to Nickelodeon, than the basic tier of local stations and public access channels. The second, broader tier of service is subject to much lighter regulation.
Indeed, the biggest effects and the biggest fights have been over provisions of the bill that would affect other industries: television broadcasters, satellite companies and manufacturers of television decoders.
 
Fight by Affected Industries
 The bill passed today would require the Federal Communications Commission to set regulations for reasonable prices for basic service, based on prices charged in the few communities where cable franchises face direct competition.
The bill also includes a controversial feature intended to encourage greater competition from satellite companies and "wireless cable" services that transmit television programming over microwave frequencies. Known as "program access," the provision requires big cable companies that own local franchises as well as produce popular programming to license their programs to rivals.
The big losers would be cable giants like Time Warner Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. of Denver, which owns interests in the Discovery Channel, Black Entertainment Television, Turner Broadcasting System and other programmers.
The most immediate winner may well be Hughes Network Systems, a unit of General Motors that is starting a satellite service that will beam multiple channels of television directly to small home antennas. The National Rural Telecommunications Cooperative, an association of rural telephone companies, is investing $250 million in the venture and plans to market the service to rural households.
"I know this is election time, and we are all hungry for votes, but this is not the way," declared Representative Norman Lent, Republican of Long Island, in the course of the debate. "Consumers are smart enough to recognize that this bill is going to raise, not lower, rates."
The intense industry and Hollywood lobbying did erode support in the House. Twenty-eight Democrats and 19 Republicans who supported the House bill on July 23 did not today. The Senate version passed in January by 73 to 18.
But the biggest threat to the bill may be the calendar. Congress is planning to adjourn in early October, and the President is allowed to consider a bill for 10 days before signing or vetoing it. Senate opponents of the bill are expected to try a filibuster.

HEADLINE: Lifting the Veil on Executive Pay

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
The head of the Gerber Products Company has overhauled the baby-food maker's executive-pay system so that the bosses will get big increases in compensation only if the company prospers. In addition, stockholders will get a much clearer picture of what management salaries will be.
Shareholders got their first glimpse of the new philosophy in the proxy statement that Gerber's chairman, Alfred A. Piergallini, distributed before last month's annual meeting. The document detailed precisely how much he and his team earned last year -- down to the last penny of the estimated value of their stock options; it is already being viewed by shareholder groups and others as a model of corporate candor. 
 "We are attempting to make it as clear as possible to shareholders what they're paying the people who are managing their business, why they're paying that amount of money, and what they're getting for it," said Mr. Piergallini, who made $2 million last year.
 
Argue for Confidentiality
 Most corporate managers vigorously oppose any formal limit on executive pay, arguing that they should be free to pay whatever is necessary to attract the best people. They regard some compensation information as confidential and not to be shared with competitors.
But they are under increasing pressure from stockholders and face mounting criticism from others, including managers in Japan and Germany, who maintain that executive compensation in America is often excessive and a big factor in reducing competitiveness.
Some other executives in the United States, in addition to those at Gerber, have also taken measures toward being more informative about salaries. Robert H. Campbell, for one, who took over the top job at the SunCompany a year ago, rewrote Sun's 1992 proxy because of the frustration he felt trying to decipher the first draft he was shown.
 
 
Other Examples
 "Proxies spend about 80 percent of the pages talking about how we pay executives and then, when you get done reading them, you still don't have much of an idea how executives get paid," he said. I.B.M. and the Gannett Company are among other companies that are providing more information than they once did.
Some smaller companies have started to limit the boss's salary to a certain percentage of what the rank-and-file make. Jack Stack, the chief executive of the Springfield Remanufacturing Corporation in Springfield, Mo., caps his annual salary and bonus at six times the $25,000 that the average factory worker takes home.
"I do it from the standpoint of being a leader and setting an example," Mr. Stack said. "I would personally be embarrassed to take some of the salaries other c.e.o.'s take, especially when they are not purchasing the fixed assets they need to be competitive or creating jobs."
But by comparison with Gerber, the efforts of the other big corporations in control and disclosure of management pay are regarded as -- well -- baby steps.
And pay packages over all continue to show signs of bloat. Chief executives at the nation's largest public companies averaged $2.56 million last year, up 5.3 percent from 1990, according to new statistics compiled by Graef S. Crystal, a business professor at the University of California at Berkeley. That sum was roughly four times what the typical Japanese chief executive made and 139 times the average American paycheck. Gerber's stockholders are thrilled. As the owner of 781,100 shares, the California Public Employees' Retirement System sent an uncharacteristically laudatory letter to Gerber's directors last week congratulating them on their chief executive's "pioneering stance."
Likewise, Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat who wants companies to voluntarily put a dollar value on stock options given corporate employees or risk facing laws that will force them to do so, could not be more tickled.
"The Gerber proxy is miles ahead of the average company proxy in giving its stockholders clear and straightforward information about what its executives are paid and why," he said.
The rare set of revelations in the proxy statement by Gerber, based in Fremont, Mich., also drew appreciative comments from some of the nation's biggest critics of executive pay. Professor Crystal devoted an entire issue of his usually scathing newsletter to praising Mr. Piergallini and arguing that he be given an immediate $700,000-a-year raise in light of his superior performance and gumption.
If Gerber's overhaul of its executive-compensation system is uncharacteristic of American companies, so is Mr. Piergallini uncharacteristic of chief executives. Only 46 years old, he took over in 1990 and almost from the start aimed for drastic changes in the corporate culture. Many mailings to shareholders are now printed on recycled paper, and the company's 12,000 employees are referred to as associates. "The term implies partnership rather than servitude," he said.
Since Mr. Piergallini's arrival, shareholders have earned a 52.5 percent return on their investment, versus the 30.8 percent they would have made with the Standard & Poor's 500.
Part of the reason he changed the compensation system, he said, was to make more employees think like owners. He expanded incentive plans so that 400 people, up from 90, now receive stock options, and 300, up from 100, receive annual bonuses. At his insistence, long-term incentive awards are now paid in stock rather than cash.
The new system includes even more carrots. Senior executives who acquire stock by exercising options and hold those shares for three years get a fifth of a share of restricted stock as a bonus. In addition, senior executives can take 20 to 100 percent of their annual bonuses in stock and get 20 percent more if they maintain their holdings in the company for five years.
The result is that pay packages are far more sensitive to Gerber's performance in the stock market than ever.
Mr. Piergallini's own 1991 pay is a case in point: it shot up 39 percent, but 63 percent of his total compensation came from some form of stock, versus 37 percent the year before. And because his total Gerber stake is worth some 7.1 times his annual salary and bonus, future downdrafts in the stock could wipe out much of the gain to his net worth.
 
A Clear-Cut Statement
 That said, Mr. Piergallini would still not be regarded as much of a maverick were it not for the proxy statement he mailed to shareholders before last month's annual meeting.
While most other companies force investors to hunt for the information, Gerber's shareholders can, with minimal effort, glean from the proxy statement that Mr. Piergallini made $2.02 million in 1991, compared with the $1.45 million he earned the year before. The document provides, too, an estimated value for his 8,333 stock options, that is, rights he was given to buy the company stock at a set price at any time over a period of 10 years. To compute the figure, $203,000, Gerber relied on a mathematical model widely used for nearly two decades by traders, economists -- and personnel departments.
That information is almost never shared with investors. Among other things, the other companies contend that a stock option's present value cannot be calculated with absolute certainty.
"There's no question that a corporation which chooses to provide that information in its proxy materials has every right to do so, and it may well be good corporate policy," said Brian Borders, the president of the Association of Publicly Traded Companies. But he added, "Mandating that kind of disclosure, especially under a disputed formula, is something that this association would oppose."
 
An Eclectic Board
 A veteran of several consumer products companies before Gerber, Mr. Piergallini graduated from the University of Chicago's business school in 1970, three years before the first powerful model for evaluating options was developed. Nonetheless, he seems at ease with the model, and brushes aside the corporate arguments against the practice. "We would be lying to you if we said that it couldn't be done," he said.
One reason why Gerber might have been able to bolt from the pack was the varied and unconventional makeup of its board. A poet sits on the board, along with a pediatrician and a top officer of the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America. Because Mr. Piergallini is the only chief executive on the board, no directors were likely to reject his ideas for fear of setting a precedent at their own companies. All this is not to suggest that Gerber has achieved a perfect peace with its shareholders. The company had to allot space in its proxy and time at its annual meeting so a group of five former executives and one local businessman could state their grievances against management, and its proxy mentions a few corporate practices that a die-hard reformer could still harp about.
The most serious: the company hands out replacement options to executives who exercise their options early, a controversial practice because it allows the executives to benefit from temporary jumps in the stock price. This runs counter to the attempts to get more people at Gerber to think about the long-term future instead of short-term gain for themselves.
 
Criticism of Chairman
 "I was concerned about some of the things current management was doing that I thought demonstrate short-term thinking," said Ray Frodey, a former vice president of the company who is one of the dissidents. He cited the $280,959 cash bonus Mr. Piergallini received last year based solely on 1991's results as one example. He also believes that Mr. Piergallini's total pay should be trimmed in half.
Others dismiss the criticisms as nitpicking. "When you look at the Gerber situation, it's difficult to find much that a shareholder would get too exercised about," said Stephen O'Byrne, a leading compensation consultant at Stern, Stewart & Company.
For his part, Mr. Piergallini understands that multimillion-dollar pay packages will always be controversial, no matter how well deserved. "If someone who owns a share of stock is making $45,000 a year, and the chief executive made $700,000 in salary, it's human nature to say maybe this guy is making too much money," he said. "I might say the same thing."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Woes at Telmex Not of Its Making

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
ON paper at least, Telefonos de Mexico ought to trade among American investors the way well-regarded companies like Pacific Telesis or BellSouth do. Of publicly traded Latin American telephone companies, Telmex has managers who stand head and shoulders above the rest, analysts say. The United States is the most frequently telephoned country from Mexico, and Mexico is the second most frequently telephoned country, after Canada, from the United States.
And as Congress debates the North American Free Trade Agreement, chatter on telephone lines between Mexico and the United States is bound to rise to a din. This year, Mexico-to-United States phone conversation is expected to total some 1.5 billion minutes, or more than 2,850 years. 
 Yet since February, when it peaked at $60.12 per American depository share, Telmex has suffered successive blows, dropping more than 25 percent, to the mid-40's. (One depository share, an instrument representing ownership of foreign stocks, equals 20 Telmex shares.) The Mexican Government's tight-money policy, unfounded rumors of big employee stock sales, and even the stillborn Presidential candidacy of Ross Perot, who strongly opposed the free-trade agreement, all battered Telmex's price.
In recent days, Telmex stock has fallen to $42 and rebounded to more than $45, driven by no particular news event. The shares closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $43.625, down 12.5 cents.
The major problem: sheer size. At current exchange rates, Telmex's market capitalization is nearly $24 billion, almost one-fifth of the entire Mexican stock market.
"For all intents and purposes, Telmex and the Mexican stock market are identical," said William Kurtz, who follows Telmex for H. G. Wellington & Company, a Wall Street brokerage house. Stephanie Georges, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said, "Telmex tends to get swept up in Mexico frenzy -- uncertainty over gross domestic product growth, dollar weakness because its earnings are denominated in dollars, and political currents resulting from how U.S. politicians view Mexico."
Telmex's second major problem is the tight-money policy. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari wants to reduce Mexico's 1991 annual inflation rate of more than 18 percent to close to single digits in 1993 by the time the free-trade pact, if it is ratified, goes into effect. Meanwhile, higher short-term borrowing costs, 18 percent today, up from 11 percent last year, mean higher borrowing costs for Mexican equities, the king of which is Telmex.
That Telmex is not the captain of its own fate is a shame, analysts say. Alone among the major publicly traded Latin American telephone companies -- the others are Argentina, Brazil and Chile -- Telmex has committed a great deal of time, money and management savvy to improving a creaky telephone system, analysts say.
In an $8 billion project that comes to a close next year, Telmex, among other tasks, is installing modern telephone switching computers in some 2,000 central offices serving 10,000 cities and towns. Included in this expenditure is a $400 million specialized network for the country's 700 largest domestic and foreign companies, mainly United States companies.
This network uses digital signals for improved service and reliability. Known as Red Digital Integrada, or integrated digital network in Spanish, it will be expanded as early as next year to more than 1.5 million business customers. Telmex also plans to spend at least $8 billion more over the next three years to modernize, Hector Carlos, marketing vice president, said.
Because Mexican telecommunications is flat on its back -- only 55 percent of calls are completed, up from 47 percent in 1987 -- every peso spent on improved phone service yields a bigger return on investment than a similar investment in a developed country.
By the calculations of Ms. Georges of Salomon Brothers, the market has already given a high value to Telmex, about $4,800 in market capitalization and debt per telephone line, compared with $3,200 for Chile, $2,700 for Argentina and $575 for Brazil, where inflation is high and the Government is under a cloud from scandal.
Joanne C. Smith of Nomura Research Institute sees Telmex earning $4.80 per A.D.S. this year, up from $3.80 in 1991, and she expects $6 in 1993. At those levels, Telmex is going for about six times cash flow for a company growing at 20 percent annually. By comparison, American "Baby Bells" typically cost five times cash flow and grow only 3 percent to 4 percent annually.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Bush Paints Clinton as 'Social Engineer'

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JONESBORO, Ga., Sept. 17

 BODY:
President Bush delivered a slashing assault on Gov. Bill Clinton's economic policies today, painting his rival as a "social engineer" whose proposed tax and spending increases threaten the life styles and freedoms of Middle America.
Unleashing some of the most pointed language of his campaign, Mr. Bush cast the Democratic Presidential nominee as an Oxford-educated liberal bent on reviving big-government theories that have failed in capitals "from Warsaw to Prague to Moscow." 
 "He would unite the Presidency and the Congress to achieve one end above all others: more government," the President said at a rally here. "A government that taxes more, spends more, regulates more, encourages more lawsuits and shuts off more products from the markets that Americans create."
Adopting Mr. Clinton's policies, the President said, "would be like going out to the used car lot down the road and buying the lemon that you got rid of 12 years ago." That was an allusion to former President Jimmy Carter, who presided over the last economic downturn to rival the current one.
 
Enthusiasm in Oklahoma
 Mr. Bush spoke in Enid, Okla., an oil-patch town of about 50,000 people that has not fully recovered from the 1980's collapse of oil prices but which turned out enthusiastically for him today. About 2,000 people filled a civic auditorium to hear Mr. Bush's remarks, and thousands more lined a town square to watch his limousine roll by.
That was a far larger crowd than met him this afternoon in Jonesboro, an Atlanta suburb. Here, perhaps a thousand people visited a new subdivision to hear Mr. Bush talk about his efforts to help home ownership.
In Enid, Mr. Bush billed his address from the outset as "a serious talk, not a rally speech" about the economy. In fact, it was a bare-fisted effort to sow fear among voters unhappy with the President about the consequences of voting for the Democratic alternative.
That follows a strategy set by Mr. Bush's top aide, James A. Baker 3d, to focus the debate on the future of the economy rather than on its current condition.
The strategy also underscores what opinion polls have long indicated: that confidence in Mr. Bush's economic stewardship is so low that he must make Mr. Clinton seem even more unpalatable if he is to win a majority.
With its disparaging references to Oxford, the 1960's and Mr. Clinton's "economic elite," and its allusions to socialism, the 41-minute speech was redolent with the blue-collar appeals that helped Ronald Reagan lure Democrats to his fold in 1980 and 1984.
Mr. Bush made no attempt today to explain or minimize the economy's present problems. Instead, he argued that the real danger facing the nation is that voters will "grasp change blindly, without considering seriously where these changes will lead us or what they mean in our daily lives."
"At a decisive moment in history comes your choice about who should lead the American economy: the government planner or the entrepreneur, the risk-taker," the President said. "This is the most fundamental disagreement between us: whether the driving engine of growth is government interventionism or entrepreneurial capitalism."
 
Risk-Taker Turned Politician
 Mr. Bush, a full-time politician and Federal official since 1966, cast himself today as the risk-taker -- a Texas oil man who for 18 early years "built a business from the ground up, created jobs and paid my taxes."
By contrast, he said, the role model for Mr. Clinton, who has spent almost his entire adult life in government and politics, "is not the entrepreneur but the government planner, the lawyer or policy professor who flatters himself that he understands the American economy better than the workers and the entrepreneurs who have their sleeves up."
Later, he added: "My opponent is drawn to these views. He and a number of his advisers studied them at Oxford in the 1960's."
The Clinton campaign quickly counterattacked by questioning Mr. Bush's talk of his experience running a small business. "When George Bush left Yale to work in the oil industry, he got the benefit of some 'family values,' Kennebunkport style," the campaign said in a press statement.
Quoting from published reports, it said Mr. Bush's uncle Herbert Walker had given Mr. Bush $300,000 to start his oil business in the early 1950's, an amount that the Democrats said would be the equivalent of $1.5 million in today's dollars. They said fewer than 5 percent of small businesses have a stake of more than $30,000 at the outset.
"George Bush is saying that everybody would be better off if they had an Uncle Herbie," the Clinton camp said. "What small businesses need to survive is Uncle Sam on their side, not in their way."
Mr. Bush holds an economics degree from Yale University. But he warned today that a Clinton administration would be ruled by a different "economic elite of the so-called 'best and brightest,' " who he said "can trace their intellectual roots to the social-engineering ideas popular at the turn of the century" that created the modern welfare state.
Mr. Clinton calls his economic policy "investment" in the nation's infrastructure, Mr. Bush said. "But no matter what you call it," he added, "it's still big-time government spending, directed by Washington planners who want to reorder social and economic priorities. And we can't have that."
That, he said, is the way of "command and control" economies that have been discarded "from Mexico to Eastern Europe, from Russia to South China."
On paper, at least, the two candidates do have opposing views of what the next four years should hold. Mr. Clinton's proposal for change includes $150 billion in new taxes on the well-off and on business, and $220 billion in new Federal spending to stimulate economic growth.
 
Freeing Money to Invest
 Mr. Bush has proposed to cut taxes, by perhaps $130 billion or more, and to reduce Federal spending by hundreds of billions more, mostly by restraining the rise in Federal spending on Medicaid, Medicare and other programs. The President says that would increase growth by freeing money for businesses to invest and hire new workers.
But the two candidates' records suggest the differences are not so stark. As the Governor of Arkansas, Mr. Clinton has espoused pro-business, fiscally moderate policies. And despite Mr. Bush's advocacy of lower taxes and smaller government, the share of national income consumed by Federal spending has risen to near-record levels during his tenure, from 22 cents to 24 cents of each dollar.
In Georgia, Mr. Bush again handed out Federal benefits to prospective voters, announcing a cut in insurance premiums on 15-year Federal Housing Administration mortgages. The White House said that would reduce the up-front cost of buying a home with such a mortgage by $650, and cut annual premium costs by $165 to $325 a year.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

PRESIDENT BUSH
In a speech yesterday at a campaign rally in Enid, Okla.
"Look at the differences. My opponent and his advisers propose something quite different. Their writings refer to European models and industrial policy. And that's an academic term for letting the government pick economic winners and losers. 
 Their idea is not the entrepreneur but the government planner, the lawyer or the policy professor who flatters himself that he understands the American economy better than the workers and the entrepreneurs who have their sleeves up and really make it work.
And my opponent and his advisers can trace their intellectual roots to the social engineering ideas popular at the turn of the century. And those old social -- some of you historians remember this -- those old social engineers advocated large-scale government ownership to give the state the leading role in society and economy. And today, European governments are still selling off the inefficient industrial monstrosities that were born from those ideas."
 
GOV. BILL CLINTON
In a speech yesterday at a campaign rally in Denver
"We have to cooperate -- government, business, labor and education -- we have to compete, so that we can win in the world economy. Let's do what works, for a change, and abandon what has plainly failed.
I want to have an investment program for this country which, yes, asks the wealthiest 2 percent of Americans to pay a little more in taxes, but uses that money to say, if you want to get it back, you can get it back, but no more across-the-board tax cuts. You can get it back if you'll invest in American factories and in starting small businesses and in putting the American people back to work, a real investment plan for the United States of America.
I want a new partnership between government and business and labor in this country, to develop the best ideas we have and turn them into jobs here in America. That is why, that is why, two days ago, in Northern California and San Jose, 21 -- 21 -- chief executives of high technology companies, two-thirds of them Republican, in an unprecedented break with party, endorsed the Clinton-Gore ticket, because we have a technology policy for the 21st century."

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN EUROPE;
Crisis There, But Not Here
Little Impact Is Seen On Presidential Race

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
During the 40 years of the cold war, foreign crises often helped American Presidents win re-election, beginning with Harry S. Truman, the designated role model of the 1992 campaign. The striking success of the Berlin airlift played a significant part in Mr. Truman's upset victory in 1948.
Sometimes a President's failure to satisfy the nation that he was moving effectively enough to defuse a crisis abroad contributed to his defeat. That was the case with Jimmy Carter and the hostages in Iran in 1980. 
 But the currency crisis in Europe is another matter. American policies and actions contributed relatively little to its development, and there is little that Washington can do to alleviate it, economists believe. So there is not much room, at least at the moment, for President Bush to strut his Presidential stuff, demonstrating in the process how invaluable experience is, or much room for Bill Clinton to view with alarm and call for more vigorous American leadership.
"Up until now, the United States has been relatively unaffected," said David C. Mulford, the Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs, noting that the dollar had recovered recently. That, he argued, showed that its earlier decline constituted no adverse "pronouncement on the fundamentals of the U. S. economy."
If the turbulence in currency trading continued unabated, of course, it would sooner or later cause trouble in other financial markets, and that might further damage Mr. Bush, who is already regarded as an uncertain economic steward by large majorities of voters, according to opinion polls. But the situation seemed to be stabilizing yesterday as European governments maneuvered to restore order.
Few voters are likely to grasp, and fewer still to be swayed by, the nuances of the situation -- for example, the fact that the United States was ill placed to persuade the Europeans to lower their interest rates as a stimulus to growth, which might have averted the crisis, at a time when its own huge deficits have contributed to international difficulties.
Learned discussions about economic abstractions on the other side of the Atlantic are not the same thing at all as an electorate bombarded on television with questions about the fate of hostages. Americans, who even today buy many fewer imported goods than Europeans, are not nearly so politically sensitive to or knowledgeable about currency relationships.
Nonetheless, anything that keeps the spotlight on the economy or seems likely to prolong the recession cannot do the President any good. And C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research group, said that continued high interest rates and stagnating economies in Europe would inhibit American exports, make it "very, very hard" for the United States to emerge from recession anytime soon.
The sudden disintegration of the system linking European currencies -- and the possibility that it may lead to the collapse of the hard-won Maastricht agreement on greater European unity -- has other lessons to teach politicians in the United States as well as those at its center.
One is the age-old lesson about the limits on the power of even the strongest men and institutions, which apply with increasing force in modern political economics. If George Bush has failed to make the American economy do his bidding, he has plenty of company among Western political leaders.
The man at the center of the crisis is the German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl. He is one of the premier advocates of European unity, largely because it offers the best way to defuse fears of German dominance among Germany's neighbors, born of three wars in a century. Yet he has been caught in a policy vise that has almost certainly slowed the movement toward unity.
German reunification is costing far more than Mr. Kohl or anyone else calculated, but he is committed to it. He has chosen to pay for it by running up a deficit, and to stop that from causing the kind of runaway inflation that destroyed the Weimar Republic in the 1930's, the German central bank has kept interest rates high. Mr. Kohl could have raised taxes to pay for rebuilding the East, but like other Western politicians in the last 10 or 15 years, he has come to see higher taxes as a tool with an unacceptable political cost.
He could also have cut spending for other purposes, but that might have hurt his re-election hopes.
Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said that budget deficits in Germany and Italy must be reduced quickly to restore stability, and other officials of the fund argue that deficits in the United States are siphoning off capital and slowing economic recovery.
"In Germany as in the United States, there is a lot of economic pain to be allocated, and not much political will to allocate it," said Jeffrey Garten, the author of "A Cold Peace," a new book about Germany, Japan and the United States and their economic relations over the next decade. He said the world economy was "in a rudderless situation," with inadequate leadership at home and abroad.
The power of modern, polycentric markets, with trading roaring ahead 24 hours a day in London and New York and Frankfurt and Tokyo, has all but overwhelmed governments. Using traditional tactics, the British poured hundreds of millions into the markets to prop up the pound, and increased interest rates dramatically, but they were pop-guns against the onrushing tanks of the currency speculators.
Already, the momentum toward European unity has been weakened, and it will be stopped in its tracks if the Maastricht Treaty is rejected by the French in a referendum on Sunday. The Danes have already voted down the treaty, opinion in Britain has turned negative and the Germans, if not their Government, are having second thoughts about giving up the Deutsche mark.
 
'Nobody's Following Them'
 "Our leaders find themselves marching along the road to unity," said a senior European diplomat, "and nobody's following them. They forgot to bring public opinion along, rather like Lyndon Johnson in Vietnam. It's a fundamental problem in democratic societies, and a very serious one."
If European unity is stymied, European leaders and economies are likely for a time to turn in upon themselves, considerably complicating the job of the next President.
"Bush talked about the importance of increasing exports in his Detroit speech, and that means Europe, among other places," said Robert Hormats, an investment banker who has held ranking positions in several administrations. "But it's going to be much harder to deal with Europe on trade questions, and it's going to make the business environment much more difficult. Whether Clinton or Bush is elected, the job will be tougher."
It will also require an economic team of considerable talent and finesse, just as the cold war required national-security experts of a high order. Mr. Bush's economic aides, most notably Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, have been under fire for months from within his party as well as experts in other nations.

HEADLINE: Credit Markets;
Seeking Opportunities in Europe's Woes

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The rupture of the European Monetary System is causing chaos in Europe. But for Stephen C. Bartow, who manages foreign bond funds, it is creating opportunities.
"It doesn't make any difference to me as a portfolio manager," said Mr. Bartow, who is the chief investment officer for the global fixed-income group at the Putnam Companies in Boston. "There is an opportunity in every situation." 
 Mr. Bartow said the withdrawal of both Britain and Italy from the monetary system was setting the stage for cuts in interest rates in Europe. A rate reduction is positive for bond markets there, which have been suffering under the weight of the high rates that Germany set and members of the European Monetary System were required to follow.
"Our view would be that if you take a three-to-six-month view, European bonds offer the best value," he said.
The breach of the monetary system has also pleased David W. Rossmiller, vice president of international fixed-income operations at the Travelers Investment Management Company in Hartford.
"It makes me a happy guy," he said. "I have not really been hurt by the crisis. And in the long term it provides more opportunity because the relationship among all markets will be sloppier."
What Mr. Rossmiller means is that without the knitted currency and interest rate relationships of the European Monetary System, there will be less similarity in the performance of bond markets.
For example, he said the spread, or differential, between the yield of French bonds and German bonds would widen. In the last year, he said, this spread narrowed to 40 to 60 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, because investors expected the European Monetary System and the prospect of a single European currency to narrow the differential among inflation rates, budget deficits and interest rates. And this meant that European bond markets would move more in concert with one another.
But if the current crisis puts off the single currency, things will change. The spread yesterday between 10-year French and German bonds was more than 100 basis points, and Mr. Rossmiller said he expected the gap to widen. And with this variance in performance, he has more chances to jump from one market to another and build on his capital gains as interest rates move at different paces.
It had been the view of many bond portfolio managers and analysts at the beginning of this year that European bonds would be the best value because they expected Germany to cut interest rates in the spring or fall. But that did not happen. Instead, the Germans raised interest rates in July. A lot of American investors would have been badly hurt, had it not been for the decline of the dollar, which cushioned their losses.
The paradox is that a crisis that could doom the European Monetary System, which tied the currencies of 11 countries in fixed trading ranges before the exit of Italy and Britain, may finally make the promise of European bond markets a reality.
 
Foreign Bonds
 The activity in bonds was in foreign markets yesterday, especially in Britain.
"It was a pretty bizarre day," said David E. Smart, managing director of Fiduciary Trust International Ltd. in London. He said trading was heavy and it was hard to trust the prices on computer screens, because the market was moving so fast.
Five-year gilts were up sharply, rising about 1 1/2 to 1 3/4 points. The 10-year gilt was up about 1/2 point. But the 20-year gilt was off 1 1/2 points.
Mr. Smart said the cut in the Bank of England's base lending rate back to 10 percent, after the British withdrew from the European Monetary System, helped to bolster the short end of the market.
He also said that a rejection on Sunday by the French of the Maastricht Treaty, which outlines the steps to a single European currency by the end of the century, would seriously damage the monetary system. But, he argued, the lack of a disciplined monetary system would also allow Britain to cut interest rates further to try to revive its economy. That prospect also lifted short maturities.
Mr. Smart said longer maturities were hurt because the British withdrawal from the monetary system was also sparking longer-term fears of inflation. The British Government could be much more lax in its economic policy if it paid attention only to domestic concerns, he said, and no longer had the discipline of a fixed trading range of exchange rates.
Bonds in Germany and France were off a little after rallying on Wednesday on the hope that the German central bank would cut interest rates yesterday. Those hopes were unfulfilled.
 
Treasury Market
 In the United States, investors seemed to be sitting on their hands, waiting to see how the situation played out in Europe. One of the interesting deals of the day was in the corporate market, where the Mexican Government issued its first dollar-denominated securities in the United States in 10 years.
The $250 million in 10-year noncallable notes were priced to yield 8.53 percent, 215 basis points over the yield of the comparable Treasury bill. Although the notes are not investment grade, Jon Winkelried, a partner at the lead underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the spread of 10-year Treasuries was narrower than for other noninvestment-grade issues, which means that in a sense investors have upgraded Mexico before the rating agencies.
In secondary trading in the Treasury market, the 7.25 percent 30-year bond was down just 2/32 to 993/32 to yield 7.32 percent, the same as on Wednesday. The prices of notes were also down slightly. The discount rate on three-month bills was unchanged; it was up one basis point for the six-month bill.
The new one year bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 3.02 percent, the lowest since Jan. 9, 1963. Following are the results of the Treasury's auction yesterday of one-year bills:

HEADLINE: D'Amato Ad Puts Abrams On Defensive

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Still catching his breath after a brutal Democratic primary, State Attorney General Robert Abrams found himself on the defensive yesterday against his Republican opponent, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who unleashed a radio commercial branding him as "mudslide Bob Abrams" and accusing him of a "fund-raising shakedown."
That was a paradoxical description coming from Mr. D'Amato -- who takes some pride in his reputation as the Peck's Bad Boy of New York politics and has faced repeated inquiries into whether he has done favors for contributors. It was also a not-so-gentle hint of the tone of the seven-week campaign to come. 
 Meanwhile, Mr. Abrams heard only an eerie silence from the woman whom he defeated for the Democratic nomination by a single percentage point. Geraldine A. Ferraro declined to concede, pending a final tally -- or to return a telephone call Mr. Abrams placed on Wednesday -- and prepared to leave town on a five-day retreat in an undisclosed location, her aides said.
"I think it's just tough for her to digest when it's that close," one Democratic Party official said. "But she'll be O.K.."
 
Thank-You Calls
 Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that Ms. Ferraro had told him that she simply wanted to be sure of the final results and that she had questioned what Mr. Abrams would do in her place.
Mr. Abrams also spent the day out of sight, making thank-you calls to supporters and starting to raise money for his race against Mr. D'Amato, whose $3.7 million treasury is five times bigger than his.
About the only bit of good news for the Democratic nominee was one he had nothing to do with: the National Abortion Rights Action League announced that it would run what it called a major independent drive to identify Republican and independent women voters around the state who support abortion rights and urge them to vote against Mr. D'Amato. "We are going to invest as much as we can afford," said Kate Michelman, the league president. "I think this is doable. It's not easy. He's a well-entrenched incumbent, but this is a big issue this year. I think Republicans are appalled at what their party put out at the Republican Convention."
Ms. Michelman declined to say how much her group would spend, but she said its efforts would include polling on voter preferences and door-to-door canvassing, as well as "highly targeted media" efforts or direct mail.
 
To 'Shake Things Up'
 Officially, Mr. D'Amato's new 60-second commercial, which began airing yesterday in some markets and is to be heard statewide starting today, was merely a rebuttal to Mr. Abrams, who in his victory speech on election night said he wanted to go to Washington to "shake things up" while Mr. D'Amato had been "shaking people down."
But it was more than that. Having already begun tagging Mr. Abrams as "hopelessly liberal" in television commercials, Mr. D'Amato is now tring to paint him as a bully who beat up on Ms. Ferraro unfairly, which could hurt Mr. Abrams among the Catholic and white ethnic voters whose support he will need.
Mr. Abrams's press secretary, Timothy Gilles, said it was Mr. D'Amato himself who had first harshly attacked Ms. Ferraro, raising questions in August about a convicted labor racketeer who was a fund-raiser in her early Congressional years.
"Al D'Amato is the person who ran the mother of all negative campaigns in the history of New York State 12 years ago, when he attacked one of the most respected and revered figures in our state, Senator Jacob Javits, in a campaign that is still remembered as one of the nastiest and most brutally unfair in our history," Mr. Gilles said.
The perception that Mr. Abrams's attacks on Ms. Ferraro may have left a residue of ill-feeling among Democrats was noted yesterday by Governor Cuomo, who said he had spoken to Mr. Abrams and would support him "very strongly."
But Mr. Cuomo repeated his past criticism of the tone of the primary campaign and said it had invited Mr. D'Amato to make the very attacks he is now making. "He is so obviously vulnerable on the ethical issues that what you had to anticipate is exactly what he has done," Mr. Cuomo said. "As soon as you give him an excuse by being negative against another candidate, that's what he'll do.
"Our best chance to win is by arguing the economy," he added. "The worst thing is to get involved in a mudslinging campaign, because that will obscure the real issues. And when the mud from him obscures the message from you, that's a terrible mistake."
 
Talked With Ferraro
 The Governor said he had also spoken to Ms. Ferraro but had not urged her to concede.
"How could I?" he said. "What would I say? She says, 'I don't know if I've lost yet.' What you say to her is, 'Well, yeah, but you've likely lost.' "
Mr. Cuomo said Ms. Ferraro had asked whether Mr. Abrams would concede if he were in her shoes, especially since he had refused to rule out continuing on the Liberal Party line, which he already held, if he lost the Democratic primary. "And she made a good additional point. She said: 'There's nothing slowing him down from campaigning now. He is the Liberal Party candidate. What's he waiting for?' "
