HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN EUROPE;
Taking the Pulse of the Major Economies

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Like a disease that strikes those already weak with other illnesses, the turmoil in the world's currency markets afflicts nations struggling with huge budget deficits, high interest rates, shaky banking systems and lingering recessions. Not one of the world's major industrialized economies now enjoys good health and a bright prognosis. Diplomacy and political leadership often involve recommending tough measures only for the other nations' economic ailments. Here, country by country, are the challenges that economists and business leaders say these nationsl face.
 
BRITAIN
 When Harold Wilson reneged on his pledge to maintain the pound's value 25 years ago, his Government toppled. Now John Major faces a continuing recession, high interest rates and a currency crisis that forced him to go back on his word.
 
GERMANY
 No end in sight to the fallout from the takeover of eastern Germany, the largest leveraged buyout in history. With expenses of $100 billion a year, Germans borrow what they refuse to pay in higher taxes. They and their fellow Europeans pay up anyway in higher interest rates, slower growth and monetary turmoil.
 
FRANCE
 Savvy, competitive industries and continuing growth fail to relieve high unemployment. Still, it's politics, not economics, that dominates the agenda. The nation's role in a unified Europe, and its sufferance of President Mitterrand, turn on a referendum this Sunday.
 
ITALY
 Coalition governments prove incapable of clinging to office or bringing huge budget deficits under control. State-owned industries are no more efficient than the tax collectors. Currency traders, doubting the fight against inflation willever turn serious, continue to profit by betting against the lira.
 
SPAIN
 Marrying into the European Community in 1986 meant marrying for better (at first) or for worse (right now). Foreign investors and builders have backed off, production costs have risen, and jobs are harder to find. Budget and trade deficits show the strain.
 
UNITED STATES
 It's the morning after in America - a joyless, jobless recovery. Government, bowed under its debts, continues to spend. Consumers, ruling their borrowing binge and fearing for their jobs, practice austerity. Both presidential candidates vow to reduce the budget deficit; neither dares offer a credible plan.
 
JAPAN
 The stock market off more than 50 percent, the banks wobbling, real estate in decline - and this the healthiest among the world's major industrial economies. A recession Japanese-style just means slow, 1 to 2 percent growth. With help from a new, $86 billion public spending plan, Japan can recharge by next year.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 19, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A map in Business Day yesterday showing the relative sizes of nations based on their economies described the figures incompletely. They were in 1985 dollars.

HEADLINE: North Korea's A-Bomb Plans Seem Less Perilous

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 17

 BODY:
President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea said today that while he remained suspicious of North Korea's nuclear intentions, he had become convinced that its "determination to develop nuclear weapons has become weaker."
Mr. Roh's comments marked a reversal from predictions only five months ago by the Director of Central Intelligence, Robert M. Gates, and other United States and Korean officials that North Korea could be only months way from building an atomic weapon. 
 In a wide-ranging interview, President Roh said he would continue to insist that North Korea go beyond the inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency now under way and agree to far more intrusive mutual inspections on both sides.
"We still have suspicions about the North Korean nuclear program," he said, "just as the United States and other allies are not satisfied." But American officials have begun to say that Mr. Gates may have overestimated North Korea's nuclear skills.
 
3 Little Pacts, No Big One
 In talks that ended today in Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea, the Prime Ministers of the two countries signed three minor agreements but failed again to agree on a program that would allow the South to conduct "challenge inspections" of military sites in the North and the South.
But Mr. Roh said, "My own view is that in the long run, North Korea will have to submit to mutual inspection" because it will be the only way to improve relations with the United States and Japan.
Mr. Roh, who is 60 years old and leaves office in February, talked at length about his trip later this month to China, which recently established diplomatic relations with South Korea.
 
Presidential Goals
 "The main goal of my 'northern policy' was to open formal relations with North Korea's friends and allies, and through them to influence North Korea itself," he said, referring to diplomatic initiatives that have turned Russia and China, once among the South's most hated enemies, into its newest trading partners.
The Chinese no longer "want North Korea to be a threat to this region," he said. While China is believed to have more influence over the North than any other nation, its sudden interest in Seoul is largely economic: Trade between South Korea and the nation that 40 years ago tried to crush it is expected to double this year, to over $10 billion.
Like other Asian leaders in recent months, Mr. Roh, who is to visit the United States next week, appealed for Washington to remain an active player in Asia. Saying he trusted the Administration's commitments to keep forces in the region, he nonetheless expressed concern that budgetary constraints would force the United States to gradually pull back from its post-World War II role of keeping Asia's biggest powers in check.
"Whenever the United States played that role, the region has enjoyed stability," he said. "Whenever the United States withdrew, we saw disputes and wars. This is the clear lesson of history."
President Roh's assessment of North Korea's nuclear intentions came just days after the International Atomic Energy Agency completed its third inspection of the North's atomic sites. While the results have not been made public, agency officials have said recently that they had little doubt that North Korea had been building a plutonium-reprocessing plant, which could make bomb fuel from the waste products of atomic reactors.
But the state of the plant, at a heavily guarded site at Yongbyon, 60 miles north of Pyongyang, suggested that the North Koreans were far from mass production of plutonium. The vast building was incomplete. Most of the equipment was described as outmoded, and it is still not clear if North Korea has the technology to turn plutonium into effective weapon fuel.
In the interview, Mr. Roh suggested that North Korea, while initially hoping to build a bomb, had been taken aback by the pressure from the United States, Japan, Russia and other large powers to give up the project. American and Japanese officials have made it clear to North Korea, as recently as this week, that they would not improve relations without much more intensive inspections.
"As for North Korea's will to persist in the development of nuclear weapons," the President said, "it has been somewhat alleviated by pressure."
In Washington, a growing number of experts are coming to similar conclusions.
"They would have loved to continue the nuclear program, but they were suffering a diplomatic cost overrun," said Leonard S. Spector, who heads a committee studying Korean nuclear policy for the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. "They are caving into pressure. But that doesn't mean they are trying to hide and preserve what they have got."
In talking about the North Korean Government, Mr. Roh spoke with the confidence of an ex-general who appeared, in the last months of his administration, to have finally outflanked his foe.
He said today that the Government of Kim Il Sung, the North's Stalinist leader, "is much more isolated this year than it was last year."
"Their economic situation has deteriorated," he said, "and their people are suffering from the lack of food.
"The system is becoming somewhat unstable," he said of North Korea's rigid and closed society, but he declined to venture a guess about how long it could last. He warned, however, that the North could lash out, comparing it at one point to Iraq before the Persian Gulf war.
Mr. Roh has been sometimes criticized for moving too quickly to reach agreements with North Korea -- including last December's agreement on "reconciliation and nonaggression" -- in hopes of meeting directly with Kim Il Sung and being remembered for breaking through the four-decade struggle between the two Koreas.
Mr. Roh said today that while a summit meeting would be "better than tens or hundreds of meetings at a lower level, . . . the situation has changed significantly" since he first sought such meetings.
Tensions on the peninsula, which were at their height five years ago after the bombing of a Korean Airlines jet by North Korean agents, are now much reduced, he said.
 
Democracy Taking Hold
 What he hoped to be remembered for, he added, was not the opening to the North but the restoration of democracy in the South: It was Mr. Roh's declaration on June 29, 1987, that paved the way for free elections after years of military dictatorship, coups, repression and assassination.
While the system is still plagued with scandals and vote buying, recent evidence that local elections early this year were fixed by the ruling party may force out several leading members of Mr. Roh's Cabinet.
"We have not completed our democratization yet," he said. "The process was very difficult, we had many complaints, but we did our best."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Ross Perot;
Perot Says He May Rejoin Race To Publicize His Economic Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Ross Perot today took to his favorite forum, talk television, with a new twist to his on-again, off-again designs on the White House.
The Texas businessman said he might want to run for President, but not because he actually wants to be President. Instead, he said, re-entering the race would make it easier to buy television time from the networks for commercials pushing his prescription for the ailing economy. 
 "Interestingly enough, I'm trapped," Mr. Perot said on the NBC News "Today" program. "They won't sell it to me unless I declare as a candidate. So I may be the first guy in history that had to declare he was a candidate so he could buy TV time."
On July 16, Mr. Perot abruptly dropped out of the race, and nothing he said today contradicted that earlier announcement. But Mr. Perot has continued to tease interviewers and the public about his intentions, and he kept up this familiar routine this morning and this evening on the "MacNeil/ Lehrer Newshour" on PBS and on ABC's "Nightline."
 
Possible Debate Role
 At the same time, Arizona became the 50th state to submit his name for the November ballot, a development that coupled with his continued respectable showing in recent polls could make Mr. Perot more of a factor in the campaign. He could demand, for instance, that he be included in Presidential debates because he appears to meet the threshold of the bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates: that a candidate's name be on the ballot in a majority of states and have a substantial standing in the polls.
Mr. Perot said his decision to revive a full-fledged campaign would depend on whether President Bush or Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas presents an economic plan that Mr. Perot deems responsible. But he put the burden on his supporters to "make that decision eventually" about whether he should run.
While it is, as usual, not clear what Mr. Perot will eventually do, neither is it clear what a Perot candidacy would mean for either major party.
Fourteen percent of voters say they would cast their ballot for Mr. Perot if his name appears in their state, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken last week. The poll found that Mr. Perot would draw equally from both parties, with 10 percent of Mr. Bush's supporters saying they would vote for Mr. Perot, and about 12 percent of Mr. Clinton's. The margin of sampling error for the poll was plus or minus three percentage points.
Stephen J. Wayne, a professor of government at Georgetown University, referred to Mr. Perot's well-known dislike for Mr. Bush as he summed up the Texan's options: "Here's a guy with a big ego who wants to show that people still love him. How do you get in and show that people love you without looking foolish and without resulting in the re-election of President Bush?"
Mr. Wayne echoed many academics and strategists who believe an active campaign by Mr. Perot could tip the balance to Mr. Bush or to Mr. Clinton in battleground states like Texas and California.
 
A Question of Betrayal
 But a looming question is whether Mr. Perot left his many original supporters with such a feeling of betrayal that they might not vote in November for him or anyone else.
In a Times/CBS News Poll taken last June after the California primary, Mr. Perot's popularity was at its peak. He was virtually tied with Mr. Bush, with the backing of 30 percent of the voters to Mr. Bush's 33 percent, while Mr. Clinton had 24 percent.
In the current poll, however, Mr. Perot has something he did not have then: negative ratings about twice as high as his positive ones. Twenty-one percent of voters have a favorable view of Mr. Perot but 39 percent have an unfavorable view.
After Mr. Perot dropped out of the race, more than half of his supporters said he had walked away from what he had set out to do without accomplishing very much. A Times/CBS News Poll conducted July 16-17, also found 41 percent of Mr. Perot's supporters bearing some anger toward him, saying they felt deserted, while 50 percent did not feel that way.
Yet there still seem to be many Perot loyalists around the country. "In July, we lost half of our volunteers," Catherine Boley, a volunteer in the Phoenix office of Mr. Perot's political organization, United We Stand, America, said today in a telephone interview. "But we started the petition drive just 10 days ago and we've just been amazed at how many people are crawling out of the woodwork everywhere. We can't even believe it ourselves."
Mr. Perot said his lawyers were figuring out whether he had to formally declare his candidacy to buy television time. Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania, said buying television time is a legitimate issue.
She said, for instance, that the networks might be reluctant to allow Mr. Perot to buy a five-minute block because it could "wreak havoc with their scheduling." But if Mr. Perot were an actual candidate, the networks would be required to sell him the time because the Bush campaign bought a five-minute block last week.
"It's a funny world out there," Mr. Perot said on the "Today" show, "that you're forced to become a candidate so that you can explain to the American people what these problems are."
Calling on Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush to come forward with more specific economic plans, Mr. Perot said, "at this point, neither plan will do the job."
But Mr. Perot's call for painful economic choices represents something of a conversion for him. When he appeared to be in the race, he offered what he described as painless proposals. Not until he dropped out did Mr. Perot put out his austere plan to raise taxes and trim the Federal deficit.
He boasted today that people were so interested in his book that outlines "a non-politician's platform" that it has risen to No. 1 on The New York Times best-seller list for non-fiction paperbacks.

HEADLINE: BONN URGED TO ACT BY U.S. AND BRITAIN

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18

 BODY:
With the finance ministers of the leading industrial nations scheduled to meet here Saturday, American and British officials teamed up today to put pressure on Germany's central bank to cut its interest rates. Lower German rates would encourage world economic growth and help to stem the currency crisis in Europe.
Though the Bush Administration was actively urging Germany to ease its tight money policy last year, it has been relatively quiet recently, even as Europe's system of economic coordination seemed in near collapse this week. But a senior Administration official said the White House now saw in the European chaos an opportunity to "demonstrate leadership" on a high-profile economic issue and "be a force for stability." 
 Indeed, in some ways, President Bush could turn the crisis to his advantage, because there is not a lot at stake economically for the United States in the short run.
 
U.S. Indicates Impatience
 David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury, in an interview today on the Cable News Network, indicated impatience with the Bundesbank, which has kept Germany's short-term interest rates above 9 percent to fight inflation.
"I think there will be pressure on Germany on the interest rate question," Mr. Mulford said. "It is hard to imagine putting the system back together again in Europe without Germany taking some sort of action."
Officials from the so-called Group of Seven, the leading industrial nations of the world, said the most urgent topic at their meeting would be figuring out how to help bring a semblance of order back to Europe's chaotic markets. Several officials said the key to this was a scaling back of interest rates by the German central bank.
During a day of frequent telephone calls between the Group of Seven ministers and central bankers, the officials indicated that the United States and Britain would play the heavies in putting pressure on the Bundesbank, while France and Italy would support the effort, but more politely. The other members of the Group of Seven are Canada, Germany and Japan.
During a series of angry exchanges with German officials, Prime Minister John Major of Britain slammed the Bundesbank, saying his nation wanted to "make sure that monetary policy is run in the interests of all the countries of Europe and not geared toward national interests in any individual country."
In the television interview, Mr. Mulford said the seven nations' finance ministers were working on contingency plans to stabilize European markets if they erupt into turmoil on Monday. Officials said those plans could include devaluations and heavy central bank intervention to defend whatever currencies come under attack. Throughout the turmoil of the last week, American officials gave no indication that the Federal Reserve was intervening in currency markets to help stabilize the dollar or European currencies.
Many currency traders predict that the French franc could be hit hard if the French vote on Sunday to reject plans for further steps of European unification, including the establishment of a European central bank and a single currency. Britain, Italy and Spain were forced to devalue their currencies earlier this week when they came under attack.
Speaking privately, several American and European officials said they were very dissatisfied that the Bundesbank cut its main interest rate by just one-quarter of 1 percent last weekend.
"Everyone feels that way," one Treasury official said.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who is serving as chairman of Saturday's meeting of the seven nations, has spoken repeatedly over the week with European finance ministers. One aide said he had spoken at least once a day with Norman Lamont, the Chancellor of the Exchequer in Britain, and that Mr. Brady had twice briefed President Bush at length about Europe's currency crisis.
In diplomatic language clearly directed at Germany, Treasury Secretary Brady said in a speech today in Washington: "Lower interest rates in Europe are inevitable if that Continent is to return to growth. It is important that a return to growth be accomplished as soon as possible."
Mr. Lamont said today that his nation would not put its currency back into the European Monetary System, an arrangement of linked exchange rates, until Germany and the Bundesbank budged. Mr. Major's Government has prolonged Britain's recession and weathered considerable protest for linking the country's interest rates to Germany's with the aim of squeezing out British inflation.
"We want to be satisfied that German policy, which has produced many of the tensions within the Exchange Rate Mechanism, is actually going to have some changes and be able to operate within a more stable environment," he said.
Last spring, Mr. Mulford touched off an angry clash with German Finance Ministry officials by urging Bonn to cut its sizable budget deficit, which has swelled as a result of financing German unification. That, he said, would give the Bundesbank more latitude to cut rates because the German central bank has kept rates high mainly to offset the inflationary pressures created by the budget deficit.
If they are going to promise further deficit cuts, German officials might demand a quid pro quo from the United States or other members of the Group of Seven.

HEADLINE: Foundation Is Giving $10 Million To Help South Florida to Rebuild

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The Knight Foundation announced today that it was giving $10 million in grants to help rebuild Dade County in the aftermath of Hurricane Andrew.
The money was committed by trustees this week after a tour of areas in the southern part of the county that were most devastated by the hurricane. Of the $10 million, $3.6 million has already been granted, including $1 million to the American Red Cross for disaster relief. 
 "Our first grant was directed toward relief, but now rebuilding will be the foundation's focus," said Lee Hills, chairman of the charitable group.
 
Other Donations Cited
 The Knight Foundation, created in 1950 by John S. and James L. Knight, two founders of the Miami-based Knight-Ridder Inc., the newspaper and broadcasting chain, is one of the nation's largest private foundations. A spokeswoman said it has assets of more than $620 million.
In addition to its hurricane aid, the foundation plans to give more than $27 million nationally to social service, cultural, education and other organizations.
Besides the hurricane-aid grant to the Red Cross, the foundation has given $2.5 million to We Will Rebuild, an organization of community, political and business leaders charged with raising money for the recovery, $100,760 to United Way of Dade County for a state relief hot line, $25,000 to the University of Florida's Center for Affordable Housing and $15,000 to Planned Parenthood for an emergency clinic.
The rest of the $10 million, to be disbursed over the next two years, will be divided among organizations who apply and qualify for the grants.
In a related matter today, state officials said that a $10 million state fund meant for small businesses damaged by Hurricane Andrew had been exhausted and that more money was needed.
The money was taken from state emergency funds to offer six-month, interest-free loans of $5,000 to $25,000 to help with things like relocating or replacing damaged merchandise.
Gov. Lawton Chiles offered the $10 million two weeks ago, and more than 300 applications had been approved. But applications were cut off today after more than $8 million had been distributed because requests on file were expected to eat up the rest, state officials said.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Prosecutor Bows Out of the Spotlight

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 18

 BODY:
Los Angeles County's District Attorney, Ira Reiner, who failed to win convictions in the beating of Rodney G. King and other high-profile cases and who faced long odds in his bid for a third term, pulled out of the race today, saying he did not have the stomach for a negative campaign.
Mr. Reiner, a 56-year-old Democrat, said he had called today to congratulate his opponent, Gilbert L. Garcetti, a former top aide who is now a bitter personal rival and who defeated him in a nonpartisan primary last June by 34 percent to 26 percent. 
 After that setback, Mr. Reiner said in an interview, it was clear that the only chance he had to win in the general election was to wage a particularly negative campaign. "I just didn't have the stomach for it," said Mr. Reiner, who has gained a reputation as a highly political District Attorney with an eye for the limelight. "It's just too distasteful; distasteful for me and for my family, disruptive for the office and divisive for the community."
 
Major Setback in 1990 Race
 A fast-rising political star who went from City Controller to city attorney to District Attorney in less than a decade, Mr. Reiner suffered a humiliating defeat in 1990 Democratic primary for State Attorney General.
Though he won convictions in a number of important cases, his name became associated with several high-profile losses, including the McMartin Pre-School child molestation trials and the trial of John Landis, the director of the film "Twilight Zone," in which three actors were killed by a helicopter.
Most stunning was the failure of his office to win convictions in the trial of four Los Angeles police officers who were captured on videotape beating and kicking Mr. King, a failure that touched off widespread rioting.
Mr. Reiner's announcement came amid speculation that Mayor Tom Bradley would soon announce that he would not seek re-election next year.
 
'I May Come Back'
 Mr. Reiner declined to say whether he was interested in joining the mayoral race, saying he had not given thought to his long-term future. "I may come back into public life again," he said. "I have no idea."
A spokesman for the 74-year-old Mayor said he would disclose late next week whether he would seek a sixth term. Some of the Mayor's staff members have already taken other jobs and the local press has reported that Mr. Bradley has received offers from top law firms.
His departure, along with those of Mr. Reiner and former Police Chief Daryl F. Gates, who resigned under pressure in June, would reshape the political landscape at a time when the city and county are struggling to deal with the social and economic problems raised by the riots and recession.
Mr. Garcetti said today that polls had consistently shown him leading in the general election -- a race between the two top finishers in the primary -- and that Mr. Reiner "must have seen the handwriting on the wall."
In the past, Mr. Garcetti, a longtime prosecutor whom Mr. Reiner demoted from his post as chief deputy, has told reporters that he is prepared to disclose the contents of "173 spiral notebooks" documenting his years in that office. Mr. Reiner has said that Mr. Garcetti "is not to be trusted in a position of power" and hinted that he would make public previously undisclosed reasons for his demotion.
Noting that candidates around the country were making political calculations like his and proceeding with negative campaigns, Mr. Reiner said today: "I've been in politics some time now and I know it's a tough business. But it doesn't have to be creepy."
Although he asserted today that he had never made a decision based on politics, Mr. Reiner is viewed by many local politicians as a man who will go to extremes to win public acclaim.
 
 
Shooting of Grocer
 After an outcry over the leniency of a judge in sentencing a Korean grocer who was convicted of shooting a young black customer, Mr. Reiner ordered his prosecutors to refuse to argue cases before the judge.
In a current case against three black men accused of beating a white truck driver, Reginald O. Denny, at the start of the riots, prosecutors refused to accept a black judge to hear the case. In the face of criticism, Mr. Reiner offered several explanations, then tried to get a different black judge to hear the case to quiet his critics.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail;
In Little Rock, a Group Plans for a Transition in Washington

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

 BODY:
Down in Little Rock, Ark., it's called long-range planning. But that's just a political euphemism.
The fact is, in recent weeks the Clinton campaign has begun laying plans for a takeover from the Bush Administration next January -- the transition. And in coming weeks the pace of that planning will quicken. 
 Mickey Kantor, the campaign chairman, has been directing the half dozen or so people who have been working on the transition plans. In fact, he's spending most of his time on them when he's not trying to negotiate where, when and if there will be any Bush-Clinton debates.
He's not providing any details. But as early as next week he'll announce that the transition staff will expand to 16 people.
Presumptuous?
Most Presidential candidates engage in transition planning to some degree, even those trailing badly in the polls, which Mr. Clinton is not. Normally the planning looks ahead to things like White House staff positions, liaison with Congress and possible Cabinet appointees.
"You have to engage in transition planning now," Mr. Kantor said. "It would be irresponsible not to. On the other hand, it would be foolhardy to let it distract from the issue at hand, and that's Nov. 3."
 
Reaganomics Man Isn't Behind Bush
 When it comes to the economy, nothing seems to being going right for President Bush much of the time. Now he's behind the curve with Arthur Laffer.
Mr. Laffer is the economist who first propounded the "Laffer curve" theory of cutting the national deficit by cutting taxes. He is also considered one of the founders of "Reaganomics," which incorporated the curve theory.
Mr. Bush once asserted that "Reaganomics" was "voodoo economics." But that was before Ronald Reagan invited him to be Vice President and Mr. Bush had a change of economic mind.
For Mr. Laffer, it hasn't been change enough. He was a Bush supporter for awhile, but now he considers Mr. Bush's economic performance to be a disaster, mainly because the President broke his pledge of "no new taxes" and let Federal spending increase.
"I really think Bush does not deserve to be re-elected," he is telling audiences these days.
Message: Arthur Laffer is going to vote for Bill Clinton.
 
Gay Declaration By Schlafly's Son
 John Schlafly, the son of Phyllis Schlafly, the prominent Republican and family-values proponent, has announced that he is homosexual.
Mr. Schlafly, a 41-year-old lawyer who lives with his parents in Alton, Ill., discussed his politics and sexuality in an interview published yesterday in The San Francisco Examiner. He said he "warmly endorsed" his mother's political views but said he disagreed with Vice President Dan Quayle's recent assertion that homosexuality is a matter of choice.
Mrs. Schlafly told The Examiner that she has never advocated discrimination against homosexuals. She said her work was devoted to opposing abortion and the equal rights amendment.
"Adult children don't always do what their parents wish," she said. "He is my son, and I do love my children."
Mr. Schlafly said he saw a need for some recognition of same-sex couples, but added he was not sure legal marriage should be an option. Mrs. Schlafly said she opposes same-sex marriages, but added, "I wouldn't call that gay-bashing."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Turmoil in Europe
Germany's Chancellor exchanged sharp criticisms with British leaders over whether high German rates had caused this week's chaos in the currency markets. But Mr. Kohl also renewed his pledge to work for European economic and political unity. [Page 1.] The crisis has brought Chancellor Kohl harsh criticism from abroad while putting new pressure on him at home. [36.]

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

PRESIDENT BUSH
In a speech yesterday to A.T. & T. employees and women service organizations at A.T. & T. corporate headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J.
"Let me talk just about another job-related issue, something that's called the glass ceiling. Today companies are promoting some women in greater numbers, but not fast enough, and so a lot of talented women are going into the businesses for themselves. And this isn't just a corporate problem. We're seeing the same thing happen in government. And I am proud of our record in promoting women, but I'm especially proud that these talented women -- that we've put talented women in important economic positions, running the Department of Labor, running the Department of Commerce or the Small Business Administration, or handling all of our trade negotiations. 
 The women I work with tell me they don't want any special opportunity. They just want the right to succeed or fail, to be measured by the same standard as men.
And we want to see the Lynn Martins of corporate America succeed, too. And that's why this Secretary of Labor, Lynn Martin, has made shattering the glass ceiling a top priority. She's making sure that companies who receive your tax dollars through Federal contracts make career opportunities available to women."
 
GOV. BILL CLINTON
In a speech yesterday at a campaign rally at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque
"I believe we should have a system, like everybody else that we're competing with, to guarantee training and retraining to adults throughout their working lives. Today the Germans are spending five times as much as we are educating their adult work force, and that's why they make 20 percent more than our folks do for working a shorter work week. I believe we can do better if we'll take our heads out of the sand and face the future.
Finally, I want to open the doors of college education to all Americans, to every American. But to do that, I have to challenge you to help. I want to replace the student loan program, which is costly and inefficient, with a new program, a national trust fund, out of which any American, without regard to income, can borrow the money to go to college and pay it back in one of two ways -- either as a small percentage of your income after you go to work, at tax time, so no one can beat the bill, or, even better, by giving two years of your life to your country here at home.
To rebuild America. Think of it. Just think of it. Think of New Mexico. What if every young person borrowed the money, all of it, for four years, to go to college, and then paid it back with two years of work at reduced pay as a teacher, a police officer, working to help children, working to help the elderly, working to support the independence of people with disabilities, working in housing programs. We could revolutionize this country and educate a whole generation of Americans. It would be the best money we ever spent."
 
SENATOR AL GORE
 In testimony yesterday before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in Washington
"President Bush, unfortunately, is locked in the past. I mean, here is a man who sees 20-year-old technology at the supermarket checkout line and looks like an ape discovering fire. No wonder when the Japanese and Europeans come up with the ideas of marketing these new technologies that clean up the environment and create jobs, he just can't imagine that this is going to benefit our country. But it will. And what will hurt our economy is continued adherence to more of the same."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Watch;
In Bid for Attention, Weather Wins

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
It was George and Bill versus Andrew and Iniki. The real windstorms won.
The Presidential candidates have been having a hard time competing against a couple of hurricanes for news time in recent days. Indeed, only Bill Clinton's draft record and George Bush's refusal to attend the first scheduled Presidential debate have prevented the contest from turning into a total rout. 
 As the campaign plays out on television radio, it has been difficult to escape the sense over the last several days that the President and his Democratic challenger are running out of tricks for getting attention. Even Rush Limbaugh, the right-wing radio host who introduced Hillary-bashing as a Republican sport, seems vaguely bored by the whole spectacle.
Over the last few days, Mr. Limbaugh has reserved most of his venom not for his favorite, Mrs. Clinton, but for Elizabeth Holtzman, the New York City Comptroller. By placing fourth in New York's Senate primary, Ms. Holtzman provided the radio host with all the evidence he needed to declare the year of the woman a feminist hoax.
 
Still Pulling Air Time
 To be sure, the Presidential candidates have never been allowed to slip far from the top of the news, even when the weather upstaged them daily.
And last week, when attention to Hurricane Andrew finally began to recede, President Bush had a few good days, dominating the newscasts by handing out Federal largess and making what was called a major economic address. But then Hurricane Iniki, like rain at a picnic, brought the fun to an end.
By the time most tourists were evacuated from the island of Kauai and the images of palms trees doubled over in the wind started to grow dull, the President once again lost control of the story line. The networks produced new polls showing that Mr. Bush, for all his generosity with Federal money, was still trailing Mr. Clinton by a significant margin.
On Wednesday, CBS returned to Florida to illustrate the President's plight; despite Mr. Bush's pledge of billions of dollars in hurricane relief to the state, polls showed him barely holding onto his lead there. "This is a catastrophe here," a grizzled old man told CBS. "And the Government don't really care."
 
Solace in the Weather
 For Mr. Clinton, there has been a bright side to the tropical disturbances: the more real storms, the fewer "storm of controversy" reports.
On Tuesday, for example, when Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton's speeches to the National Guard Association led the news, the coverage was none too favorable to the Arkansas Governor. For NBC, the speeches provided the opportunity to list the inconsistencies in Mr. Clinton's account of his draft record, one by one. ABC used the occasion to devote a "Nightline" program to Mr. Clinton's history with the draft, starting with a film clip from 1978 showing one Lieut. Col. Billy Geren voicing concern about the Governor's lack of military service.
"Among campaign issues, it could be his Achilles' heel," Ted Koppel said, beginning one of the season's mixed podiatry metaphors. "But is Bill Clinton shooting himself in the foot?"
As he did in the New York primary campaign, Mr. Clinton turned to Don Imus, the New York radio personality, for solace when the television reporting took an unflattering turn. On Monday, the Governor appeared on Mr. Imus's morning program on WFAN-AM and expressed regret that he had mishandled questions about his draft record. The appearance seems to have paid off; on Tuesday, Mr. Imus, who typically refers to Mr. Clinton as a "redneck bozo," said that he would vote for the Governor in November.
Looking for new views of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Bush as their traveling show grows stale, some networks have taken a novel approach to the campaign: reporting on it from places where the candidates themselves have never been sighted.
On Tuesday night, for example, ABC's Peter Jennings reported the evening news standing in a suburban subdivision in Charlotte, N.C. "It certainly doesn't look like a battleground," Mr. Jennings said, gesturing to a cluster of white colonial homes. (No, one had to agree, it looked like a subdivision.)
On the same night, in a report ambitiously called "Reality Check," Mark Phillips led the CBS Evening News broadcast with a visit to a Pittsburgh bowling alley. In one of the weirder efforts to demonstrate what is actually going on in this campaign, Mr. Phillips asked viewers to think of the bowling balls as the candidates' positions on the issues and the bowling pins as the voters.
"What happens when one meets the other?" he asked, as a ball skidded down the alley. "These days it seems something like total confusion." And indeed it did.

HEADLINE: Adding an Extra Pair of Eyes on School Buses, to Help Insure Safety

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 16

 BODY:
In one of her first mornings as a school bus monitor, Peggy Brady retrieved a lost backpack, tended to a bloody nose and comforted a little girl who wasn't yet sold on this kindergarten business.
But her real purpose was saving lives. 
 As the bus threaded its way along the back roads of Westport, Mrs. Brady hopped off at 30 stops to help children cross the street and scramble aboard. Before the driver moved, Mrs. Brady checked in front of the bus, in back and under the wheels.
Mrs. Brady is part of a trend in Connecticut and throughout the nation as parents and school officials seek ways to make school buses safer. Similar bus-monitor programs are operating in Buffalo, Rochester, and North Haven, Conn. In Rhode Island, monitors are mandated by state law.
"When people talk about school bus-safety issues," Mrs. Brady said, "it's usually over seat belts, but there are rarely fatalities inside a school bus because they are so well made. Where the danger lies is just outside the bus where small children can be difficult to see."
 
A Fatal Accident
 In Westport, the bus monitors were the town's response to an accident in December in which an 8-year-old girl, Holly Finley, was killed. A drawstring on her jacket became caught in a railing as she got off the bus at her driveway. When the bus drove away, she was pulled beneath it.
"It was a horrible tragedy that caused great sorrow and great concern," said Joyce Losen, assistant to School Superintendent Paul Kelleher, "and after that, the superintendent appointed a systemwide school bus safety committee who felt it was necessary to institute a bus-monitoring program for all elementary school students."
The program costs $80,000 a year out of a school budget of $33 million. Most parents think it is well worth it.
"I don't know of anything more valuable than your kids and it's a very cheap program to insure their safety," said Mary Lou Zinser, the mother of an elementary school student. "My child was on the bus where the accident happened that put this all in motion and I feel much better knowing there is an adult monitor on the bus."
After Holly Finley's death, parents learned how common such accidents are. Nationally, about 36 children a year are killed when they are struck by school buses or by passing cars as they board or leave buses, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
In Connecticut, 20 children have been killed in school bus accidents since 1972, said Ronald Harris, a staff lawyer for the State Department of Education.
[Friday morning, in Bristol, Conn., a school bus struck and killed a 3-year-old boy as it pulled away from a curb after dropping off passengers, the Bristol police said. The boy, Brandon Courchesne, who lived on the block where the accident occurred, had not been among the passengers on the bus, said a police spokesman, Officer Thomas Calvello. The officer said he did not know if a monitor had been on the bus.]
Earlier this year, a State School Bus Transportation Study Committee released a report saying that monitors would be helpful on all elementary school buses but that "it was not economically feasible at this time to make it a mandate," Mr. Harris said. Doing so could cost the state $20 million a year, he said.
Still, Mr. Harris said the state would reimburse part of what school districts pay for bus monitors. At the moment only Westport and North Haven have year-round programs. Glastonbury has one for the beginning of the school year and phases it out as young children become familiar with bus travel, he said.
Bob Perry of West Hartford, the president of the Connecticut chapter of Families Insisting on Safe Student Transportation, said his group would continue to fight for a state mandate for elementary-school bus monitors.
Mr. Perry got involved in the issue after his 6-year-old nephew was killed when he was hit by his school bus in Glastonbury two years ago.
"School districts worry more about sports, music and art than they do about the fact that they are putting young children in a really dangerous situation getting off and on school buses," he said. "We've talked with pediatric associations and other experts who say that children ages 5 to 8 are not mentally or physically capable of handling a school bus situation. They need an adult to help them."
 
Bill Was Defeated
 Last year, a bill requiring monitors passed in the Transportation Committee but was narrowly defeated in the Appropriations Committee.
Senator Kevin Sullivan, a West Hartford Democrat and chairman of the Education Committee, said he planned to support such legislation again but would like to see more districts try pilot programs.
In West Hartford, three schools are in a pilot program, and the state Parent-Teacher Association recently agreed to extend liability coverage to all volunteers who work as monitors.
Like many school districts, New York City uses monitors only on buses for special education students.
New Jersey, which this year adopted the nation's first law requiring seat belts on school buses, does not have bus-monitoring programs, said Linda Wells, director of the Bureau of Pupil Transportation. While there have been several fatalities in the last 20 years, she said, "we have nowhere near the Connecticut figure."
In Westport, the monitors are paid $85 a week. They are run through a police check and must pass tests for drugs and tuberculosis.
 
'Hard Position to Fill'
 Finding the monitors has been no easy task, said Ms. Losen, the superintendent's aide. "It's a hard position to fill because for many people it cuts into the workday hours," she said.
Mrs. Brady has been involved from the outset as a parent and because one of her children was a good friend of Holly Finley. Shortly after the accident, Mrs. Brady began researching school bus safety. She has spent hours recruiting and training bus monitors.
Mrs. Brady said a monitor's presence on a bus encouraged orderly behavior, which helps the driver. As she was helping students off the bus on Wednesday at Kings Highway Elementary School, she made sure the younger children were not mistreated by the older students and stopped one boy from pulling a girl's hair as she made her way off the bus.
"A lot can happen when a driver has his back to 55 children," she said. "We all wish our kids were angels, but if they cause a problem and the bus driver is distracted, that's when the worst can happen."
Edward Gomeau, the director of fiscal management for the North Haven schools, said North Haven had had bus monitors since 1976, following two fatalities in the early 70's.
"We have had no fatalities since," said Mr. Gomeau, who has testified in favor of the program in Westport and other towns. North Haven spends about $81,000 a year on monitors out of a budget of $24 million.
"It's an absolutely essential part of our school budget every year," Mr. Gomeau said.

HEADLINE: Some Unexpected Suspects in Currency Turmoil

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Currency traders who have been placing high-risk bets have had a lot to do with the crisis that is rolling through Europe. The word speculator, an accusation in itself, has rolled easily off the lips of finance ministers, like Norman Lamont of Britain, who are looking for scapegoats.
But there is growing evidence that it is the much more conservative institutional investors -- the mutual funds, corporations and pension funds -- that have humbled the British pound, the Italian lira and the Spanish peseta and helped to threaten the future of the European Monetary System and economic unity. 
 These institutions have invested hundreds of billions of dollars in Britain, Italy and Spain, where interest rates are high, on the assumption that the European Monetary System was providing them inexpensive protection against adverse currency fluctuations. The underlying weakness of these currencies, which normally would threaten to wipe out gains from the investments, could be ignored.
But as the European Monetary System crumbled this week the safety of those investments and corporate strategies has been undermined. And the sudden rush of many institutions to protect their investments by buying strong German marks and selling the weaker currencies in Europe -- the pound, the lira, and the peseta -- may well have provided the weight needed to break the system's back.
"If you add up the funds, it is billions and billions of dollars that trickled in slowly, but they all wanted to get out at once," said Richard Jaycobs, the managing director of Finex, a financial exchange in New York that offers instruments for protecting against currency fluctuations.
Other financial executives offer similar views.
"I think the market is driven by the big investors: the mutual funds, the pension funds, the endowments," said David W. Rossmiller, vice president of international fixed-income management at the Travelers Investment Management Company in Hartford. He said he had contributed to the currency turmoil himself by shifting his strategy earlier this month in a way that forced the selling of the weaker European currencies.
"It is portfolios like these that are really driving the market, and it is the speculators that come in and chase the trend," he added.
 
Safety Was Attractive
 In fact, it appears that it was the very credibility of the European Monetary System, which attracted so much investment money, that helped bring the system down so quickly, market participants said. The system provided a safety net that allowed money managers to take risks that they would not ordinarily consider.
It was taking such risks that allowed mutual funds investing in high-yield short-term investments around the world to pay attractive returns. Such funds were run by big firms like Merrill Lynch in the United States and Lombard Odier in Europe. Corporate treasurers also used the security of the monetary system to reduce their costs. And funds protecting themselves against money-losing currency swings -- a practice known as hedging -- also depended on the European Monetary System.
"They would never have dreamed of taking these risks," Matthew Daniel, manager of financial markets at Union Carbide, said. "Why did they? They had the safety net of the European Monetary System under them. Now that has been blown out of the water."
Indeed, the breakdown has changed all these equations. "It was the strength of the system that had sucked in so much money," said David Smart of Fiduciary Trust in London. "And now it had brought about the potential demise of the system."
At the heart of this currency crisis is a practice in the arcane world of currency risk management called proxy hedging.
For example, a rise in the dollar cuts the gain from foreign bonds when the foreign currency earnings are translated back into dollars. To protect those gains, an investor who put $50 million in British bonds might try to offset the risk of a falling pound by selling an equivalent amount of pounds for dollars when the investment was made.
But because of the stability of the European Monetary System, a trader did not have to hedge in the same currency as the investment, but could use a stronger currency, like the mark; that is the practice of proxy hedging. The attraction was that short-term interest rates in Germany were lower than in Italy or Britain, which made the cost of hedging in marks cheaper than in pounds. Theoretically there was little risk because the monetary system made the mark and other currencies move within set trading ranges of each other, and that limited the potential losses.
Arthur Zeikel, the president of Merrill Lynch Asset Management, said this opportunity made the global income funds possible. In discussing the rupture of the system this week -- and the losses for his fund and others -- he sounded like a man whose faith had been betrayed. Without the insurance of the monetary system, his costs of operating will rise sharply.
"By doing cross-hedging and capturing the disparity in interest rates, you create a fund with less volatility and higher return," he said, adding, "In my lexicon, risk and volatility are synonymous."
Corporate treasurers and other fund managers who had also used such techniques were forced to unwind their positions last week, adding to the downward pressure on Europe's weak currencies.
Mr. Rossmiller of Travelers and Thomas J. Berger, a director of Lombard Odier International Portfolio Management Ltd. in London, both made such shifts recently. Mr. Berger, who manages the $1 billion Blanchard Short-Term Global Income Fund, got out of his proxy hedges in early September, as the pressure began to build.
"The speculators may be driving the train but we had to get on to be prudent," he said.

HEADLINE: Your Taxes;
Senate Fight Set On Top Brackets

BYLINE: By John H. Cushman Jr.

 BODY:
AFTER a hiatus for the Republican Convention and Labor Day recess, the Senate next week will revive its debate on a tax bill.
The tax bill would provide enterprise zone incentives for businesses to locate in economically depressed neighborhoods, and has been considered one of Congress's most urgent priorities since the riots in Los Angeles. It would also contain many provisions that are not particularly controversial, like extension of several expiring tax breaks. 
 The Senate version also contains some of President Bush's recommendations for stimulating the economy, such as a tax break for first-time home buyers. But as drafted by the Senate Finance Committee, the bill includes taxes on wealthier individuals which President Bush adamantly opposes, and with the election so close, the debate on these taxes is likely to be hot and partisan.
Senate leaders want to complete the work quickly, and are trying to persuade senators not to offer most of the 90 or so amendments that have been suggested. Once a Senate bill is passed, lawmakers would fashion a compromise with the version already passed by the House, and send the bill to President Bush before adjourning and hitting the campaign trail in ernest.
But with taxes high on the list of Presidential election issues, the bill's fate is uncertain, even though both Congress and the Administration have reasons for wanting a bill enacted.
"If we don't get a bill, I think then it's a pox on both institutions, the Administration and the Congress," said Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the Finance Committee chairman. "I don't think anybody profits by that."
Two years ago, as part of the budget pact between Congress and the Bush Administration that the President has since repudiated, limits were placed on itemized deductions for high-income taxpayers, whose personal exemptions were also phased out. The effect was to increase tax rates for the uppermost tax brackets from 31 percent, to 33 percent.
These tax increases were supposed to be temporary, one expiring at the end of 1995 and the other a year later. The Finance Committee voted in July to make them permanent, which would raise an additional $7.7 billion in 1996 and 1997.
Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, will offer an amendment to reverse the Finance Committee's action. But Senator Bentsen said that would represent "a tax cut for those making over $100,000 a year." And what of Senator Dole's assertion that the White House simply won't sign a bill that contains the upper-income taxes?
"I'm not going to get into that," Senator Bentsen said. "I turn my cards over one at a time."
 
Pension Plan Fee
 The Internal Revenue Service, which for the last few years has been seeking to encourage more voluntary compliance with the tax rules, is about to make it easier for businesses, especially smaller ones, to make sure that their pension plans conform to the law.
In the past, according to John E. Burke, assistant I.R.S. commissioner, pension plan managers were effectively left playing "audit roulette," meaning that they had to correct technical violations of pension tax rules only if they were audited. In serious cases, pension plans could be disqualified from the usual tax benefits.
A year ago, the agency set up a new program for pension plans that knew they were not in compliance but wanted to correct the defects in the plans, pay a negotiated tax settlement, and remain in the agency's good graces.
Although the agency has worked out about 200 agreements covering more than 10,000 pension plan participants, some companies have been reluctant to come forward even though they know of defects in their plans, because the tax sanctions could be quite large.
Now Mr. Burke has announced an I.R.S. experiment that will let pension plans voluntarily disclose minor defects in their plans, pay a fixed compliance fee, and agree to correct the problems. The compliance fee is expected to be just $1,250 for a plan with fewer than 1,000 participants, and just $500 for plans with less than $500,000 in assets. Larger plans would pay more.
 
Busy Signal Blues
 Taxpayers who called the I.R.S. telephone assistance hot lines during the 1992 spring filing season were more likely than ever to get accurate advice -- assuming somebody picked up the phone. According to I.R.S. test results provided to the General Accounting Office, employees answered 88 percent of the tax law questions correctly, up from 84 percent last year and better than the agency's 85 percent goal. But about two calls out of three to the toll-free lines were never answered at all, as callers either got a busy signal or got tired of waiting for an answer and hung up.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans;
Women Need Free Markets, Not Government, Bush Says

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: BASKING RIDGE, N.J., Sept. 18

 BODY:
Facing a significant gap in support between men and women in the latest opinion poll, President Bush took his top female aides in tow, lined his speaker's dais end-to-end with women and cast himself today as a feminist, free-market style.
Speaking to several hundred employees at A.T. & T. corporate headquarters in central New Jersey, Mr. Bush argued that his economic programs offer women and families more equality and opportunity than the "Government mandates" that he said were favored by his opponent, Gov. Bill Clinton. 
 "The first order of business," he conceded early, "is to admit that there is still unfinished business" on the agenda of women's concerns.
"Women work as hard as men and still earn less, and that's not acceptable," he said. "And most working women do more than equal work on the job and at home, and that's not acceptable either. And many women are trying to do it all alone."
 
Bush Discounts Argument
 But Mr. Bush maintained that laws that mandate sexual equality or confer social benefits, like family leave in emergencies, were in fact counterproductive because they cost businesses money, forced layoffs and slowed the economy. Better, he said, to help the economy create more jobs and to give women more opportunities to advance in those jobs.
If such an indirect argument seemed unlikely to appeal to women who feel shortchanged by the marketplace, one Presidential aide brought along to brief reporters, Constance Horner, put it more succinctly. "It doesn't do a pregnant woman any good to take leave from her job if some other member of the family doesn't have a job because of it," she said.
Ms. Horner, director of the White House Office of Personnel Management, said nevertheless that such a situation would never occur in her office. Using discretion granted her by White House personnel rules, she said, she has recently allowed two aides to extend their pregnancy leaves from the normal maximum of 10 paid weeks to three months or more, with the extensions unpaid.
Ms. Horner said she was not sure at the time what the Federal policy was on maternity and other family-related leaves of absence. "I just did it," she said.
The President's message was warmly applauded by the A.T. & T. employees in this overwhelmingly Republican, upper-income region, but it was not clear how well it would be received in the working-class regions where the Bush campaign most needs women's votes.
Mr. Bush is struggling to raise his political stock with women, a task both Congress and his own campaign have made none too easy.
A poll of 1,504 registered voters published today by The Wall Street Journal and NBC News indicated that male voters are evenly split between Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton, with each getting 46 percent of the support. But among women, Mr. Bush trailed by 18 points, 54 percent to 36 percent. And among working women, the gap was cavernous: 58 percent to 34 percent. The poll was conducted between last Saturday and Tuesday and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The Bush campaign's spokeswoman, Torie Clarke, said today that the reasons for Mr. Bush's sagging popularity with women were not easy to pinpoint. But some seem clear: even Republicans concede, for example, that Mr. Bush suffered with women after a series of strident messages on family values conveyed at last month's Republican National Convention, often on prime-time television.
The Republican platform and some televised speakers, like Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, Marilyn, and the conservative commentator Patrick J. Buchanan, were implicitly critical of working women and women's rights. The party platform is hostile toward the sizable majority of women of both parties who support at least some form of legalized abortion.
Ms. Clarke said campaign strategists "are not happy with the perception" created by the convention that the President is unsympathetic to women's issues. She asserted that the perception was baldly inaccurate.
"What's important -- what's the real issue -- is to look at President Bush," she said. "he's the one people will be voting for."

HEADLINE: French Pitch for a Yes on the Treaty

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
For years, Elf Aquitaine, the oil producer that is France's largest company, has confidently built service stations across Europe, looking forward to the time late this decade when a single currency would make it as easy for a French company to pump gasoline in Barcelona or Berlin as in Lyons. But then this spring, Loik Le Floch-Prigent, Elf's chairman and chief executive, heard many of his own employees speak against the Maastricht treaty that would bring about this unification. Some innocently asked him where he stood.
Mr. Floch-Prigent, joining other French business leaders to found the "Yes Committee," has since taken his cause to television, radio and newspapers, as well as his own refineries and plants. The prosperity of their companies and their expansion across the Continent, the business leaders say, rests on the referendum tomorrow. 
 A no vote, they say, would whipsaw them with continued currency turmoil and higher interest rates, as speculators rushed again into marks, weakening the franc. The persistence of separate currencies would render some of their strategies through the end of the century obsolete.
 
No Scenario for Defeat
 Under the sponsorship of Merrill Lynch & Company, the French executives gathered yesterday to promote their companies to investors at New York's Metropolitan Club, a gilded, frescoed palace where American plutocrats can feel like royalty from Europe.
In interviews, all the business leaders expressed brave confidence, with none confessing to laying contingency plans in case the referendum fails. "There is no scenario for a no vote," said Bernard Thiolon, the president of Credit Lyonnais, France's largest bank, with a dismissive toss of his head. "You cannot prevent a bank like us from having a presence in every market."
A minute later, however, he worried that a rejection by voters would delay the unification of banking services for years, slowing his march into other countries.
The executives' support for the creation of a single currency by 1999 represents the latest stage in the turnabout of what was long one of Europe's most protected business communities. French Governments have shielded their industries at least as far back as when Jean-Baptiste Colbert served as controller general to Louis XIV. Now, the French say that dismantling Europe's trade barriers has helped them export more per person than even the Japanese.
Several executives pointed to the currency crisis as one more reason for adopting a single currency. Only then, they said, could Europe capably compete with Japan and the United States. "If you had 50 different dollars -- a Colorado dollar, a Nevada dollar, a North Carolina dollar -- you would be much weaker," Mr. Floch-Prigent said.
Rejection of the referendum, they said, would expose them to much greater risks or the expenses of hedging. Many of the executives would then welcome a unified currency covering just France, Germany and a couple other countries with strong currencies.
Most are set to erase the borders from the atlas. Bertrand Collomb, the chairman and chief executive of Lafarge Coppee, the world's second-largest cement company, stretched out his arms, as if holding up a map, to illustrate the stakes for a maker of building materials.
"If you look at a map of Europe," he said, "there are no good connections between France and Spain, between France and the Netherlands. You need more high-speed trains, highways, airports."
Even the most ardent backers of unification shifted in their seats and frowned, however, when asked about meddling by Eurobureaucrats from Brussels. Referendum foes have warned that the stature of French industry, the distinctiveness of French culture, even the pre-eminence of French wine, would collapse under the weight of European regulation.
"The bureaucrats have been irritating a lot of people," Mr. Floch-Prigent of Elf said. "Many people in my company think, 'We will vote against the bureaucrats.' "
Patrick Bompoint, executive vice president for finance at Remy Cointreau, said that the referendum's passage would in fact mean more uniform taxes and regulations for his company, which sells more liquor in Germany than France.
In the short term, though, his company will reap some benefits no matter which side wins. "There will be a celebration," Mr. Bompoint said with a generous chuckle, "and that is an opportunity to drink Cognac or Champagne."

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN EUROPE;
Winds of Change Blow, and Europe's Governments Feel the Chill

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

 BODY:
The storm buffeting Europe is a strong one, but it has not yet uprooted a government or tossed a leader aside. The leaders on the Continent all are buttoning up, however, as the vote on European union approaches.
 
Jacques Delors
European Community Leader
 Jacques Delors, the head of the European Community's executive commission, is often referred to as Mr. Europe. After taking office in 1985, he breathed life into the flagging community, committing it to create a single regional market by Jan. 1, 1992, then promoting the idea of a single currency. 
 It is not surprising, then, that he considers eight years of campaigning for closer integration in the balance. French rejection of the treaty on Sunday would require a fundamental rethinking of community policy, which he believes could be better managed by a successor. If they say "no," Mr. Delors warns, he will resign in December.
His premature departure would strike a severe psychological blow at faith in European unity. None of his predecessors since the community was formed in 1957 enjoyed his power or displayed his vision.
A stocky intense former Finance Minister, Mr. Delors fervently believes the treaty, which commits the community to closer political as well as economic ties, is essential to withstand competition from the United States and Japan. He even sees it as a step toward creation of a federal Europe.
But he has been thrown on the defensive by attacks on his executive commission, which critics say exercises too much power over national governments.
This week's crisis in European currency markets, Mr. Delors has insisted, came as no surprise. Rather, he said, it was further proof of the community's need for tighter monetary union and a single currency.

HEADLINE: And Now a Word From Our Announcer;
30 Years Before the Mike: Inside Work, No Heavy Lifting (Fame Not Included)

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
He can do a smooth delivery. He can do what he calls a "smash-them-in-the-mouth" delivery (popular for pushing analgesics). He can do an average-guy-on-the-street delivery. He can do a quiet, syrupy delivery that makes you feel warm and joyous inside and think what an awfully sweet man that is talking to you.
Chances are you've heard his voice before -- perhaps obstinately elaborating on the grip of dental adhesive or breaking the news about the reductions in your health benefits during that personnel film (that takes the syrupy delivery). 
 But you never get his name. Here is the name: Ken Allen.
Mr. Allen is a voice for hire. Pay the right price and he'll talk -- and talk and talk. As a freelance announcer available for commercials, corporate films and station break announcements, he is one of a motley crew of malleable voices heard a lot but rarely seen and never identified.
"We don't take credit for what we do," he said the other day between talking assignments. "It's an anonymous way of life. And, to tell the truth, I like it that way. I'm sort of a private guy. I have never had an appetite to do things that were exotic. I've never wanted to be a star."
Every sizable city boasts loquacious freelance announcers, and there are a few dozen willing voices who operate in and around New York. Ken Allen has managed to keep going as a journeyman voice for about 30 years. He doesn't like to specify his age, but he's no kid. He will say only that he can ably do roles for someone in his 50's.
A husky man with well-chiseled features, Mr. Allen is blessed with a pleasing baritone. When he talks, even to a wrong number, every word is enunciated just so. No slurs, no mumbling. He projects. Chatting with him is like talking to the evening news.
If something needs to be said, Mr. Allen will say it, but most often he is hired as a product spokesman or as a narrator of a film. He's talked for American Airlines, Tide, Bufferin, Cadillac, Federal Express and I.B.M. Usually, there's just the voice, though sometimes he shows up on camera, too. For example, that's him in the current commercials for Sea Bond dental adhesive telling you how "it holds them comfortably all day long."
Mr. Allen tackles his share of film work, and at times is inclined to regard himself as an actor. Unfortunately, the films are not great starring vehicles. All too often, they'll be about pension plans. But then, he did play a captain in an Army training film and he was a doctor in several medical films. It adds up. The work allows one to become skilled in areas not many people become skilled in. "I would say I'm an expert in narrating health and benefits information," Mr. Allen said. "I've got that stuff down cold."
The other day, blackening clouds packing the skies, Mr. Allen caught the train into Manhattan from his home in Darien, Conn., to fulfill some talking assignments. First he hastened to a film-editing center on West 44th Street. He had been there before, to speak some lines in a film that the client wished to keep under wraps. One line had somehow been overlooked, so Mr. Allen needed to complete it.
The line was: "C'mon, you folks, we have a lot to do today. Let's hurry up."
Mr. Allen did it once animatedly, and the producer suggested, "A little more of a pause, so 'hurry up' will fall into his open mouth."
After the second take, the producer said, "I think that's very good."
In six minutes, Mr. Allen was finished.
Over the years, Mr. Allen has had a wordy career. He fell into radio as a teen-ager when he was the janitor at a station in Framingham, Mass. He fully expected to move beyond floors, and not long afterward became a staff announcer at a radio station in Holyoke, Mass., where he read the news, read the commercials, introduced the music, did station promos. He moved his voice to an Albany station before settling in at a radio and TV station in Hartford.
He thought he would sample moonlighting, so he auditioned for a job with New England Telephone telling customers about push-button phones. There were 102 applicants; Mr. Allen's voice won.
Emboldened, he decided he was ready for New York and, in 1963, got hired as an announcer for CBS. Once in a while, he was the standby announcer for Lowell Thomas. If Mr. Thomas were to get sick, Mr. Allen would do the talking. Mr. Thomas did not get sick.
"As a staff announcer, you were bigger than life," Mr. Allen recalled. "People think of me as being very elegant sounding, as having a sophisticated, cultivated voice. I was influenced as a staff announcer, because we all tried to be very dignified. You thought God was talking when one of us went on."
After four years, Mr. Allen decided to leave CBS. He has been a freelance mouth ever since.
 
A Comfortable Living
 Voice pay fluctuates a lot, though union rules dictate minimums. A local radio commercial pays at least $275, which includes use of the spot for 13 weeks. A voice-over on a local television commercial pays at least $662 for 13 weeks' use; an on-camera spot rises to $936 for a day's work. The fee to narrate a corporate film starts at $285 for the first hour plus $84 for each subsequent half hour and escalates to two or three times that for seasoned veterans. All told, a busy freelance announcer can collect more than $100,000 a year.
Mr. Allen said he has made a comfortable living, though talking assignments have dwindled in recent years as a consequence of the sputtering economy. He does about two jobs a week, whereas he used to average five easily. Maybe that's just as well, because the work can be harsh on the body. "I've gone into sessions where I've lost weight," Mr. Allen said. "I come out of the studio and I'm down five or six pounds."
Away from the microphone, Mr. Allen is quieter. He raises racing pigeons. He has about 60 at his home. It takes a lot of training. You start the pigeons about five miles from home and wait for them to return. Then you drop them farther and farther away. Sometimes you never see them again and you deal with the loss.
In early afternoon, rain drumming down, Mr. Allen arrived dripping at a studio at 231 East 55th Street. Karen Miller, a freelance producer, greeted him warmly and ushered him into a studio. She handed him the script.
The assignment was to read a brief opening and close to be edited onto an I.B.M. film -- already shot -- promoting a medical application of an I.B.M. mainframe computer. The entire script was a mere three sentences.
Mr. Allen read aloud the opening, testing the words, exploring the proper modulation, trying out pauses: "When most people think of Chapel Hill, North Carolina, they immediately think of a picturesque college town, home to the University of North Carolina's record-breaking Tar Heels basketball team, and its favorite son, Coach Dean Smith. But just down the road from the Dean Dome are the University of North Carolina Hospitals, where another kind of winning streak is happening."
Ms. Miller signaled it was time to start. Standing erect at the microphone, Mr. Allen gave it his all.
"I think you have to punch up Tar Heels a little more and punch up Dean Dome," Ms. Miller said.
"I think I know what you're talking about," Mr. Allen replied. "A little more animation."
"Give me about 10 percent more energy," Ms. Miller said.
Mr. Allen got carried away and gave about 20 percent more energy.
"That was really good," Ms. Miller said. "But when you start, use a little warmer tone."
Then it was too fast.
Then it was too slow in one part and too fast in another.
Then it was too fast at the beginning.
Then it was too slow.
Then it was still too slow.
Then it was too loud.
Then it wasn't natural.
Then it was all right.
Mr. Allen moved on to the close, a single sentence that sounded good on the first try.
"I liked it," Ms. Miller said. "I think we're going to do it again just because I like to do things a lot of times."
Then it was too fast at the end.
Then he flubbed "formulated."
Then Ms. Miller said, "That was so good we're trying to think of a way to improve it and we can't."
"Oh, great," Mr. Allen said.
Everyone shook hands and Mr. Allen hurried to catch the train home. Having uttered 110 words, his professional day was done.

HEADLINE: Bonds Mixed Awaiting French Vote

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended mixed yesterday as long-term bonds fell early in the day but recovered in the afternoon ahead of tomorrow's vote in France on economic unity.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond was up 1/16 point, or 63 cents per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, was 7.32 percent, unchanged from late Thursday. 
 Traders and investors were reluctant to hold large positions over the weekend for fear that the French vote would further roil the international currency and securities markets, which are already in disarray because of a currency crisis in Europe.
The 30-year bond hit a low of 98 1/2, but then began retracing its losses in midafternoon. The recovery was based on rumors that Barron's, the financial weekly, would report today that if Bill Clinton is elected he would appoint Robert Rubin, a managing director at Goldman, Sachs, as Treasury Secretary.
Knight-Ridder Financial News reported that Mr. Rubin is believed to be interested in stopping further sales of 30-year Treasury bonds. A halt of new bonds would push up the price of 30-year securities already issued. Barron's declined to confirm or deny the rumors.
A Goldman, Sachs spokesman said yesterday that Mr. Rubin had not been interviewed by Barron's and that he had not made any public statements about the advisability of eliminating 30-year bond sales.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, short-term maturities rose 1/32 and intermediate maturities fell between 1/32 and 1/8 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
