HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Dutch-British Merger Forms Publishing Giant

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
The Dutch publisher Elsevier N.V. and Reed International P.L.C. of Britain have announced a stock merger that will create one of the world's largest publishing empires, with sales of nearly $5 billion a year.
The new corporation, to be called Reed Elsevier, will trail such media giants as Time Warner Inc. and Bertelsmann A.G. in size, but because Reed and Elsevier have relatively little debt, the new enterprise will be able to expand its operations far more easily than can competitors like Time Warner. 
 And while Bertelsmann and Time Warner are committed largely to consumer publishing, Reed Elsevier will also be heavily involved in business-to-business publishing.
 
Terms of the Deal
 Under the deal, which was announced Thursday, each company will own 50 percent of the new business. Stockholders of each of the companies will receive shares in the newly formed enterprise.
Both companies have extensive holdings in the United States. Reed owns Cahners Publishing, and Reed publications, which number more than 70, include Variety and Modern Bride. Elsevier is a leading publisher of scientific journals in the United States and abroad.
Analysts say that with the prices of American media properties depressed, continued expansion in the United States is likely. Reed's chairman, Peter Davis, confirmed that view in a telephone interview yesterday.
"We want business-to-business and professional-information businesses," Mr. Davis said. "We want good, sound, long-run businesses."
He added, referring to businesses that do not depend on advertising revenues, that "both of us place a higher value on businesses that are less cyclical."
 
Mixed Sources of Revenue
 Reed owns many publications that depend on both subscription and advertising revenues, like Modern Bride. Mr. Davis said 40 percent of Reed's revenue came from advertising.
"I would buy Variety again," he said. "It has the subscription revenue and newsstand sales revenues. But Martindale-Hubbell, that we can put on CD and on line, is the sort of business we are even more keen on." Martindale-Hubbell Inc. publishes a law directory that provides biographical information and ratings on more than 800,000 lawyers; the service is also available to computer users.
Besides possible acquisitions in the United States, the companies are also interested in exploring deals in Germany, France, Italy and Spain.
Despite the worldwide economic weakness, the two companies are forecasting a 24 percent increase in profits for this calender year.
Reed had 1991 profits of $243 million on sales of $2.84 billion, while Elsevier had profits of $217 million on sales of $1.34 billion. The higher profit margins of Elsevier reflect its ownership of publications that are less heavily dependent on advertising than are those of its rivals.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
HOWARD SAVINGS UNABLE TO LIFT CAPITAL RATIO

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Howard Savings Bank said it was not able to increase its capital to meet the required ratio imposed by regulators. The Newark-based savings bank received a cease and desist order yesterday from the New Jersey Department of Banking requiring the bank to increase its leverage capital ratio to 4 percent by Sept. 30. Howard's leverage capital ratio, or common equity divided by average assets, was 1.53 percent as of June 30. The savings bank said it would be unable to meet the leverage ratio because of its level of nonperforming assets and the current economic condition.

HEADLINE: Turf Battles Are Beginning Over Atlanta Olympics

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 18

 BODY:
The Olympic flag arrived in the heart of the South today, two years to the day after Atlanta was designated as the surprise host for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games.
But even before the flag got here something else did: a recognition that having sold the world a vision of itself as an amicable, multiracial, civil rights capital in a world increasingly racked by racial and ethnic strife, Atlanta now has to live up to it. 
 Two years after Atlanta went into ecstasy over its long-shot Olympic designation, emotions about the Games are still high but a lot more complicated. Along with boosters, the flag's arrival from Barcelona, Spain, today brought out 5,000 demonstrators protesting what they described as plans for an exploitative low-wage Olympiad. Some frustrated black officials assert that the Games, sold to the world on the image of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and held in one of the nation's poorest cities, are being unduly controlled by rich, white suburbanites.
Few people doubt that Atlanta grabbed the opportunity of a city's lifetime by getting the multibillion-dollar prize of the 1996 Games, the 100th anniversary of the modern Olympics. And people who follow the Olympics say this sort of turf battle between competing interest groups is not unusual for this stage of the Games.
But amid a flurry of dust-ups over things as small as Atlanta's ill-received, slug-like mascot, Whatizit; as predictable as who will profit, and as large as the vision that the Games will project, it has become clear that mounting the $1.35 billion Games and playing host to about two million visitors may be the least of Atlanta's problems.
The biggest challenge may be the human and urban revitalization many expect the Games to bring to a city that symbolizes much of the pain and promise of race in America.
"It will be a travesty if the Games are presented and if nothing is fundamentally done to improve Atlanta in the process," said Bill Campbell, an Atlanta City Councilman. "This can't come down to putting on a great track meet. My grave concern is that we're losing this grand opportunity."
The two men most responsible for Atlanta's getting the Games, Billy Payne, president of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, and former Mayor Andrew Young, the Olympics co-chairman, say the Atlanta Olympics from their inception have been about more than sport. Both say the questions now have more to do with what kind of vision will emerge and what role will be played by groups like local governments and Jimmy Carter's Atlanta Project.
"This has always been a passion and a cause," Mr. Payne said.
But both he and Mr. Young say the money that will be raised to mount the Games will cover just that job -- not rebuilding inner-city Atlanta. And who does the rest, with what resources and in what form, is already shaping up as a drama that will traverse the fault lines of race and poverty common to urban America and the South in particular.
Atlanta's host role kicked off this week with an Olympic Flag Jam concert that brought out President Bush Thursday night and with a ceremony this morning welcoming the flag to Atlanta. But ever since the glittering Barcelona Olympics, the magnitude of Atlanta's challenge has come into sharp focus.
The comparisons with Barcelona, the difficulty of reconfiguring downtown Atlanta as a visitor-friendly pedestrian setting, and questions on finance and race have left some people wondering if Atlanta is up to the task.
"Barcelona was a big success and so was Los Angeles, but the memory of Montreal is always there," said Dana White, an Emory University expert on Atlanta's history, referring to Montreal's financial debacle after the city was host to the 1976 Games. "Part of Atlanta's booster spirit is that people talk a good game, but I think there's still some very serious doubts about whether we can pull it off."
 
'Enormous Confidence'
 One major concern is that the loss that NBC took on the Barcelona Olympics makes it highly unlikely an American network will spend anything close to the $600 million for the American television rights that the Atlanta organizers have projected.
But the Atlanta committee figures to gain in international television rights what it falls short on in domestic ones. And with plans progressing to market sponsorships for around $40 million each, experts say the Atlanta organizers are on track to raise the money they need. In fact, experts who study the Games say the Atlanta committee's performance in putting together its bid and beginning the plans for the Games has been extraordinarily sure-footed thus far.
"There's enormous confidence in Atlanta internationally," said John MacAloon, a University of Chicago anthropologist who studies the Olympics. "This is a highly internationalized and sophisticated group of people running the Games."
Professor MacAloon said Atlanta's toughest challenge may have more to do with image and vision than the nuts and bolts of putting on the competition.
"Atlanta is expected to contribute and to some extent was selected for the images of biracial and multiracial cooperation," he said.
 
'There Are Two Atlantas'
 But the images and the political and economic achievements of blacks in Atlanta can obscure the reality of a poor city, largely black, surrounded by a rich metropolitan area, largely white. The fact that the Games are controlled largely by wealthy whites is not lost on local city officials. Some are seething over what they see as a lack of input into the planning process. Unlike Barcelona, where city officials had a major share in mounting the Games, in Atlanta the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games is a private nonprofit corporation with no formal ties to local governments.
"The games were sold on it being a harmonious environment, of people living together and working together and everybody's happy," said Jared Samples, an Atlanta Councilman. "But the reality is there are two Atlantas, those who have and those who have not. I'm quite sure there will be some things said and done over the coming months that will show the true divisions that exist."
But as Mr. Payne and Mr. Young point out, the Games represent not just the 400,000 people of the city of Atlanta but also the 2.8 million in the metropolitan area and the 6.4 million in Georgia. And if some in the city are suspicious of the Atlanta committee, many suburbanites see Atlanta's concerns as just a push for more of the Olympic pie.
"This isn't about anything other than base human nature," said Claibourne Darden Jr., a political poll taker. "A number of people apparently are unhappy because they can't line their pockets or their group's status to a degree sufficient to please them."
 
Unions Seek Participation
 The financial issues go beyond race. The city has a wish list of more than $500 million in proposed projects for the downtown area, where much of the Olympics activities will take place, but so far has no way to pay for them. At a march sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. today, demonstrators called for more union participation in construction and accused the Atlanta committee of planning a low-wage Games that would depress wages locally.
But many of the knottiest issues revolve around race. There is a stalled plan to revitalize the Techwood Public Housing Project that sits at the edge of what is supposed to be the Olympic Village. There are fears by neighborhood people who say they will be displaced by the proposed Olympic Stadium. There are sensitive questions about the cultural symbols for the Games that have led some to wonder whether the committee is planning a bland, neutered cultural landscape with a dollop of Dr. King and a dollop of country music but steering clear of anything more visceral.
Mr. Payne heatedly denies it. And Mr. Young points to figures indicating 46 percent of contracts so far have gone to companies owned by minorities or women as proof of the Atlanta committee's sensitivity.
To some, the jostling for position, given the size of the stakes, is not unusual, either for business as usual in Atlanta or for the Olympics.
"My view is this is the tension from which creativity emerges," said Michael Lomax, Commissioner of Fulton County, which includes most of Atlanta. "I think we're going to come up with something which is rich, which is dynamic, which is not always harmonious, but is the reality of the new American city which I think Atlanta represents."
But in an America racked by urban despair, Atlanta's bid and history raised the social ante much the way Barcelona's dazzling Games raised the bar for the overall presentation of the Games.
"If this society can't do something creative about race in the Olympic arena," said John Hoberman, a University of Texas professor who studies the Olympics, "where you have unique kinds of opportunity, a very visible black presence and a celebrated one at that; if you can't do something creative about race relations in that context, then God help us."

A picture caption on Saturday about the Olympic flag's arrival in Atlanta for the 1996 Summer Games misstated A. D. Fraser's position with the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games. He is chief operating officer.
